headline: Beijing Deplores Taiwan’s Next President, but Welcomes an Old One
abstract: A rare visit to mainland China by Ma Ying-jeou, who’s now in the opposition, is a chance for political messaging on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
lead_paragraph: As tensions fester between China and Taiwan, one elder politician from the island democracy is getting an effusive welcome on the mainland: Ma Ying-jeou, a former president.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For Farmers in France, a Fierce Fight to Survive
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “There’s no point talking about farm practices that help save the environment, if farmers cannot make a living.”

headline: No Corrections: April 1, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: What 10 Years of Modi Rule Has Meant for India’s Economy
abstract: Narendra Modi has kept India on its swift upward path among the world’s largest economies. Many Indians are better off, though wealth gaps have widened.
lead_paragraph: As Narendra Modi was storming to victory in the election of 2014, he said that “acchhe din aane waale hain” — good times are coming.

headline: A New Chapter for Irish Historians’ ‘Saddest Book’
abstract: A globe-spanning research project has turned the catalog of a public archive destroyed in Ireland’s civil war into a model for reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: In the first pitched battle of the civil war that shaped a newly independent Ireland, seven centuries of history burned.

headline: What Happened When This Italian Province Invested in Babies
abstract: The area around Bolzano has a thick network of family support provided by the government. That means a steady birthrate in a country facing a demographic plunge.
lead_paragraph: In a municipal building in the heart of the alpine city of Bolzano, Stefano Baldo clocked out of work early for his breastfeeding break.

headline: 5 Things to Know to Understand India’s Economy Under Modi
abstract: As Prime Minister Narendra Modi seeks a third term, India’s growth has received the attention of the world’s investors but inequality has deepened.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi has big money behind him as he appears set to win a third term as India’s prime minister. His party has collected more political cash than the others combined, and the country’s richest business leaders support him.

headline: China’s Advancing Efforts to Influence the U.S. Election Raise Alarms
abstract: China has adopted some of the same misinformation tactics that Russia used ahead of the 2016 election, researchers and government officials say.
lead_paragraph: Covert Chinese accounts are masquerading online as American supporters of former President Donald J. Trump, promoting conspiracy theories, stoking domestic divisions and attacking President Biden ahead of the election in November, according to researchers and government officials.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Protests against Israel’s prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people gathered outside Israel’s Parliament yesterday in one of the largest demonstrations against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu since the start of the war in Gaza.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Blade’ and the CMT Music Awards
abstract: Syfy airs the 1998 vampire movie. The CMT Music Awards are live in Austin, Texas.
lead_paragraph: For those like myself who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, April 1-7. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: tenuous
abstract: This word has appeared in 175 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word tenuous has appeared in 175 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 7 in “How to Move a 1,000-Pound Rescued Manatee (Swimming Isn’t an Option)” by Catrin Einhorn:

headline: ‘Oppenheimer’ Opens in Nuclear-Scarred Japan, 8 Months After U.S. Premiere
abstract: While some viewers lamented the movie’s exclusion of scenes from Hiroshima or Nagasaki, others said they recognized that it had another story to tell.
lead_paragraph: Watching “Oppenheimer,” the Oscar-winning biopic about the father of the atomic bomb that opened in Japan on Friday, Kako Okuno was stunned by a scene in which scientists celebrated the explosion over Hiroshima with thunderous foot stomping and the waving of American flags.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Anger in Chinatown Over a Huge Jail Project: ‘We Are the Dumping Ground’
abstract: The demolition of a Manhattan jail complex to make way for a bigger one has damaged a neighboring building and raised concerns about years of dust and disruption.
lead_paragraph: Construction has not yet started on what could become the world’s tallest jail, a 300-foot-tall tower on a site in Manhattan’s Chinatown where the remnants of a former detention center still stand.

headline: Attention, New York Adulterers: Your Sin May Soon No Longer Be a Crime
abstract: Adultery has been illegal in New York since 1907, but state lawmakers seem poised to repeal the antiquated law.
lead_paragraph: In the halls of the New York State Capitol, with a budget deadline bearing down, it seems that all that anyone wants to talk about is adultery.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Baltimore Opens Temporary Shipping Route Around Key Bridge Wreckage
abstract: The temporary alternate channel will be able to accommodate some barges and tugboats but not larger vessels, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Baltimore opened a temporary channel on Monday to help restore some traffic in and out of the Port of Baltimore, one of the nation’s busiest commercial shipping hubs.

headline: Secrets of a Danish Castle
abstract: A writer returns to his grandparents’ former castle-home in a seaside corner of Denmark known for its chalk cliffs, ‘dancing elves’ and haunting World War II past.
lead_paragraph: My first conscious memory occurred on the lower landing of a staircase that spiraled up four floors of the 14th-century, moat-encircled Gjorslev castle in Denmark. I was hugging the railing while my tweed-clad grandfather, Edward Tesdorpf, who owned the place, smiled at me as he walked down the hall to take care of his ever-expanding farm businesses. I was 3 years old.

headline: Trump Preaches to the Faithful at His Rallies
abstract: Donald Trump has been ending many of his rally speeches with theatrical sermons complete with a cinematic music track, solidifying his growing deification among his supporters.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has been ending many of his rally speeches with theatrical sermons complete with a cinematic music track, solidifying his growing deification among his supporters.

headline: The Church of Trump: How He’s Infusing Christianity Into His Movement
abstract: Ending many of his rallies with a churchlike ritual and casting his prosecutions as persecution, the former president is demanding — and receiving — new levels of devotion from Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Long known for his improvised and volatile stage performances, former President Donald J. Trump now tends to finish his rallies on a solemn note.

headline: A Novelist Comes Home to Bury Her Words, and Brings Them Back to Life
abstract: In Julia Alvarez’s “The Cemetery of Untold Stories,” a boneyard in the Dominican Republic becomes a rich wellspring for discarded narratives.
lead_paragraph: The best stories live within us long after the final word; characters and places continue beyond the lines on a page. Yet the image of all the unfinished, unsatisfying, impossible stories we leave in our wakes haunts the writer as well as the reader. And with more than 20 books published across a three-decade career, no one may be haunted more than Julia Alvarez.

headline: Peter Brown, One of the Beatles’ Closest Confidants, Tells All (Again)
abstract: At 87, the dapper insider is releasing a new book of interviews conducted in 1980 and 1981 with the band and people nearest to it.
lead_paragraph: Peter Brown stood in his spacious Central Park West apartment, pointing first at the dining table and then through the window to the park outside, with Strawberry Fields just to the right.

headline: The Benefits of Living in the Same Place for a Long Time
abstract: Thirty years ago, a woman got a $250-a-month, rent-stabilized apartment in Inwood. She says the neighborhood has defined not only her life but her life’s work.
lead_paragraph: The last time Arlene Schulman went looking for an apartment, the internet was only in its infancy. “I did what everyone did 30 years ago,” Ms. Schulman said. “I asked everyone I knew if they knew about an available apartment.”

headline: Pedal Steel Noah’s Covers Charm Fans Online. Up Next: His Own Songs.
abstract: This 16-year-old from Austin, Texas, plays New Wave and post-punk hits with his brother and dog beside him. This week, his first EP, “Texas Madness,” comes out.
lead_paragraph: Like many American teenagers, Noah Faulkner, 16, is obsessed with music. He’ll spend hours going down rabbit holes, listening to every note played by his favorite artists and studying new discoveries. He recently came out of a monthslong deep dive on Clarence Ashley, a banjo player who recorded during the Great Depression and “makes me feel like I’m an old man,” Faulkner said. Ashley’s music “feels very spooky, and I imagine it’s like an abandoned place somewhere.”

headline: Don’t Overlook the Power of the Civil Cases Against Donald Trump
abstract: Why civil litigation against Trump has been more successful and might be a less fraught way to pursue accountability for the country.
lead_paragraph: For months now, the country has been riveted by the four criminal cases against Donald Trump: the New York state case involving hush-money payments to an adult film star, the federal case involving classified documents, the Georgia election-interference case and the federal election-interference case. But some have been postponed or had important deadlines delayed. The only case with a realistic shot of producing a verdict before the election, the New York case, involves relatively minor charges of falsifying business records that are unlikely to result in any significant prison time. None of the other three are likely to be resolved before November.

headline: The Two-State Solution Is an Unjust, Impossible Fantasy
abstract: For Palestinians, American calls for a two-state solution ring hollow.
lead_paragraph: After 176 days, Israel’s assault on Gaza has not stopped and has expanded into what Human Rights Watch has declared to be a policy of starvation as a weapon of war. More than 32,000 Palestinians have been killed, and the international community has reverted to a deeply familiar call for a two-state solution, under which Palestinians and Israelis can coexist in peace and security. President Biden even declared “the only real solution is a two-state solution” in his State of the Union address last month.

headline: How the Renovation of a House Rocked a Famous Church
abstract: Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem and one of its most well-known members have been ensnared in a seven-year saga, after a deacon hired to renovate another member’s house didn’t finish the job.
lead_paragraph: Abyssinian Baptist Church is one of the oldest Black churches in America, and certainly one of the most storied. As a college student at Columbia University, Barack Obama often lingered in the back pews during Sunday services, taking in the sermon and the choir.  Hundreds of mourners have gathered at the 216-year-old institution in recent years for the memorial services of Cicely Tyson and André Leon Talley.

headline: Salt Is Hiding Everywhere. Can You Spot It?
abstract: Sodium lurks in surprising places. See if you can identify the biggest offenders with this quiz.
lead_paragraph: Sodium lurks in surprising places. See if you can identify the biggest offenders with this quiz.

headline: Do You Wish You Had More Places to Go?
abstract: Where do you go when you want to leave your home and see your friends outside of school and extracurricular activities?
lead_paragraph: Picture this: It’s a weekend afternoon and there is nothing you need to do. You want to go somewhere — perhaps to people-watch, shop, take a walk, get some fresh air, hang out with friends or just take a break from social media. What places come to mind as options?

headline: The Benefits of a Walking Group
abstract: In London, ramblers are finding friendship and fitness by strolling the city together.
lead_paragraph: Clustered outside a tube station, 20 or so Londoners were preparing to roam around Tufnell Park, which is not actually a park, in their role as part of a Ramblers group, who do not, by the most rigid definition, ramble. (That typically requires a roam through the countryside.) They huddled under street lamps for the customary introduction to the night’s event: a three-mile loop around a residential stretch of the city, culminating with a trip to the pub.

headline: For 50 Years Ailey II Has Been a Proving Ground, Not Just for Dance
abstract: As the second company of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater has evolved, it has trained dancers and choreographers for tenacity as much as technique.
lead_paragraph: Ailey II, the second company of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, turns 50 this year. Since its creation, some things have remained consistent: It has always served as a bridge between student and professional life. It has always been filled with ambitious young people aspiring to join the main troupe. And, as members of every generation agree, the experience has always been demanding — extremely so.

headline: Is This the Silicon Valley of Latin America?
abstract: A big investment in semiconductors could transform the relationship between the United States and its neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Americans used to think of China as a place to do business and Latin America as a place to vacation. More recently, our neighbors to the south are seen as the source of desperate migrants. That mind-set led us to the mess that we are in now. Today the American economy is far too dependent on China for critical supplies while imports from countries in our hemisphere, aside from Canada and Mexico, are lagging, experts say. Our influence in our own neighborhood is waning.

headline: What the TikTok Bill Is Really About, According to a Leading Republican
abstract: Representative Mike Gallagher on what message a potential ban of TikTok sends to the rest of the world and what he views as the real threat.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the House passed a bill that would require TikTok’s parent company, ByteDance, to sell its U.S. business to a company without ties to the Chinese government or face a ban of the TikTok app in the United States.

headline: Madonna and Barbra Are Fans. Broadway, Meet Lempicka.
abstract: A new musical aims to restore the reputation, in life and art, of the ambitious yet undervalued painter Tamara de Lempicka.
lead_paragraph: The playwright Carson Kreitzer specializes in difficult women, disparaged women, women who should be better known. But 14 years ago, when a friend suggested the painter Tamara de Lempicka as a potential subject, Kreitzer wasn’t initially enthusiastic. The name meant nothing to her.

headline: Violence and Disorder in New York’s Mental Health Shelters
abstract: Carlton McPherson, who was charged in the fatal shoving of a stranger in the subway, had stayed at shelters designed to help those with mental illness.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the mental health shelters that struggle to provide services to some residents, including Carlton McPherson, who was charged in a fatal subway shoving last week.

headline: ‘The People’s Joker’ and the Perils of Playing With a Studio’s Copyright
abstract: Vera Drew used the Batman villain to tell a trans coming-of-age story. When Warner Bros. found out, the filmmaker wasn’t sure what would come next.
lead_paragraph: Vera Drew never received a cease-and-desist letter. She would like to be very clear on that point.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in April
abstract: “Sex and the City” and a new adaptation of “The Talented Mr. Ripley” highlight the new offerings this month.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of April’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: The Nobel Winner Who Liked to Collaborate With His Adversaries
abstract: He insisted on the value of working with those we disagree with.
lead_paragraph: Our all-American belief that money really does buy happiness is roughly correct for about 85 percent of us. We know this thanks to the latest and perhaps final work of Daniel Kahneman, the Nobel Prize winner who insisted on the value of working with those with whom we disagree.

headline: Toes Out in the Workplace? You Might Want to Tread Carefully.
abstract: A sandal enthusiast wonders how much “toe cleavage” is too much for a business-casual office.
lead_paragraph: In the spring, a person’s fancy turns to thoughts of … open-toe shoes! Sandals, Birkenstocks, mules — any footwear that allows your feet, trapped for months under layers of socks and boots, to breathe a little. To feel the breeze on your bare heels and toes is to know that warmer times have arrived. Yet feet also trail a host of associations, stereotypes and prejudices.

headline: Did Prosecutors’ Sex Shaming Help Send Brenda Andrew to Death Row?
abstract: The Supreme Court will soon decide whether to hear an appeal in her case, which, as one judge put it, “focused from start to finish on Ms. Andrew’s sex life.”
lead_paragraph: During his closing argument in the 2004 murder trial of Brenda Andrew in Oklahoma, a prosecutor dangled her thong underwear before the jury. She had packed the undergarment for a trip to Mexico a few days after her estranged husband was killed.

headline: ‘Plan Ahead’: Baltimore Traffic Reporter on Congestion After Bridge Collapse
abstract: Tony Thornton looks ahead to years of crowded tunnels and highways with the loss of the Francis Scott Key Bridge.
lead_paragraph: When the Francis Scott Key Bridge was built in the 1970s, it was intended to relieve congestion from the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel.

headline: What the Bridge Meant to Baltimore
abstract: The victims, the history, the void. Residents reflect on their collective pain, and the city’s strength.
lead_paragraph: Blue-collar workers crossed it. Families went crabbing around it. Teenagers celebrated new driver’s licenses by traversing it. And couples were known to get engaged near it.

headline: Politicians Aren’t Even Fooling Themselves
abstract: April Fools’ Day is coming to a political system near you.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Hey, Bret, we just hit April Fools’ Day. Did you have any political nominees?

headline: $2.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1911 bungalow with a guesthouse in Los Angeles, a French Normandy-style home in Alameda and a four-bedroom retreat in Ukiah.
lead_paragraph: This house was renovated by Barbara Bestor, recognized by the American Institute of Architects for her contributions to local residential and commercial architecture. It is in Eagle Rock, a few blocks from Colorado Boulevard, one of the neighborhood’s main thoroughfares, and a 15-minute walk from Eagle Rock Junior/Senior High School. Rockdale Elementary School and Occidental College are five minutes away by car.

headline: The War in Gaza and the Emerging Rift in American Jewish Life
abstract: A conversation on whether liberalism and Zionism can continue to coexist for American Jews.
lead_paragraph: In this interview with the Times Opinion editor Max Strasser, the journalist Peter Beinart explores what he calls the twin pillars of American Jewish life: Zionism and liberalism. Beinart argues that the two are fundamentally in conflict with each other, a longstanding tension that has become even more fraught since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7 and Israel retaliated in Gaza. In this conversation, Beinart makes the case for liberalism over Zionism and calls on the American Jewish community to see that “Palestinian equality doesn’t need to be a threat to Jewish safety.”

headline: In ‘Godzilla x Kong,’ They Came. They Pounced. Who Suffers?
abstract: The latest sequel in the Monsterverse has plenty of destruction, but little concern about the death toll.
lead_paragraph: This article contains spoilers for “Godzilla x Kong: The New Empire.”

headline: How to Breathe With the Trees
abstract: Our poet laureate Ada Limón is on a mission to reconnect us to nature.
lead_paragraph: Even on a computer screen, Ada Limón, who is serving her second term as poet laureate of the United States, projects such warmth and reassurance that you could almost swear she was sitting beside you, holding your hand. This kind of connection between strangers, human heart to human heart, is so rare as to be startling, especially these days.

headline: Israeli troops pull out of a major Gaza hospital after a two-week battle.
abstract: The soldiers left widespread devastation after battles with Palestinian militants in and around the Al-Shifa complex. “Now it looks like a wasteland,” a surgeon at the hospital said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers withdrew from Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City after two weeks of fighting in which they killed around 200 Palestinians and arrested hundreds of others, the Israeli military said on Monday. The troops left widespread devastation in their wake after extended gun battles with Palestinian militants in and around the complex.

headline: The Bizarre Chinese Murder Plot Behind Netflix’s ‘3 Body Problem’
abstract: Lin Qi, a billionaire who helped produce the science-fiction hit, was poisoned to death by a disgruntled executive. His attacker now faces the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: Lin Qi was a billionaire with a dream. The video game tycoon had wanted to turn one of China’s most famous science-fiction novels, “The Three-Body Problem,” into a global hit. He had started working with Netflix and the creators of the HBO series “Game of Thrones” to bring the alien invasion saga to international audiences.

headline: Ronna McDaniel, TV News and the Trump Problem
abstract: The former Republican National Committee chairwoman was hired by NBC and then let go after an outcry.
lead_paragraph: Ronna McDaniel’s time at NBC was short. The former Republican National Committee chairwoman was hired as an on-air political commentator but released just days later after an on-air revolt by the network’s leading stars.

headline: Protests Intensify Against Netanyahu, and China Tries to Sway U.S. Politics
abstract: Plus, fast food workers get a raise.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The New Climate Tech
abstract: Ambitious projects are trying to engineer the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Infusing clouds with sulfur dioxide to block the sun. Vacuuming carbon dioxide out of thin air. Adding iron to the ocean to draw greenhouse gases down to the sea floor. As recently as a few years ago, technologies designed to change Earth’s atmosphere — what is broadly known as geoengineering — were considered too impractical, too expensive and too outlandish to be taken seriously.

headline: Auto Execs Call for New Measures as E.V. Wars Heat Up
abstract: The latest proposal comes from Luca de Meo, the C.E.O. of Renault Group, who is pushing for an Airbus-inspired alliance that would help European automakers fend off competition from cheaper Chinese-made electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Tesla is scheduled to announce first-quarter delivery data this week, a key update as investors grow increasingly rattled about Chinese rivals — especially the Warren Buffett-backed BYD — gaining ground in the electric vehicle race.

headline: Cease-Fire Talks to Confront How Displaced Palestinians Can Return
abstract: Many Palestinians from northern Gaza are now sheltering in the south, but they want to return home.
lead_paragraph: For months, Israel and Hamas have been at odds over a host of issues during talks aimed at brokering a truce, including whether Israeli troops would withdraw and the length of a cease-fire.

headline: These Spelling Bee Hint Writers Want to Help You Get to Genius
abstract: Four enthusiasts talk about why they wake up in the middle of the night to write hints for other Spelling Bee solvers.
lead_paragraph: In the early hours of the morning, a small but dedicated group of solvers log on to the Spelling Bee Forum to share hints for anyone who gets stuck on the way to Genius, the game’s official top score. They post shortly after the new Spelling Bee replaces the previous day’s at 3 a.m. Eastern time.

headline: Hospitals Must Get Written Patient Consent for Pelvic Exams, H.H.S. Says
abstract: In a letter to teaching hospitals, the federal health agency said that institutions could lose Medicare funding if they didn’t comply.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Health and Human Services said on Monday that hospitals must obtain written informed consent from patients before they undergo sensitive examinations — like pelvis and prostate exams — especially if the patients will be under anesthesia.

headline: Winning City Halls, Turkish Opposition Strikes Blow to Erdogan
abstract: A raft of local election victories by rivals of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s governing party could serve as a check on his power.
lead_paragraph: Last May, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey handily secured another term as head of state, shattering the morale of the political opposition and raising fears among his critics that his hold on the government would enable him to further edge Turkey toward autocracy.

headline: Storms Lash Parts of Central U.S.
abstract: A powerful storm system struck sections of Missouri, Oklahoma  and Texas before moving east, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Thunderstorms and hail blanketed parts of the Central United States on Monday evening as the storm system marched east, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Sports Illustrated’s Owner Sues Energy Drink Mogul After Chaos at Magazine
abstract: Authentic Brands Group, which owns Sports Illustrated, is accusing Manoj Bhargava of failing to pay millions of dollars for the rights to publish the magazine.
lead_paragraph: Sports Illustrated’s owner on Monday sued Manoj Bhargava, the energy drinks mogul whose foray into media has been rife with chaos and conflict, accusing him of failing to pay millions of dollars for the rights to publish the iconic magazine.

headline: California’s Fast-Food Workers Just Got a Pay Bump
abstract: They now must be paid at least $20 an hour, near the top of what minimum-wage earners make anywhere in the country.
lead_paragraph: Wages went up today for roughly half a million of the lowest-paid Californians.

headline: American YouTube Personality Released After Being Kidnapped in Haiti
abstract: Adisson Pierre Maalouf, who is from Georgia, was kidnapped two weeks ago by a gang leader after traveling to Haiti.
lead_paragraph: An American YouTube personality who was kidnapped two weeks ago by a gang leader in Haiti was released over the weekend and was on his way home to the United States on Monday morning, according to his father.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Outside Israel’s Parliament, Protesters Explain Why They Think Netanyahu Must Go
abstract: A tent camp is a temporary home for some of the thousands of Israelis who are mounting a four-day protest calling for early elections to oust the Israeli prime minister.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of small silver tents were clustered on the pavement outside Israel’s Parliament in Jerusalem on Monday, stretching at least a city block. Many had Israeli flags taped to their roofs, along with stickers bearing slogans. “There is no greater mitzvah than the redemption of captives,” reads one. Another is more to the point, saying simply: “ELECTIONS.”

headline: Do You Know the Places Mentioned in These Poems?
abstract: April is National Poetry Month! Test your knowledge on a variety of verse with this short quiz.
lead_paragraph: April is National Poetry Month! Test your knowledge on a variety of verse with this short quiz.

headline: L.S.U.’s Kim Mulkey Courts Controversy With Style
abstract: Inside the coach’s winning fashion playbook.
lead_paragraph: The smog of a Washington Post exposé may have been hanging over Kim Mulkey’s head during the L.S.U. game on Saturday afternoon, but the highest paid coach in women’s collegiate basketball wasn’t going to hide. How could you tell?

headline: ‘Star Trek’ Fan Leaves Behind a Collection Like No One Has Done Before
abstract: When Troy Nelson died, his shelves were filled to the rafters with memorabilia from the popular franchise. Soon, the massive collection will be boldly going, going, gone.
lead_paragraph: Editors’ Note, April 2, 2024: After publication, The Times learned that Troy and Andrew Nelson were named in a civil lawsuit filed in Pierce County Superior Court in 1998, in which they were accused of molesting three disabled adults in a state-licensed facility that they operated. After a six-week jury trial, Washington State was ordered to pay $17.8 million to the plaintiffs. The state said it intended to appeal but missed the deadline and paid the victims. The Nelson brothers denied the allegations and were never criminally charged.

headline: Future and Metro Boomin’s First Joint Album Opens Big at No. 1
abstract: The Atlanta rapper and star producer topped Ariana Grande’s first-week total for “Eternal Sunshine,” but Beyoncé’s “Cowboy Carter” may beat them all next week.
lead_paragraph: Future and Metro Boomin, two of the biggest stars of Atlanta hip-hop, have scored the best opening of the year so far with their joint album “We Don’t Trust You,” though Beyoncé is on deck for next week’s chart with potentially even bigger numbers.

headline: How One Tech Skeptic Decided A.I. Might Benefit the Middle Class
abstract: David Autor, an M.I.T. economist and tech contrarian, argues that A.I. is fundamentally different from past waves of computerization.
lead_paragraph: David Autor seems an unlikely A.I. optimist. The labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is best known for his in-depth studies showing how much technology and trade have eroded the incomes of millions of American workers over the years.

headline: Will A.I. Boost Productivity? Companies Sure Hope So.
abstract: Economists doubt that artificial intelligence is already visible in productivity data. Big companies, however, talk often about adopting it to improve efficiency.
lead_paragraph: Wendy’s menu boards. Ben & Jerry’s grocery store freezers. Abercrombie & Fitch’s marketing. Many mainstays of the American customer experience are increasingly powered by artificial intelligence.

headline: Gloriously Crispy Chicken for Tonight
abstract: Put Christian Reynoso’s schnitzel-like chile crisp chicken cutlets on your cooking bucket list immediately.
lead_paragraph: The great epicure and writer Joseph Wechsberg once wrote that the hallmark of a good schnitzel was the absence of a grease stain on your pants if you sat on it. Why anyone would sit on a schnitzel is a mystery to me, but the principle stands, that the ideal thin fried cutlet must be perfectly crisp without being at all greasy.

headline: Don Winslow Is Ready to Trade His Pen for a Protest Sign
abstract: “City in Ruins” is the third novel in Winslow’s Danny Ryan trilogy and, he says, his last book. He’s retiring in part to invest more time into political activism.
lead_paragraph: Like the cops, crooks and gangland toughs who populate his books, Don Winslow has something of a street fighter’s mentality.

headline: Trump’s Call for Israel to ‘Finish Up’ War Alarms Some on the Right
abstract: Recent remarks he made urging an end to the Gaza conflict, with no insistence on freeing Israeli hostages first, were another departure from conservatives’ support for Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: Two Israeli journalists traveled to Palm Beach, Fla., a little over a week ago, hoping to elicit from Donald J. Trump a powerful expression of support for their country’s war in Gaza.

headline: Once Upon a Time, the World of Picture Books Came to Life
abstract: The tale behind a new museum of children’s literature is equal parts imagination, chutzpah and “The Little Engine That Could.”
lead_paragraph: On a crisp Saturday morning that screamed for adventure, a former tin can factory in North Kansas City, Mo., thrummed with the sound of young people climbing, sliding, spinning, jumping, exploring and reading.

headline: Talking (or Not) About Your Cancer
abstract: Responses to an Opinion essay by Dr. Daniela J. Lamas. Also: “political anxieties”; a mystery from England’s Bronze Age.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 10 Years of ‘Aladdin’ on Broadway
abstract: The musical “Aladdin” has been running on Broadway for 10 years, a bright spot in an industry that hasn’t fully recovered from the pandemic. Michael Paulson, a theater reporter for The New York Times, attended the March 28 anniversary performance.
lead_paragraph: The musical “Aladdin” has been running on Broadway for 10 years, a bright spot in an industry that hasn’t fully recovered from the pandemic. Michael Paulson, a theater reporter for The New York Times, attended the March 28 anniversary performance.

headline: Nor’easter to Bring Springtime Snow to New England This Week
abstract: Sleet and rain will lash coastal areas, while heavy, wet snow is expected farther inland, particularly in areas of higher elevation, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: A nor’easter is forecast to bring an April onslaught of snow, rain, high winds and coastal flooding to the Northeastern United States this week, the National Weather Service said.

headline: Betty Cole Dukert, Top ‘Meet the Press’ Producer, Dies at 96
abstract: She worked as a secretary before being hired as an associate producer at the NBC News public affairs show in 1956. She went on to spend 41 years there.
lead_paragraph: Betty Cole Dukert, who began her career in Washington as a secretary in the 1950s and later became the top producer of the weekly NBC News public affairs program “Meet the Press,” died on March 16 at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 96.

headline: You Can Bet on Caitlin Clark Making Threes. The N.C.A.A. Isn’t Happy.
abstract: Americans will wager $2.7 billion on the N.C.A.A. basketball tournaments this year, raising concerns about what happens to sports when people bet on the performances of student athletes.
lead_paragraph: Iowa crushed its opponent to start the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament this year, with Caitlin Clark, the sport’s shining superstar, finishing with 27 points to help the Hawkeyes cruise past Holy Cross. But for many, Clark blew it.

headline: What to Know About the Bird Flu Outbreak in Dairy Cows
abstract: The infections, which include one associated human case, add another worrying wrinkle to a global outbreak that has devastated bird and marine mammal populations.
lead_paragraph: An unusual bird flu outbreak in dairy cows has now affected at least 13 herds in six states, according to federal and state officials. These infections represent the first time that a highly pathogenic bird flu virus, which is often fatal in birds, has been detected in U.S. cattle.

headline: Johnson Outlines Plan for Ukraine Aid; House Could Act Within Weeks
abstract: The G.O.P. speaker’s proposed conditions for sending a fresh infusion of military assistance to Kyiv are the strongest sign to date that he plans to defy critics in his own party and push through the aid package.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson has begun publicly laying out potential conditions for extending a fresh round of American military assistance to Ukraine, the strongest indication yet that he plans to push through the House a package that many Republicans view as toxic and have tried to block.

headline: Barbara Rush, Award-Winning TV and Film Actress, Dies at 97
abstract: She received a Golden Globe in 1954 as that year’s rising star and appeared in movies alongside Dean Martin, Frank Sinatra and Paul Newman.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Rush, the supremely poised actress who rose to fame with supporting roles in 1950s films like “Magnificent Obsession” and “The Young Lions,” died on Sunday at her home in Westlake Village, Calif., in Los Angeles County. She was 97.

headline: Pressure Is Building on Netanyahu From All Sides
abstract: The prime minister is being pulled in opposing directions by his coalition partners, Israeli public opinion and allies abroad, with the war in Gaza and his political future in the balance.
lead_paragraph: As the war between Israel and Hamas approaches the six-month mark, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is confronting rising pressure on multiple fronts, at home and abroad.

headline: 2 Men Charged With Supplying Drugs That Killed Cecilia Gentili
abstract: Ms. Gentili, a transgender activist and actress, died in February after buying fentanyl-laced heroin, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Two men have been charged with providing fentanyl-laced heroin that killed Cecilia Gentili, a prominent transgender activist and actress who was found dead in her Brooklyn home in February.

headline: A Transgender Holiday Fell on Easter. Republicans Lashed Out at Biden.
abstract: President Biden, in acknowledging both days, drew the ire of many on the right, who attacked him as besmirching Christianity.
lead_paragraph: The Republican outrage machine kicked into gear over Easter weekend after President Biden noted that Sunday was being celebrated for more than one reason.

headline: Tropicana Las Vegas Closing Tuesday to Make Way for a Baseball Stadium
abstract: The hotel and casino opened in 1957. A Major League Baseball stadium will rise in its place.
lead_paragraph: The famous Tropicana Las Vegas resort, which held the city’s longest-running cabaret and was known for its lavish midcentury décor, will close on Tuesday as it prepares for demolition to make way for a new Major League Baseball stadium.

headline: Michael Stuhlbarg Is Attacked in Central Park Before ‘Patriots’ Debut
abstract: The actor was walking on the Upper East Side on Sunday when a man threw a rock at him, the police said. On Monday evening he appeared on Broadway in the first preview of the play “Patriots.”
lead_paragraph: A day after he was struck with a rock in a random attack on the Upper East Side, the actor Michael Stuhlbarg appeared Monday evening in the first preview of the Broadway play “Patriots,” in which he stars as a Russian oligarch who helped facilitate Vladimir V. Putin’s rise.

headline: Trump Media Shares Slump as Early Fervor Fades
abstract: A rapid fall in price erased billions of dollars in the market value of the parent company of Truth Social, eating into some of the gains made in the volatile stock’s public debut.
lead_paragraph: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company slumped just over 20 percent on Monday, as the fervor around the company’s debut on public markets last week appeared to subside.

headline: Review: Millepied and Muhly, Partners in Space and Sound
abstract: Benjamin Millepied and Nico Muhly’s evening of minimally accessorized dance and contemporary music feels right at home at the Philharmonie in Paris.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Benjamin Millepied is a protean figure. The founder of the L.A. Dance Project, he has been a principal dancer with New York City Ballet, the director of the Paris Opera Ballet, a filmmaker and a perennially well-connected catalyst for adventurous collaborations with figures from the worlds of fashion, movies, music and dance.

headline: Unproductive Agriculture Is Holding Africa Back
abstract: Farm output has grown, but at a high cost — and that’s a problem for the region.
lead_paragraph: Africa south of the Sahara is producing more than six times as much food as it did in 1961. That’s a much bigger increase than that of the world as a whole, which has merely quadrupled agricultural output, as this chart shows. From this data alone, sub-Saharan Africa seems to be an agricultural success story.

headline: Oregon Is Recriminalizing Drugs. Here’s What Portland Learned.
abstract: Oregon’s governor has signed a measure to reimpose criminal penalties for hard drugs. Mayor Ted Wheeler of Portland talks about why the experiment “failed.”
lead_paragraph: When Oregon embarked on a landmark plan three years ago to decriminalize hard drugs, it wagered that a focus on treatment over punishment would create a new model for drug policy around the country.

headline: Read the Florida Supreme Court’s Ruling on the Constitutional Amendment
abstract: The Florida Supreme Court allowed voters to decide this fall whether to expand abortion access, ruling 4 to 3 that a proposed constitutional amendment that would guarantee the right to abortion “before viability,” usually around 24 weeks, could go on the November ballot.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Supreme Court allowed voters to decide this fall whether to expand abortion access, ruling 4 to 3 that a proposed constitutional amendment that would guarantee the right to abortion “before viability,” usually around 24 weeks, could go on the November ballot.

headline: Florida Court Allows 6-Week Abortion Ban, but Voters Will Get to Weigh In
abstract: The Florida Supreme Court found that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion. But it also allowed a ballot question on whether to expand abortion access.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Supreme Court overturned decades of legal precedent on Monday in ruling that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion, effectively allowing Florida to ban the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy.

headline: ‘Pretty Big Bunny, Huh?’: Biden Hosts White House Easter Egg Roll
abstract: Even before the skies opened up on children rolling eggs down a soggy South Lawn, the 146-year-old tradition was caught up in the latest partisan storm.
lead_paragraph: Bunny ears. Rain slickers. Sixty-four thousand hard-boiled eggs.

headline: Read the Florida Supreme Court’s Ruling on the Abortion Ban
abstract: The Florida Supreme Court overturned decades of legal precedent in ruling that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion, effectively allowing Florida to ban the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Supreme Court overturned decades of legal precedent in ruling that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion, effectively allowing Florida to ban the procedure after six weeks of pregnancy.

headline: A Solar Eclipse Means Big Science
abstract: To study an eclipse you need cameras, rockets, giant balloons and beehives.
lead_paragraph: To study an eclipse you need cameras, rockets, giant balloons and beehives.

headline: Netanyahu Says Israel Will Shut Down Al Jazeera in Israel
abstract: The move came after Israeli lawmakers passed a new law that allows the government to temporarily shutter foreign media outlets deemed to be a risk to national security.
lead_paragraph: Israeli lawmakers passed a law on Monday allowing the government to temporarily shutter foreign media outlets that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has determined undermine the country’s national security, and the Israeli leader said he would use the new law to block Al Jazeera broadcasts and activities in Israel.

headline: 3 Top Iranian Commanders Are Reported Killed in Israeli Strike in Syria
abstract: The airstrike on an Iranian Embassy building was one of the biggest attacks yet in a shadow war that has increasingly been moving into the open.
lead_paragraph: At least three senior commanders and four officers overseeing Iran’s covert operations in the Middle East were killed on Monday when Israeli warplanes struck a building in Damascus that is part of the Iranian Embassy complex, according to Iranian and Syrian officials.

headline: Lou Conter, Last Survivor of the Battleship Arizona, Dies at 102
abstract: Escaping injury in the Japanese attack on the ship in Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, he went on to help in recovering bodies and putting out fires.
lead_paragraph: Lou Conter, the last known survivor of the battleship Arizona, which sank with the loss of 1,177 sailors and Marines in Japan’s sneak attack on Pearl Harbor, plunging the United States into World War II, died on Monday at his home in Grass Valley, Calif. He was 102.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Iran Said Israel Killed Top Generals
abstract: Also, the U.S. could vote on aid to Ukraine in the coming weeks.
lead_paragraph: At least seven officers including three generals overseeing Iran’s covert operations in the Middle East were killed in an Israeli strike in Syria yesterday, according to Iranian and Syrian officials.

headline: In Kyoto, Five Hotels to Add to Your Travel Wish List
abstract: The city’s newest crop of hotels — from a luxury retreat on a historic estate to a 10-room inn surrounded by forested mountains — were worth the wait.
lead_paragraph: The pandemic lockdown in Japan coincided with a flurry of new hotels, especially in Kyoto, where the Park Hyatt, Aman and Four Seasons were joined by a group of independent properties and the first Ace hotel in the archipelago. When the country finally reopened to foreign visitors in October 2022, tourists came flooding back to the city of 800-year-old temples and bamboo forests spoiled for choice of accommodations, at a range of prices. The number continues to grow: Next month, the wellness-focused Six Senses brand will open its first Japanese outpost in the city’s Higashiyama district, home to many of the main tourist sites. Here, a look at five of Kyoto’s newer hotels that are redefining the city’s hospitality scene.

headline: What Excites You About This Election Year?
abstract: Not everyone feels like tuning out.
lead_paragraph: For some Americans, the rematch between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump feels inherently tired, or perhaps inescapably depressing, depending on your views.

headline: Warner Bros. Discovery Directors Step Down Amid Antitrust Inquiry
abstract: The Justice Department was investigating whether the two violated a law forbidding simultaneous service on the boards of competitors.
lead_paragraph: Warner Bros. Discovery said on Monday that two members of its board of directors, Steven Newhouse and Steven Miron, had stepped down after the company learned about an investigation into whether their presence on the board violated antitrust law.

headline: Florida’s Top Court Allowed a Six-Week Abortion Ban
abstract: Also, an Israeli strike killed top Iranian commanders, Iran said. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Florida Supreme Court ruled today that the State Constitution’s privacy protections do not extend to abortion. The move overturns decades of precedent and clears the way for a ban on abortions in the state after six weeks of pregnancy to take effect within 30 days.

headline: Google to Delete Billions of Chrome Browser Records in Latest Settlement
abstract: The internet giant resolved a lawsuit that claimed it had deceived users by tracking their web activity in the Chrome browser’s private Incognito setting.
lead_paragraph: In recent months, Google has raced to settle a backlog of lawsuits ahead of major antitrust showdowns with the Justice Department later this year.

headline: Scottish Hate Crime Law Takes Effect as Critics Warn It Will Stifle Speech
abstract: The legislation expands protections and creates a new charge of “stirring up hatred.” Critics, including J.K. Rowling, said the law was “wide open to abuse.”
lead_paragraph: A sweeping law targeting hate speech went into effect in Scotland on Monday, promising protection against threats and abuse but drawing criticism that it could have a chilling effect on free speech.

headline: How I Learned to Love the Rerun Election
abstract: Have you got the Biden-Trump blues?
lead_paragraph: When our pollsters recently asked voters how they felt about the coming election, they heard words that could also describe rancid garbage, personal regret or a meteor headed for Earth.

headline: Will MAGA Republicans Block Baltimore’s Rebuilding?
abstract: In Congress, rebuilding the Key Bridge could be the next Ukraine funding debate.
lead_paragraph: Soon after a huge container ship struck Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge, bringing it down, President Biden pledged that the federal government would “pay the entire cost of reconstructing” the bridge. This would clearly be the right thing to do, not just to help the state of Maryland but also to limit the economic damage from a disaster that has blocked both a major road artery and a major port. Among other things, the Port of Baltimore plays a key role in both exports of coal and trade in farm and construction equipment, so the bridge disaster will have direct adverse effects on the heartland as well as the East Coast.

headline: In First Court Appearance, U.S.S. Cole Case Judge Sets Goal of 2025 Trial
abstract: If Col. Matthew S. Fitzgerald meets his goal, the trial would start a quarter century after the terrorist attack that killed 17 U.S. sailors off Yemen.
lead_paragraph: An Army judge who was in law school at the time of the U.S.S. Cole bombing restarted hearings in the case on Monday and declared it was his intention to put the accused mastermind of the attack on trial at Guantánamo Bay in 2025. If he does, the trial would start a quarter century after the terrorist attack that killed 17 U.S. sailors off Aden, Yemen.

headline: The 100 Best Restaurants in New York City in 2024
abstract: Our critic, Pete Wells, drops his annual ranking. See what’s new, what moved and what left the list.
lead_paragraph: Our critic, Pete Wells, drops his annual ranking. See what’s new, what moved and what left the list.

headline: We Want to Know: What’s Your No. 1 New York City Restaurant?
abstract: The Times’s critic, Pete Wells, has shared his second-annual list of the city’s best, but tell us what tops yours.
lead_paragraph: This week, The New York Times restaurant critic, Pete Wells, has revisited his list of the 100 best restaurants in New York City, adding new places, dropping others and changing his rankings of many old favorites.

headline: Man Charged With Killing Officer Was Seen With Gun Beforehand, D.A. Says
abstract: Another officer patrolling Far Rockaway said he noticed Guy Rivera carrying a gun before he fatally shot Detective Jonathan Diller, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: A police officer saw the man accused of killing Detective Jonathan Diller carrying what appeared to be a gun before the confrontation that led to the fatal shooting last week, according to new details released by the Queens district attorney.

headline: Gag Order Against Trump Is Expanded to Bar Attacks on Judge’s Family
abstract: Donald Trump had in recent days targeted the daughter of Juan Merchan, the judge overseeing his criminal trial in Manhattan, in blistering social media posts.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Trump Gets Bond Deal to Ward Off $454 Million Judgment, for Now
abstract: The guarantee means that New York’s attorney general will not be able to pursue Donald Trump’s assets and bank accounts until Mr. Trump’s appeals are settled.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump averted a financial disaster on Monday, reaching a deal that will spare him from paying a $454 million judgment in his civil fraud case while he appeals the penalty.

headline: Checks Out
abstract: Billy Bratton has decided to extend his stay.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: World Central Kitchen Aid Workers Killed in Israeli Strike
abstract: Seven workers for the aid group were killed overnight when their convoy was struck in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Seven workers for the aid group were killed overnight when their convoy was struck in Gaza.

headline: Iran Says the Deadly Israeli Strike in Damascus Will Not Go Unanswered
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran’s supreme leader, said Israel would be punished for the strike, which killed three top commanders.
lead_paragraph: Iranian leaders said on Tuesday that the Israeli airstrikes on an Iranian embassy compound in Damascus, Syria, that killed three top Iranian commanders would not go unanswered. Government supporters took to the streets and called for retaliation against Israel.

headline: Corrections: April 2, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A picture caption with an article on Sunday about Ukrainian troops using marketing to attract recruits misstated the Ukrainian armed forces unit of which the Da Vinci Wolves battalion is a part. It now belongs to the 59th Motorized Brigade, not the 67th Separate Mechanized Brigade.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Ireland Is Recovering Historical Documents Lost to the Flames of War
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Archivists may not always know what they have, but they never throw anything out.”

headline: North Korea Missile Test Hints at Greater Menace to U.S. Bases
abstract: The test, analysts said, may have involved a new intermediate-range hypersonic missile that is faster to launch and more difficult to intercept.
lead_paragraph: North Korea launched an intermediate-range ballistic missile off its east coast on Tuesday, an indication that the country was continuing to develop missiles capable of targeting American military bases in the Western Pacific.

headline: Poor Nations Are Writing a New Handbook for Getting Rich
abstract: Economies focused on exports have lifted millions out of poverty, but epochal changes in trade, supply chains and technology are making it a lot harder.
lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, the handbook for how developing countries can grow rich hasn’t changed much: Move subsistence farmers into manufacturing jobs, and then sell what they produce to the rest of the world.

headline: Ukraine’s Arms Industry Is Growing, but Is It Growing Fast Enough?
abstract: Kyiv is aiming to build its own weapons to bring the fight to Russia. But it will take time Ukraine might not have.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s military had only one Bohdana artillery cannon in its arsenal when Russia invaded the country two years ago. Yet that single weapon, built in Ukraine in 2018 and able to shoot NATO-caliber rounds, proved so effective in the earliest days of the war that it was trucked to battlefields across the country, from the northeastern city of Kharkiv to the southwestern coast along the Black Sea and points in between.

headline: Israeli Army Withdraws From Major Gaza Hospital, Leaving Behind a Wasteland
abstract: Al-Shifa Hospital lies in ruins after a battle there between Israeli soldiers and Gazan gunmen. Shortly before withdrawing, the Israeli military brought journalists from The Times to witness the damage.
lead_paragraph: Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City, once the fulcrum of Gaza’s health system and now an emblem of its destruction, stood in ruins on Sunday, as if a tsunami had surged through it followed by a tornado.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Iran says Israel struck its generals in Syria.
lead_paragraph: At least three generals and four officers overseeing Iran’s covert operations in the Middle East were killed in an Israeli strike in Syria yesterday, according to Iranian and Syrian officials.

headline: Word of the Day: inexplicable
abstract: This word has appeared in 107 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word inexplicable has appeared in 107 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 27 in “Helping a Child Navigate Grief? Open a Picture Book” by Elisabeth Egan:

headline: Late Night Assesses Donald Trump’s Slumping Media Company
abstract: Jimmy Fallon joked that “Truth Social stock tanked so fast, they’re changing the name to Twitter.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: A Lifetime Under the Moon’s Shadow
abstract: The late Jay Pasachoff inspired generations of students to become astronomers by dragging them to the ends of the Earth for a few precarious moments of ecstasy.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the total solar eclipse.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: His Brownstone Is Worth $5.4 Million. Why Is His Tax Bill So Low?
abstract: Housing advocates and even some homeowners in wealthier neighborhoods say New York’s property tax system is unfair. A court case could force the city to make changes.
lead_paragraph: New York City is known for its pricey real estate, but some homeowners get an unexpected bargain: Property taxes on some of the fanciest, most coveted properties are often very low — at least relatively.

headline: 100 Years of Furniture
abstract: What’s your favorite furnishing?
lead_paragraph: The bean bag chair. The water bed. The sectional couch. Do you have a favorite piece of furniture, either in your home — or in your dreams? Which designs would you nominate to a Furniture Hall of Fame?

headline: World Central Kitchen Has Fed People in Disaster and War Zones Around the Globe
abstract: The group is a relatively new aid provider in Gaza, but it has garnered notice by making bold moves, like building a jetty out of rubble to bring aid in by sea.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 2010 by the chef José Andrés after a devastating earthquake in Haiti, the relief group World Central Kitchen has turned up at some of the globe’s biggest disasters, crises and conflicts, with the goal of doing what chefs do best: feeding people.

headline: ‘The Plane Is Fine’: An Airline Course Looks to Overcome Fear in the Skies
abstract: Anxiety when flying might not seem so unreasonable these days, but a British Airways program seeks to reassure the lightly nervous and the abjectly terrified alike.
lead_paragraph: No sooner had British Airways Flight 9240 roared into the air over Heathrow Airport than the cabin air was pierced by a sharp, scary noise, like an alarm or a siren. The power surged and then seemed to falter, and the plane became worryingly quiet. (Too quiet?)

headline: In This Heartbreaker, Hard Choices Come With Hidden Costs
abstract: An editor’s ambition. A coveted manuscript. The gift of a cow. Lives and lies graze one another in Neel Mukherjee’s tragicomic novel.
lead_paragraph: Neel Mukherjee’s “Choice” is a novel full of characters deciding how much truth to tell. As in “The Lives of Others,” the author’s 2014 Booker Prize-shortlisted novel, we are confronted with subtle, powerful narratives within narratives exploring the gap between wealth and poverty, myopia and activism, fact and fiction. But here these themes deepen into an exploration of free will. A line from V.S. Naipaul’s “In a Free State” comes to mind: “The only lies for which we are truly punished are those we tell ourselves.”

headline: 6 Hotel Pools Perfect for Swimmers
abstract: Many hotel pools are built with children and sun-seekers in mind: too short, too warm and too crowded. These, in cities across the U.S., let you get your laps in, in style.
lead_paragraph: Michele Heisler, 61, is an avid swimmer, putting in 45 minutes three times a week in a local 25-yard-long pool. But swimming while traveling can be challenging. “Most hotel pools are too tiny or too crowded,” she said.

headline: A Journey to the Boot of Italy, With Murder, Romance and Ricotta
abstract: A Philadelphia chef goes searching for her family history in Jo Piazza’s sun-baked multigenerational tale “The Sicilian Inheritance.”
lead_paragraph: I am a novelist and a reader — all I want in the world is hot coffee and time to read and write. Since I was a tween devouring “Flowers in the Attic” and the Rabbit Angstrom novels — who let me read Updike as a kid? — I have been drawn to flawed characters, complicated worlds and propulsive stories that overwhelm me with uncomfortable emotions.

headline: How Exercise Strengthens Your Brain
abstract: Physical activity improves cognitive and mental health in all sorts of ways. Here’s why, and how to reap the benefits.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the Netherlands, Henriette van Praag had always been active, playing sports and riding her bike to school every day. Then, in the late-1990s, while working as a staff scientist at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies in San Diego, she discovered that exercise can spur the growth of new brain cells in mature mice. After that, her approach to exercise changed.

headline: What’s the Quickest Path to World War III?
abstract: In “The Return of Great Powers” and “Up in Arms,” Jim Sciutto and Adam E. Casey consider modern-day superpower conflict through the lens of the past.
lead_paragraph: Every few months in the years that Donald J. Trump was president, Iran made a show of its ballistic missiles — the powerful rockets that can deliver nuclear warheads from one nation to another — and set off a small panic in Washington. The tests went like this: A missile flew up from one part of Iran, traveled through the country’s airspace and, ideally, blew up harmlessly in another part of Iran, hundreds of miles away.

headline: Is It Healthier to Eat Your Vegetables Before Your Carbs?
abstract: “Nutrient sequencing” is said to regulate blood sugar. We asked experts if the science holds up.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve heard that it’s best for my health to eat a salad before dinner. But if I’m eating vegetables regardless, does the order really matter?

headline: 5-Star Bird Houses for Picky but Precious Guests: Nesting Swiftlets
abstract: To lure swiftlets, whose saliva-built nests fetch high prices in China, people in Borneo compete to build them the most luxurious accommodations: safe, clean, dark and with pools for bathing.
lead_paragraph: With no windows, the gloomy, gray building looming four stories above the rice fields in a remote village in Indonesian Borneo resembles nothing more than a prison.

headline: Israel Must No Longer Live by the Sword
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is wildly unpopular — but it will take a movement to unseat him.
lead_paragraph: The moment Israel’s devastating war in the Gaza Strip ends, the unfinished conflict within Israel over its future will begin again. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his right-wing coalition partners know this. That may be, in part, why they have set the improbable aim of “total victory” as the war’s ultimate objective, and why they have so far refused any deal that would end the fighting in exchange for returning the roughly 100 hostages still in Hamas captivity. After almost six months, this war is already Israel’s longest since Israel’s war of independence.

headline: Puccini’s ‘Butterfly’ and ‘Turandot’: More Than Appropriation
abstract: The history and curiosity behind these operas, both set in Asia, complicate often simplistic criticisms of borrowing and stereotyping.
lead_paragraph: A key relic of the genesis of Giacomo Puccini’s two operas set in Asia can be found not in Italy, where both works premiered, nor in China or Japan, where they are set, but — of all places — in Morristown, N.J.

headline: So Much Produce Comes in Plastic. Is There a Better Way?
abstract: As governments impose limits on plastic food packaging, climate-friendlier alternatives are in the works. Here are some that might be coming to a grocery store near you.
lead_paragraph: If it seems like plastic surrounds nearly every cucumber, apple and pepper in the produce aisle, it does.

headline: The Case Against ‘Good’ Coffee
abstract: Instant coffee tastes … just OK. And that’s fine by me.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I went through a long period during which I awoke every morning with absolutely no desire to make coffee. Don’t misunderstand: I still wanted to drink the stuff. With a 3-year-old and 1-year-old waking me up around — if I was lucky — 6 in the morning, I relied on coffee’s sharpening effect more than ever. I was just tired of working for it.

headline: Take Me Out to the Gift Shop
abstract: For a lot of fans at the new Mets team store, game day is all about the shopping.
lead_paragraph: On Friday morning, at 11:40 on the dot, hundreds of Mets fans flooded into the new team store at Citi Field in Queens. It was the opening day of baseball season, and they were the first ones into the new space, located in the Jackie Robinson Rotunda, the grand entryway to the ballpark.

headline: How Will Self-Driving Cars Handle Jaywalkers?
abstract: The city is introducing a permit process for testing autonomous cars on the streets of New York. The vehicles will face some unique challenges.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at Mayor Eric Adams’s recently announced plan to allow the testing of self-driving cars on New York City’s streets.

headline: Let People Sell Their Kidneys. It Will Save Lives.
abstract: A regulated market for donations could help end the shortage of these organs for transplant.
lead_paragraph: I owe the past 25 years of my life to my father, who dozed under general anesthesia as a surgeon cut eight inches from stomach to spine, removed one of his kidneys, placed it on ice and sent it to a nearby operating room, where it was fitted into my abdomen. My brother had a kidney transplant the same week, six days before I did. His new kidney came from a man we never knew who had died in a car accident in the mountains.

headline: What Have You Learned From a Grandparent or Elder?
abstract: Do you wish you had closer relationships with the older people in your life?
lead_paragraph: Have you had close relationships with grandparents or other elders? What memories come to mind when you think of them? What life lessons have you gained from your time together?

headline: I’m an Economist. Don’t Worry. Be Happy.
abstract: An economist explains why his lens makes him so much more optimistic about the state of our economy than the average American.
lead_paragraph: I, too, know that flash of resentment when grocery store prices feel as if they don’t make sense. I hate the fact that a small treat feels less like an earned indulgence and more like financial folly. And I’m concerned about my kids now that house prices look like telephone numbers.

headline: A Remote Escape in Newfoundland
abstract: The craggy island had long held special appeal for one Canadian, who bought a pair of historic houses that had been on the market for years.
lead_paragraph: The craggy island had long held special appeal for one Canadian, who bought a pair of historic houses that had been on the market for years.

headline: A Second Home That’s Far Away From It All
abstract: Two saltbox houses on the island of Newfoundland, in Canada, were hard to resist. What would be harder still: Renovating them without road access.
lead_paragraph: When Cailey Heaps wants to get away from it all, one place comes to mind: the island of Newfoundland in Canada.

headline: ‘Shogun’ Episode 7 Recap: Death Wish
abstract: As the walls close in around Lord Toranaga, his vassals and family look for ways out.
lead_paragraph: “When the legend becomes fact, print the legend.” Few cinematic genres have had as fruitful a conversation with one another as the samurai film and the western, so it’s only fitting to use an epigraph from “The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance” to sum up the central conflict in this week’s episode.

headline: I Hope to Repeal an Arcane Law That Could Be Misused to Ban Abortion Nationwide
abstract: The Comstock Act is a major concern if Donald Trump is re-elected.
lead_paragraph: A long discredited, arcane 150-year-old law is back in the news in 2024, and that should terrify anyone who supports reproductive freedom. Last week at the Supreme Court, the Comstock Act of 1873 was referenced on three separate occasions during oral arguments in a case dealing with access to mifepristone, one of two drugs typically used in medication abortions.

headline: What Happened to the Wrap Dress?
abstract: A pandemic, the demise of “girlboss” culture and new values around what’s “flattering” have made the classic design seem outdated to some.
lead_paragraph: By Amanda Sanders’s estimate, she owns more than 100 Diane von Furstenberg wrap dresses. She has been collecting the style since the 1990s, after she graduated from college.

headline: How Should I Be Using A.I. Right Now?
abstract: Give your A.I. a personality, spend 10 hours experimenting, and other practical tips from Ethan Mollick.
lead_paragraph: There’s something of a paradox that has defined my experience with artificial intelligence in this particular moment. It’s clear we’re witnessing the advent of a wildly powerful technology, one that could transform the economy and the way we think about art and creativity and the value of human work itself. At the same time, I can’t for the life of me figure out how to use it in my own day-to-day job.

headline: Nicholas Galitzine Wants to Prove He’s More Than Just a Pretty Face
abstract: Known for playing princes and their modern equivalents, this British actor hopes his steamy new drama, “Mary & George,” will change how Hollywood sees him.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve often found that the way people see me is very different from how I see myself,” Nicholas Galitzine said. “People attribute a pristineness to me.”

headline: With Abortion Ballot Question, a ‘Path to Relevance’ for Democrats in Florida?
abstract: Rulings allowing a strict abortion ban, along with a ballot question on expanding abortion access, may inject new life into Democratic campaigns in the state.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, November got a lot more interesting in Florida.

headline: Ruben Gallego, Democratic Senate Candidate in Arizona, Raises $7.5 Million
abstract: The congressman’s campaign said it had more than $9.6 million cash on hand as it looks toward a fall race against Kari Lake, a Trump ally, who has yet to announce first-quarter fund-raising figures.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ruben Gallego, the expected Democratic nominee for Senate in Arizona, raised $7.5 million in the first three months of the year, his campaign said on Tuesday, a significant sum for what is likely to be a competitive general election race in the battleground state.

headline: Japan’s New Royal Instagram Page Forgoes Flash for Formality
abstract: No memes or spontaneity to see here, people. Just the usual official pictures of Emperor Naruhito and his family.
lead_paragraph: Anyone expecting the Japanese royal family’s new Instagram account to generate memes or showcase a new side of the world’s oldest continuous monarchy should lower their expectations.

headline: Beyoncé’s New Album Reviewed
abstract: “Cowboy Carter” is more than country.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot to unpack in Beyoncé’s new album, “Cowboy Carter,” says The Times’s chief pop music critic, Jon Pareles. It’s a sprawling 27-track opus, and, despite being anticipated as a country album, it’s the work of an artist who’s willing to take chances, openly questioning the whole idea of formats, categories and genres, Pareles says. Here’s his review.

headline: Israel Escalates Shadow War With Iran, and Trump Makes Bond
abstract: Plus, it’s the end of an era in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Kids Are Missing School at an Alarming Rate
abstract: How the pandemic changed families’ lives and the culture of education.
lead_paragraph: Long after schools have fully reopened after the pandemic, one concerning metric suggests that children and their parents have changed the way they think about being in class.

headline: China, Russia and Trump
abstract: What Beijing and Moscow hope to gain from a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: America’s biggest adversaries evidently want Donald Trump to win the 2024 presidential election.

headline: After Strike, Aid Groups in Gaza Are More Fearful Than Ever
abstract: “Gaza right now is one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a humanitarian worker,” a spokeswoman for Save the Children said after a strike killed World Central Kitchen workers.
lead_paragraph: Aid groups in Gaza said on Tuesday that they were more concerned than ever about the safety of their staff members there after seven World Central Kitchen workers were killed in an airstrike, saying that the deaths underscored the growing challenges of meeting Palestinians’ basic needs.

headline: 12-Year-Old Detained After Fatal School Shooting in Finland
abstract: Another 12-year-old was killed and two other students were wounded in a country with one of the highest rates of gun ownership in Europe.
lead_paragraph: A young boy fatally shot a 12-year-old student and wounded two others at a school in Finland on Tuesday, the police said, a rare act of violence by a child in a country that changed its gun laws after earlier school shootings but where gun ownership remains widespread.

headline: Regulators Force Another Microsoft Split
abstract: The tech giant is unbundling Teams from its Office software suite, as it faces mounting scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is separating Teams, its popular video and chat app, from its Office software suite in markets around the world, broadening a split that began in the European Union last fall.

headline: The Winners of Our ‘How To’ Contest
abstract: Over 2,200 teenagers submitted essays on how to do everything from fix a toilet to fight a kangaroo. We’ll be publishing the work of the winners all week.
lead_paragraph: Almost from the time our new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers went live in January, we knew it would be a success.

headline: How to Do the Worm
abstract: A winning essay by Camille Gonzales, age 18.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Camille Gonzales, 18, from Houston, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.

headline: How to Find Your Balance
abstract: A winning essay by Chelsea Hu, age 18.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Chelsea Hu, 18, from Andover, Mass., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.

headline: How to Befriend an Introvert
abstract: A winning essay by Ashley Zhang, age 14.
lead_paragraph: This essay, by Ashley Zhang, 14, of West Vancouver, British Columbia, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.

headline: What We Know About the Israeli Strike That Killed 7 Aid Workers in Gaza
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel acknowledged on Tuesday a “tragic case of our forces unintentionally hitting innocent people.”
lead_paragraph: Seven aid workers with World Central Kitchen were killed in the Gaza Strip when their convoy came under fire on Monday night, according to the aid organization and Gazan health officials.

headline: Strike in Damascus Is an Escalation in Israel’s Undeclared War With Iran
abstract: Tehran promises major retaliation, and the danger of a miscalculation is ever-present. But neither side wants a major shooting war, given the stakes.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s bombing of an Iranian Embassy building in Damascus, which killed senior Iranian military and intelligence officials, is a major escalation of what has long been a simmering undeclared war between Israel and Iran.

headline: Readers Share Their Favorite Places to See Art in California
abstract: Contemporary art with a hillside winery in Napa, a Roman villa-inspired museum in Pacific Palisades and more.
lead_paragraph: The Haggin Museum in Stockton has an impressive art collection, particularly for a city that has seriously struggled for years.

headline: The Caitlin Clark Show Rolls On
abstract: While off-the-court drama has raged in the women’s tournament, Clark and Iowa dispatched with their foils from last season en route to the Final Four.
lead_paragraph: One way to view the meteoric growth of women’s college basketball is through the career arc of its current protagonist: Caitlin Clark, the University of Iowa’s stone-cold mad bomber.

headline: Tesla’s Sales Drop, a Sign That Its Grip on the E.V. Market Is Slipping
abstract: Sales of the company’s electric cars dropped in the first three months of the year, even as other automakers sold more battery-powered vehicles.
lead_paragraph: Tesla appeared to be losing command of the market it effectively created after it reported a stunning drop in quarterly sales on Tuesday, raising fresh questions about Elon Musk’s leadership of the company.

headline: Trump to Focus on Border as Democrats Eye Boost From Florida Abortion Ruling
abstract: Democrats, bolstered by a pair of court rulings out of Florida on Monday, have fresh optimism about their ability to center the campaign on abortion.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump will campaign on immigration and border policy today with events planned in Michigan and Wisconsin, two crucial battleground states in the Midwest.

headline: Biden Critics Push Democrats to Submit Blank Ballots in New York
abstract: Activists pressuring the president over Gaza urge voters to leave ballots unmarked, since New York does not allow “uncommitted” votes in primaries.
