headline: Ugandan Court Upholds Draconian Anti-Gay Law
abstract: The law, which includes the death penalty as a punishment in some cases, has been strongly condemned, including by the United States.
lead_paragraph: Uganda’s Constitutional Court on Wednesday largely upheld a sweeping anti-gay law that President Yoweri Museveni signed last year, undermining the efforts of activists and rights groups to abolish legislation that drew worldwide condemnation and strained the East African nation’s relationship with the West.

headline: It’s a Free Country. For How Much Longer?
abstract: Three new books explore the complications of liberty and the seductions of authoritarianism in American life.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of the Covid-19 pandemic, amid encouragement to stay at home, a Las Vegas school board candidate’s tweet went viral: “I just went to a crowded Red Robin.” Her reason? “Because this is America. And I’ll do what I want.”

headline: ‘Carefluencers’ Are Helping Older Loved Ones, and Posting About It
abstract: On TikTok and Instagram, people are sharing what it’s like to take care of relatives who have reached their final years.
lead_paragraph: On the east side of San Jose, Calif., there is an abuela who seems to have more grandchildren than she can count.

headline: Traveling Light: How to Pack a Carry-on
abstract: Should you fold or roll your clothes? Is a duffel bag better than a backpack or a bag with wheels? How to pack light and avoid checked-bag fees (not to mention lost luggage).
lead_paragraph: For some travelers, the mere thought of packing a carry-on bag can sour even the most potent vacation anticipation. But packing light can also be a creative endeavor that helps build excitement for your upcoming getaway. And with fees for checked bags on the rise, it makes economic sense to master the art of packing a carry-on. Here are some tips on how to save space — and your sanity.

headline: How a Pandemic Boom Led to a ‘Property Tax Mess’ in Colorado
abstract: A surge of new residents into Rocky Mountain states drove up home prices. The result was property tax increases of 40 percent or more for some of those already there.
lead_paragraph: Marleen Gamble had already taken out a reverse mortgage on her townhouse in 2018 to keep up with the steady increase in expenses eating into the Social Security checks that are her only source of income.

headline: Alice Randall Made Country History. Black Women Are Helping Tell Hers.
abstract: In “My Black Country,” the musician and author who cracked a Nashville color barrier is telling her story — and hearing her songs reimagined.
lead_paragraph: The country singer Rissi Palmer could not understand why Alice Randall was emailing her.

headline: The Problem With Saying ‘Sex Assigned at Birth’
abstract: The term creates doubt about a biological fact when there shouldn’t be any.
lead_paragraph: As you may have noticed, “sex” is out, and “sex assigned at birth” is in. Instead of asking for a person’s sex, some medical and camp forms these days ask for “sex assigned at birth” or “assigned sex” (often in addition to gender identity). The American Medical Association and the American Psychological Association endorse this terminology; its use has also exploded in academic articles. The Cleveland Clinic’s online glossary of diseases and conditions tells us that the “inability to achieve or maintain an erection” is a symptom of sexual dysfunction, not in “males,” but in “people assigned male at birth.”

headline: Desert Drives and Sea Lion Dives: The Enduring Draws of La Paz, Mexico
abstract: New hotels and destination-worthy restaurants now complement the ever-appealing outdoors surrounding La Paz, the capital of Baja California Sur.
lead_paragraph: For our last night in La Paz, Mexico, we kept it simple: A couple of cans of cold Pacifico, a bench on the malecón, the city’s waterfront promenade, and the sunset glowing orange over the shimmering silver-blue Sea of Cortez. My husband, Alex, and I had spent nearly a week taking scenic desert drives and lazy city strolls, visiting stunning beaches and mountains, and enjoying a steady diet of fish tacos and mezcalitas. But now we were salt-coated and sinking into a blissful exhaustion that comes only after a day spent scuba diving.

headline: In These Books, the Parents Are the Problem
abstract: The children in three illustrated satirical tales are up against something far more complex than ogres, witches and big bad wolves.
lead_paragraph: Children’s books have long featured pint-size heroes overcoming fierce antagonists: ogres, witches and big bad wolves. So it comes as no surprise that a similar drama occurs in these three stories. Only here, children are up against something far more complex: their parents.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Shirley Horn
abstract: The pianist and vocalist was at once magnetically powerful and laid-back, glamorous and understated. A mix of musicians, writers and radio personalities share their favorites.
lead_paragraph: We’ve spent five minutes with icons of the avant-garde, big-band heroes and saxophone titans. This time around, we’re putting the spotlight on one of jazz history’s rarest talents, the pianist and vocalist Shirley Horn, who would have turned 90 next month.

headline: What Doctors Want You to Know About Beta Blockers for Anxiety
abstract: Start-ups are making it easier to get the pills online, but experts warn they should be used with caution.
lead_paragraph: Anxious ahead of a big job interview? Worried about giving a speech? First date nerves?

headline: The Second Best Way to Get Divorced, According to Maya Hawke
abstract: The “Stranger Things” actor reads an essay about a “nobody-moves-out” breakup and reflects on her own experience growing up with divorced parents.
lead_paragraph: When Maya Hawke’s famous parents got divorced, she was just a little kid trying to navigate their newly separate worlds. Paparazzi aside, Maya’s experience of shuttling between two homes was still more common than the arrangement described in the essay Maya reads: “Our Kinder, Gentler, Nobody-Moves-Out Divorce,” by Jordana Jacobs.

headline: Life Gave a Pastry Chef Lemons. She Made Lemon Bars.
abstract: These sunny, sweet-tart treats have a little twist: a rich pecan short crust.
lead_paragraph: I’m from a lush land. Green abounds in the South. Our climate is so dewy, so thick, that we learn how to breathe through our skin down here. The nearly neon green kudzu, not just a romantic notion, climbs. The vines creep over our lives, over corners, around hills, down slopes, into gutters. We pulse with the heat. We sit with the rain during our summer storms. We ride out hurricanes with rum. We stop and listen to the cicadas when they request our audience every number of years.

headline: How Soccer Learned to Embrace Ramadan: From Faked Injuries to Bespoke Diets
abstract: In competitions like the Premier League, Muslim pros who once faced pressure to avoid daily fasts during the monthlong holiday now benefit from custom diets and in-game breaks.
lead_paragraph: Youseff Chippo had a secret.

headline: $3.2 Million Homes in New York, Georgia and Utah
abstract: A 19th-century farmhouse with a guesthouse in Leeds, an 1850 townhouse in Savannah and a 1927 home in Salt Lake City.
lead_paragraph: This expansive property is in a small hamlet in Greene County, about 15 minutes from the town of Greenville, which has a supermarket, a farm supply store and a drive-in movie theater, and within a 20-minute drive of several antique and home décor stores. It is half an hour from the city of Hudson and from Olana State Historic Site, the former home and studio of the painter Frederic Edwin Church.

headline: A Gender Theorist Who Just Wants Everyone to Get Along
abstract: Judith Butler’s new book, “Who’s Afraid of Gender?,” tries to turn down the heat on an inflamed argument.
lead_paragraph: As the example of Judith Butler shows, the boons of intellectual celebrity come at a cost. Yes, your work will command the kind of attention that would be the envy of most scholars; but the substance of that work will get eclipsed by your name, and your name will trigger a reaction in people who have never read a single thing you wrote. Throw some misogyny into the mix, and the most scornful attacks can take a lurid turn — even (or especially) if, like Butler, you identify as nonbinary. In 2017, when Butler visited Brazil for a conference on democracy, far-right protesters burned an effigy of Butler dressed in a pink bra and a witch hat.

headline: Could Trump Financially Ruin the G.O.P.?
abstract: The Republican Party is in disarray. The former president and his mounting legal woes are to blame.
lead_paragraph: The G.O.P. has a Donald Trump money problem. The former president is facing multiple indictments, and fighting those legal battles hasn’t been cheap. Unfortunately for Trump — and the Republican Party — big donors have noticed and are losing interest in filling the G.O.P.’s draining coffers. That means trouble for states like Michigan and Arizona, which are in desperate need of party money for down-ballot races.

headline: When Latin America Became the Seat of Modernity
abstract: A new MoMA exhibition looks at design from six countries, spanning 1940 to 1980. Some beautiful chairs tell the tale.
lead_paragraph: Lina Bo Bardi, the great Italian-Brazilian architect, liked to say we all invent architecture just by climbing a stair, crossing a room, opening a door or sitting down in a chair. All of “these little gestures,” she said, along with the objects they involve, are richly endowed with meaning and memory.

headline: Kristen Wiig and Maya Rudolph Just Want You to Like Them
abstract: Good friends and “Saturday Night Live” alumnae, the actresses are each headlining an Apple TV+ comedy of wealth and status.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes Maya Rudolph will watch a movie and marvel at how miserable an actor looks. “They’re covered in fake blood and broken glass, and they’re crying the whole time,” she said. “I don’t know how people do that for work! That looks so hard and stressful.”

headline: What I Saw Working at The National Enquirer During Donald Trump’s Rise
abstract: Inside the notorious “catch and kill” campaign that now stands at the heart of the former president’s legal trial.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, April 4, 2023, I was outside Manhattan criminal court. It was a sunny spring day, and the Secret Service and the Police Department had blocked off the streets with barricades. The sidewalks were clogged with news crews from around the world. Supporters of Donald Trump roamed a pen that was set up to house them. Eventually, the former president was rushed out of the courthouse after being charged by Alvin Bragg, the district attorney of Manhattan, with 34 counts of falsifying business records. His convoy departed to cheers from fans.

headline: Biden and Corporate America? It’s ‘Complicated.’
abstract: The president has courted executives with long listening sessions and sustained outreach, but frustrated many with his tax plans and regulations.
lead_paragraph: In the days before delivering his State of the Union speech last month, President Biden called the chief executives of General Motors and Cisco Systems to ask their advice on the state of the American economy and share how he planned to talk about it.

headline: Why Does Steam Float Over the Streets of Manhattan?
abstract: The orange cylinders that funnel hot vapor up and away serve an important purpose in New York City’s steam system.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at an unlikely New York icon: the orange steam funnels that spew clouds of vapor over the streets of Manhattan.

headline: Is Your Garden Missing Something? You May Need a Large Pot (or Several).
abstract: An imposing work of pottery can be as important to the design of a landscape as any well-placed plant. And no, we’re not talking about flower pots.
lead_paragraph: Flower pots, they are not. But Stephen Procter’s large stoneware garden vessels, some as tall as five feet and incorporating 250 pounds of clay, are nevertheless functional pottery — even without the soil and the plants.

headline: I’m a Doctor. Dengue Fever Took Even Me by Surprise on Vacation.
abstract: Without urgent reforms to how we educate travelers, doctors, nurses and others, we are doomed to miss textbook dengue cases.
lead_paragraph: I hate mosquitoes so much that I take my own bug repellent to parties. But in early March, on a trip with my partner to the idyllic island of Curaçao off Venezuela, I was caught off guard by insect bites after our bed-and-breakfast hosts said that mosquitoes didn’t usually appear until late summer.

headline: How Beagles and a Fever Dream Made Rebel Wilson a Star
abstract: The actress, known for roles in the “Pitch Perfect” movies, gets vulnerable about her weight loss, sexuality and money in her new memoir, “Rebel Rising.”
lead_paragraph: About five years ago, when she was 39, the actress Rebel Wilson faced a dilemma. She had just had a string of successes, having made $20 million for her comic roles in “Pitch Perfect 3,” “Isn’t It Romantic” and “The Hustle.” But a visit to a fertility doctor had filled her with self-doubt.

headline: Switching From iPhone to Android Is Easy. It’s the Aftermath That Stings.
abstract: Even if you manage to ditch your iPhone, Apple’s hooks are still there.
lead_paragraph: When I temporarily switched from an iPhone to an Android phone last week, I was bracing for a world of hurt. I’ve owned only Apple phones ever since buying the first-generation iPhone in 2007. And, like many, I’ve bought other Apple products that pair nicely, including AirPods, an Apple Watch and an iPad.

headline: Disney Fends Off Activist Investor for Second Time in 2 Years
abstract: Nelson Peltz had campaigned for two seats on Disney’s board of directors, as he sought to shake up the company’s growth plan.
lead_paragraph: The activist investor Nelson Peltz and Ike Perlmutter, the former chairman of Marvel Entertainment, have failed to infiltrate Disney’s board for the second time in two years, losing a tensely fought contest for support of the company’s shareholders as part of a campaign to alter its direction.

headline: Trump’s Backers Are Determined Not to Blow It This Time Around
abstract: The right-wing networks Trump can count on are ready for action.
lead_paragraph: In a rare display of unity, more than 100 conservative tax-exempt organizations have joined forces in support of Donald Trump and the MAGA agenda, forming a $2 billion-plus political machine.

headline: Stephen Breyer: The Supreme Court I Served On Was Made Up of Friends
abstract: If justices who disagree so profoundly can do so respectfully, perhaps it is possible for our politically divided country to do the same.
lead_paragraph: Recently, the Supreme Court justices Sonia Sotomayor and Amy Coney Barrett spoke together publicly about how members of the court speak civilly to one another while disagreeing, sometimes vigorously, about the law. Considerable disagreements on professional matters among the Supreme Court justices, important as they are, remain professional, not personal. The members of the court can and do get along well personally. That matters.

headline: Two Shakespearean Triumphs in Paris, or a Plague on Both Their Houses?
abstract: New productions of “Macbeth” and “Hamlet” follow a French tradition of adapting familiar works. The results are innovative, and sometimes cryptic.
lead_paragraph: Two Paris playhouses, both alike in dignity, putting on rival new Shakespeare productions.

headline: Zelensky Lowers Ukraine’s Draft Age, Risking Political Backlash
abstract: The idea of requiring more men to join the fight against Russia’s invasion has become toxic, but Russia is not relenting in its assault.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has signed into law three measures aimed at replenishing the ranks of his country’s exhausted and battered army, including the politically poisonous step of lowering the age when men become eligible for mobilization, and eliminating some medical exemptions.

headline: What We Know About the Earthquake in Taiwan
abstract: The quake set off aftershocks and damaged dozens of buildings, killing nine people and leaving many injured or trapped.
lead_paragraph: A powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake that rocked Taiwan during the morning commute on Wednesday was the strongest quake to hit the island in 25 years.

headline: Inflation Cools in Eurozone, Nearing Central Bank’s Target
abstract: Prices in the countries that use the euro rose 2.4 percent in the year through March, coming closer to the European Central Bank’s 2 percent inflation target.
lead_paragraph: The annual inflation rate across most economies in Europe eased for the third month in a row, nearing the target set by the European Central Bank. Consumer prices in the 20 countries that use the euro rose 2.4 percent in the year through March, down from 2.6 percent the month before, the European Union reported on Wednesday.

headline: The Accidental Tax Cutter in Chief
abstract: President Biden says he wants to rake in more money from corporations and high earners. But so far, he has cut more taxes than he’s raised.
lead_paragraph: In his campaign for re-election, President Biden has said that raising taxes on the wealthy and on big corporations is at the heart of his agenda. But under his watch, overall net taxes have decreased.

headline: Israel Takes Responsibility for Strike That Killed Aid Workers, and Tesla’s Sales Drop
abstract: Plus, the fight to see the eclipse.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Interest Rates and the Election
abstract: The Fed is expected to cut rates soon. Doing so could pull it into a partisan fight.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is in a tough spot. It expects to cut interest rates soon. But doing so before an election will yank the apolitical central bank directly into a partisan fight.

headline: Taiwan’s Strongest Earthquake in 25 Years Kills 9 and Injures Hundreds
abstract: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks. Dozens of people were trapped. Two buildings in the city of Hualien teetered perilously.
lead_paragraph: The first quake was alarming enough — a rumble more powerful than anything felt in Taiwan for a quarter-century, lasting for more than a minute on Wednesday morning, knocking belongings and even whole buildings askew. It was so strong it set off tsunami warnings in Japan, China and the Philippines.

headline: What Tesla’s Troubles Signal for the E.V. Revolution
abstract: The carmaker’s disappointing results point to slowing demand and a “sharp deterioration in growth” that extends beyond Elon Musk’s company.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has sounded the alarm for weeks that the transition to electric vehicles may be stalling, despite billions in government subsidies and huge investments by auto giants.

headline: Storm Brings Heavy, Wet Snow and Strong Winds to New England
abstract: The storm system disrupted travel across much of the region and left more than 500,000 utility customers without power on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: A storm system brought significant springtime snowfall to northern New England as rain lashed much of the coast, delivering high winds and leaving close to half a million customers without power as of Thursday night.

headline: How a Snake Uses Its Sense of Smell
abstract: These reptiles and their social networks are understudied, according to researchers applying scents to different snakes to assess their behavior.
lead_paragraph: Say the words “animal self-recognition,” and many scientists will think of chimpanzees, crows and elephants.

headline: Christopher Durang, Playwright Who Mixed High Art and Low Humor, Dies at 75
abstract: In a career spanning more than 40 years, he established himself as a hyperliterate jester and an anarchic clown.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Durang, a Tony Award-winning playwright and a master satirist, died on Tuesday night at his home in Pipersville, Pa., in Bucks County. He was 75.

headline: NATO Weighs Taking Over U.S.-Led Group Directing Ukraine Military Aid
abstract: The proposal faces several obstacles, including whether all members would agree to the changes. But the alliance is worried about wavering American support for Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: With continued American aid to Ukraine stalled and the looming prospect of a second Trump presidency, NATO’s top diplomat said on Wednesday that the alliance was poised to take more control over military support sent to Ukraine — a role that the United States has played for the past two years.

headline: How Can Our Friends Choose a Realtor Other Than My Husband?
abstract: A reader is angered by friends who list their homes with other real estate brokers — sometimes without giving his husband a chance to make his case.
lead_paragraph: My husband is an experienced Realtor. Like many, he has stories of friends who choose not to use him in their real estate transactions. Their excuse is usually that they don’t want to mix business with friendship. (This suggests to me that they don’t believe the friendship is strong enough to weather the experience or that my husband isn’t professional enough to provide top-notch service.) He has lost friends who promised to use him and then didn’t — and others who didn’t even give him a chance to make his case. They have caused him personal and financial pain. One good friend listed her home recently without even telling him. My husband is a sensitive soul, and it angers me to see him hurt by thoughtless friends. Advice?

headline: How California’s Fire Season Might Shape Up This Year
abstract: It’s been a rainy winter, but that won’t necessarily mean fewer wildfires.
lead_paragraph: Luckily for us, the 2023 fire season in California was exceptionally mild.

headline: Have the Brands Gone Too Far? Boston Marathoners Think So.
abstract: Runners are disappointed that the new finisher medals feature a large bank logo across the bottom. “This isn’t a turkey trot.”
lead_paragraph: Cathy Connor loves the Boston Marathon. She loves the camaraderie. She loves the mystique of the event, which dates to 1897 as the world’s oldest annual marathon. She loves the idea that she gets to run the same rolling course that has been conquered by greats like Kathrine Switzer, Meb Keflezighi and Des Linden.

headline: Christopher Durang, the Surrealist of Snark
abstract: In works like “Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike,” the playwright would force you to laugh, not to dull the pain but to hone it.
lead_paragraph: Pickpocketing Chekhov for dramatic capital is almost a rite of passage among playwrights, but only Christopher Durang invested the loot in beefcake.

headline: Whitney Museum Names Chief Curator
abstract: Kim Conaty will steer exhibitions and the permanent collection, saying she will pay close attention to work by Latino and Indigenous artists.
lead_paragraph: When Scott Rothkopf, the former deputy director and chief curator of the Whitney Museum of American Art, stepped up as director of the New York institution last fall, he knew he would have to hire his replacement in the curatorial area. That role — one of the most influential in the contemporary art world — will be filled, effective next week, by Kim Conaty, the museum’s curator of drawings and prints since 2017. In her new position she will steer the institution’s permanent collection and acquisitions, as well as its exhibitions and conservation activities.

headline: I.D.F. Says U.N. Observers in Lebanon Were Wounded by Buried Explosive
abstract: A spokesman for the Israeli military said the blast was caused “by an explosive previously installed there by Hezbollah,” a Lebanese militia and political movement.
lead_paragraph: A buried explosive device was the source of a blast that injured U.N. military observers in Lebanon over the weekend as they were patrolling the border with Israel, Israel’s military said Wednesday.

headline: A 15-Minute, Five-Ingredient Childhood Favorite
abstract: Priya Krishna’s headily spiced everyday dal is essential comfort food.
lead_paragraph: Every culture has its comfort dishes, the ones with powers to calm the frazzled, succor the ailing and mollify the homesick. Chicken soup and blintzes with cottage cheese and cinnamon sugar whisk me right back to my Brooklyn Jewish childhood, and I still regularly self-medicate with both of them.

headline: Lauren Boebert Has Blood Clot Removed After Hospitalization for Leg Swelling
abstract: The far-right firebrand from Colorado, who is part of a slim Republican majority in the House, is expected to make a full recovery, her campaign said.
lead_paragraph: Representative Lauren Boebert, a far-right ally of former President Donald J. Trump from Colorado who is part of the razor-thin Republican majority in the House, had surgery on Tuesday to remove an acute blood clot in her leg, her campaign said.

headline: #MeToo Stalled in France. This Actress Might Be Changing Things.
abstract: Judith Godrèche says the abuse of children and women is stitched into the fabric of the French movie industry. This time, the country seems to be listening more closely.
lead_paragraph: Judith Godrèche did not set out to relaunch the #MeToo movement in France’s movie industry.

headline: Nebraska Republicans Renew Push for ‘Winner Take All’ Electoral System
abstract: In 2020, Joseph R. Biden Jr. won one electoral vote in a state that divides its votes by congressional district. Donald J. Trump has supported the stalled effort to change the system.
lead_paragraph: A renewed push by Nebraska Republicans to move to a “winner-take-all” system in presidential elections has raised the prospect that the 2024 contest could end in an electoral college tie — with the House of Representatives deciding the winner.

headline: She’s Shaking Up Classical Music While Confronting Illness
abstract: The pianist Alice Sara Ott, who makes her New York Philharmonic debut this week, is upending concert culture — and defying stereotypes about multiple sclerosis.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Alice Sara Ott, barefoot and wearing a silver bracelet, was smiling and singing to herself the other day as she practiced a jazzy passage of Ravel at Steinway Hall in Midtown Manhattan. A Nintendo Switch, which she uses to warm up her hands, was by her side (another favored tool is a Rubik’s Cube). A shot of espresso sat untouched on the floor.

headline: I Inherited a Nazi Helmet From My Husband. What Should I Do With It?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what to do with a politically charged heirloom.
lead_paragraph: I own a Nazi helmet my husband, now deceased, inherited from his father. For a long time it didn’t bother me; it only left me wondering about the soldier who wore it. But with the resurgence in white supremacy, neo-fascism and antisemitism, I am now very uncomfortable with it. I can’t seem to figure out what to do with it. I don’t think a museum would be interested in it. I certainly would never sell it, being uneasy about who might buy it. Donating it to a theater costume shop is a possibility. Or should I save it as a piece of history for my great-grandchildren to learn from? — Name Withheld

headline: Ex-Leader of South Africa Legislature Is Arrested on Corruption Charges
abstract: The legal problems of Nosiviwe Mapisa-Nqakula expose the governing African National Congress to one of its biggest weaknesses — corruption allegations — before a crucial national election.
lead_paragraph: The lawmaker who resigned as the leader of South Africa’s top house of Parliament this week was arrested on Thursday on charges that she had taken bribes in her earlier role as defense minister.

headline: Julia Stiles Wanted to Be Just Like Kat Stratford, Too
abstract: Twenty-five years after “10 Things I Hate About You” made her stand out among a generation of young stars, she’s stayed true to the ideals of her most famous character.
lead_paragraph: Julia Stiles starts lunch with a disclaimer: “I’m kind of like a bundle of emotions, because I have a 5-month-old baby and I went into directing my first movie.”

headline: For Len Cariou, Dying Onstage Each Night Has Been ‘Invigorating’
abstract: In “Tuesdays With Morrie,” the 84-year-old actor was eager to tackle “a rich role in a show that asks, ‘What if despair and death are not the end?’”
lead_paragraph: Chris Domig was ready to throw in the towel.

headline: Review: Jonathan Tetelman Arrives at the Met in ‘La Rondine’
abstract: The tenor sang the role of Ruggero in a revival of Puccini’s opera that was performed with such restraint, it verged on overly careful.
lead_paragraph: The revival of Nicolas Joël’s Art Deco-inspired production of Puccini’s “La Rondine” at the Metropolitan Opera highlights a quality that Puccini is not necessarily known for: restraint.

headline: Fed Chair Awaits More Inflation Cooling as Path Proves ‘Bumpy’
abstract: Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said officials can take their time cutting rates. He also underscored the Fed’s independence as election season heats up.
lead_paragraph: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, reiterated on Wednesday that the central bank can take its time before cutting interest rates as inflation fades and economic growth holds up.

headline: The Various Mr. Ripleys
abstract: “Ripley” on Netflix is the latest riff on the con-artist character the author Patricia Highsmith invented in the 1950s. Here’s a look at the earlier versions.
lead_paragraph: One of fiction’s most famous impostors returns on Thursday with the debut of Netflix’s “Ripley,” the latest adaptation of a character invented in the 1950s by the author Patricia Highsmith. In eight episodes, all written and directed by the Oscar-winning screenwriter Steven Zaillian (“Schindler’s List,” “The Night Of”), a classic chameleon changes colors yet again, returning to a few core elements of Highsmith’s original creation while also boosting the creepiness quotient.

headline: A New Way of Looking at the Nude
abstract: The artists redefining portraits of the human body for a more inclusive age.
lead_paragraph: THE ARTIST PAUL Cadmus was flipping through Modern Maturity, the AARP’s official magazine, in 1991 when he saw something that made him angry. A disgruntled reader had written a letter to the editor slamming the publication for reproducing the Italian Renaissance artist Masaccio’s famous painting of Adam and Eve without including the fig leaves that church officials later added to cover their genitals.

headline: Who ‘Won’ Covid? It Depends How You Measure.
abstract: Four years after the pandemic began, we’re still learning basic facts about what happened.
lead_paragraph: Twenty months ago, in July 2022, I wrote a long essay sketching what I called the “pretty brutal” endemic future for Covid: probably about 100,000 deaths annually, at least for the next few years. The number was just a ballpark estimate, drawn from modeling by the epidemiologist Trevor Bedford. But as it is turning out, it looks to have been almost exactly right. The official count is that about 170,000 Americans died of Covid over those 20 months, at a pace that suggests at the end of the second year, the total might have been just past 200,000.

headline: Trump and R.N.C. Announce a $65.6 Million Haul in March
abstract: The new numbers help the former president narrow the financial gap with President Biden, who had amassed $155 million with the Democratic Party at the end of February.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump had the best fund-raising month of his 2024 campaign now that he’s working in tandem with the Republican National Committee, pulling in $65.6 million in March, the party announced on Wednesday.

headline: At New Directors/New Films, the Kids Are Not All Right (Nobody Really Is)
abstract: This year’s edition of the festival tends toward familiar art-house fare, but there are standouts in which characters young and old grapple with childhood.
lead_paragraph: The terrific Ukrainian documentary “Intercepted” — screening in this year’s New Directors/New Films festival — is an austere and harrowing chronicle of life, death and indifference. For roughly 90 minutes, it juxtaposes images from everyday life in Ukraine with audio gleaned from phone calls between Russian soldiers and their families. As the camera steadily focuses on the devastations of war, you hear these soldiers talking about what they’re doing, how they’re feeling, what they ate, what they plundered and who they killed.

headline: 2 Brothers in Trump Media Insider-Trading Scheme Plead Guilty
abstract: Michael and Gerald Shvartsman, who had originally pleaded not guilty to securities fraud charges, each pleaded guilty to one count of securities fraud.
lead_paragraph: Two brothers from Miami pleaded guilty on Wednesday in federal court in Manhattan for their role in a nearly $23 million insider-trading scheme surrounding the 2021 announcement that former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company planned to merge with a cash-rich shell company.

headline: Donald Trump and the Justice System
abstract: Readers discuss how the former president is or is not getting special treatment. Also: The killing of aid workers in Gaza; screens in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Eli Noyes, Animator Who Turned Clay and Sand Into Art, Dies at 81
abstract: His innovative stop-motion animation influenced a generation of filmmakers, including the creators of Wallace and Gromit.
lead_paragraph: Eli Noyes, a filmmaker whose use of clay and sand in stop-motion animation garnered an Oscar nomination and shaped the aesthetic of Nickelodeon and MTV during the early days of cable television, died on March 23 at his home in San Francisco. He was 81.

headline: New Jersey Challenges N.Y.C. Congestion Pricing in Federal Court
abstract: A closely watched lawsuit could block or upend the city’s new tolling program, which will charge most vehicles for entering the busiest parts of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Federal transportation officials allowed New York to move ahead with congestion pricing without fully addressing how traffic and pollution would be shifted to its neighbors across the Hudson River as drivers avoid the new tolls, a lawyer for the State of New Jersey argued in federal court on Wednesday.

headline: The Best Way to Ring In Spring? Herby Chicken and Noodles
abstract: Balanced with an asparagus-beet salad and a simple citrusy dessert, this dinner from David Tanis has all the best of early spring.
lead_paragraph: The tips of deciduous trees are showing the barest tinge of green, and flowering fruit trees are in full bloom. A neighbor’s forsythia has come to life, bulbs are busily doing their thing. Spring has arrived.

headline: Met Opera Taps German Conductor as Next Chorus Director
abstract: Tilman Michael, who leads the Frankfurt Opera’s chorus, will succeed the veteran conductor Donald Palumbo, who steps down this season after 17 years.
lead_paragraph: The chorus master at the Metropolitan Opera has one of the company’s most demanding jobs. There are singers to corral, notes to correct and centuries-old scores to pore over.

headline: For Red State Holdouts Like Kansas, Is Expanding Medicaid Within Reach?
abstract: As Southern states reconsider Medicaid expansion, Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas is pushing her own plan meant to appeal to conservatives. So far, success has been elusive.
lead_paragraph: As lawmakers in a nearby hearing room debated last month whether to support her legislation to expand Medicaid, Gov. Laura Kelly of Kansas dared the state’s Republican House speaker to hold a vote.

headline: He’s on Death Row for Murders. Prison Workers Say He Should Be Spared.
abstract: Brian Dorsey, who pleaded guilty to murder in the 2006 killings of Sarah and Ben Bonnie, is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday unless Missouri’s governor or the courts step in.
lead_paragraph: Among those asking Missouri’s governor to spare the life of Brian Dorsey, who was convicted of two murders and is set to be executed on Tuesday, were Roman Catholic bishops, law professors and national mental health groups.

headline: Partying on a Tuesday With Elon Musk and His 3-Year-Old
abstract: Futurists and the future-curious, including Seth Meyers and Darren Aronofsky, attended a screening in New York City for a new PBS documentary.
lead_paragraph: The future looked bright despite the rain on Tuesday evening at the Museum of Modern Art, where guests — including Elon Musk and Seth Meyers — gathered for a screening of a new PBS documentary series, “A Brief History of the Future.”

headline: Everybody Wants a Piece of South Carolina’s $1.8 Billion Surplus. Is It Real?
abstract: Whom does it belong to? How did it get there? Why? The more legislators dig, the murkier things seem to get.
lead_paragraph: South Carolina recently discovered that $1.8 billion of state money has been sitting in a bank account for more than five years, and no one seems to know its origin or what it was intended for. Now lawmakers are looking for answers, but the more they dig, the murkier it seems to get.

headline: A Quick Skillet Turkey Dinner You’ll Make Over and Over
abstract: This easy Melissa Clark recipe, inspired by the zesty, pungent flavors of larb, turns unassuming ground turkey into a star.
lead_paragraph: Bunches of fresh mint and piles of sugar snap peas are still weeks away from showing up at my local farmers’ market, but April’s lengthening days and warming temperatures already have me craving that classic spring pairing. Luckily, they can also be foraged right now at the supermarket down the street.

headline: Inside World Central Kitchen’s Work in Gaza
abstract: World Central Kitchen has suspended its relief efforts in Gaza after seven aid workers were killed in Israeli airstrikes on Monday. Videos reveal the challenges of food distribution in a territory under siege.
lead_paragraph: World Central Kitchen has suspended its relief efforts in Gaza after seven aid workers were killed in Israeli airstrikes on Monday. Videos reveal the challenges of food distribution in a territory under siege.

headline: Beyoncé Doesn’t Skimp on Flowers
abstract: In recent weeks, Beyoncé has sent elaborate all-white arrangements to musicians including Jack White, K. Michelle and Nicki Minaj.
lead_paragraph: The expression “to give someone their flowers” means to praise a person and show them care.

headline: Lizzo Says She Is Not Leaving Music Industry After ‘I Quit’ Post
abstract: Lizzo clarified that she was not quitting music after writing on Instagram last week that she was “starting to feel like the world doesn’t want me in it.”
lead_paragraph: Lizzo, the Grammy Award-winning singer, clarified on Tuesday that she was not quitting the music industry, days after her social media post saying “I QUIT” led some fans to speculate that she was ending her music career.

headline: Contradicting Trump, Ruby Garcia’s Sister Says He Never Contacted Family
abstract: The former president held up the death of a young Michigan woman at a campaign rally as an example of what he calls “migrant crime,” and claimed to have spoken to her family.
lead_paragraph: The sister of the young Michigan woman whose killing has become the latest flashpoint for Republicans on illegal immigration is pushing back on former President Donald J. Trump, criticizing him for using her sister’s death to score political points and contradicting his claims that he contacted the family.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The Iron Giant’ and More
abstract: I cover the Supreme Court for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying recently.
lead_paragraph: I cover the Supreme Court for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying recently.

headline: Many Democrats Are Worried Trump Will Beat Biden. This One Isn’t.
abstract: Simon Rosenberg has spent the past two years telling Democrats they need to calm down. His Biden-will-win prediction is his next big test.
lead_paragraph: Simon Rosenberg was right about the congressional elections of 2022. All the conventional wisdom — the polls, the punditry, the fretting by fellow Democrats — revolved around the expectation of a big red wave and a Democratic wipeout.

headline: What Janet Yellen Needs to Tell China’s Leaders
abstract: The economic course correction that the United States wants would also help average Chinese people.
lead_paragraph: It would be great if Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen had a copy of “The Portable Karl Marx” with her on her trip to China this week. She could quote from it to the Chinese leaders, whose amended constitution promises to follow “the guidance of Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought, Deng Xiaoping Theory, the Theory of Three Represents, the Scientific Outlook on Development and Xi Jinping Thought on Socialism with Chinese Characteristics for a New Era.”

headline: Traders Are Betting Millions That Trump Media Will Tumble
abstract: The parent company of Truth Social is a popular target for short-sellers, even after they lost $100 million last month betting on a decline in the stock that didn’t come.
lead_paragraph: Before former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company made its stock market debut, many investors were lining up to bet on its collapse. After the company’s share price plunged following an initial surge, the appetite to bet against the stock has grown even more ravenous.

headline: George Santos May Not Be in the House, but He’s in Your Springtime Quiz
abstract: Pep up your entry into April with a politics quiz.
lead_paragraph: Pep up your entry into April with a politics quiz.

headline: Powerful Earthquake Shakes Taiwan
abstract: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: The magnitude-7.4 quake was followed by more than 200 aftershocks.

headline: Demetri Martin Confronts the Paradoxes of a Veteran Stand-Up Career
abstract: In his new Netflix special, “Demetri Deconstructed,” he tries a more conceptual approach than the simplicity he was known for.
lead_paragraph: A comedy career can be a tricky puzzle. You must evolve to stay relevant and interesting, but change too much and fans will revolt.

headline: Son of Dominican Republic Politician Is Fatally Shot in Houston, Police Say
abstract: Luis Alfredo Pacheco Rojas, 34, son of Alfredo Pacheco, the president of the Chamber of Deputies of the Dominican Republic, was killed on Monday in a drive-by shooting, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The son of a politician from the Dominican Republic was fatally shot outside a gas station in Houston on Monday night in what the police said they believed was a “targeted” drive-by shooting.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Listening to Beyoncé & Future (and the Discourse)
abstract: How conversation about very specific aspects of the new albums “Cowboy Carter” and “We Don’t Trust You” can obscure talk of their musical quality.
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: Another Poll Shows Biden Trailing in Key States
abstract: The findings from the Wall Street Journal’s poll of seven battleground states echo other recent surveys.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump still leads President Biden in the battleground states likeliest to decide the presidency, according to polls from The Wall Street Journal in seven key states.

headline: 100,000 Live Salmon Spilled Off a Truck. Most Landed in a Creek and Lived.
abstract: A tanker carrying young salmon crashed. But most of the fish flopped into a creek and “hit the water running,” a wildlife official said.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning in March, while dew was still on the road, there occurred the salmon smolt mishap of Northeast Oregon.

headline: Did One Guy Just Stop a Huge Cyberattack?
abstract: A Microsoft engineer noticed something was off on a piece of software he worked on. He soon discovered someone was probably trying to gain access to computers all over the world.
lead_paragraph: The internet, as anyone who works deep in its trenches will tell you, is not a smooth, well-oiled machine.

headline: Angel Reese Declares for the W.N.B.A. Draft … in Vogue
abstract: Athletes like Ms. Reese and Serena Williams know that fashion is now part of the game.
lead_paragraph: L.S.U. may have lost to Iowa in the Elite Eight round of the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament, but even two days afterward their star forward Angel Reese was still making headlines — this time in Vogue.

headline: They Had Just Delivered Tons of Food. Then Their Convoy Was Hit.
abstract: The deaths of World Central Kitchen workers pushed the number of aid employees killed during the war in Gaza to at least 196, according to the U.N. secretary general, António Guterres.
lead_paragraph: Lalzawmi Frankcom’s text message was short and sweet: a heart emoji reply at 10:38 p.m. on Sunday to her friend Josh Phelps, who had sent along photos of their humanitarian work together on a reservation in South Dakota.

headline: Patient With Transplanted Pig Kidney Leaves Hospital for Home
abstract: Richard Slayman, 62, is the first patient to receive a kidney from a genetically modified pig. Two weeks after the procedure, he was well enough to be discharged, doctors said.
lead_paragraph: The first patient to receive a kidney transplanted from a genetically modified pig has fared so well that he was discharged from the hospital on Wednesday, just two weeks after the groundbreaking surgery.

headline: Apollo Valued Paramount at $26 Billion in Overture That Was Ignored
abstract: Paramount’s board of directors, which was already deep into talks with the media company Skydance, didn’t engage with the offer.
lead_paragraph: As Paramount, the media company that’s the home of the “Top Gun” franchise and Nickelodeon, was preparing to enter exclusive talks to sell itself to the media company Skydance, another suitor emerged.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Ukraine Lowers the Draft Age
abstract: Also, dozens remain trapped after the earthquake in Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a law lowering the draft age from 27 to 25 and eliminated some medical exemptions in an effort to replenish Ukraine’s exhausted  army. He also created an electronic database of men, starting at age 17, to crack down on draft dodgers.

headline: Judge Won’t Delay Trump’s Criminal Trial to Wait for Immunity Ruling
abstract: The former president had asked the judge to push back his Manhattan criminal trial, slated to begin April 15, until after the Supreme Court decides whether he is immune from prosecution.
lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal case in Manhattan rejected his last-ditch bid to delay a trial beyond April 15, removing on Wednesday one of the final obstacles to the first prosecution of a former American president.

headline: An Ozempic Relative Slowed Parkinson’s Disease in a Small Study
abstract: The trial lasted only one year but offered embers of hope to some experts.
lead_paragraph: In 1817, James Parkinson expressed a hope about the disease that is named after him. He thought that at some point there would be a discovery and “the progress of the disease may be stopped.”

headline: ‘Stop It Now’: Jill Biden Privately Urges an End to Conflict in Gaza
abstract: The president recounted the first lady’s concerns as he was pressed about the war at a meeting with Muslim community members.
lead_paragraph: One of the strongest voices inside the White House urging an end to civilian casualties in Gaza is the person closest to the president: Jill Biden.

headline: Can Oats Really Help You Lose Weight?
abstract: A viral TikTok trend touts “Oatzempic” as a weight-loss hack. We asked the experts if there’s anything to it.
lead_paragraph: On TikTok, a woman blends a half cup of rolled oats with a cup of water and the juice of half a lime. She forces a smile and then hesitantly takes a sip. “That,” she says with a colorful flourish, “is nasty.”

headline: How Biden’s White House Gathering for Ramadan Unraveled Over Gaza
abstract: Some Muslim community leaders said it would be wrong to attend an iftar meal with President Biden while Gaza is under siege.
lead_paragraph: When the White House invited Muslim community leaders for a dinner this week celebrating the holy month of Ramadan, the responses started coming in fast: Decline. Decline. Decline.

headline: Food Aid for Gazans Was Sent Back to Cyprus
abstract: Also, Ukraine lowered its draft age. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: World Central Kitchen, the charity group that paused its operations in Gaza this week after seven of its workers were killed in an Israeli strike, sent three ships with hundreds of tons of food meant for Gazans back to port in Cyprus. It was the most tangible sign yet that the attack, which Israel called a mistake, has set back efforts to address severe hunger that experts say is approaching famine.

headline: Biden Is ‘Outraged.’ But Is He Willing to Use America’s Leverage With Israel?
abstract: President Biden, at least in public, has limited his responses to Israel’s war in Gaza to ever more indignant declarations.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden said he was “outraged and heartbroken” about the killing of seven World Central Kitchen aid workers in Gaza, his forceful language raised a natural question: Would this strike, even if a tragic error, lead him to put conditions on the weapons he sends to Israel?

headline: Abortion and the Florida Fakeout
abstract: Will the state sit the presidential election out, like a retiree watching pickleball?
lead_paragraph: It seemed, for a while there, that 2024 was going to be The Presidential Election Year Without Much Florida.

headline: U.S. and China Continue to Talk, but Economic Divide Remains Wide
abstract: Election-year rancor will make it difficult for Washington and Beijing to find areas of cooperation on trade and investment.
lead_paragraph: When Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen traveled to Beijing last summer, her mission was to re-establish a dialogue between the world’s largest economies and stabilize a relationship that appeared to have reached rock bottom.

headline: Has the FAFSA Delay Changed Your Decisions Around College?
abstract: We want to hear from readers about how they’re choosing their schools while waiting for financial aid packages.
lead_paragraph: Applying for financial aid was supposed to get easier with the new version of the Free Application for Federal Student Aid, which millions of families and thousands of schools rely on to determine how students will pay for college in America.

headline: Texas National Guard Member Charged With Migrant Smuggling
abstract: The arrest marked at least the second time in the last year that National Guard members in Texas had been caught trying to transport migrants from the border.
lead_paragraph: A silver sport utility vehicle, driving at speeds of more than 100 miles per hour, led the police on a 15-mile chase over the weekend near the U.S. border with Mexico in an area that has long been popular with migrant smugglers.

headline: The Necessary Discomfort of Jerrod Carmichael’s ‘Reality’
abstract: Jerrod Carmichael’s stock in trade is the exploitation of the awkward.
lead_paragraph: The comedian Jerrod Carmichael spends a remarkable amount of time in his new HBO series, “Jerrod Carmichael Reality Show,” with his head in his hands like Henri Vidal’s 19th-century statue of Cain after he has killed his brother Abel.

headline: Canadian Politicians Were Targeted by China in 2021, Report Says
abstract: Lawmakers testified at a public hearing on foreign interference that they had been caught in China’s cross hairs after criticizing it over human rights.
lead_paragraph: A top-secret intelligence report drafted a week before Canada’s 2021 general election warned about ongoing attempts by the Chinese government to meddle in specific races, saying that Beijing had “identified Canadian politicians considered” to be opponents of China.

headline: NASA Picks 3 Companies to Help Astronauts Drive Around the Moon
abstract: The agency’s future moon buggies will reach speeds of 9.3 miles per hour and will be capable of self-driving.
lead_paragraph: NASA will be renting some cool wheels to drive around the moon.

headline: Lawmaker Is Left With ‘Lifetime Trauma’ as Attacker Pleads Guilty
abstract: Andrey Desmond pleaded guilty to three felony charges this week in the attack on Maryam Khan, a member of the Connecticut House of Representatives, last June.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly 10 months since a man attacked Maryam Khan, the first Muslim elected to the Connecticut House of Representatives, outside an Eid al-Adha prayer service in Hartford, Conn. She is still struggling to heal, she said.

headline: Hospital at Center of Alabama Embryo Ruling Is Ending I.V.F. Services
abstract: The hospital cited a “lack of clarity” in recent state legislation meant to shield I.V.F. providers as a factor in its decision. A separate fertility clinic at the site said it would relocate.
lead_paragraph: A Mobile, Ala., hospital at the center of a State Supreme Court ruling that found that frozen embryos could be considered children said on Wednesday that it would no longer provide in vitro fertilization lab services after this year.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Often Ignores Parking-Permit Abuse, Report Says
abstract: Failing to ticket illegally parked cars with officially issued permits is “a form of corruption that erodes the public trust,” the Department of Investigation said.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department routinely fails to ticket illegally parked cars that have city-issued parking permits, especially near precinct houses, and residents’ complaints about permit abuse rarely result in summonses, according to a report issued on Wednesday.

headline: Trump Spoke Recently With Saudi Leader
abstract: It is not clear what the former president discussed with Prince Mohammed bin Salman, but news of their call came amid Biden administration negotiations with the Saudis over a Middle East peace plan.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump spoke recently with Saudi Arabia’s de facto ruler, Prince Mohammed bin Salman, their first publicly disclosed conversation since Mr. Trump left office in January 2021, according to two people briefed on the discussion who were not authorized to speak publicly about it.

headline: U.S. Charges 8 in Beer Heists That Targeted Trains and Warehouses
abstract: The men stole hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of beer, mostly Modelo and Corona, by robbing rail yards and warehouses across the Northeast, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Eight Bronx men were charged on Wednesday with stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars’ worth of beer, mostly Modelo and Corona imported from Mexico, by robbing train yards and warehouses in dozens of thefts across the Northeast over the past two years.

headline: Big Sur Urged to Evacuate as Another Storm Approaches
abstract: Officials are advising people to leave one of the nation’s most scenic coastal stretches before rain washes away more of Highway 1.
lead_paragraph: California officials temporarily shut down part of Highway 1 on Wednesday and warned residents to evacuate one of the nation’s most scenic coastal stretches as an incoming bout of spring rain threatened to worsen a road collapse near Big Sur.

headline: Coastal Retreat
abstract: Kevin Curry makes a delicious solo crossword debut in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: April 4, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, April 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a new project to create a pedestrian-friendly, archaeological area in downtown Rome referred incorrectly to the city’s age. It is approaching its fourth millennium, not its third.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Spotting a Bug That May Have Been Meant to Cripple the Internet
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, April 4, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I find it very odd. I’m a fairly private person who just sits in front of the computer and hacks on code.”

headline: Back-to-Back Israeli Strikes Show Tragic Gaps in Choosing Targets
abstract: In an airstrike on Monday in Damascus, Israel’s military displayed pinpoint precision. Hours later in Gaza, that same military killed seven aid workers.
lead_paragraph: About 5 p.m. on Monday, Israeli warplanes streaked across the Syrian border, striking an embassy building in Damascus and killing a cadre of senior Iranian military commanders with the kind of pinpoint accuracy that has earned Israel’s military fear and respect across the Middle East.

headline: She Slept With a Violin on Her Pillow. Her Dreams Came True in Italy.
abstract: As a teenager in South Korea, Ayoung An decided to become a violin maker. Her journey eventually took her to Cremona, Italy, a famed hub for masters like Antonio Stradivari.
lead_paragraph: When Ayoung An was 8, her parents bought her a violin. She slept with the instrument on the pillow next to her every night.

headline: Global Forest Loss Remains High, Despite Recent Progress
abstract: Wildfires and agricultural expansion offset big gains in protecting tropical forests last year.
lead_paragraph: Despite major progress in protecting vast tracts of rainforest, the world failed again last year to significantly slow the pace of global forest destruction, according to a report issued on Thursday. Record wildfires in Canada and expanding agriculture elsewhere offset big gains in forest protection in Brazil and Colombia, the report found.

headline: As Doctors’ Walkout Drags On, Some South Koreans Are Losing Patience
abstract: Thousands of interns and residents who stopped working in February are testing the public’s high regard for physicians. But there is also anger at the government.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks after thousands of residents and interns at South Korean hospitals walked off the job, frustration is rising.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Ukraine expands its draft.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a law lowering Ukraine’s draft age from 27 to 25, an attempt to replenish the ranks of a battered army that could create a political backlash. He also signed laws to eliminate some medical exemptions and create a database to crack down on draft dodgers.

headline: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in April
abstract: Will Heinrich covers Beau Dick’s alluring masks, Al Freeman’s jokey book and album covers and Meghan Brady’s radiant new paintings from Maine.
lead_paragraph: This week in Newly Reviewed, Will Heinrich covers Beau Dick’s alluring masks, Al Freeman’s jokey book and album covers and Meghan Brady’s radiant new paintings from Maine.

headline: Late Night Rebuts Trump’s Call for ‘Christian Visibility Day’
abstract: “This is America, buddy. Every day is ‘Christian Visibility Day,’” Desi Lydic said on Wednesday’s “Daily Show.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

abstract: This word has appeared in 61 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Name-Calling and Calling the Police: How N.Y.C. Parent Meetings Got Mean
abstract: In school districts across the city, families are fighting over transgender athletes and how race and discrimination are taught in the classroom.
lead_paragraph: New York City has never been immune to heated education fights, but in recent months those fights have taken on a new level of vitriol and aggression, and expanded to focus on a broader menu of divisive issues.

abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.

abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: On the Hunt, a Real Estate Reporter Strikes Gold
abstract: A man’s bizarre scheme to take over a hotel had the makings of an only-in-New-York story.
lead_paragraph: I first heard of Mickey Barreto a few hours after he was arrested early on Valentine’s Day this year. He had been arraigned in a Manhattan court in what prosecutors said was a blatant, persistent scheme to take ownership of the once-grand New Yorker Hotel in Midtown. Mr. Barreto’s bizarre takeover bid was based on a one-night stay he booked more than five years ago.

headline: Why Adams’s Campaign Strategy Involves Burger King and Baptisms at Rikers
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams keeps finding eye-catching ways to seize the spotlight on the issue of public safety, even when the narrative turns against him.
lead_paragraph: It was the day after a New York City police officer had been fatally shot in the line of duty and a man killed after being shoved onto the subway tracks, and Mayor Eric Adams had reached the end of a somber hourlong news conference.

headline: Trump’s Trial Lawyer Gambled a Gilded Manhattan Career to Represent Him
abstract: Todd Blanche was a prosecutor and worked for a prestigious firm. Now, he is the principal lawyer for Donald Trump as he becomes the first former president to face prosecution.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Trump’s Bond Benefactor Earned Billions From Subprime Car Loans
abstract: Don Hankey said his decision to help Mr. Trump post a $175 million bond was a business decision, though he voted for him in 2016.
lead_paragraph: The California billionaire Don Hankey made his fortune by offering high-interest auto loans to buyers with bad credit. This week, he signed up a new client in need of urgent help: Donald J. Trump.

headline: In a Box
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Has Your Relationship to School Attendance Changed Since the Pandemic?
abstract: School absences have exploded across the United States. What do you make of this trend?
lead_paragraph: Take a look at the graph above. It shows rates of chronic absence in the United States since 2016. What do you notice? What do you wonder? What story does it tell about the state of education today? What headline would you write to capture the graph’s main idea?

lead_paragraph: This essay, by Zoe Brown, 14, of Bend, Ore., is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s new “How To” Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers.

headline: U.S. Defense Secretary Denounces Israel’s Strike on Aid Workers in Gaza
abstract: A bristling phone call reflected a shift in Lloyd J. Austin III’s tone toward his Israeli counterpart as he stressed the need for better protection of aid workers.
lead_paragraph: In a tense phone call on Wednesday, Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III upbraided his Israeli counterpart, Yoav Gallant, over Israel’s deadly attack on a humanitarian food convoy in Gaza earlier this week.

headline: Biden and Netanyahu speak as a senior official says the president’s anger with Israel has hit a peak.
abstract: President Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday, three days after international aid workers were killed in an Israeli strike, as senior American officials said his frustration over Israel’s actions in Gaza was coming to a head.
lead_paragraph: President Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday, three days after international aid workers were killed in an Israeli strike, as senior American officials said his frustration over Israel’s actions in Gaza was coming to a head.

headline: Workers Stuck on Mountain After Taiwan Earthquake
abstract: Footage shows people trapped in a mountainous area after a 7.4-magnitude earthquake triggered a landslide.
lead_paragraph: Footage shows people trapped in a mountainous area after a 7.4-magnitude earthquake triggered a landslide.

abstract: A letter sent to the White House
lead_paragraph: A letter sent to the White House

abstract: A letter sent to the Trump campaign
lead_paragraph: A letter sent to the Trump campaign

headline: From One Leaning Tower to Another, Tips to Stop the Tilt
abstract: Bologna is looking to Pisa, home of the most famous leaning tower, for help keeping its own tipping tower upright.
lead_paragraph: Leaning for centuries at a worrisome tilt, the Garisenda Tower in Bologna has endured insults and trauma. Dickens called it “sufficiently unsightly,” if extraordinary, while Goethe said it was “a spectacle that disgusts.” And then there were the earthquakes, the Allied bombing raids of the city during World War II and urbanization that doomed other towers.

headline: How to Revive a Burned Forest? Rebuild the Tree Supply Chain
abstract: As forests succumb to ever-fiercer wildfires, the federal government and some adventurous private companies are trying to resuscitate an industry.
lead_paragraph: When it came to wildfires, 2021 was an increasingly common kind of year in Montana: Flames consumed 747,000 acres, an area nearly the size of Long Island.

headline: Video Game Reviews of 2024
abstract: New York Times critics have reviewed games including Final Fantasy VII Rebirth, Tales of Kenzera: Zau and Harold Halibut.
lead_paragraph: Playing every video game that is released would be an incredibly time-consuming project. To help you sort through the options (and maybe your backlog), here is an alphabetical list of the games that New York Times critics have written about in 2024.

headline: What Are We Told About the Health of Biden and Trump? They Decide.
abstract: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump are the oldest people ever to seek the presidency, challenging norms about what the public should know about candidates’ health.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, when Senator John McCain was the oldest person to seek a first term in the White House, his campaign set out to reassure the public about his health. It let reporters examine 1,173 pages of handwritten notes, lab results and insurance documents, including details of the senator’s biopsies, his prostate exams and even the “very light tan freckling” on his buttocks.

headline: Ada Limón Won’t Let Prose Touch the Poetry on Her Shelves
abstract: “I mean that as an organizing principle,” says the U.S. poet laureate, who has edited a new anthology of nature poetry called “You Are Here,” “and also as a slight against prose.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Anxiety, Bedtime and Mating: How Animals May React to the Eclipse
abstract: When the total solar eclipse happens on Monday, animals at homes, farms and zoos may act strangely. Researchers can’t wait to see what happens when day quickly turns to night.
lead_paragraph: While millions of people are preparing to watch the total solar eclipse that will make its way across North America on Monday, the animals in that affected area — in homes, on farms, in zoos and in the wild — missed the news that the moon will block the sun, briefly turning day into night.

headline: Do You Need a Home Watcher? Here’s What One Could Do for You.
abstract: Hiring a local to keep an eye on your weekend house can give you peace of mind and keep small problems from becoming big headaches.
lead_paragraph: Leslie Young has a message for new second-home owners: That house of yours isn’t going to look after itself.

headline: ‘Música’ Review: What He Hears Is What We Get
abstract: Rudy Mancuso stars in and directs an inventive debut feature about a man with synesthesia who tries to manage his complicated life and relationships.
lead_paragraph: The artist Rudy Mancuso has a prolific career that’s hard to define. He sings, shoots puppet skits and films wistful live action shorts set to his own piano tunes. Mancuso uploads most of his output online; however, he opened for Justin Bieber in Brazil, where he once lived. “Música,” Mancuso’s phenomenal feature debut, is a comic trip inside a mind that’s forever feverishly creating — even against his will. In the first scene, Rudy (Mancuso), his semi-autobiographical lead, gets dumped at a diner because his synesthesia won’t allow him to focus on a serious talk about the future. His brain can’t ignore a knife chopping, a broom sweeping, a spatula clanking. The percussion swells, the clatter harmonizes and his romance collapses, leaving Rudy alone in his bedroom with a lamp attached to — oh dear — a Clapper.

headline: In Zen Painting, It Takes Years of Practice to Do Almost Nothing
abstract: How do you make an artwork sing? Let your unconscious mind do it. That’s the message of an alluring show at the Japan Society.
lead_paragraph: Two longtime painters recently told me how joyful their studio practices had become in their 40s once they took their minds off their ambitions, stopped trying to impress anyone, and just let the paintings paint themselves. I’ve been dabbling with working that way myself, so I was thrilled to find the memorable demonstrations of unburdened artistic spontaneity that are scattered in “None Whatsoever: Zen Paintings from the Gitter-Yelen Collection” at the Japan Society.

headline: ‘The Old Oak’ Review: The Audacity of Hope
abstract: A family of Syrian refugees connects with a once-thriving mining town in Ken Loach’s moving drama.
lead_paragraph: “The Old Oak” is named for the pub where much of its action happens — an old drinking hole in a village outside of Durham, England, that’s seen better days. Its back room, once a gathering place for the miners and their families who populated the town a generation ago, has been locked up for many years, fallen to disuse. Its walls are still hung with photographs of those miners taken during the lengthy strike of 1984-1985, a labor effort that ended without the resolution the miners sought and with weakened trade unions. But during the action, the village marched in solidarity — at least for a while — and came together to share meals in that back room, to support one another, a point of pride for the men who were children back then.

headline: Are You a Second-Home Person?
abstract: A place outside the city might sound like heaven, but there are some things you should consider.
lead_paragraph: You understand the importance of being organized. You make lists to ensure that you don’t have two jars of turmeric in the city and none in the country (and vice versa). You listened very carefully and took appropriate action when a knowledgeable source told you it was necessary to book at least a month ahead for a table at a popular restaurant on Saturday night, and three months ahead for a Pilates class on Saturday morning, during high season.

headline: Help! Japan Airlines Downgraded Us From First Class and Skimped on the Refund.
abstract: A couple is bumped from ultraluxury to semi-luxury on a trans-Pacific flight and receives what they feel is only a pittance in compensation.
lead_paragraph: Last year, my husband and I splurged on round-trip first-class tickets on Japan Airlines from San Francisco to Tokyo for $13,474 each. We reserved them in February for an October flight through American Express Travel. On the same day, I also bought business class tickets for a couple who was traveling with us at $8,429 apiece. In September, Amex notified me that we had been downgraded to business class for the return flight. JAL’s conditions state that we would receive “the difference between the normal fare amount of original class of service and for the normal fare of lower class of service.” To me that means that since the difference between our first class seats and our friends’ business seats was $5,045 each, we should be refunded about half of that — around $2,522 per person — for the second leg. But we got only $941 each. I contested this with Amex Travel, but they rejected our claim. Can you help? Teri, San Francisco

headline: Corporate America: Employees Need Stability, Not Constant Change
abstract: Silicon Valley was all about disruption. Turns out, that’s not all workers need.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a brutal year for Silicon Valley, with dozens of mass layoffs and company reorganizations. Ashley Goodall, a former tech executive and the author of the forthcoming book, “The Problem with Change,” believes that this is a byproduct of C.E.O.s trying to please shareholders and that we have corporate success all wrong. In this audio essay, he argues that change and disruption are not always good and that if executives want better work environments, they should prioritize their employees.

headline: If You Give a Kid a Notebook, He’s Going to Ask for Time to Write
abstract: John Schu is a best-selling author, a children’s librarian and a tireless evangelist for the power of a blank page.
lead_paragraph: When John Schu was admitted to Linden Oaks Hospital in Naperville, Ill., as a teenager, the staff gave him a gray notebook and encouraged him to write in it every day. “I would write a lot in the beginning, but I refused to share anything,” Schu said in a phone interview. “I would do some of the assignments, but I would always say, ‘Nobody can read it.’”

headline: The Guantánamo Spy Who Wasn’t
abstract: Ahmad Al-Halabi was an immigrant who did the most American thing possible: join the military. Then the U.S. government accused him of espionage.
lead_paragraph: It was all a big mistake. Ahmad Al-Halabi was sure this had to be some sort of misunderstanding that he could clear up before his flight in a few hours.

headline: Making a Meal for a Date: When Is the Right Time?
abstract: Cooking for someone you’re seeing in the early stages of dating can be a great way to make a good impression. Or a clear sign that you’re hooked.
lead_paragraph: In a scene from the 1997 romantic comedy “Love Jones,” a young poet named Darius recounts to his friend over a game of pool how his first date went with Nina, a beautiful photographer he recently met. They ended up having sex that night, and the next morning, he got up and made breakfast.

headline: Amid Recalls, Are Eye Drops Safe to Use?
abstract: Here’s why some products have been pulled from store shelves, and what to know to protect your eyes.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of eye drops and ointments have been pulled from store shelves after a wave of recalls in 2023 and 2024, raising concerns about whether products used to relieve dry or irritated eyes are safe.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are on Central Park West, in the financial district and in Park Slope.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, 1,400-square-foot apartment with marble countertops, a dining nook, a large primary suite, 11-foot ceilings, ample closets, a washer/dryer and window-unit air-conditioning, on the 13th floor of a 23-story prewar doorman building with a live-in super, shared laundry and shared storage. Simona Stanica and Harry Triantis, Douglas Elliman, 917-623-8326; elliman.com

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Mill Neck, N.Y., and Haddonfield, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath house built in 1918, with an entry foyer, a formal living room with a wood-burning fireplace, an enclosed porch, a formal dining room, a den, an en suite primary bedroom with a balcony, a sauna and a laundry room in a partially finished basement, a heated swimming pool and a detached three-car garage, on 3.2 acres. Kim Bancroft, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 516-404-5053; danielgale.com

headline: Hopes for a Very Sunny, and Dark, Wedding
abstract: A number of couples are choosing to marry during the upcoming total solar eclipse. Several cities in the path of totality are holding mass weddings.
lead_paragraph: When Zach Horrall, a social media specialist at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, and Corlan McCollum, a children’s librarian, got engaged two years ago, they wanted to connect their wedding to a larger event. At first, they considered Halloween, but when they realized Indianapolis was in the path of totality for the April 8, 2024, solar eclipse, they changed course.

headline: Celebrating History With 200,000 Tulips
abstract: Tulip Day is coming, as part of an initiative by the Netherlands Consulate General and other groups to mark the 400th anniversary of Dutch settlers’ arrival in what is now New York.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at why truckloads of tulips are coming to Union Square this weekend.

headline: Where to Drink Wine in Chicago
abstract: Great wine lists abound in this fascinating city. Here are eight places with distinctive lists that stand out.
lead_paragraph: The motto of Chicago ought to be, “Too much to do, not enough time.”

headline: Welcoming Underexposed Black Photographers Into the Canon
abstract: The Vision & Justice publishing initiative hopes to build a richer, more racially inclusive history of photography.
lead_paragraph: Elegant in a burnt-orange linen dress and wearing necklaces of her own design, Coreen Simpson, 82, said that because she was raised in foster homes, “I have always felt like an outsider — which is a good thing for a photographer.” But as a Black artist of an older generation, she was made to feel like an outsider in other ways, too. “I’ve wanted my own book for a long time,” she said, during an interview in her Brooklyn apartment. “I just wanted a serious book on my work, because I think I deserve it, to tell you the truth.” Thanks to the Vision & Justice project, that deficit is about to be corrected.

headline: A.I. Is Spying on the Food We Throw Away
abstract: Artificial intelligence is peering into restaurant garbage pails and crunching grocery-store data to try to figure out how to send less uneaten food into dumpsters.
lead_paragraph: A hotel chain installs a camera in its trash bins to spy on what guests are tossing. Turns out its breakfast croissants are too big. Many are going to waste — along with profits.

headline: They Want to Become Nuns and Priests. Student Debt Holds Them Back.
abstract: For young adults who want to join certain religious orders, paying off debt before taking a vow of poverty can prove challenging. But their communities are willing to help.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until after college that Kendra Baker began to consider becoming a nun. She had been raised a Roman Catholic, and after her father fell from the roof of their home, suffering life-threatening injuries, her family called a priest to come and pray with them. A few hours later, her father opened his eyes.

headline: Terrified Parents, New Age Health Nuts, MAGA Exiles. Meet the R.F.K. Jr. Faithful.
