abstract: Trump voters are picking up on his mix of New Age individualism, paranoia and intense nostalgia for the America of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Chris Inclan, an alcohol and drug counselor from Sonoma, Calif., voted for the Green Party candidate Jill Stein in 2016. In 2020 he backed Andrew Yang in the Democratic primary and cast a ballot for Donald Trump in the general election. Joe Biden, he said, was “so ingrained in the establishment and politics as usual,” while Trump “went against the grain on a lot of issues,” including wars and government regulation. But Inclan, a big bearded 39-year-old with tattoos on his hands, doesn’t want to have to make that choice again, which is why he’s now enthusiastically supporting Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Wants You to Listen to Older Women
abstract: The actress reflects on Season 2 of “Wiser Than Me.”
lead_paragraph: Our Well columnist, Jancee Dunn, talks with the actress Julia Louis-Dreyfus about her podcast “Wiser Than Me,” which just started its second season. Louis-Dreyfus discusses why putting older women in the spotlight is powerful, how the show has affected her own thoughts about aging, and how being comfortable in your own skin makes for some refreshing real talk.

headline: Biden Is Winning the Money Race. Does It Matter?
abstract: Inside the very expensive business of running for president.
lead_paragraph: Last week, President Biden, flanked by former Presidents Barack Obama and Bill Clinton, came to Radio City Music Hall for what Mr. Biden’s campaign called “the most successful political fund-raiser in American history.” The three Democratic presidents, alongside celebrities like Stephen Colbert, Mindy Kaling, Lizzo and Queen Latifah, spoke to an audience of 5,000 donors. According to the Biden campaign, the event brought in more than $25 million.

headline: A Reversal Cannot Undo the Damage Caused by This Voting Fraud Case
abstract: What happened to Crystal Mason in Texas could have broader consequences in chilling people’s willingness to exercise their right to vote.
lead_paragraph: When a Texas appeals court reversed itself last week and acquitted Crystal Mason, a mother of three, in a voting fraud case, it ended almost a decade in which Ms. Mason lived in fear of being torn away from her family and imprisoned.

headline: ‘Ripley’ Review: The Con Man Gets the Art House Treatment
abstract: Andrew Scott stars in a Netflix series that looks like what you might get if Antonioni or Resnais had directed a season of “The White Lotus.”
lead_paragraph: Patricia Highsmith’s 1955 novel “The Talented Mr. Ripley” sets its dark action in a succession of colorful Italian locales: the Amalfi coast, San Remo, Rome, Palermo, Venice. Movies based on the book, like René Clément’s “Plein Soleil” (released in the United States as “Purple Noon”) and Anthony Minghella’s “The Talented Mr. Ripley,” have taken the opportunity Highsmith gave them to capitalize on sun and scenery. The audience gets its brutal murders and brazen deceit wrapped in bright visual pleasure.

headline: 36 Hours in San Juan, Puerto Rico
abstract: Bar-hop in an old quarter, explore a street splashed with murals and fly kites on the lawn of a fortress in this Caribbean capital.
lead_paragraph: Bar-hop in an old quarter, explore a street splashed with murals and fly kites on the lawn of a fortress in this Caribbean capital.

headline: The Buzz on Boat Shoes
abstract: The category of footwear created when Franklin D. Roosevelt was president is being reinterpreted and rediscovered.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes fashion just seems like “Groundhog Day” with better outfits. Designers vanish only to reappear suddenly (looking at you, Alessandro Michele). Trends sputter out and abruptly are back. Skinny jeans were cool until everyone was wearing oversize drop-crotch khakis — everyone, that is, except that cadre of teen style-setters intent on bringing back 2000s-era jeggings so bad they’re good.

headline: Panama’s 2024 Election: What to Know
abstract: Political crisis has embroiled Panama’s May 5 presidential election, exacerbating uncertainty in a country dealing with drought and fallout from widespread protests.
lead_paragraph: Political crisis has embroiled Panama’s May 5 presidential election, exacerbating uncertainty in a country dealing with drought and fallout from widespread protests.

headline: Wes Moore’s Big Experiment for Maryland
abstract: Gov. Wes Moore’s public service jobs programs are lifelines to the future.
lead_paragraph: Taking a gap year, or devoting a year to public service, whether to develop yourself or to serve a higher purpose, can be very alluring and, just as often, very impractical: How do you find the right opportunity, or fit it into your life, and most of all, swing it financially?

headline: Beyoncé Asks, and Answers, a Crucial Question in Her Latest Album
abstract: Beyoncé singing country music in this political climate was always going to cause a stir.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé released a genre-bending country album, “Cowboy Carter,” last week. After listening to it in all the requisite settings — on a walk, in a car and on a plane — I finally understand what Beyoncé, a notoriously enigmatic pop star, wants to say to the world. She wants to be more than popular. She wants to be legendary. But first, she isn’t through taking everyone who has doubted her to the woodshed.

headline: A Manhattan Pied-à-Terre for Less Than $800,000? Two Virginia Farmers Gave It a Shot.
abstract: With life on the farm losing its appeal, a couple sought a small second home in the heart of New York’s cultural scene.
lead_paragraph: With life on the farm losing its appeal, a couple sought a small second home in the heart of New York’s cultural scene.

headline: Welcome to Raleigh, the New Epicenter of College Basketball
abstract: Students at Duke and U.N.C., both basketball powerhouses, have long labeled North Carolina State their “little brother.” But little brother — and sister — are off to the Final Four.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Sammy’s Tap & Grill, a sports bar for fans of North Carolina State University, had a glaring problem: The school’s basketball teams did not win all that much. David Harris, one of the owners, would concoct creative specials in hopes of drawing customers on game days, but it didn’t matter. Few ever came.

headline: Our Reporter on Voters’ Age Concerns
abstract: President Biden and his predecessor, Donald Trump, are the oldest people ever to run for president, and many voters believe that both men are too old to serve. Michael D. Shear, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, says that the lack of medical information about each candidate makes it hard for voters to make their assessments.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his predecessor, Donald Trump, are the oldest people ever to run for president, and many voters believe that both men are too old to serve. Michael D. Shear, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, says that the lack of medical information about each candidate makes it hard for voters to make their assessments.

headline: Environmental Protection Agency Gives $20 Billion in ‘Green Bank’ Grants
abstract: The E.P.A. said the fund will spur a clean energy transition in overlooked communities. Republicans called it a “greendoggle.”
lead_paragraph: When Marcus Jones and his business partner, Akunna Olumba, set out to open a pizzeria in Detroit, they spoke with banks about their green vision: solar panels on the roof, an energy-efficient tankless water heater and a rooftop system to capture storm water.

headline: Here’s How Congress Can Use Leverage on Weapons Sales to Prod Biden on Israel
abstract: Congress has oversight over American weapons sales to allies. Some Democrats say lawmakers should try to delay or even block them until Israel agrees to conditions on its offensive in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Democrats in Congress, increasingly concerned about how Israel is waging war in Gaza, are weighing whether to use their leverage over weapons sales to register objections to the civilian death toll and ratchet up pressure on President Biden to place conditions on American backing for the military offensive.

headline: In Moscow Attack, a Handful of Suspects but a Million Tajiks Under Suspicion
abstract: The main suspects in a deadly assault near Moscow were from Tajikistan. Now many other Tajiks, who fill jobs in Russia’s wartime economy, are being deported and harassed.
lead_paragraph: Muhammad said he had found a better life in Russia. After emigrating from Tajikistan last fall, he began driving delivery vans in Siberia, enrolled his children in a local school, applied for a Russian passport and started planning to buy an apartment with the savings from his much higher salary.

headline: Israel’s Deadly Airstrike on the World Central Kitchen
abstract: The story behind the pioneering aid group and how it mistakenly came under attack.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli airstrike that killed seven workers delivering food in Gaza has touched off global outrage and condemnation.

headline: What Biden’s Anger Could Mean for Israel, and a Look at the Drama at Disney
abstract: Plus, aftershocks rattle Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Lawyers Call on U.K. Government to End Arms Sales to Israel
abstract: The government is coming under more pressure to suspend arms sales to Israel after the strike on a convoy in Gaza that killed seven aid workers, including three Britons.
lead_paragraph: The British government is coming under escalating pressure to suspend arms sales to Israel after the strike on a convoy in Gaza that killed seven aid workers, including three Britons. More than 600 lawyers and retired judges sent a letter to the government, arguing that the sales violated international law.

headline: World Central Kitchen Demands an Independent Investigation Into Israeli Strike
abstract: The Israeli military, which has accepted responsibility for the strike, has started looking into the killings of seven aid workers. But the disaster relief organization said that was not enough.
lead_paragraph: World Central Kitchen on Thursday called for an independent investigation into the killing by Israeli forces of seven of its staff members this week as they worked to deliver aid in Gaza.

headline: Iran’s Axis of Resistance
abstract: We examine what could push Iran and Israel toward a confrontation.
lead_paragraph: Its members refer to it as the Axis of Resistance.

headline: The Hottest Luxury Second-Home Markets
abstract: Sales of luxury second homes increased in many U.S. markets last year. If you want to see some of the priciest, head to Rhode Island.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard enough buying a first home these days. Who on Earth is out there buying a second one? The wealthy, mostly: In 2023, sales of luxury second homes increased in many U.S. markets.

headline: ‘The Beast’ Review: Master of Puppets
abstract: Bertrand Bonello’s latest film, starring Léa Seydoux and George MacKay as lovers in three different eras, is an audacious sci-fi romance.
lead_paragraph: Bertrand Bonello’s “The Beast” is an audacious interdimensional romance, techno-thriller and Los Angeles noir rolled up in one. This shamelessly ambitious epic is about, among other things, civilizational collapse and existential retribution, yet it is held together by something delicate.

headline: ‘Chicken for Linda!’ Review: A Comedy That Cooks
abstract: In this madcap film, a mother’s apology leads to a delightful misadventure that begins with mourning and ends with a father’s favorite recipe.
lead_paragraph: In the animated French feature “Chicken for Linda!,” directed by Chiara Malta and Sébastien Laudenbach, a mother accuses her young daughter of stealing a ring of great and mournful value. When the mother, Paulette (voiced by Clotilde Hesme), discovers her error, she promises to do whatever Linda (Mélinée Leclerc) wishes by way of apology. Linda was an infant when her father died, so she asks her culinarily challenged mother to cook her father’s go-to dish: chicken and peppers.

headline: ‘The First Omen’ Review: The Days Before Damien
abstract: A prequel to the original franchise, this debut feature from Arkasha Stevenson is a thrilling mash-up of horror tropes that gives the story new life.
lead_paragraph: If the “Omen” franchise left us with memorable tropes — the boy Antichrist, lurking among us; those dreaded three repeated numbers — the content of the movies themselves did little else. The original horror trilogy, kicked off by “The Omen” in 1976, never had the sticking power of other classics in popular consciousness, and a 2006 revamp came and went. What could another attempt, this time a prequel to a middling franchise, really offer?

headline: ‘Girls State’ Review: One Nation, Under Girls
abstract: Balancing confidence with broad smiles, the high school students in this documentary understand that camaraderie goes hand in hand with political ambition.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, over 1,000 boys gathered in Texas for an elaborate, weeklong program aimed at students interested in politics. This meeting of teenage minds — part of a countrywide initiative sponsored by the American Legion — was captured in the Sundance hit “Boys State,” a vérité chronicle of the event, where participants are elected by their peers to different positions in government.

headline: ‘Housekeeping for Beginners’ Review: Daddy Nearest
abstract: Sad news forces a diverse group of friends to take unorthodox action in this volatile, affecting drama.
lead_paragraph: For his third feature, “Housekeeping for Beginners,” the writer and director Goran Stolevski returns to his birthplace, North Macedonia, to capture the tumbling energy and volatile emotions of a household in crisis.

headline: ‘Kim’s Video’ Review: Following the Tapes to Italy
abstract: This documentary details how the coolest video collection in downtown New York ended up in a small Italian town.
lead_paragraph: Longtime New Yorkers of bohemian bent may be intrigued by the prospect of a documentary about Kim’s Video, the downtown rental outlet, retailer and shambolic hangout that shut its doors, as video stores tended to do, in 2014. Its title notwithstanding, “Kim’s Video,” co-directed by David Redmon and Ashley Sabin and narrated by Redmon, is less a retail history than a shaggy dog story. One that actually appears to be true. Go in knowing that and you might get a kick out of it.

headline: ‘The People’s Joker’ Review: A Wild Card
abstract: Pure chaos is at play in a scrappy and unauthorized new parody about a character who looks a lot like the Joker. It’s a daring slice of queer cinema.
lead_paragraph: The director Vera Drew got in hot water making this DC Comics-inspired origin story about a transgender simulacrum of the Joker, Batman’s frozen-smile nemesis. A disclaimer that now starts the film calls it an unauthorized parody, and any trademark infringement “was not done intentionally.”

headline: ‘Scoop’ Review: The Story Behind That Prince Andrew Interview
abstract: In 2019, the prince went on air to respond to accusations involving Jeffery Epstein. The drama here is in how the BBC convinced him to do it.
lead_paragraph: The exposés that brought public attention to Watergate, the predations of Harvey Weinstein and the abuse tolerated by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston have all been the subjects of movies. The drama revolved, in part, around the difficulty of getting people to talk.

headline: ‘Yannick’ Review: First Act Problems
abstract: Audience members revolting against bad art isn’t a new thing, but Quentin Dupieux puts a fresh twist on that theme in his surreal new comedy.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, you might think that with around a dozen movies to his credit, Quentin Dupieux is finally settling down. The French director’s latest takes place entirely inside a Parisian theater, during a play — we are far from superheroes with a giant rat for a boss (“Smoking Causes Coughing”), time-travel passages (“Incredible But True”) and serial-killing tires (“Rubber”).

headline: What to Know About ‘Scoop’ and Prince Andrew’s Explosive TV Interview
abstract: A new Netflix film dramatizes the 2019 BBC conversation that led to the royal stepping back from public life.
lead_paragraph: When Prince Andrew, Queen Elizabeth II’s second son, agreed to be interviewed on the BBC in November 2019, he likely didn’t expect it would one day inspire a feature film. But “Scoop,” which comes to Netflix on Friday, follows a TV musical and a documentary in depicting the 58-minute interview and its fallout. (Amazon is also producing an upcoming limited series.)

headline: The Takeaways From Disney’s Board Fight with Nelson Peltz
abstract: New voting rules made for sharper attacks, while a bold defense kept the activist investor at bay. But pressure remains on the company’s chief, Bob Iger.
lead_paragraph: It’s over. Disney fended off the activist investor Nelson Peltz for the second time in two years, as its shareholders rejected his effort to win two seats on its board.

headline: A.L.S. Drug Relyvrio Will Be Taken Off the Market, Its Maker Says
abstract: Results of a large clinical trial found the treatment did not work any better than a placebo.
lead_paragraph: The maker of the newest treatment approved for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis said Thursday that it would withdraw the drug from the market because a large clinical trial did not produce evidence that the treatment worked.

headline: Why Taiwan Was So Prepared for a Powerful Earthquake
abstract: Decades of learning from disasters, tightening building codes and increasing public awareness may have helped its people better weather strong quakes.
lead_paragraph: When the largest earthquake in Taiwan in half a century struck off its east coast, the buildings in the closest city, Hualien, swayed and rocked. As more than 300 aftershocks rocked the island over the next 24 hours to Thursday morning, the buildings shook again and again.

headline: Nebraska Lawmakers Block Trump-Backed Changes to Electoral System
abstract: The state awards an electoral vote to the winner of each congressional district. Former President Donald J. Trump and allies want a “winner take all” system, which may have another chance to pass.
lead_paragraph: Nebraska legislators on Wednesday night overwhelmingly declined to change how the state awards its Electoral College votes to a winner-take-all system.

headline: Shohei Ohtani’s Arrival Reflects Diversity of Dodgers Fans, and Los Angeles
abstract: Around Camelback Ranch, the Dodgers’ spring training home in Phoenix, fans of all backgrounds were wearing Ohtani jerseys and many spoke Japanese and Spanish.
lead_paragraph: The fans had been gathering for more than an hour while the Arizona sunshine grew brighter by the minute. Parents nudged their children toward the front of the scrum, baseballs in hand, Sharpie pens at the ready for autographs.

headline: Reworked Italian Jerseys That Celebrate Soccer Style
abstract: Plus: a Nancy Brooks Brody exhibition, a Nile sailboat charter and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: I’m a big double cleanser, sometimes even a triple cleanser. Step one is usually Biologique Recherche Eau Micellaire Biosensible, followed by Lait Dermo-S. At night, I’ll use Vintner’s Daughter Active Renewal Cleanser with cold water. I’m a big fan of Clean Skin Club towels in XL. I’m prone to acne and hyperpigmentation, and those towels really changed my skin. I use Tower 28’s SOS Rescue Spray to prevent transdermal water loss. Then I do three big droppers of Dr. Barbara Sturm’s Hyaluronic Serum, followed by Paula’s Choice Discoloration Repair Serum and Biologique Recherche Crème Dermopurifiante. I use Supergoop’s Unseen Sunscreen to lock everything in. Every evening, I cleanse and do my Dr. Dennis Gross Spectralite FaceWare Pro LED mask. I use my hyaluronic serum and, after a few minutes, apply a Tretinoin Cream USP 0.1% — my skin responds well to the constant turnover. I’ll follow with my Biologique Recherche Crème Dermopurifiante and Prequel’s Skin Utility Ointment as an occlusive layer. As needed, I use Cosmelan 2 Maintenance Cream for a spot treatment and Biologique Recherche Masque Visolastine+ as a hydrating mask. SK-II Treatment Masks are just good to have in the fridge. I’m a devotee at the temple of Vanessa Lee from the med spa the Things We Do. I did a Cosmelan peel last winter and it took away 80 to 90 percent of my hyperpigmentation. I also love the High Frequency Wand; when I have little breakouts, I’ll use that to help.

headline: Trump Venues Bank on Golf, With Help From Saudi Arabia
abstract: The focus of the former president’s hotel business is shifting from big cities to his golf resorts, which are benefiting from a relationship with the Saudi-funded LIV Golf tournaments.
lead_paragraph: Amateur golfers lined up on Thursday at the Trump National Doral near Miami, having agreed to pay more than $9,000 apiece to play a friendly round alongside some of the world’s top professionals.

headline: For Sale: One Huge Drawing, Maybe by Michelangelo
abstract: Former owners of the Renaissance artist’s villa want to sell a sketch once on a kitchen wall. But scholars are divided over whether Michelangelo actually drew it.
lead_paragraph: For half a century, the Sernesi family lived in a storied villa overlooking Florence where the Renaissance artist Michelangelo was raised and which he later owned. The property came with several buildings, an orchard and a drawing of a muscular male nude etched on the wall of a former kitchen. Tradition has it that the work was drawn by a young Michelangelo, though scholars are not as sure.

headline: ‘Alarming’ Ocean Temperatures Suggest This Hurricane Season Will Be a Daunting One
abstract: An early forecast from one set of experts sees an above-average hurricane season that may rival the busiest years on record.
lead_paragraph: A key area of the Atlantic Ocean where hurricanes form is already abnormally warm, much warmer than an ideal swimming pool temperature of about 80 degrees and on the cusp of feeling more like warm bathtub water.

headline: Biden Takes Aim at SpaceX’s Tax-Free Ride in American Airspace
abstract: President Biden wants companies that use American airspace for rocket launches to start paying taxes into a federal fund that finances the work of air traffic controllers.
lead_paragraph: Every time a rocket soars into the sky carrying satellites or supplies for the International Space Station, air traffic controllers on the ground must take crucial steps to ensure that commercial and passenger aircraft remain safe.

headline: Plan to Stash Pollution Beneath the Sea Could Save Money and Jobs
abstract: The Italian energy giant Eni sees future profits from collecting carbon dioxide and pumping it into natural gas fields that have been exhausted.
lead_paragraph: Renowned for ancient churches and the tomb of Dante, the 14th-century poet, the city of Ravenna and its environs along Italy’s Adriatic coast are also home to old-line industries like steel and fertilizer. The manufacturing plants are of little interest to the many tourists who help sustain the area’s economy, but these sites employ tens of thousands of people.

headline: Al Franken’s Memories of Christopher Durang
abstract: The comedian and former senator writes about the late playwright.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tell Us Your Stories About Retirement
abstract: If you’ve reinvented your life after retiring from a career, we want to hear how it’s going and any advice you have for others.
lead_paragraph: Have you retired? Or at least left your full-time, traditional job and embarked on a new chapter? For a special section on retirement and longevity to be published in June, The New York Times wants to hear from readers who have reinvented their lives after jobs or careers.

headline: Approaching Weeknight Burnout? The Solution Is Pasta.
abstract: Specifically, midnight pasta with garlic, anchovy, capers and red pepper from David Tanis.
lead_paragraph: This is the time of year when kitchen burnout really sets in. You battled the holidays — and won! — then realized there was still cooking to be done. Every. Single. Day. You’ve braised and stewed, indoors, for months now, fantasizing about when the season turns and “cooking” becomes a matter of slicing and salting fragrant tomatoes, ripe melons and juicy stone fruit.

headline: A Tantalizing ‘Hint’ That Astronomers Got Dark Energy All Wrong
abstract: Scientists may have discovered a major flaw in their understanding of that mysterious cosmic force. That could be good news for the fate of the universe.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, astronomers who are conducting what they describe as the biggest and most precise survey yet of the history of the universe announced that they might have discovered a major flaw in their understanding of dark energy, the mysterious force that is speeding up the expansion of the cosmos.

headline: Judge Orders Timely Housing for Migrant Children Waiting at Border
abstract: The decision established that minors at open-air sites were in legal custody of the Department of Homeland Security and thus must receive safe shelter, even if they had not yet been formally processed.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is required to “expeditiously” house migrant children who cross into the United States unlawfully, rather than allow them to remain in unsafe open-air sites along the border, a Federal District Court judge ruled Wednesday night.

headline: TikTok Turns to Nuns, Veterans and Ranchers in Marketing Blitz
abstract: The video app is spending millions on ads as Congress considers a bill that could lead to a U.S. ban.
lead_paragraph: In a TV commercial, Sister Monica Clare, a nun in northern New Jersey, walks through a church that’s bathed in sunlight and sits in a pew, crossing herself. Her message: TikTok is a force for good.

headline: ‘Música’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The director and composer Rudy Mancuso narrates a one-shot sequence from his film, in which he also stars.
lead_paragraph: The director and composer Rudy Mancuso narrates a one-shot sequence from his film, in which he also stars.

headline: Watch an Elaborate One-Shot Montage in ‘Música’
abstract: Rudy Mancuso, the film’s director, composer, co-writer and star, narrates this sequence, which plays out in real time with movable sets.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Welcome to Venice. That’ll Be 5 Euros.
abstract: Starting this month, tourists intending to visit the city on busy dates will be required to register on a website, and those coming for a single day will have to pay an entry fee.
lead_paragraph: On its busiest days, Venice swells with tourists who clog the city’s narrow streets, leave behind piles of garbage and often frustrate locals. So the canal-crossed city is fighting back.

headline: Gaetano Pesce, Designer Who Broke the Rules, Is Dead at 84
abstract: He brought surrealism, and politics, into the design world, disdaining conformity and right angles. “He was an enemy of the grid.”

headline: Ford Slows Its Push Into Electric Vehicles
abstract: The automaker said it would delay new battery-powered models and shift its focus to hybrid cars, sales of which are rising fast.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor on Thursday delayed the production of at least two new electric cars and said it would pivot to making more hybrids. Its decision was the latest sign that large automakers have been forced to rethink their strategy for electric vehicles because sales for those models are slowing.

headline: When the Rubin Museum Was Divine
abstract: The Rubin will be “reimagined” as a global museum, but our critic says its charismatic presence will be only a troubling memory.
lead_paragraph: A brick-and-mortar presence can be, often is, a crucial part of an art museum’s allure. The Guggenheim’s mother ship interior is such a thrill that it prepares you to love whatever’s on view. The interiors of the Frick and the Morgan are intimate enough to make you feel proprietarily, and fabulously, at home.

headline: Do You Have Experience With Gun Violence? Tell Us About It.
abstract: Headway wants to hear from people affected by gun violence and those working to end it.
lead_paragraph: As of the beginning of the month, there had been 95 mass shootings in the United States in 2024, according to the Gun Violence Archive, or roughly a mass shooting every day of the year.

headline: John Sinclair, 82, Dies; Counterculture Activist Who Led a ‘Guitar Army’
abstract: His imprisonment for a minor marijuana offense became a cause célèbre. He was released after John Lennon and Yoko Ono sang about him at a protest rally.
lead_paragraph: John Sinclair, a counterculture activist whose nearly 10-year prison sentence for sharing joints with an undercover police officer was cut short after John Lennon and Yoko Ono sang about his plight at a protest rally, died on Tuesday in Detroit. He was 82.

headline: ‘Monkey Man’ Review: Vengeance Is His
abstract: Dev Patel stars as Kid, a human punching bag who comes up with a plan to avenge a past wrong. The hits keep coming and the hero keeps taking them in this rapid-fire film.
lead_paragraph: The thriller “Monkey Man” opens on a tender scene and a nod to the power of storytelling, only to quickly get down to down-and-dirty, action-movie business with a flurry of hard blows and faster edits. For the next two frenetic hours, it repeatedly cuts back to the past — where a mother and child happily lived once upon a bucolic time — before returning to the grubby, raw-knuckle present. There, the hits keep coming and the hero keeps taking them, again and again, in a movie that tries so hard to keep you entertained, it ends up exhausting you.

headline: Inside a G.O.P. Plan to Encourage Early Voting Despite Trump’s Attacks
abstract: Donald Trump’s falsehoods about mail voting have created a strategic disadvantage for Republicans, who must rely on Election Day turnout. The group Turning Point Action has a $100 million plan to change voters’ habits.
lead_paragraph: Inside a sprawling compound in Phoenix, leaders of the influential conservative group Turning Point Action were hatching plans to fix what they see as a mortal threat to the Republican Party: its voters’ avoidance of early voting, especially by mail, since the 2020 election.

headline: Review: A Tribute to the Jazz Great Max Roach Meets His Standards
abstract: Ayodele Casel leads a program celebrating Roach’s centenary that also includes works by Rennie Harris as well as by Ronald K. Brown and Arcell Cabuag.
lead_paragraph: Nothing dates like technology. The video effects in the Kit Fitzgerald film that opens “Max Roach 100” at the Joyce Theater — a centenary celebration of the great drummer, composer and activist — are clearly from the 1980s. (Remember Max Headroom?) The performances of Roach that the film preserves, however, are timeless.

headline: Denmark Closes Shipping Lane Over Risk of Accidental Missile Launch
abstract: The military said the missile malfunctioned during a test aboard a warship, and there was a possibility it could fly a short distance, but no risk of the warhead exploding.
lead_paragraph: Denmark halted traffic in a busy shipping lane and closed the airspace above it on Thursday, warning of a possible accidental missile launch and falling debris.

headline: How an Editors’ Note Fueled Another Kate Conspiracy Theory
abstract: A routine Getty Images caption beside the Princess of Wales’s cancer announcement has fanned disinformation about her. Researchers say there is no evidence that the video is fake.
lead_paragraph: When Catherine, Princess of Wales, announced last month that she had been diagnosed with cancer, it seemed to quell the rumors that had swirled over her stepping back from public life.

headline: Review: Turning Dancers Into Aliens One Step at a Time
abstract: Under the artistic leadership of Emily Molnar, Nederlands Dans Theater returned to New York City Center with a less than stellar triple bill.
lead_paragraph: Emily Molnar, the artistic director of Nederlands Dans Theater, is committed to giving her dancers, as she has said, “creative agency and a greater sense of belonging.”

headline: G.O.P. Congressman’s Wild Claim: F.B.I. Entrapped Jan. 6 Rioters
abstract: More than three years after the attack on Congress, a Republican subcommittee chairman offered a series of baseless and disproved claims about it, reflecting an effort on the right to falsify what occurred.
lead_paragraph: Even by a conspiracy theorist’s standards, the wild claims made by Representative Clay Higgins, Republican of Louisiana, stand out.

headline: A New York Housing Deal Could Be Close. What’s Holding It Up?
abstract: The deal could clear the way for the construction of new homes and make it more difficult for landlords to evict renters, if lawmakers in Albany can find a compromise.
lead_paragraph: Everyone — landlords, tenants, builders and their various allies — seems to agree that a deal is desperately needed to address the worsening housing crisis in New York State.

headline: As Heartbeat Opera Reaches a Milestone, So Does Its Musical Leader
abstract: Dan Schlosberg, who for 10 years has adapted opera classics for the company, has written its first world premiere.
lead_paragraph: For the last decade, Heartbeat Opera has treated the classics like rough drafts: The scores of “Carmen” and “Madama Butterfly,” “Fidelio” and “Der Freischütz” have been starting points for something fresh, urgent and immediate.

headline: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Where are all the books about work? That question lands in our inbox from time to time, and no wonder: In terms of hours and paychecks and the sense of identity they impart, jobs are a consuming part of our lives that authors do indeed too often neglect. So this week we recommend three books that put the world of paid labor front and center: Adelle Waldman’s novel “Help Wanted” is set in a suburban box store, Hamilton Nolan’s “The Hammer” assesses the current state of union organizing, and Jane Kamensky’s “Candida Royalle and the Sexual Revolution” takes the measure of a proto-girlboss who went from starring in pornographic movies to launching her own production company with a feminist slant.

headline: Sexual Assault of Migrants in Panama Rises to Level Rarely Seen Outside War
abstract: The New York Times interviewed more than 70 people who said they had been victims of armed robbery. Fourteen were women who said they had suffered sexual violence.
lead_paragraph: The girl, 8, from Venezuela, had slept fitfully the night before, wailing in her dreams, her mother said, about the men trying to kill her.

headline: ‘Coup de Chance’ Review: Woody Allen’s Usual With a French Twist
abstract: Despite its Parisian setting, the setup is familiar from any of Allen’s New York movies: An act of infidelity presents a dilemma. Some of the jokes are funny.
lead_paragraph: “Coup de Chance,” the latest from Woody Allen, looks and plays like many of his recent movies, only better; it sounds like them, too, except that it’s in French. Set entirely in France, it features well-heeled, loquacious narcissists who circle one another in a comic-dramatic story that touches on existential worries and folds in lightly jaundiced observations about life. There are pretty people and handsome homes, repressed lives and unleashed desires, the usual. As is often the case in Allen’s movies, there’s also an act of infidelity, which presents a dilemma, if not an especially torturous one. The jokes are fairly muted; some are funny.

headline: Behind Our Reporting on Sexual Assaults in the Darién Gap
abstract: Robbery and rape have long been a risk for migrants crossing the Darién Gap, but recently, there has been a sharp rise in sexual violence directed at women and girls. Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios of The New York Times captured a snapshot of that violence, speaking with 14 women who said they had experienced sexual violence, ranging from forcible touching to rape.
lead_paragraph: Robbery and rape have long been a risk for migrants crossing the Darién Gap, but recently, there has been a sharp rise in sexual violence directed at women and girls. Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios of The New York Times captured a snapshot of that violence, speaking with 14 women who said they had experienced sexual violence, ranging from forcible touching to rape.

headline: Have a Wine Bar Night at Home With These Recipes
abstract: Vegetables with cashew romesco, saucy roasted cauliflower, whipped ricotta and more dishes that will transport you to your favorite small-plates spot.
lead_paragraph: Every now and then, poor time management leads me in a delightful direction. This happened on a recent vacation to San Juan, where I had to scramble for a last-minute dinner reservation. I settled on a wine bar, El Vino Crudo in Old San Juan, not even pausing for a beat to pore over the menu first, as I’m wont to do.

headline: Antiquarian Book Fair: From Sylvia Plath’s Papers to Vintage Matchbooks
abstract: This year’s New York International Antiquarian Book Fair features plenty of quirky items amid the high-ticket treasures. (Poison books, anyone?)
lead_paragraph: For those who love a chance to inspect stunning decorative bindings and rare volumes (or just ogle the people who can afford them), the annual New York International Antiquarian Book Fair is an unmissable date on the spring calendar.

headline: Georgia Judge Rejects Effort to Dismiss Trump Case on Free Speech Grounds
abstract: The defense had argued that some of the charges were based on statements Donald Trump and his co-defendants made in 2020 that were constitutionally protected.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Atlanta on Thursday rejected an effort by former President Donald J. Trump and his co-defendants to have the Georgia criminal case against them dismissed on grounds that it was based on comments that were protected by the First Amendment.

headline: Republican Jewish Coalition Takes on Indiana Republican
abstract: Most of the battles over Israel play out in Democratic primaries. But a G.O.P. group is putting up $1 million for ads against John N. Hostettler, who is running for Congress.
lead_paragraph: Battles over Israel are a defining feature of Democratic primaries across the country.

headline: Amid Tragedy, Anguished Pleas for Gaza
abstract: Responses to an Opinion essay by José Andrés and news articles. Also: New York City’s mental health shelters; the eclipse; Donald Trump and the Bible.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Finland School Shooting’s Motive Was Bullying, Police Say
abstract: The police said the motive emerged during interviews with the student, who after the shooting also threatened students heading to another school.
lead_paragraph: The 12-year-old boy who opened fire at his school in Finland on Tuesday, killing a schoolmate and injuring two others, has offered an explanation for the shooting: He was bullied.

headline: Michael Singer, Sculptor Who Used Nature as His Medium, Dies at 78
abstract: His work, on an increasingly large scale, attempted to highlight, and repair, the impact of human intervention on the landscape.
lead_paragraph: Michael Singer, a sculptor whose work, beginning in beaver bogs and pine forests and proceeding at an increasingly grander scale, eventually blurred the lines separating art, landscaping, architecture and urban planning, died on March 14 at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 78.

headline: Israel to Add Gaza Aid Routes as Biden Hinges Support on Civilian Protection
abstract: The president denounced the killing of seven humanitarian workers in a tense call with Israel’s prime minister. Within hours, Israel agreed to increase aid deliveries.
lead_paragraph: President Biden threatened on Thursday to condition future support for Israel on how it addresses his concerns about civilian casualties and the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, prompting Israel to commit to permitting more food and other supplies into the besieged enclave in hopes of placating him.

headline: ‘Travels’ Review: A Sonic Flight From Heartbreak
abstract: In his new show, James Harrison Monaco blends storytelling and electronic beats in service of curiosity and escape.
lead_paragraph: Some ride-share passengers are content to wear headphones and gaze out the window. But anywhere that James Harrison Monaco goes, including the back seat of a Lyft, presents an opportunity to zero in on someone else’s story.

headline: Florida Court Rulings Pose Risks for House Republicans on Abortion
abstract: The twin decisions have all but guaranteed that voters will have the issue on their minds in November, bringing potential risks for two anti-abortion Republicans in the state whose districts aren’t solidly red.
lead_paragraph: Representative Anna Paulina Luna, a hard-right Republican from Florida, has proudly described herself as a “pro-life extremist.”

headline: New York Attorney General Questions Trump’s $175 Million Bond Deal
abstract: Letitia James said in court papers that the California company providing the guarantee was not qualified to do such deals in New York.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general’s office on Thursday took exception to a $175 million bond that Donald J. Trump recently posted in his civil fraud case, questioning the qualifications of the California company that provided it.

headline: Eclipse’s Path Is Also Leaving a Trail of High Hotel Prices
abstract: One Super 8 in Illinois advertised $949 a night. Its normal rate is $95.
lead_paragraph: The solar eclipse that will cast a visible shadow across the United States on Monday is already leaving an obvious mark on hotel prices.

headline: No Labels Abandons Effort to Field a Presidential Candidate
abstract: The centrist group laid out grand ambitions of running a third-party candidate in a Biden-Trump contest, but the most prominent figures it courted all said no.
lead_paragraph: The centrist group No Labels has abandoned its plans to run a presidential ticket in the 2024 election, having failed to recruit a candidate, its leader, Nancy Jacobson, said on Thursday.

headline: In an Autocratic Region, a Glimmer of Democracy as Kuwaitis Cast Votes
abstract: With a new ruler in charge, the oil-rich emirate elected a new Parliament for the fourth time in four years while grappling with political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: As the clock struck noon on Thursday, the doors to dozens of polling stations across Kuwait opened and voters rushed in to elect one of the Middle East’s most robust Parliaments.

headline: Trains Are Cleaner Than Planes, Right?
abstract: The surprising carbon footprint of an Amtrak trip across America.
lead_paragraph: Recently, I did something I’ve long dreamed of. I took the train across America.

headline: Israel’s Military Cancels Leave for Combat Units and Jams GPS Signals
abstract: Though no reason was given for the moves, Israeli newspapers said they came amid fears of an increased threat from Iran after an Israeli strike in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said on Thursday that it was canceling leave for combat units, calling up more reservists and blocking GPS signals.

headline: Kate Shindle on Why She’s Stepping Down as Actors’ Equity President
abstract: After nine years in the role, she has decided not to seek re-election in May. Her departure comes amid significant turnover in the theater industry.
lead_paragraph: Kate Shindle, who has served as president of Actors’ Equity Association for nine years, is stepping down after a tenure dominated by the coronavirus pandemic that for a time idled all of the labor union’s members.

headline: Glasses Improve Income, Not Just Eyesight
abstract: A study found that when older workers in Bangladesh were given free reading glasses, they earned 33 percent more than those who had not.
lead_paragraph: If you’re 50 or older and reading this article, chances are you are wearing a pair of inexpensive reading glasses to correct your presbyopia, the age-related decline in vision that makes it progressively more difficult to see fine print and tiny objects.

headline: Up to a Trillion Cicadas Are About to Emerge in the U.S.
abstract: Two periodical cicada broods are appearing in a 16-state area in the Midwest and Southeast for the first time in centuries. Can you get rid of them? Do they bite you? We answer your questions.
lead_paragraph: In a rare occurrence, a trillion cicadas from two different broods are expected to begin appearing in the Midwest and Southeast regions of the United States at the end of April.

headline: Do You Know How Flavor Works?
abstract: In her new book, “Flavorama,” the flavor scientist Arielle Johnson demystifies the sense of taste. Take this quiz and see how much you know about how taste is perceived.
lead_paragraph: In her new book, “Flavorama,” the flavor scientist Arielle Johnson demystifies the sense of taste. Take this quiz and see how much you know about how taste is perceived.

headline: California Congressional Primary Has a Rare Tie for a Runoff Spot
abstract: Never before has California’s primary system resulted in a three-way runoff for a congressional seat.
lead_paragraph: California’s primary system — in which the top two vote-getters, regardless of party, advance to the general election — has seeded plenty of unusual showdowns since it was established a little more than a decade ago.

headline: Septic Installer Is Sentenced to 7 Years for Urging Jan. 6 Mob With Megaphone
abstract: Taylor James Johnatakis, 40, coordinated rioters to rush a police barricade at the Southwest stairs to the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6.
lead_paragraph: A Washington State man has been sentenced to more than seven years in prison for his role in the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol, where prosecutors said he used a megaphone to urge other rioters to barge through a police line.

headline: These Brooklyn Restaurateurs Are Crossing the East River
abstract: Big names in Brooklyn are heading to Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes I receive emails from readers saying that I recommend too many Brooklyn restaurants. Though I disagree, I will admit: That’s where I’ve lived since arriving in New York City, so I think it’s a very special place.

headline: What to Watch This Weekend: A Riveting True-Crime Drama
abstract: “Mr. Bates vs. the Post Office,” premiering Sunday on PBS, is a shattering mini-series about a real-life injustice.
lead_paragraph: Legal thrillers and true-crime sagas often succeed at generating momentum but fail at conveying genuine humanity. “Mr. Bates vs. the Post Office,” debuting Sunday at 9 p.m. on “Masterpiece” on PBS (check local listings), succeeds at both; it is a tender and shattering drama and a tense, twisty legal story.

headline: Judge Rejects Trump Dismissal Effort in Classified Documents Case
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon ruled that the former president cannot escape prosecution by arguing that the Presidential Records Act allowed him to claim secret government material as his own property.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday rejected for now one of former President Donald J. Trump’s central efforts to dismiss charges that he had mishandled classified documents after leaving office.

headline: Friday Briefing: Six Months of the Israel-Hamas War
abstract: Also, the rise of “carefluencers.”
lead_paragraph: Sunday marks six months since the Oct. 7 attacks that started Israel’s war against Hamas. More than 32,000 Palestinians have died, people are desperate for aid and dozens of Israeli hostages are still being held in Gaza.

headline: When an Editor’s Job Is to Follow the Moon
abstract: As North America prepares for the total solar eclipse on April 8, Michael Roston, an editor on the Health and Science desk, prepares The Times.
lead_paragraph: On April 8, millions of people will look toward the sky for the total solar eclipse, the first to be visible in North America since 2017. The moon will cross directly in front of the sun, blocking light and casting a shadow on Earth as it makes its journey north from Mexico, over the United States and into Canada. For the more than 30 million people who live inside the path of totality — and the many more who are traveling to optimal viewing spots — daylight will momentarily disappear. In other areas, it will dim.

headline: Richard Benedick, Negotiator of Landmark Ozone Treaty, Dies at 88
abstract: He played a key role in securing the Montreal Protocol, an international environmental pact to protect the ozone layer by reducing the use of certain chemicals.
lead_paragraph: A May 1985 report in the journal Nature was alarming. High above Antarctica, a massive hole had opened in the ozone shield that protects life on earth from the sun’s ultraviolet rays.

headline: Don’t Let Our Broken Politics Mangle Our Faith
abstract: When I think of “Christian Visibility Day,” I have very different images in mind.
lead_paragraph: In 2007, I had a conversation about the culture war with the evangelical pastor Tim Keller that I’ve never forgotten. Keller, who was the founder of Redeemer Presbyterian Church in Manhattan, died last year, a devastating loss.

headline: Under Half of Illegal Gun Cases Tracked by A.T.F. Were Involved in Black Market Sales
abstract: The report, part of an effort by the Biden administration to make public previously undisclosed data, offered a portrait of the country’s growing illegal firearms market.
lead_paragraph: Four in 10 illegal gun cases tracked by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives were involved in black market sales, including from shadow dealers who used a legal loophole to evade background checks, according to an analysis of firearms trafficking released on Thursday.

headline: Iran Says 17-Hour Battle With Separatists Leaves 28 Dead in 2 Cities
abstract: Jaish al-Adl, an ethnic Baluch group designated by the United States as a terrorist organization, claimed responsibility for the attacks.
lead_paragraph: Iranian security forces battled simultaneous terrorist attacks by a militant separatist group in a southeast province that raged for nearly 17 hours, with intense gunfights in the streets of two cities that resulted in the deaths of 10 security officers and 18 militants, according to the Ministry of Interior on Thursday.

headline: NATO Wants to Show Support for Ukraine, but Only So Much
abstract: Admitting Kyiv is a nonstarter as long as the war with Russia is raging. But the member nations want to show they are supporting Ukraine “for the long haul.”
lead_paragraph: When NATO’s leaders gather this summer to celebrate the 75th anniversary of their military alliance, the last thing they want to see is a resurgent Russian military marching across Ukraine because Europe was too weak to provide Kyiv with the support it needed.

headline: ‘Little Women’ and the Art of Breaking Grammatical Rules
abstract: In an evolving language, it ain’t always clear — or important — what’s correct.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago I wrote on the grand old rule about not ending sentences with prepositions, which is, quite simply, a long-lived hoax we’d best relegate to history. In that light, I’d like to dismantle the powerful but hopeless idea that language is something to be judged rather than observed. It can be hard to process, within the bounds of our lifetimes, the randomness of our take on what “proper” language is.

headline: Hochul Orders M.T.A. to Stop Pressuring Marathon to Pay for Lost Tolls
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority wanted the New York City Marathon to pay $750,000 to make up for toll revenue lost when the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge was closed.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Thursday said that she had ordered the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to drop its effort to charge the New York City Marathon roughly $750,000 for its use of the Verrazzano-Narrows Bridge.

headline: Jack Smith Gets a Bit of What He Wanted
abstract: The judge in the documents case rejected for now Donald Trump’s central argument to escape prosecution.
lead_paragraph: In the 10 months that she has overseen Donald Trump’s classified documents case, Judge Aileen Cannon has issued a raft of curious decisions and entertained claims from the defense that many federal judges would have rejected out of hand. She’s also allowed a pileup of unresolved legal issues to grow so thick that it’s threatening to delay any trial from taking place until after the election in November.

headline: Music Teacher Is Charged With Taking Teenagers on Trips to Abuse Them
abstract: Paul Geer taught for decades at the Family Foundation School, a rural reform academy where he abused students, an indictment states.
lead_paragraph: The music teacher’s classes at the strict, no-nonsense reform school in the woods of upstate New York would seem to be a teenager’s respite amid all the rules, a place for expression and discovery.

headline: Biden Threatens to Condition Israel Aid
abstract: Also, ocean temperatures signal a daunting hurricane season. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: During a tense 30-minute call today with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, President Biden threatened to condition future American support for Israel on whether it improves its treatment of civilians in Gaza. Biden called the humanitarian situation in the enclave “unacceptable,” and insisted to Netanyahu that he quickly put in place specific protections.

headline: R.F.K. Jr.’s Campaign Expressed Sympathy for Jan. 6 Rioters, Then Retracted It
abstract: In an email urging the United States to drop espionage charges against Julian Assange, the Kennedy campaign grouped the WikiLeaks founder with Edward Snowden and “J6 activists” in a D.C. jail.
lead_paragraph: The presidential campaign of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the vaccine skeptic running as an independent candidate, said in an email on Thursday that rioters charged with crimes in connection with the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol and held in a Washington jail had been “stripped of their constitutional liberties.”

headline: Progressive Candidate Could Upend the San Francisco Mayor’s Race
abstract: The contest has been dominated by Mayor London Breed and her moderate challengers. Supervisor Aaron Peskin seeks to change that.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco residents have repeatedly told pollsters they don’t support Mayor London Breed. But until now, every one of her challengers in the November election has sounded a lot like her.

headline: A Looming Question for Paramount’s Board: How to Navigate Shari Redstone
abstract: The board of directors has to walk a fine line, looking out for investors without running afoul of Ms. Redstone, the company’s most influential shareholder.
lead_paragraph: Shari Redstone won control over her media empire in 2018 after a hard-fought struggle with CBS. In the years since, she held off on selling the family business, merging Viacom and CBS to put iconic franchises like “60 Minutes” and “Top Gun” under one roof.

headline: Proudly Puerto Rican
abstract: When the baseball season was over, the first place Roberto Clemente wanted to visit was the farm in El Yunque. That was his haven.
lead_paragraph: When the baseball season was over, the first place Roberto Clemente wanted to visit was the farm in El Yunque. That was his haven.

headline: The Legacy of a Baseball Legend
abstract: Aguadilla, known as one of Puerto Rico’s best surfing spots, was also the last town where Roberto Clemente held a youth baseball clinic.
lead_paragraph: Aguadilla, known as one of Puerto Rico’s best surfing spots, was also the last town where Roberto Clemente held a youth baseball clinic.

headline: Puerto Rico the Clemente Way
abstract: Whenever his teammates would revisit the island, they’d always want to go back to La Parguera.
lead_paragraph: Whenever his teammates would revisit the island, they’d always want to go back to La Parguera.

headline: Jonathan Levin, Dean of Business School, Is Stanford’s New President
abstract: Dr. Levin faces the challenge of guiding the university through politically fraught times.
lead_paragraph: Stanford University’s next president will be Jonathan Levin, an economist who currently serves as dean of the graduate business school and whose association with the university dates back to his undergraduate days in the 1990s.

headline: Why Some Billionaires Will Back Trump
abstract: It’s about taxes — and a false belief in their own impunity.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s campaign is reportedly strapped for cash. Small-dollar donations are running far behind their 2020 pace. Big Trump rallies aren’t yielding his biggest cash hauls. Some large-dollar donors are hesitant, in part because they worry (with good reason) that their money will be used not for the campaign but to pay his legal bills. So he has been wooing right-wing billionaires.

headline: Why Is Technology Mean to Me?
abstract: I want my technology to have many capacities, but free will is not among them.
lead_paragraph: It is never easy to re-examine one’s fundamental convictions, but now I am forced to question my previous disbelief in the existence of Satan. I am compelled to confront this ugly possibility by the fact that from time to time my electronic devices seem to fall under demonic possession.

headline: Inside a Father’s Struggle to Feed His Family in Gaza
abstract: Anwar Ghilan worked as an English teacher before the Israeli siege on Gaza. After the war broke out, he lost his source of income and turned to selling clothes to keep his family fed amid high food prices.
lead_paragraph: Anwar Ghilan worked as an English teacher before the Israeli siege on Gaza. After the war broke out, he lost his source of income and turned to selling clothes to keep his family fed amid high food prices.

headline: Israel Agrees to Open Erez Crossing for Gaza Aid After Biden Pressure
abstract: Israel has come under rising pressure from U.S. officials and humanitarian agencies to allow more aid into Gaza, amid warnings that famine is looming.
lead_paragraph: Israel has agreed to open another crossing and increase the flow of aid getting into Gaza, a move seemingly aimed at tempering the U.S. president’s growing frustration over the dire humanitarian crisis in the enclave.

headline: Prisoners Who Sued Over Lockdown Will Be Allowed to View Solar Eclipse
abstract: The six inmates at an upstate New York prison had said the eclipse was “a religious event that they must witness.” A statewide prison lockdown will remain in place.
lead_paragraph: New York State’s corrections department agreed on Thursday to allow six men who had sued to be able to view Monday’s total solar eclipse to do so at the upstate prison where they are held, but the department stopped short of lifting a statewide prison lockdown during the eclipse.

headline: Land Artist Files Lawsuit Against Des Moines Museum to Protect Her Work
abstract: Mary Miss’s lawsuit claims that the planned demolition of her work violates the Visual Artists Rights Act, which empowers artists to save their work from destruction.
lead_paragraph: The artist Mary Miss filed a lawsuit on Thursday against the Des Moines Art Center to halt the planned destruction of a work of land art the museum commissioned her to create less than 40 years ago.

headline: Chief Justice Extols Legacy of Sandra Day O’Connor
abstract: In remarks at an award ceremony, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. described his colleague as a trailblazing and civic-minded presence on the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. delivered a fond tribute to former Justice Sandra Day O’Connor on Thursday, celebrating her legacy as the first woman on the Supreme Court and her commitment to advancing civics and civility after her retirement.

headline: High Point
abstract: Rebecca Goldstein says hello from the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart’s puzzle nods to a major upcoming event.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s puzzle is a reminder of the total solar eclipse that is expected to shroud parts of Mexico, Canada and the United States in darkness on April 8. The solution is a passage from a book called “Sun, Moon, Earth: The History of Solar Eclipses From Omens of Doom to Einstein and Exoplanets,” by Dr. Tyler Nordgren, an astronomer whose enthusiasm for the phenomenon is infectious enough that I regret choosing to stay home a little and settle for a partial, 90 percent eclipse. I hope that everyone who will see it in its totality, including Mr. Balton and Ms. Stewart, gets clear skies!

headline: Netanyahu Faces Pressure at Home and Abroad, From Foes and Friends
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has the challenge of trying to defeat Hamas while preserving both his government and Israel’s international alliances.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is facing challenges on multiple fronts, with his domestic support appearing to erode at a time when international fury and frustration over the war in Gaza have reached new heights.

headline: Putting the Real Me in My Dating Profile
abstract: Among the staged photos and silly prompts of online dating, I get one sentence where I get to be my true self.
lead_paragraph: I name my houseplants after movie characters that die. That way, if they don’t survive, it’s less tragic and more like a plotline.

headline: Knowing She was the One, with Surgical Precision
abstract: Anika Bieg was ready to swear off dating. Then she met Dr. Olivia Sacks — and after 10 minutes, kissed her.
lead_paragraph: In October 2022, Dr. Olivia Arden Sacks’s professional life as a surgical resident was consumed by long hours, an academic paper, and thoughts about her rotation. But amid all the hard work, she had a moment of clarity: Anika Lynn Bieg was the person she wanted to marry.

headline: Her First and Last Dating App Date
abstract: Krystle-Jayne Ng said she was a “serial dater.” Hanna Rinderknecht-Mahaffy was new to online dating. They hit it off instantly.
lead_paragraph: In February 2020, when Krystle-Jayne Mei-Ying Ng first saw the dating app profile of Hanna Sophia Rinderknecht-Mahaffy, one crucial detail struck her: her listed height.

headline: A Fate Potentially Guided by a Late Brother’s Hand
abstract: Tanya Sareen met Joel Adolphson, a former squadron mate of her brother Taj, who had been killed while serving six years earlier.
lead_paragraph: Though Tanya Tanwar Sareen’s brother died in 2015, she feels he had a hand in introducing her to her future husband.

headline: Corrections: April 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: The item in Thursday’s “Headline From History” feature about a libel case brought by the writer Oscar Wilde misspelled the title of the nobleman who Wilde was suing. He was the Marquis of Queensberry, not Queensbury.

headline: Quotation of the Day: One Leaning Tower in Italy Looks to Another for Advice
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like a patient in intensive care, there are 64 instruments that continually monitor its vital signs.”

headline: At the Singles Table, Sparks Flew
abstract: When they met at the wedding of two good friends, Alexandra Dale and Patrick Kohout discovered they had been born at the same hospital.
lead_paragraph: Like many single people attending friends’ weddings, Alexandra Telford Dale and Patrick John Kohout were each given a rundown of eligible guests attending the June 4, 2022, nuptials of John O’Malley and Samantha Pelcher in Manchester, Vt.

headline: China’s Young People Are Giving Up on Saving for Retirement
abstract: Citing a rapidly aging society, difficult job market and uncertainty about the future, some young people are rejecting the idea of saving for old age.
lead_paragraph: China wants young people to put money away for retirement. Tao Swift, an unemployed 30-year-old, is not interested in hearing it.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief on six months of war between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: It will be six months this Sunday since the Oct. 7 attacks that started the war between Israel and Hamas. More than 32,000 Palestinians have died, people in Gaza are desperate for aid and dozens of Israeli hostages are still being held there.

headline: In Australia, a Nation’s Banh Mi Love Affair
abstract: “We’ll make the best of it here. And they can call it a pork roll.”
lead_paragraph: It is only a slight exaggeration to say that Australia runs on banh mi — the Vietnamese sandwich of a baguette with tangy pickled vegetables, a slick of mayonnaise and your protein of choice.

headline: Baltimore Shipping Channel Will Partially Reopen by End of April, Officials Say
abstract: The Army Corps of Engineers plans to reopen the channel at full capacity by late May, as officials scramble to resume operations at one of the nation’s busiest ports.
lead_paragraph: A shipping channel in the Baltimore harbor that has remained blocked since last week’s collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge will be partially reopened by the end of April, with full traffic expected to be restored by late May, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers said Thursday.

headline: Stephen Colbert Says Trump’s ‘April Trials Bring Me Smiles’
abstract: “The Late Show” host changed up the adage about spring after Donald Trump had a bad day in court.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: archipelago
abstract: This word has appeared in 123 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word archipelago has appeared in 123 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 3 in “How Charles Darwin Found Inspiration on the Cape Verde Islands” by Ben Crair:

headline: Rats on a Dog
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: What Children’s Book Worlds Do You Wish You Could Visit in Real Life?
abstract: A new museum of children’s literature brings “Caps for Sale,” “Blueberries for Sal,” “Goodnight Moon” and many more tales to life. What book worlds have most captivated you?
lead_paragraph: What were your favorite books during childhood? Did you ever yearn to be a part of the worlds they conjured? Did you ever draw or map out a children’s book, or even make a shoe-box diorama based on one?

headline: New York Has a Budget Trick to Try on the Federal Government
abstract: The state hopes to take advantage of Medicaid reimbursement rules to divert federal funds into state coffers.
lead_paragraph: Facing increased Medicaid enrollment and a cash crunch across New York’s health care system, Democrats in Albany hope to employ a maneuver that they say will allow the state to generate billions of dollars a year essentially out of thin air.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: She Finally Reunited With Her Father. Then He Was Killed in the Subway.
abstract: Janna Volz’s father, Jason Volz, was largely absent from her life as he fought addiction. They were rebuilding their relationship when he was pushed to his death on the subway tracks.
lead_paragraph: There is an unfinished wooden dollhouse sitting in the attic of Janna Volz’s mother’s house that her father made for her 8th birthday.

headline: U.N. Rights Body Calls for a Halt to Arms Transfers to Israel
abstract: The resolution adds diplomatic weight to international demands to curb the supply of weapons being used in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ top human rights body adopted a resolution on Friday that calls for all countries to stop supplying arms to Israel and puts its key allies under international scrutiny for possible violations of international humanitarian law.

headline: A Willy Wonka Event Ended in Disaster. From Its Ashes Rose a Budding Star.
abstract: The internet latched on to 16-year-old Felicia Dawkins’ performance as The Unknown at a shambolic Willy Wonka-inspired event. This weekend, she’s heading to a bigger and scarier stage in London.
lead_paragraph: On one chilly evening in March, after the sun had set and when most school-aged children were begrudgingly starting their homework, Felicia Dawkins, 16, enthusiastically hopped on the phone from Scotland to share that her life had changed — for the better.

headline: A Showdown Pits Owners of Second Homes Against Full-Time Residents
abstract: The pandemic upset a delicate balance of part-time and full-time residents in a community in the Poconos, sparking a debate over short-term rentals.

headline: There’s an Explosion of Plastic Waste. Big Companies Say ‘We’ve Got This.’
abstract: Big brands like Procter & Gamble and Nestlé say a new generation of plants will help them meet environmental goals, but the technology is struggling to deliver.
lead_paragraph: By 2025, Nestle promises not to use any plastic in its products that isn’t recyclable. By that same year, L’Oreal says all of its packaging will be “refillable, reusable, recyclable or compostable.”

headline: For $367 a Month, She Has 345 Square Feet, a Hot Tub and a River
abstract: After a lifetime of seeking out tiny spaces, she finally found a keeper: a former barbershop in an old mill village in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: If there is a word for people who behave like terriers, tucking themselves into cramped spaces that would drive others into fits, it probably has not been invented. But it would describe Liz Gilson.

headline: Standby Cruising: A New Option for Bargain Seekers
abstract: Are you a flexible traveler? Holland America’s standby cruises may be for you. The cost: $49 a day, excluding fees, taxes and extras. The catch: It might be a hair-raising, last-minute scramble.
lead_paragraph: In February, Barb McGowan took a seven-day cruise on Holland America Line, visiting the Bahamas, Turks and Caicos, and the Dominican Republic for just $343, or $49 a day, excluding taxes, port fees and extras. By comparison, Holland America currently lists a seven-day Caribbean itinerary in October from about $700.

headline: Documentary Filmmaker Explores Japan’s Rigorous Education Rituals
abstract: Her movies try to explain why Japan is the way it is, showing both the upsides and downsides of the country’s commonplace practices. Her latest film focuses on an elementary school.
lead_paragraph: The defining experience of Ema Ryan Yamazaki’s childhood left her with badly scraped knees and her classmates with broken bones.

headline: Back in the ’90s, This Eclipse Webcast Put the Cosmos on Demand
abstract: A total solar eclipse in Aruba was streamed to millions of users of the World Wide Web in 1998, helping to start an ongoing era of viral videos of space and astronomy.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the total solar eclipse.

headline: How Does Dev Patel Become an Action Star? By Directing Himself.
abstract: With his feature filmmaking debut, “Monkey Man,” Dev Patel joins a list of performers known for dramas taking on unlikely parts.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, when Dev Patel started thinking about making the film that would eventually become his feature directing debut, “Monkey Man,” he was not getting offered roles that, in his words, had “any sort of ass kickery involved or coolness.”

headline: Fewer Pesky Words, More Movie Stars Steer a New ‘1984’
abstract: A hectic high-profile adaptation for Audible plays fast and loose with George Orwell’s original text.
lead_paragraph: 1984, by George Orwell, read by Andrew Garfield, Cynthia Erivo, Andrew Scott, Tom Hardy, Chukwudi Iwuji and others.

headline: Her Art Is at Odds With Museums, and Museums Can’t Get Enough
abstract: Gala Porras-Kim has confronted the restitution of cultural artifacts and now — with melting Antarctic ice — climate change.
lead_paragraph: Inside the Museum of Contemporary Art in Denver, little pieces of Antarctica were melting: cross-sections of an ice core from the continent’s Newall Glacier, each one about the size of a beverage coaster and encased in a vacuum-sealed plastic bag. The artist Gala Porras-Kim watched approvingly during a visit in March, pointing out the air pockets that had started to form.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Getting Angry at Someone for Things They Did in a Dream
abstract: Their justification? Whatever happened in the dream is something I “would have done.”
lead_paragraph: Stephanie writes: Sometimes my husband wakes up angry at me for something I did in his dream. He feels he’s justified because whatever happened in his dream is something I “would have done.” I say this is not fair.

headline: The Next Frontier? Philosophy in Space.
abstract: STEM can’t solve all our problems.
lead_paragraph: The window to apply to be a NASA astronaut — a window that opens only about every four years — closes this month, on April 16. Though I’ve submitted an application, I don’t expect to make the cut.

headline: Who Will Pay for the Baltimore Bridge Collapse?
abstract: Disputes over liability and the cost of claims could take years for insurers to resolve and result in billions of dollars in payouts.
lead_paragraph: On the day the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore collapsed, President Biden said the federal government would pay the “entire cost” of rebuilding it, which some suggest could run to more than $1 billion. Washington will foot the bill so the bridge and nearby port can reopen “as soon as humanly possible,” he said.

headline: The Surfer Dude Behind a Famous Jewel Heist
abstract: Murph the Surf became an unlikely folk hero after robbing the American Museum of Natural History’s Hall of Gems in 1964. A collector is selling his archive for $30,000.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at how a trove of letters and art belonging to a famous jewel thief ended up at New York’s antiquarian book fair.

headline: $700,000 Homes in Mexico City
abstract: A sunny two-bedroom in Condesa, a condo for presale in Juarez, and a five-bedroom Spanish colonial house in Cuajimalpa De Morelos.
lead_paragraph: This sunny condominium in Mexico City’s elegant Condesa neighborhood, with spaces for living, working and entertaining, overlooks the treetops of Parque Mexico. Built in 1985 and remodeled in 2004 by the Mexican design and architecture firm HABITACIÓN 116, the residence features honey-colored hardwood floors, double pane windows, quarters for a live-in housekeeper and a flex room that could be converted into an office or third bedroom. The unit, one of two residences on the seventh floor of a mid-rise condominium, comes with two gated parking spaces.

headline: Are Smartphones Just a Scapegoat for Our Unhappy Children?
abstract: Why ditching phones won’t save the kids.
lead_paragraph: It’s not just bad vibes — America’s kids are not OK. As study after study shows worsening youth mental health, a popular theory has emerged: The rise of smartphones and the addictive nature of social media is making young people miserable. But can it really be that simple?

headline: Is This the End of Academic Freedom?
abstract: Silencing pro-Palestinian speech and action sets a dangerous precedent.
lead_paragraph: ​At New York University, the spring semester began with a poetry reading. Students and faculty gathered in the atrium of Bobst Library. At that time, about 26,000 Palestinians had already been killed in Israel’s horrific war on Gaza; the reading was a collective act of bearing witness.

headline: Dwindling Ammunition Stocks Pose Grave Threat to Ukraine
abstract: What few munitions remain are often mismatched with battlefield needs as the country’s forces gird for an expected Russian offensive this summer.
lead_paragraph: The crew at an artillery position in eastern Ukraine had 33 shells in its ammunition bunker, stacked neatly like firewood against a wall.

headline: Are You a ‘Spring’ or a ‘Winter’? It Could Cost You $500 to Find Out.
abstract: Seasonal color analysis, a fad from the 1980s seeking to identify a person’s most flattering color palette, is drawing views and exasperation on TikTok.
lead_paragraph: A barefaced woman studies her reflection, trying on fabric bibs that could have been yanked from a production of “Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat.” In a video posted on TikTok last month, she is draped in lustrous silver, faint pink, a deep green that recalls a jalapeño pepper.

headline: The Market May Have Finally Hit a Real Record, but It Could Be a Problem
abstract: Robert Shiller, the Nobel laureate, says valuations adjusted for high inflation suggest stock returns for the next decade are likely to be modest.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a splendid run for the market — so emphatically great that in just the first three months of the year, the S&P 500 climbed to record highs on 22 separate days.

headline: ‘Girls State,’ ‘Boys State’ and Democracy Through the Eyes of Teenagers
abstract: Though both documentaries follow programs for rising high school seniors, their differences speak volumes about the challenges the participants face.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries about the American political system are legion, and grow every week. You can bet we’ll be seeing dozens more by the time this year’s presidential election rolls around. But “Boys State” (Apple TV+), the 2020 documentary directed by Amanda McBaine and Jesse Moss, came at government from a different and very refreshing angle. That film chronicles a few participants in the Boys State program run by the American Legion in Texas and every other state except Hawaii. It’s an immersive mock government approach, designed to give rising high school seniors a taste of campaigns, diplomacy and the structure of American government.

headline: Literary Gold From the Gilded Age, in Poster Form
abstract: For lovers of vintage books and periodicals, “The Art of the Literary Poster” celebrates a vibrant niche in late-19th-century advertising.
