lead_paragraph: Trends come and go; one era’s tulip fever is another’s Beanie Baby craze. The vogue for literary posters burned briefly, beginning in 1893 and lasting not much more than a decade. But the body of work it produced often hewed closer to fine art than advertisement, and slyly captured the zeitgeist of the times: a bellwether for the modern man or woman whose fondness for the intellectual enrichment of periodicals like Collier’s and Harper’s Magazine was matched only by an aggressive commitment to physical health and attractiveness. (See Charles Arthur Cox’s rendering of five lithe beauties on a tandem bicycle, leisurely perusing the latest copy of Bearings. Gibson Girls who read!)

headline: Our Mom Is 75. We’re Moving Heaven and Earth for This Eclipse.
abstract: A total eclipse is worth moving heaven and earth to experience.
lead_paragraph: If all goes according to plan, on Monday, our 75-year-old mother, Nancy, will be settled into a lawn chair in Waco, Texas — some 1,300 miles from her recliner in Las Vegas — and joining a great many other Americans as they put on solar eclipse glasses, tilt their heads up and try to make sense of what’s happening in the heavens.

headline: ‘Sugar’ Review: In a Lonely Place With Colin Farrell
abstract: This Apple TV+ mystery celebrates and subverts film noir.
lead_paragraph: This much I can tell you: Colin Farrell plays a private detective in “Sugar.” He has a license. We see it being handed to him and everything.

headline: The Secret to Caitlin Clark’s Shooting Power
abstract: The University of Iowa basketball star has made one “logo” shot after another. Her coach and other fitness experts say it’s all in the physical and mental training.
lead_paragraph: When Caitlin Clark, the 22-year-old University of Iowa point guard, lines up against the University of Connecticut team on Friday night, she will most likely shoot the ball from far past the 3-point line. Then, against all odds and all coaching philosophies, she is likely to do so again, and again, and again. Whoever is unlucky enough to try to defend her is left to do little but shrug.

headline: The Rage in ‘Carrie’ Feels More Relevant Than Ever
abstract: Stephen King’s debut novel, about a bullied girl who gets revenge, used to horrify me. Now I find Carrie’s story inspiring.
lead_paragraph: In “On Writing,” Stephen King’s nonfiction account of his career, he talks about a girl he calls Dodie Franklin. She attended his high school and, he recalls, was often bullied for wearing the same clothes every day. In their sophomore year, on the first day back after Christmas vacation, she came to school wearing newly fashionable clothes with a trendy hairstyle — but the bullying and teasing never stopped. “Her peers had no intention of letting her out of the box they’d put her in,” Mr. King writes. “She was punished for even trying to break free.”

headline: A ‘Taxi Driver’ Remake: Why Arthur Jafa Recast the Scorsese Ending
abstract: The artist has gone back to his filmmaking roots, re-examining what he sees as racial undertones in Martin Scorsese’s classic 1976 movie.
lead_paragraph: Call it a return to his roots. The artist Arthur Jafa began his career as a cinematographer, working with his then-wife, Julie Dash, on the acclaimed “Daughters of the Dust” (1991) and with Spike Lee on “Crooklyn” (1994), before garnering art world fame, including a Golden Lion at the 2019 Venice Biennale, for “The White Album,” created from original and collaged video footage. Jafa’s practice has embraced film and video, sculpture, installation, and even painting.

headline: Want to Invest in SpaceX or Stripe? There’s a Fund for That.
abstract: A new publicly traded fund allows individual investors to own a piece of 23 private tech companies, including Stripe, SpaceX, OpenAI and Discord.
lead_paragraph: Stripe, a payments start-up, is one of the most successful companies to emerge from Silicon Valley in a generation. Last year, it hit a valuation of $65 billion. But in the 15 years since it was founded, there has not been a way for most individuals to invest in it.

headline: Will A.I. Break the Internet? Or Save It?
abstract: Nilay Patel discusses the near-future of an internet as A.I.-generated content improves.
lead_paragraph: The internet is in decay. Do a Google search, and there are so many websites now filled with slapdash content contorted just to rank highly in the algorithm. Facebook, YouTube, X and TikTok all used to feel more fun and surprising. And all these once-great media companies have been folding or shedding staff members, unable to find a business model that works.

headline: Woody Allen, Reputation Bruised, Finds Muted Reception to 50th Film
abstract: “Coup de Chance,” a milestone, is being released in the United States after opening in Europe months ago.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, 13 movie theaters around the country will be showing “Coup de Chance,” a brisk French-language thriller about a bored wife in Paris who cheats on her wealthy, aloof husband with an old high school classmate, triggering fatal consequences.

headline: What Does Larry David Know About Manners?
abstract: Our critic on what ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ can teach us about etiquette.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 15, 2000, HBO aired the first episode of “Curb Your Enthusiasm.” Now in its 12th season, the show was created by and stars the comedian Larry David, playing a fictionalized version of himself navigating life in Los Angeles. On the show, Larry is opinionated, loudmouthed and often abrasive. He’s also, according to the New York Times critic Wesley Morris, a 21st-century Emily Post, dispensing wisdom about etiquette in the modern world. Morris joins the culture editor (and “Curb Your Enthusiasm” fan) Melissa Kirsch to discuss what one of television’s brashest characters can teach us about manners.

headline: Three Democratic Senators Are Stuck Indulging an Outdated Fantasy
abstract: Why Is Adeel Mangi’s confirmation still in jeopardy?
lead_paragraph: In 1999 a Florida lawyer, Anuraag Singhal, represented a man convicted of gunning down a police officer. Singhal had to somehow persuade a jury that his client, Jeffrey Lee Weaver, should face life in prison rather than the electric chair, the punishment the hard-charging prosecutor sought.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 5, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: ‘Reglobalization’ to the Rescue?
abstract: The term, which emerged in response to calls for "deglobalization," has been popping up more in trade and policy circles.
lead_paragraph: The term, which emerged in response to calls for "deglobalization," has been popping up more in trade and policy circles.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Isabella Hammad, Charles Frazier, Emily Flitter and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Isabella Hammad, Charles Frazier, Emily Flitter and more.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the sci-fi romance “The Beast.”
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of the sci-fi romance “The Beast.”

headline: 4 Mistakes Couples Make When Discussing Money
abstract: Therapists share the secrets to a drama-free money chat.
lead_paragraph: I like talking to my husband about a lot of things, but money isn’t one of them. Most of our conversations about spending go something like this: We lament our credit card balances. We grumble about child care costs. Then we retreat until the next bill arrives or tax season shines a bright, unsparing light on our finances — as it is right now.

headline: Biden Tells Baltimore: ‘Your Nation Has Your Back’
abstract: President Biden took an aerial tour of the site of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge and met with the families of the six victims. The authorities later announced the recovery of a third body.
lead_paragraph: President Biden told the people of Baltimore on Friday that “your nation has your back” as he stood in front of the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge, which was destroyed after a cargo ship plowed through it last week, killing six people.

headline: Is A.I. Already Taking Jobs? +A Filmmaker Tries Sora + The XZ Backdoor Caper
abstract: “I’ve always said if you have a ChatGPT subscription and a hose, you can get very far in this life.”
lead_paragraph: This week we look at how A.I. is affecting jobs. As companies start announcing A.I.-related job cuts and experimenting with customer service bots, economists are placing bets on whether A.I. will lead to major gains for companies and workers. Some are even predicting it will help rebuild the middle class.

headline: U.S. Employers Added 303,000 Jobs in 39th Straight Month of Growth
abstract: The March data increased confidence among economists and investors that robust hiring and rising wages can continue to coexist while inflation eases.
lead_paragraph: Another month, another burst of better-than-expected job gains.

headline: Women Who Made Art in Japanese Internment Camps Are Getting Their Due
abstract: A traveling exhibit will focus on the work of three Japanese American women artists, Hisako Hibi, Miki Hayakawa and Miné Okubo.
lead_paragraph: Ibuki Hibi Lee remembers waking up to the sounds of her mother’s paintbrush hitting the canvas in their small New York City apartment.

headline: After 6 Months of War, Some Israelis Ask: Is Netanyahu Dragging It Out?
abstract: Despite growing pressure from President Biden, the Israeli prime minister appears in no rush to end the war in Gaza. Some think he has political reasons for extending the stasis.
lead_paragraph: Nearly six months since it began, Israel’s war in Gaza is dragging on. So, too, is the tenure of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In Israel, some are now asking: Are the two linked?

headline: Israel Vows to Enable More Aid for Gaza; Blinken Says ‘Real Test Is Results’
abstract: Under pressure from President Biden, Israel said it would allow new aid routes into Gaza, but it remains to be seen when they will open or how much they will provide.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said that the United States was looking for “results” in response to news that Israel would open up more routes for aid to flow into Gaza.

headline: Inside the Biden-Netanyahu Phone Call, and a Narrowly Averted Cyberattack
abstract: Plus, the dangers of the Darién Gap.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: An Engineering Experiment to Cool the Earth
abstract: A new technology is attempting to brighten clouds and bounce some of the sun’s rays back into space.
lead_paragraph: Decades of efforts to cut carbon emissions have failed to significantly slow the rate of global warming, so scientists are now turning to bolder approaches.

headline: String of Israeli Errors Led to Fatal Attack on Aid Convoy, Military Says
abstract: “It’s a serious event that we’re responsible for, and it shouldn’t have happened,” Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari said of the strike that killed seven World Central Kitchen workers.
lead_paragraph: A series of Israeli failures, including a breakdown in communication and violations of the military’s own rules of engagement, led to the deadly airstrikes that killed seven humanitarian aid workers in Gaza this week, senior Israeli military officials said on Friday.

headline: The Rise of Sports Betting
abstract: Six years ago, sports betting was illegal under federal law. Today, it is everywhere.
lead_paragraph: In the coming days, the country’s best men’s and women’s college basketball teams will clash in the N.C.A.A. tournament finals. For fans, these are some of the biggest events of the year — a chance to see the best young athletes in the highest-stakes games. They are also some of the most lucrative events for sports betting apps. Americans will legally wager nearly $3 billion this year during March Madness, the American Gaming Association estimates.

headline: Thousands in New England Still Without Power After Spring Snowstorm
abstract: A nor’easter that dumped more than a foot of snow across the region, causing blackouts and flight cancellations, is expected to weaken on Friday, the National Weather Service said.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of customers were still without power in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont on Friday after a powerful storm system brought springtime snowfall to northern New England.

headline: Tensions Run High on Last Friday of Ramadan at Al Aqsa Mosque
abstract: The Israeli police said they arrested eight people at the compound in Jerusalem, where thousands of Muslim worshippers had come for dawn prayers amid heavy security.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli police said they arrested eight people at the Aqsa Mosque compound in Jerusalem, where thousands of Muslim worshippers had come for dawn prayers on the last Friday of Ramadan amid heavy security.

headline: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a true story of hope and persistence, and Timothée Chalamet’s recent turn as Willy Wonka.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, Anthony Madu’s dance teacher in Lagos, Nigeria, posted a video of the then 11-year-old student gracefully pirouetting and pulling off grand jetés barefoot in the rain. The video went viral, which led to Anthony receiving a scholarship to study at the prestigious Elmhurst Ballet School in England for seven years. This Disney documentary follows Anthony’s journey as he leaves his family to pursue his dream of becoming a professional dancer.

headline: Rising Oil Prices Reignite Inflation Fears
abstract: The price of Brent crude rose to a six-month high on Friday, a potential dose of bad news for central bankers and for the White House.
lead_paragraph: The price of Brent crude rose again on Friday, at one point topping $91 a barrel. Growing tensions in the Middle East have pushed the global benchmark to levels last reached in October.

headline: Is Larry David the Most Unsung Fashion Critic of Our Time?
abstract: The “Curb Your Enthusiasm” creator and star has been commenting on the human condition through people’s sartorial choices for decades.
lead_paragraph: In a midseries episode of “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” Larry David, the HBO show’s star and creator, greets his No. 1 frenemy, Susie, (Susie Essman), who has turned up at a fancy gathering wearing a top hat and a morning coat.

headline: After 6 months of war, some Israelis wonder if Netanyahu is dragging it out.
abstract: Nearly six months since it began, Israel’s war in Gaza is dragging on. So, too, is the tenure of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In Israel, some are now asking: Are the two linked?
lead_paragraph: Nearly six months since it began, Israel’s war in Gaza is dragging on. So, too, is the tenure of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. In Israel, some are now asking: Are the two linked?

headline: Harlem Was No Longer the Same After This Dinner Party
abstract: Harlem was synonymous with the arts. But what I didn’t know was how that had come to be.
lead_paragraph: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.

headline: Author Who Defected From North Korea Wins Defamation Lawsuit
abstract: Jang Jin-sung​, known for his memoir “Dear Leader,” was accused of rape by a fellow North Korean defector. He sued her and a South Korean broadcaster and won.
lead_paragraph: An author who defected from North Korea has won a defamation lawsuit that he filed in South Korea against a fellow defector who accused him of rape and the broadcaster that first reported her allegations.

headline: New York to Pay $17.5 Million for Forcing Removal of Hijabs in Mug Shots
abstract: New York City reached a settlement in a lawsuit brought by two women who were arrested and made to remove their head coverings by the police before being photographed.
lead_paragraph: New York City has agreed to pay $17.5 million to settle a lawsuit filed by two women who said their rights were violated when they were forced to remove their hijabs before the police took their arrest photographs.

headline: A’s Move to Sacramento Puts the City in an Unfamiliar Sports Role
abstract: The Major League Baseball team says it will move to the capital region from Oakland for at least three years.
lead_paragraph: Sports fans in Sacramento suddenly find themselves playing the unfamiliar role of villain.

headline: Lou Whittaker, Mountain Adventurer and Entrepreneur, Dies at 95
abstract: While his identical twin was the first American to summit Everest, he was best known  for his devotion to Mount Rainier, the peak of their youth.
lead_paragraph: Lou Whittaker, a patriarch of the nation’s foremost mountaineering family, who helped to make climbing broadly accessible by building a trusted guide company and creating a tourism industry on Mount Rainier, died on March 24 in Ashford, Wash., a town at the base of that mountain. He was 95.

headline: Yellen Faces Diplomatic Test in Urging China to Curb Green Energy Exports
abstract: The United States wants to persuade China to dial back its green energy industrial strategy as the Biden administration subsidizes its own supply chain.
lead_paragraph: After three hours of meetings on Friday, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen and Vice Premier He Lifeng of China sat down for a working dinner at the White Swan Hotel in Guangzhou, China. They planned to follow that with a scenic boat cruise along the city’s Pearl River.

headline: Opposition to Muslim Judicial Nominee Leaves Biden With a Tough Choice
abstract: Adeel Mangi would be the first Muslim American to be a federal appeals court judge, but has faced vitriolic attacks from the G.O.P. The president could run out of time to fill the seat.
lead_paragraph: The nomination of the first Muslim American to a federal appeals court judgeship is in deep trouble in the Senate, leaving President Biden with a painful choice between withdrawing the name of Adeel Mangi or trying to overcome the opposition at the risk of losing the chance to fill the crucial post before the November elections.

headline: What to Know About R.F.K. Jr. and His Threat to Biden and Trump
abstract: Mr. Kennedy has become the most prominent independent or third-party presence in the 2024 race.
lead_paragraph: The independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has emerged as a wild card of the 2024 election, attracting a motley mix of ideologically diverse supporters, raising piles of cash and drawing legal attacks from Democrats and verbal barrages from former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: You Can Still Smoke in Atlantic City Casinos. Workers Want to Ban It.
abstract: The New Jersey casinos are the last large refuge for smokers in the Northeast, but some employees say their health is at risk.
lead_paragraph: Atlantic City casino workers have tried unsuccessfully for years to persuade New Jersey lawmakers to outlaw smoking on gambling floors. On Friday morning, they took their efforts to court.

headline: Melania Trump Plans to Appear at a Mar-a-Lago Fund-Raiser This Month
abstract: The former first lady is set to attend an event for the Log Cabin Republicans, marking a return of sorts to the political arena.
lead_paragraph: Melania Trump, who has been mostly absent from public view while her husband, Donald J. Trump, campaigns for president this year, will appear at a fund-raiser at Mar-a-Lago on April 20 for the Log Cabin Republicans, the group’s president said.

headline: The Bumpy Gourd That’s Winning Over Bartenders
abstract: In bars from Hong Kong to Vancouver, the medicinal tang of bitter melon is making its way onto drinks menus.
lead_paragraph: Austin Hennelly, the 35-year-old bar director at Kato, a Taiwanese restaurant in Los Angeles, likens tasting bitter melon to “going down the drop of a roller coaster.” Sipping the fruit’s juice — which is the star ingredient in his Garden Tonic, a mocktail he considers the best drink on Kato’s menu — is, he says, “a little bit unpleasant and maybe a little bit scary, but it’s exhilarating, and then you just want to do it again.”

headline: What to Know When You’ve Felt an Earthquake
abstract: And what else to be aware of when the Earth moves.
lead_paragraph: If you just felt the ground shaking, you might be wondering what happened or how to react the next time an earthquake strikes. Here are the answers to some common questions about earthquakes.

headline: McDonald’s to Buy Back 225 Franchised Outlets in Israel After Boycotts
abstract: The move highlighted deepening political rifts for multinational corporations in the region and followed boycotts after the chain’s Israeli franchise owner donated meals to soldiers.
lead_paragraph: McDonald’s said it would buy back all of its 225 franchised restaurants in Israel, weeks after the company warned that boycotts and protests over the Israel-Hamas war had hurt its business in the Middle East.

headline: Go All-In on Detroit-Style Pizza
abstract: It’s hard to resist the charred and cheesy edges, a thick and chewy crust and a reverse order of toppings.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Spring’s sprung and I’m back on the pizza beat after a few months of wintry downtime. What that means: I’m feeding my sourdough starter more regularly. I’ll use it for dough I’ll proof for days and days. And then I’ll spin up some margheritas as a warm-up exercise while I contemplate what pizza obsession I’m going to take up for the rest of the year.

headline: How to Photograph a Solar Eclipse
abstract: There's a right way to do it.
lead_paragraph: There's a right way to do it.

headline: Larry David’s Rule Book for How (Not) to Live in Society
abstract: He’s a wild, monomaniacal jerk. He’s also our greatest interpreter of American manners since Emily Post.
lead_paragraph: Suppose you’re out at brunch and find yourself in a buffet line that a fellow diner does not appear to have noticed. He casually approaches with his plate and tries to serve himself. Do you A. join the hangry mob cursing him or B. rise to this man’s defense, because you can see that he’s holding a plate, which means he already waited in line and is now returning for another helping? If you’re Larry David, not only is the answer B. but the misunderstanding warrants, in your scratchy Brooklyn accent, a triumphant clarification: “That’s not how we do things here in America! We don’t wait for seconds! Never!”

headline: Review: A Conductor’s Philharmonic Debut Is a Homecoming
abstract: Karina Canellakis, a born-and-raised New Yorker, led her hometown orchestra alongside another debut, of the pianist Alice Sara Ott.
lead_paragraph: Recently, there has been more speculation than usual about the future of American orchestras. This week, the 28-year-old conductor Klaus Mäkelä became the youngest music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, and there are openings at a number of the highest-profile ensembles in the country — especially after Esa-Pekka Salonen announced his departure from the San Francisco Symphony in March.

headline: Is Soccer’s Model Club Actually … Real Madrid?
abstract: The club is strutting into a future different from the one envisioned by its president, Florentino Pérez. But its prospects are as bright as ever.
lead_paragraph: Florentino Pérez had a contented smile on his face, and with good reason. He had just watched Spain and Brazil share a thrilling, freewheeling draw at the stadium he has expensively, lavishly, reappointed. Now, Pérez, Real Madrid’s all-powerful president, found himself in a whitewashed tunnel, presented — completely by chance, obviously — with his favorite kind of photo opportunity.

headline: Map: 4.8-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes New Jersey
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and its aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and its aftershocks.

headline: Beyond the Beer Fridge: What Does Your Man Cave Mean to You?
abstract: Times Opinion asks readers to share what makes their man cave retreats special to them.
lead_paragraph: It evokes, in the most rudimentary sense, beer fridges and car parts, Super Bowl ads and maybe even Jerry Seinfeld’s bachelor pad, where he displayed his 17 favorite cereal boxes on a shelf. It’s the man cave: punchline, poker hub and perennial source of masculine escape.

headline: Israeli Helicopter Fire Probably Killed a Hostage Grandmother on Oct. 7, Military Says
abstract: An inquiry found that a combat helicopter had “fired at a vehicle that had terrorists in it” but also, “in retrospect,” hostages.
lead_paragraph: A grandmother taken captive during the Oct. 7 attack on Israel probably was killed when an Israeli helicopter, responding to the Hamas-led assault, fired on the vehicle in which she was being held, Israel’s military said on Friday.

headline: Can You Get Bird Flu From Milk and Eggs?
abstract: Here’s what we know — and don’t know — about the risk the virus poses in food.
lead_paragraph: A strain of avian influenza that has killed millions of birds in recent years has now been detected in dairy cows in several states, prompting concerns about the safety of the U.S. dairy supply.

headline: Chappell Roan’s Eye-Roll Kiss-Off, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Prince, Young Miko, the Black Keys and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: The Era of Klaus Mäkelä, Conducting Phenom, Begins in Chicago
abstract: On Thursday, the richly talented 28-year-old maestro led the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for the first time since being named its next music director.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening, when Klaus Mäkelä came onstage to lead the Chicago Symphony Orchestra for the first time since being named its next music director, he seemed at pains not to bask in the roar that greeted his entrance.

headline: Thursday in the Park With Bigfoot
abstract: A publicity effort for the movie “Sasquatch Sunset” had one of the film’s cast members in full sasquatch costume, wandering through Central Park.
lead_paragraph: If you were near the Ramble in Central Park on Thursday afternoon, you might have thought you were in a “Planet of the Apes”-themed episode of “What Would You Do?”

headline: Earthquake Shakes X Awake
abstract: For a brief, quaky moment, the social media platform was atwitter.
lead_paragraph: In the olden days, before it was X and before many users decamped to alternative social media platforms, Twitter was the place to be for a collective experience. Election updates! Weather events! That time Oprah interviewed Meghan Markle! Whether these moments were fun or terrifying or both, the site was where millions of people went to ask “What’s happening?”

headline: Making Films About Outsiders, Increasingly in the Mainstream
abstract: Goran Stolevski, who is from North Macedonia and grew up partly in Australia, has made three features in three years, all teeming with unruly emotion.
lead_paragraph: Periods of personal crisis have often yielded writing sprees for Goran Stolevski,  a Macedonian filmmaker who has made three critically acclaimed features in three years.

headline: In New York City, earthquakes are generally tiny, and unnoticed.
abstract: The magnitude-4.8 earthquake recorded in Whitehouse Station, N.J., that shook buildings across the New York City region on Friday morning, though, was an unsettling reminder of the fault lines that run through the area.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers have felt tremors before.

headline: A Look at How Earthquakes Are Measured
abstract: Earthquake strength is registered on the moment magnitude scale, which measures how much energy was released when the rocks along a fault moved during the quake.
lead_paragraph: Earthquake strength is registered on what is called the moment magnitude scale, which measures how much energy was released when the rocks along a fault moved during the quake. The magnitude is calculated using data from a network of instruments, called seismometers, that record the energy spreading from the quake’s origin in the form of waves of ground movement.

headline: F.B.I. Examining Free Airfare Upgrades Received by Adams
abstract: Federal prosecutors and F.B.I. agents are scrutinizing international flights taken by Mayor Eric Adams of New York aboard Turkey’s national air carrier, Turkish Airlines.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities investigating Mayor Eric Adams’s campaign fund-raising have been examining valuable flight upgrades they believe he received from Turkish Airlines that elevated him to its highest class of seats available on international trips, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a twisty Argentine thriller, a gutting Syrian documentary, a movie about a queer club in China and more.
lead_paragraph: The sleek suspense of a mob thriller and the big, dramatic swings of a telenovela combine to produce something truly unpredictable in “Rest in Peace,” by the Argentine director Sebastián Borensztein. We first meet Sergio (Joaquín Furriel), a handsome business owner and beloved husband and father, as he’s tearing up at his daughter’s lavish bat mitzvah; in moments, the mood shifts, when he spots a menacing stranger eyeing him from a corner and faints. As his wife, Estela (Griselda Siciliani), soon discovers, Sergio is drowning in debt and facing threats from a mysterious, ruthless lender. Their picture-perfect existence is on the verge of shattering — and then it does, albeit not how either of them (or the viewer) might have expected.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Officials Deploy Aggressive Use of Force (on Social Media)
abstract: The department’s leaders frequently go on X to upbraid police critics, from media columnists to elected officials, in a departure from protocol.
lead_paragraph: A newspaper columnist was accused of being “deceitful.” A lawyer and political activist was challenged to show her face at the funeral of a fallen officer. And a city councilwoman became the target of an apparent “vote her out” campaign.

headline: Some Colleges Will Soon Charge $100,000 a Year. How Did This Happen?
abstract: Some Vanderbilt students will have $100,000 in total expenses for the 2024-25 school year. The school doesn’t really want to talk about it.
lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of time before a college would have the nerve to quote its cost of attendance at nearly $100,000 a year. This spring, we’re catching our first glimpse of it.

headline: Gazans Describe Search for Food and Wonder If It Will Get Worse
abstract: The charity food group World Central Kitchen suspended its relief efforts after seven of its workers were killed in Israeli airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: On most mornings before the war, Suhail Al-Asaad, a body builder, could be found at his kitchen counter in Gaza City, eating an omelet of eight egg whites before speed-walking along the waterfront and heading to the gym to lift weights.

headline: The Birth Dearth and the Smartphone Age
abstract: Can we make our phones serve a family-friendly society rather than undermine childhood?
lead_paragraph: My newsroom colleagues Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani have a lovely report this week about family-friendly policies in the Italian province of Alto Adige-South Tyrol, which has the highest birthrate of any region in an aging, depopulating Italy.

headline: Body of Third Victim in Bridge Collapse Is Recovered, Officials Say
abstract: Divers found the body of Maynor Yasir Suazo Sandoval, one of the six workers who went missing in the collapse. Three others remain unaccounted for.
lead_paragraph: The body of a third construction worker who died in the catastrophic collapse of the Francis Scott Key bridge in Baltimore was found on Friday morning, officials said.

headline: Outrage Over Slain Aid Workers Deepens Democratic Resistance to Arming Israel
abstract: There is strong bipartisan support for aiding Israel in Congress, but the concerns among Democrats could further bog down an already stalled security aid package for Ukraine and Israel.
lead_paragraph: Outrage over a strike by the Israeli military that killed seven aid workers in Gaza has supercharged resistance among congressional Democrats to sending arms and fresh military funding to Israel.

headline: Sensible Ways to Fight Terrorism
abstract: Responses to a guest essay about ISIS and the West. Also: The Northeast quake; R.F.K. Jr.’s claim of “censorship”; obstacles to liberalism; valuing care jobs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Is Bird Flu Coming to People Next? Are We Ready?
abstract: Unlike the coronavirus, the H5N1 virus has been studied for years. Vaccines and treatments are available should they ever become necessary.
lead_paragraph: Bird flu outbreaks among dairy cows in multiple states, and at least one infection in farmworker in Texas, have incited fears that the virus may be the next infectious threat to people.

headline: Near the Epicenter, the Earthquake Rattled Plates and Nerves
abstract: Some drivers said they were on the road and initially thought they were having car trouble; others said it felt like a bomb.
lead_paragraph: At the Spinning Wheel Diner in Lebanon, N.J., near the epicenter of the earthquake, the servers first heard the china loudly rattling on the metal kitchen shelves.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The hosts briefly discussed the upcoming solar eclipse but spent most of the week on news related to former President Trump, including his media company’s stock tanking after an early surge.
lead_paragraph: The hosts briefly discussed the upcoming solar eclipse but spent most of the week on news related to former President Trump, including his media company’s stock tanking after an early surge.

headline: An Effort to End ‘Judge-Shopping’ Turns Into a ‘Political Firestorm’
abstract: A policy meant to prevent plaintiffs from steering their cases to sympathetic judges has drawn widespread attention, with both Republicans and Democrats accusing each other of politicizing the judiciary.
lead_paragraph: When the Judicial Conference, the national policy-making body of the federal courts, announced last month that plaintiffs would no longer be able to engage in “judge-shopping” — choosing to file major lawsuits at courthouses where they could be sure that a sympathetic judge would hear them — the policy sounded like a done deal.

headline: The Big Number: $2.5 Billion
abstract: When Trump Media began public trading in late March, its stock surged. But this past week, its fortunes turned and the stock slumped.
lead_paragraph: When Trump Media began public trading in late March, its stock surged. But this past week, its fortunes turned and the stock slumped.

headline: With ‘Succession’ Complete, the Roys’ Next Takeover Is the Stage
abstract: Audiences are flocking to shows with Jeremy Strong, Sarah Snook and other alums of the acclaimed HBO series.
lead_paragraph: There seems to be a secret ingredient to stage success this season: a stint on “Succession.”

headline: Why did New York City’s earthquake alert take 26 minutes?
abstract: The administration of Mayor Eric Adams received criticism for taking nearly thirty minutes to send its first alert.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-six minutes.

headline: A Solar Eclipse Soundtrack
abstract: Songs from TV on the Radio, Brian Eno, Julianna Barwick and others than could well accompany the celestial event on Monday.
lead_paragraph: As you have probably heard, on Monday most people in the United States will be able to witness a solar eclipse that will plunge an ordinary afternoon into otherworldly darkness. Such events require planning. Where are you going to watch the eclipse? Who are you going to watch it with? And, most crucially for Amplifier purposes, what will you listen to during it?

headline: Sami Michael, Israeli Novelist With Arabic Roots, Dies at 97
abstract: A refugee from Iraq, he explored in popular books the worlds of Jews living in Arabic countries or who fled persecution, and of Arabs living in Israel.
lead_paragraph: Sami Michael, an Iraqi-born Israeli writer whose novels illuminate the world of Jews from Arabic countries and the prejudices and discrimination that they, as well as Israeli Arabs, have experienced, died on Monday in Haifa, the mixed Jewish-Arab city in Israel where he lived. He was 97.

headline: How Much Damage Might a Big Earthquake Do to N.Y.C. Buildings?
abstract: The earthquake on Friday may have felt like a few light shakes to city residents. It most likely would have been much different if the epicenter was closer.
lead_paragraph: For New York City residents, the earthquake on Friday might have felt like just a few light shakes. But if an earthquake of greater magnitude were to strike much closer to the city, the risk of serious damage could be relatively high.

headline: Israel and U.S. Are on Alert for Iran to Strike Back at Israel
abstract: The Israeli airstrike this week in Damascus that killed seven Iranian commanders was an unusually harsh blow, and officials say Iran is determined to respond, raising fears of a war.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Israel-Hamas war and the Middle East crisis.

headline: Howard Atlee, Showman Who Promoted Dramas and Dogs, Dies at 97
abstract: As a press agent, he had his first big hit with “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” In dog competitions, his first big hit was a dachshund named Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Howard Atlee, an eclectic publicist who represented award-winning shows during a now bygone Broadway era and, as an avocation, also bred dachshunds that won best in show at dog competitions, died on March 15 in Silver Spring, Md. He was 97.

headline: Biden Will Try Again to Wipe Out Student Loan Debt for Millions of Borrowers
abstract: The Supreme Court blocked President Biden’s first attempt at large-scale student debt relief last summer.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will announce a new effort on Monday to reduce or eliminate student loan debt for millions of borrowers, an election-year attempt to revive his goal of providing large-scale relief for Americans struggling to pay off their college loans, a person familiar with the plan said Friday.

headline: How to Claim Your Part of a $45 Million Walmart Settlement
abstract: A class-action lawsuit accusing the retail giant of inflating prices of certain weighed foods and produce resulted in a settlement. Customers may be eligible for a payment of up to $500.
lead_paragraph: Some Walmart customers may be entitled to claim up to $500 as part of a $45 million settlement that the retail giant is paying to resolve a class-action lawsuit, according to a settlement administrator’s website.

headline: Longtime Journalist Bob Schieffer Bares His Soul in a New Art Exhibition
abstract: Mr. Schieffer, the former CBS newsman, has taken up painting in his retirement. His work will be seen at the American University Museum in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Bob Schieffer retired from the anchor desk nearly a decade ago, but he never walked away from the news.

headline: Does My Cousin Get a Say in Whether I Have a DNA Test?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on familial duty, genetic ancestry testing and privacy.
lead_paragraph: I was recently at a family gathering and, in the course of the conversation, casually mentioned that I had always wanted to take a DNA test and find out more about the background of our family history. When I said that, my cousin reacted strongly, saying that she didn’t want any family member to take one and have their DNA in the hands of an organization or government that might use it with malicious intent. She feels uncomfortable with having related DNA in the system, because she worries this data will somehow triangulate back to her. She has not committed any crimes, but for her this is a serious privacy issue. My family is small, and my cousin has always been my closest family member. We speak several times a week, so taking the test and hiding it from her feels wrong, but I’m not sure if her wishes in this case override mine. How much am I required to consider her feelings about this? — Name Withheld

headline: If A.I. Takes All Our Jobs, Will It Also Take Our Purpose?
abstract: Life without problems to solve sounds great until it starts sounding awful.
lead_paragraph: What would life be like if artificial intelligence solved all your problems? You wouldn’t have to work anymore. You could get any luxury you wanted by raising an eyebrow. Feelings of pleasure would wash over you constantly. Death would become almost optional because you could take on digital form and keep going for a billion years.

headline: In the End, ‘The New Look’ Left Us Wanting More
abstract: More Dior. More Chanel. More fashion!
lead_paragraph: The last episode of “The New Look,” the Apple TV+ series about Christian Dior, Coco Chanel and the birth of post-World War II fashion, aired on April 4. A fictional take on the choices those designers had to make to survive, the show offered its own new look, not just at the origin story of a dress style, but at the actual characters behind the brands. Here, the Styles editor Stella Bugbee and the fashion critic Vanessa Friedman debate the possible repercussions for the two dominant red carpet names.

headline: U.K. Lawmaker Admits Giving Out Colleagues’ Numbers in ‘Honey Trap’ Scandal
abstract: William Wragg said he had been scared that a man he met on the Grindr dating app had “compromising things” on him, and apologized for causing “hurt.”
lead_paragraph: The messages targeted politicians, advisers and journalists, and even if some of them struggled to remember ever having met the sender, the texts had accurate personal information. Soon, they became flirtatious. Some came with an explicit image.

headline: Some of Trump’s Biggest Political Backers Also Threw Trump Media a Lifeline
abstract: Two billionaires, a wealthy election denier and a mysterious Russia-linked trust invested in the Trump company long before it went public.
lead_paragraph: Marty Davis, the wealthy Minnesota head of a kitchen countertop manufacturing company, is a steadfast supporter of former President Donald J. Trump. He contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to help elect Mr. Trump in 2020, and encouraged him to fight to overturn the 2020 election results.

headline: New Report Reveals N.Y.C. Areas Most Hurt by Environmental Inequities
abstract: The project uses census data and an interactive map to identify areas with high levels of pollution and other socioeconomic risks.
lead_paragraph: A new report from the Mayor’s Office of Climate & Environmental Justice digs deep into the social inequities that contribute to environmental problems in New York City neighborhoods.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Nilay Patel
abstract: The April 5, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Nilay Patel. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Was Today’s Earthquake Connected to the Solar Eclipse?
abstract: The tidal forces on Earth grow as the sun, moon and Earth begin to align, a configuration that can lead to a solar eclipse. But the results of several studies of the relationship between earthquakes and tides are inconclusive, a geophysicist said.
lead_paragraph: With a total solar eclipse set to pass through the United States on Monday, it is easy to imagine a linkage between unusual events in the heavens and on Earth. But geoscientists were cautious about making such a connection.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, April 6, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Barbie, the Book
abstract: A bookstore event for the newly published “Barbie: The World Tour” brought out the die-hards.
lead_paragraph: Some 200 Barbie fans braved a hard rain on Wednesday evening as they made their way to the Rizzoli bookstore in Manhattan for the release of a coffee-table book celebrating the doll’s fashion history.

headline: Will There Be Another Earthquake? Here’s the Forecast for Aftershocks.
abstract: So far, seismologists have not identified any distinguishing characteristics of a given quake that would warn of an impending larger one.
lead_paragraph: Will the ground around Whitehouse Station, N.J., continue to shake in the coming days? Almost certainly.

headline: Lynne Reid Banks, Author of ‘The Indian in the Cupboard,’ Dies at 94
abstract: She explored the struggles of young women in the novel “The L-Shaped Room” but found her biggest success with a children’s book about a magical cupboard.
lead_paragraph: Lynne Reid Banks, a versatile British author who began her writing career with the best-selling feminist novel “The L-Shaped Room” but found her biggest success with the popular children’s book “The Indian in the Cupboard,” died on Thursday in Surrey, England. She was 94.

headline: Trump-Kennedy 2024? Trump, at Least, Is Intrigued by the Idea.
abstract: The former president has privately floated the idea of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. as a running mate. Those close to him do not see it as a serious possibility, however, and Mr. Kennedy said he would not consider it.
lead_paragraph: Would a merger between Mar-a-Lago and Camelot prove irresistible for American voters?

headline: Earthquake Rattles New York and New Jersey, but Does Little Damage
abstract: An earthquake struck the Northeast on Friday, rippling from Philadelphia to Boston.
lead_paragraph: At a general store in New Jersey, near the epicenter of the earthquake, the sound was so loud that the staff thought a truck had crashed into the building.

headline: Cardi B Spars With an Influencer Over Colorism and Brand Deals
abstract: The rapper exchanged heated remarks with the social media personality Raymonte Cole after he suggested that her skin color was the reason brands consider her “marketable.”
lead_paragraph: The rapper Cardi B found herself embroiled in a sharp back-and-forth with a social media personality this week after he brought up her social class, upbringing and skin color. A quarrel soon erupted over colorism and questions of who gets to profit over which public affect.

headline: Should You Stand in a Doorway During an Earthquake? (Probably Not.)
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams urged New Yorkers to take cover under a piece of furniture or in a doorway during an earthquake. But experts say doorways are not the best option.
lead_paragraph: When an earthquake rattled New York City on Friday, Mayor Eric Adams advised New Yorkers to take cover under a piece of furniture or in a doorway if there were aftershocks.

headline: What Should I Wear for the Eclipse?
abstract: Silver sneakers? A spacesuit? Our fashion critic advises a reader on how to dress in theme for a coming eclipse party.
lead_paragraph: It’s human instinct, when celebrating a total solar eclipse — a magical moment of real darkness in the middle of the afternoon — to want to dress for the occasion. It’s a way of marking its importance and making a memory, along with uttering cool phrases like “the path of totality.”

headline: Talking 50 Years of Stephen King
abstract: On this week’s podcast, we talk to the novelist Grady Hendrix and TV showrunner Damon Lindelof about the work and influence of Stephen King.
lead_paragraph: This month marks the 50th anniversary of the publication of Stephen King’s first novel, “Carrie.” In our original review of the book, the crime columnist Newgate Callendar (actually the music critic Harold Schonberg writing under a pseudonym) wrote, “That this is a first novel is amazing. King writes with the kind of surety normally associated only with veteran writers.”

headline: How an Earthquake Can Throw the Body and Brain Off-Balance
abstract: People can experience dizziness, anxiety and even “phantom” aftershocks following a quake.
lead_paragraph: Earthquakes are always unnerving. But for some, the aftershocks can go on beyond the actual tremors: People can experience anxiety, sleep problems and other health issues in the hours and days after a quake.

headline: In Threatening Israel, Biden Hopes to Avoid a Rupture
abstract: The president has put Israel’s leader “on probation,” as a veteran diplomat put it. The threat is not idle, aides said, but he wants to force a course correction rather than follow through.
lead_paragraph: By the time President Biden hung up the phone, he had finally delivered the threat he had refused to make for months: Israel had to change course, he told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, or the United States would.

headline: Justice Department Says It Will Reopen Inquiry Into Realtor Trade Group
abstract: On Friday, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia made a ruling that opens the door for a renewed investigation into the National Association of Realtors.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department will reopen an antitrust investigation into the National Association of Realtors, an influential trade group that has held sway over the residential real estate industry for decades. The investigation will focus on whether the group’s rules inflate the cost of selling a home.

headline: U.S. Seeks ‘Results’ After Israel Promises More Gaza Aid Routes
abstract: World leaders welcomed the shift by an Israel facing increasing pressure, but they stressed that the measure of success would be whether enough trucks get in to ease the humanitarian crisis.
lead_paragraph: World leaders and humanitarian groups said on Friday that Israel must show concrete results after it reacted to growing pressure from the United States by announcing it would open more aid routes into the Gaza Strip, where the United Nations has warned that a famine is looming.

headline: An Overlooked Championship Team’s Final Stop: The White House
abstract: The all-Black Tennessee A&I basketball team won three back-to-back national championships at the height of the Jim Crow era, but were never invited to the White House. That changed on Friday.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris greeted Dick Barnett on Friday, he was concise in his response.

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Calls to Investigate Potential Wrongdoing Against Jan. 6 Rioters
abstract: Mr. Kennedy’s campaign again expressed sympathy for the “harsh treatment” of those who rioted at the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, after retracting a similar statement a day earlier.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the vaccine skeptic running for president as an independent candidate, vowed to appoint a special counsel to investigate the Justice Department’s effort to prosecute those who rioted at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, if he is elected, again downplaying the severity of the attack on the Capitol.

headline: An Earthquake Startled the Northeast
abstract: Also, Israel disciplined officers for aid worker killings. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: A 4.8-magnitude earthquake sent tremors from Philadelphia to Boston this morning, rattling New York City skyscrapers and surprising many East Coasters. Some ran out of their homes. Others hung on to a piece of furniture for dear life. Air traffic was briefly halted. But no major damage has been reported.

headline: Margaret Tynes, Soprano Who Soared in Verdi and Strauss, Dies at 104
abstract: Because there were few opportunities for Black singers in the U.S., she began performing in Europe, where she was praised for her work in “Tosca,” “Carmen” and other operas.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Tynes, an American soprano who was acclaimed in Europe but neglected in the United States at a time when Black singers were newly breaking into the operatic world, died on March 7 in Silver Spring, Md. She was 104.

headline: New Questions on How a Key Agency Shared Inflation Data
abstract: A government economist had regular contact with “super users” in finance, records show, at a time when such information keenly interests investors.
lead_paragraph: The Bureau of Labor Statistics shared more information about inflation with Wall Street “super users” than previously disclosed, emails from the agency show. The revelation is likely to prompt further scrutiny of the way the government shares economic data at a time when such information keenly interests investors.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Workers in Alabama Ask for Unionization Vote
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union is mounting its most ambitious effort to gain an industry foothold beyond Detroit’s Big Three.
lead_paragraph: Workers at a Mercedes-Benz factory in Alabama have petitioned federal officials to hold a vote on whether to join the United Automobile Workers, the union said on Friday, a step forward for its drive to organize workers at car factories in the South.

headline: Martha Stewart Has ‘Never-Ending Curiosity’ (And a Few Regrets.)
abstract: At 82, the entrepreneur and media mogul isn’t slowing down.

headline: Betye Saar Is Making Some of the Best Work of Her Life
abstract: At 97, the artist still greets every day eager to create.
lead_paragraph: Being raised during the Depression, we all learned to be creative with what we had on hand. At Christmas or on my birthday, I always got art supplies, and I was jealous that my siblings got bikes and stuff. I realize now that my parents were fostering my creativity.

headline: Giorgio Armani Doesn’t Think Much About Age
abstract: At 89, the fashion designer and chief executive of Armani Group is having a renaissance.

headline: Joan Collins Refuses to Be Defined by Age
abstract: At 90, the actress and writer has published a memoir and is preparing for a theatrical tour.
lead_paragraph: I love writing, I love acting, going onstage and doing my little one-woman show, and I refuse to be defined by a number, by an age. I think that’s terribly old-fashioned and not relevant in today’s world.

headline: ‘Zone of Interest’ Oscars Speech Is Defended by Jewish Film Artists
abstract: Remarks about Israel that the director Jonathan Glazer made as he accepted an Oscar for “The Zone of Interest” drew a letter of support after facing criticism last month.
lead_paragraph: More than 150 Jewish actors, filmmakers and other artists signed an open letter that was published on Friday in defense of remarks about Jewishness and the war in Gaza that the director Jonathan Glazer made in his Oscars acceptance speech for “The Zone of Interest,” his film about the Holocaust.

headline: When Food, War and Politics Collide
abstract: It is usually an afterthought in politics, but the power of food was made clear this week.
lead_paragraph: The deadly Israeli strike on an aid convoy that killed seven workers for the relief group World Central Kitchen in the Gaza Strip shook official Washington this week. It prompted President Biden to issue his sharpest public criticism of Israel to date and spurred Israel’s military to make a rare admission of fault.

headline: Man Set Fire Outside Bernie Sanders’s Vermont Office, Police Say
abstract: The authorities are trying to identify an arsonist who struck outside the U.S. senator’s office in Burlington, Vt. No one was injured, and the senator was not there.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Vermont said they were searching for a man who started a fire outside Senator Bernie Sanders’s office in Burlington on Friday morning.

headline: The Condiment Wars Come for Chile Crisp (or Crunch)
abstract: David Chang’s Momofuku company is waging a trademark battle for the term “chile crunch.” But what does ownership mean for such an everyday pleasure?
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to pinpoint exactly when we reached peak chile crisp in the United States, but if you were to inspect my kitchen today you’d see, alongside an old jar of Lao Gan Ma — years ago, the only chile crisp I could easily find in the food shops nearby — at least a half-dozen others.

headline: Book It!
abstract: Find a comfortable spot to hunker down while we wrangle with Byron Walden’s tough themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is the third really gnarly Saturday grid in a row, which makes for a somewhat unsettling pattern. Maybe it’s part of the run-up to this weekend’s American Crossword Puzzle Tournament; maybe it’s another editor’s sadistic streak in Will Shortz’s absence. (What if they’re all like this from now on? It’ll keep this column and its commentariat in business, anyway).

headline: Quotation of the Day: Graffiti Goes From Eyesore to Asset
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Hipsters attract more hipsters who have more money and are able to start paying higher prices.”

headline: Corrections: April 6, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 6, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about simultaneous terrorist attacks by a separatist group in Iran misidentified the location of Sistan and Baluchestan Province, where the attacks occurred. It is in the southeast, not the southwest, of Iran.

headline: Challenged by Uprising, Myanmar Junta Cracks Down Harder
abstract: The country’s military rulers have signaled a new wave of detentions and, rights groups say, conditions for existing prisoners have deteriorated.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of innocent people killed. Tens of thousands more pro-democracy protesters locked up. The return of military rule has wreaked havoc in Myanmar in recent years.

headline: From the Horror to the Envy of Africa: Rwanda’s Leader Holds Tight Grip
abstract: Thirty years after a devastating genocide, Rwanda has made impressive gains. But ethnic divisions persist under an iron-fisted president who has ruled for just as long.
lead_paragraph: Blood coursed through the streets of Rwanda’s capital, Kigali, in April 1994 as machete-wielding militiamen began a campaign of genocide that killed as many as 800,000 people, one of the great horrors of the late 20th century.

headline: Why Time Is Running Out Across the Maldives’ Lovely Little Islands
abstract: Global tourism brought a modern economy to the country’s thousand islands. For many Maldivians, the teeming capital beckons.
lead_paragraph: To live in the Maldives is to live in one of two worlds. Either you belong to the capital — Malé, a micro-Manhattan in the Indian Ocean — or you are out in “the islands,” among the quietest and most remote villages this side of the Arctic tundra.

headline: Mexico Breaks Diplomatic Ties With Ecuador After Arrest at Embassy
abstract: Jorge Glas, a former vice president, had taken refuge at the Mexican Embassy in Ecuador’s capital. Mexico’s president called his arrest a violation of international law.
lead_paragraph: The Ecuadorean police on Friday night arrested a politician who had taken refuge in the Mexican Embassy in Quito, after what Mexico described as a forced entry that violated the country’s sovereignty.

headline: Our Reporter on a Case of Glaring Neglect on Rikers
abstract: In 2019, eight correction officers and a captain at Rikers Island stood by for seven minutes and 51 seconds as Nicholas Feliciano, an 18-year-old, was hanging in a jail cell, video footage obtained by The New York Times shows. Feliciano suffered severe brain damage and requires round-the-clock care. New York City paid more than $28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of Feliciano.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, eight correction officers and a captain at Rikers Island stood by for seven minutes and 51 seconds as Nicholas Feliciano, an 18-year-old, was hanging in a jail cell, video footage obtained by The New York Times shows. Feliciano suffered severe brain damage and requires round-the-clock care. New York City paid more than $28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of Feliciano.

headline: How Zach Cherry, Actor From ‘Severance,’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: Before he hits the stage for an improv show, Mr. Cherry cuddles with his rescue dog, Shrek, battles his wife in video games and heads to the movies.
lead_paragraph: Zach Cherry warns that his Sundays are “pretty boring” — with the caveat that boring, for him, means a wild, 90-minute improv comedy extravaganza of nerdy jokes.

headline: Arrests Expose Rift Between N.Y.P.D. and ‘Violence Interrupters’
abstract: An outreach worker trained to intervene in street conflicts was hospitalized after he and a colleague were arrested amid an altercation with the police.
lead_paragraph: For years, New York City has employed a two-pronged approach to reducing gun violence, relying on the police and on the publicly funded conflict mediators known as violence interrupters, who try to defuse disputes before they escalate, including into gunfire.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 300
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Orchid Show After Dark, Where Green Thumbs and Plant Killers Mingle
abstract: After hours, the New York Botanical Garden becomes the lushest bar in town.
lead_paragraph: It was Saturday night in the Bronx, and as a lively, colorful crowd sipped vodka cocktails underneath dramatic palm fronds, the word people kept whispering was “phalaenopsis.”

headline: New York City Set to Pay a Record $28 Million to Settle Rikers Island Suit
abstract: Eight correction officers and a captain stood by for seven minutes and 51 seconds as Nicholas Feliciano tried to hang himself in a jail cell in 2019.
lead_paragraph: New York City has agreed to pay more than $28 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the family of Nicholas Feliciano, who suffered severe brain damage after he attempted to hang himself in a Rikers Island jail cell as more than half a dozen correction officers stood by.

headline: U.S. Warns China About Its Exports and Support for Russia
abstract: Beijing’s economic policies threaten American workers, Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen told Vice Premier He Lifeng in the southern city of Guangzhou.
lead_paragraph: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen confronted her Chinese counterpart about China’s surging exports of inexpensive electric vehicles and other green energy goods, saying that they were a threat to American jobs and urging Beijing to scale back its industrial strategy, the U.S. government has said.

headline: How Tech Giants Cut Corners to Harvest Data for A.I.
abstract: OpenAI, Google and Meta ignored corporate policies, altered their own rules and discussed skirting copyright law as they sought online information to train their newest artificial intelligence systems.
lead_paragraph: In late 2021, OpenAI faced a supply problem.

headline: They Built Three Homes Together. Now She Must Do It Alone.
abstract: A husband’s sudden death gave a widow time to reflect on the designs of their second homes and how to make one on her own.
lead_paragraph: Sarah-Mai Miller and Heath Miller lived in 10 different houses and apartments in 17 years. The couple owned three of those houses — an 1800s saltbox in Greenport on Long Island and a modern cozy cabin and a glass cabin, both in a town called Milan in upstate New York.

headline: A Mother’s Devastating Memoir of Losing Her Adult Son
abstract: In “Fi,” Alexandra Fuller describes the sudden death of her 21-year-old.
lead_paragraph: Alexandra Fuller learned the art of denial from her gloriously dysfunctional parents. “‘Mum’s having a bit of a wobbly,’ Dad would explain, that dangerous British habit of underestimating the gravity of any given situation until you were eating the last sled dog and writing your final diary entries.”

headline: My Grandfather-in-Law, My Roommate
abstract: Life lessons from a 97-year-old lawyer of the old school.
lead_paragraph: My wife and I unexpectedly lost our Brooklyn lease in the summer of 2022. With preposterous rents all around us, we decided to save money and postpone our real estate predicament by moving, for one year, into her grandfather’s apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Teen Drug Use Habits Are Changing, For the Good. With Caveats.
abstract: Dr. Nora Volkow, who leads the National Institutes of Drug Abuse, would like the public to know things are getting better. Mostly.
lead_paragraph: Historically speaking, it’s not a bad time to be the liver of a teenager. Or the lungs.

headline: The Eclipse That Ended a War and Shook the Gods Forever
abstract: Thales, a Greek philosopher 2,600 years ago, is celebrated for predicting a famous solar eclipse and founding what came to be known as science.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 585 B.C. in the Eastern Mediterranean, the moon came out of nowhere to hide the face of the sun, turning day into night.

headline: Sickened by U.S. Nuclear Program, Communities Turn to Congress for Aid
abstract: In St. Louis and around the country, people harmed by the drive for an atomic bomb have been shut out of a federal law enacted to help such victims.
lead_paragraph: When Diane Scheig’s father, Bill, came home from work at the Mallinckrodt factory in St. Louis, he would strip down in their garage and hand his clothes to her mother to immediately wash, not daring to contaminate the house with the residue of his labors.

headline: A Fictional Haven So Idyllic You Don’t Even Need Money. What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: In “A Better World,” a family hoping to escape their dangerous reality gets invited to an exclusive town only to discover that it’s not as peaceful as it seems.
lead_paragraph: Early in Sarah Langan’s lively and satirical fifth novel, “A Better World,” a woman whose family has been handpicked to move to an idyllic small town begins to suspect that the place is too good to be true.

headline: When a Couple’s Paradise Honeymoon Became a Gothic Mystery
abstract: Scarlett Thomas’s latest novel, “The Sleepwalkers,” recounts the tale of a couple’s disastrous getaway, told through letters, transcripts and more.
lead_paragraph: My arguments on vacation have always been dreary — disagreements with my mom on how far to walk before setting up a beach umbrella, squabbles with friends over where to eat — but other people’s vacation arguments are sinister and seductive. Or at least they are in books, and especially in Scarlett Thomas’s 11th novel, “The Sleepwalkers,” as a couple’s trip abroad in a dazzling, dangerous territory (a landscape familiar from Highsmith and Hitchcock, “La Piscine” and Françoise Sagan) is derailed by latent tensions.

headline: A Frozen Pond and a New Way to Experience an Ancient Jewish Ritual in Maine
abstract: Students from Colby College helped harvest ice from a pond for a new mikvah, or ritual bath, at a synagogue in Waterville.
lead_paragraph: Standing on a frozen pond in western Maine one Sunday morning last month, wearing L.L. Bean boots and a hooded sweatshirt, Rabbi Rachel Isaacs paused to consecrate the ice beneath her feet before she commandeered it for a higher purpose.

headline: Pardoned for Serving in Ukraine, They Return to Russia to Kill Again
abstract: Recruiting convicts for its army has given Russia a manpower advantage. But it is backfiring in tragic ways when former inmates are pardoned and return home to commit new crimes.
lead_paragraph: Viktor Savvinov had already been imprisoned several times for various crimes — including robbery, auto theft and assault — when he murdered a female drinking companion during a quarrel in 2020, stabbing her in the chest with four knives.

headline: Fierce Races Loom With Wisconsin’s New Political Maps
abstract: The new legislative maps reflect a near split between Republican- and Democratic-leaning districts. For more than a decade, earlier maps had helped Republicans hold power.
lead_paragraph: Yee Leng Xiong, a 29-year-old nonprofit executive, has been an elected official in Wisconsin since he was a teenager. From a north central county known for ginseng farming and downhill skiing, he has served on the local school board, the Marathon County Board and the village board of trustees in Weston, population 15,000.

headline: Berlin Was a Beacon of Artistic Freedom. Gaza Changed Everything.
abstract: The home of boundary-pushing artists from around the world has been upended by debates about what can and can’t be said about Israel and the war.
lead_paragraph: When the musician Laurie Anderson was beginning her career in the early 1970s, an avant-garde artist who wanted to work at scale had to go abroad — to one place in particular.

headline: Four Takeaways on the Race to Amass Data for A.I.
abstract: To make artificial intelligence systems more powerful, tech companies need online data to feed the technology. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Online data has long been a valuable commodity. For years, Meta and Google have used data to target their online advertising. Netflix and Spotify have used it to recommend more movies and music. Political candidates have turned to data to learn which groups of voters to train their sights on.

headline: Charity Lawson Takes Us Inside New York Bridal Fashion Week
abstract: The former “Bachelorette” star, who met her fiancé Dotun Olubeko on Season 20 of ABC’s dating show, attended runway shows and dress fittings in preparation for her wedding next year.
lead_paragraph: Charity Lawson earned a reputation of being a sweetheart after starring in the 20th season of “The Bachelorette,” which ended in August with her engagement to Dotun Olubeko, an integrative medicine specialist.

headline: To Live Long and Prosper, Do What George Takei Does
abstract: For the “Star Trek” actor and author of the new children’s book “My Lost Freedom,” it’s all about green tea and antioxidants. “I drink it every day, all day. I am an addict,” he says.
lead_paragraph: When George Takei talks about his childhood, he speaks of both anguish and beauty.

headline: What to Know About Tech Companies Using A.I. to Teach Their Own A.I.
abstract: As artificial intelligence developers run out of data to train their models, they are turning to “synthetic data” — data made by the A.I. itself.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI, Google and other tech companies train their chatbots with huge amounts of data culled from books, Wikipedia articles, news stories and other sources across the internet. But in the future, they hope to use something called synthetic data.

headline: Pete Rose Cooperated With the Author of This Book Until He Didn’t
abstract: Keith O’Brien’s “Charlie Hustle” tracks the great ballplayer’s historic career and also tells a story involving gamblers, gangsters and drug addicts.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t easy mustering sympathy for Pete Rose. He was a compulsive gambler who bet on the team he managed, the Cincinnati Reds, then lied about it for years (he was also a compulsive liar). He had a sexual relationship with a teenage girl, and barely acknowledged the child he had with another woman out of wedlock. He was a self-pitying sore loser who abandoned friends once they were no longer useful to him, including the worshipful errand-runners who enabled his gambling habit. This is the Rose who emerges in Keith O’Brien’s new book, “Charlie Hustle: The Rise and Fall of Pete Rose, and the Last Glory Days of Baseball.” A mixture of disillusioned fan’s notes (the author grew up in Cincinnati, rooting for Rose during his prime playing days with the Reds in the 1960s and ’70s), investigative reportage and baseball history, the book paints a picture of an unchecked man-child with no desire to curb his appetites.

headline: As Gen X-ers Inch Toward Retirement, They’re Considering Where to Live
abstract: The oldest members of Generation X are several years from stopping work, but some are already seeking homes that will suit their later years.
lead_paragraph: When they were raising their four children, Billy and Erin Shipley had space for their family to grow: a two-story, five-bedroom house in Sugar Land, Texas, with a large yard and a pool. But as the children became adults and moved out, the second floor was deserted and maintaining the lawn and pool became a burden.

headline: Consumers Hate ‘Price Discrimination,’ but They Sure Love a Discount
abstract: The Wendy’s debacle is a warning shot for brands: If you want to play with prices, make sure to communicate why and whom it could help.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a strange and maddening couple of years for consumers, with prices of essential goods soaring and then sinking, turning household budgets upside down.

headline: I Hired an Agent to Sell My Home. Do I Have to Pay the Buyer’s Broker Now?
abstract: The legal settlements roiling the real estate industry are changing the way commissions get paid. But the change could come slowly.
lead_paragraph: Q: I recently signed a contract with Compass to have them represent me in the sale of my Manhattan apartment. The contract provides for a commission of 5 percent, which includes the commission for the buyer’s agent. Does the recent news about real estate commissions and which party pays them mean that I can demand to pay only 2.5 percent to Compass as my agent, and then negotiate with the buyer or the buyer’s agent regarding that person’s commission?

headline: Power by Proxy: How Iran Shapes the Mideast
abstract: A guide to the armed groups that let Iran extend its influence throughout the region.
lead_paragraph: A guide to the armed groups that let Iran extend its influence throughout the region.

headline: Why Are People Obsessed With TV Finales ‘Sticking the Landing’?
abstract: As “Curb Your Enthusiasm” gets ready to exit, it’s time to let go of the idea that a story’s ending determines its final score.
lead_paragraph: Larry David is just fine with how “Seinfeld” ended. OK, I can’t read his mind — but “Larry David,” the version of himself he plays on “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” is cool with that much-maligned finale. He insisted on it, vehemently, during a season of “Curb” that was almost entirely about a fictional do-over of the landmark sitcom he created with Jerry Seinfeld.

headline: Larry David Has Always Been the ‘Seinfeld’ Finale’s Biggest Defender
abstract: As “Curb Your Enthusiasm” draws to a close, the “Seinfeld” co-creator gets another shot at ending a TV show.
lead_paragraph: Larry David has long defended the “Seinfeld” finale. He’s often been its lone champion as critics, fans and the cast, including Jerry Seinfeld, have continued to lament the conclusion of one of television’s most successful, enduring sitcoms.

headline: Leonardo DiCaprio, Tracee Ellis Ross and Gayle King Hit New York Art Parties
abstract: This week, the New Museum gala drew a crowd to Lower Manhattan and the MoMA Black Arts Council mingled in Midtown, as the Spring benefit season kicked into gear.
lead_paragraph: Outside the Staten Island Ferry terminal in Lower Manhattan on Wednesday night, the wind was howling as broken umbrellas blew across South Street like urban tumbleweeds.

headline: How ‘All in the Family’ Explains Biden’s Strength Among Seniors
abstract: Yesterday’s hippies have become today’s seniors — and they’re still voting Democratic.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday’s hippies have become today’s seniors — and they’re still voting Democratic.

headline: 4 Expert Tips for Flaky Fish Every Time
abstract: In the fourth installment of her YouTube series, the cookbook author and chef Sohla El-Waylly will help you make the most flawless fish.
lead_paragraph: Sohla El-Waylly wants you to become an a-fish-ionado. That is, the kind of cook who turns out delicious, flaky fish every time, no matter the style: roasted, braised or battered and fried. In the latest installment of her YouTube series, Cooking 101, she’ll walk you through the best ways to shop for and cook this sometimes-intimidating protein.

headline: Your Solar Eclipse Soundtrack
abstract: Songs to put you in the mood.
lead_paragraph: This Monday a total solar eclipse will appear across much of North America. Our critics Wesley Morris, Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz put together a music playlist that’s a perfect accompaniment for watching the event.

headline: Biden Waves His First-Term Résumé at a Skeptical America
abstract: With increasing urgency, the president is trying to impress upon voters that he has accomplished quite a bit — even if they don’t see it in their lives yet.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is discovering that passing one of the most ambitious legislative agendas in recent American history may have been the easy part. Persuading Americans that he deserves a second term may be far more difficult.

headline: Gaza War Turns Spotlight on Long Pipeline of U.S. Weapons to Israel
abstract: President Biden sends arms to Israel under an Obama-era $38 billion aid agreement that runs until 2026. Israel’s purchases include the types of bombs dropped in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2016, the Obama administration sealed a major military agreement with Israel that committed the United States to giving the country $38 billion in arms over 10 years.

headline: Make Room, Tennis, Pickleball and Squash. Here Comes Padel.
abstract: The sport is played with a racket on a court with a net, but watch out for those bouncing shots from the back wall. Reporters take a look at the padel scene in New York City.
lead_paragraph: I first learned about padel last summer, when my partner sent me a photo from a small court during a visit to Germany.

headline: Canada’s Federal Budget Goes From Big Secret to ‘Roadshow’
abstract: Breaking with Canadian tradition, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has been crisscrossing the country announcing measures from the April 16 budget in advance.
lead_paragraph: Even for a country with a system of government that is prone to keeping things confidential, the secrecy that once surrounded federal budgets stood out.

headline: Iran vows revenge at a funeral for commanders killed in an Israeli airstrike.
abstract: There are precedents for a forceful response by Iran to the Israeli airstrike in Syria on Monday that killed senior commanders and other officers of Iran’s elite Quds Force.
lead_paragraph: There are precedents for a forceful response by Iran to the Israeli airstrike in Syria on Monday that killed senior commanders and other officers of Iran’s elite Quds Force.

headline: Eclipse Mania
abstract: There’s still reason to get excited, even if you’re not convinced by the hype.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the moon will steal between the Earth and the sun, a total solar eclipse in North America.
