The path of totality, the strip of the continent where the moon will completely obscure the sun, begins in Mazatlán, Mexico, crosses over more than a dozen U.S. states, from Texas to Maine, and ends in Newfoundland, Canada.

headline: Minor Crimes Division
abstract: Lessons learned, and not, from breaking the rules.
lead_paragraph: People taking it upon themselves to solve the tiny, overlooked crimes of the world.

headline: My Story Was Told in ‘Hotel Rwanda.’ Here’s What I Want the World to Know Now.
abstract: For me and for so many Rwandans, the 1994 genocide remains the focal point of my life.
lead_paragraph: This week, the world will again turn its eyes toward Rwanda. April 6 marks 30 years since the start of one of the most horrific events in modern history, the 1994 Rwandan genocide. Nearer in time but not unrelated, it has been just over one year since I left Rwanda and returned to the United States, released from prison after 939 days in captivity.

headline: Regulating Opioid Prescriptions
abstract: Pain management is an inexact science; there is plenty of blame to go around for the abuse of such drugs.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: You Don’t Just See a Total Solar Eclipse. You Feel It Completely.
abstract: An eclipse chaser makes the case for seeing the event in its totality.
lead_paragraph: Almost one year ago, in the middle of the night, I drove from my hometown, Belfast, Northern Ireland, to Dublin to catch an early morning flight to Munich. From there I caught another plane to Bangkok, another to Singapore and yet another to Perth in Western Australia. There, I rented a camper van and began a drive of more than 750 miles north to the town of Exmouth on a remote peninsula on the northwest coast of the continent.

headline: Joe Lieberman and David Mixner, Exemplary Outsiders
abstract: Their experience of being outsiders deeply affected their political worldviews and caused them to embrace the struggles of other excluded Americans as their own.
lead_paragraph: The gay activist David Mixner and Senator Joe Lieberman died last month at the ages of 77 and 82, and were it not for the coincident timing, I would have no reason to reflect collectively on their legacies. Biographically, ideologically and temperamentally, they were very different men and, to my knowledge, never interacted. But I was fortunate to know them both, and after attending their funerals last week, I’ve come to appreciate some important qualities they shared.

headline: How a Vacant Lot Became Our Own Dirtbag Narnia
abstract: In the Kensington neighborhood of Philadelphia, a group of neighbors made a makeshift community oasis.
lead_paragraph: On a quiet street in the Kensington neighborhood of Philadelphia, just a few steps from my back door, is a vacant lot that my wife, Anne, and I share with our neighbors. This patch of dirty ground was once three single-family homes. Bit by bit, rains have washed away the soil, revealing corners of the buildings’ foundations and the occasional broken brick and shard of glass.

headline: Help Ukraine Hold the Line
abstract: House Speaker Mike Johnson should allow an aid package for Ukraine to come to a vote.
lead_paragraph: After more than two years of brutal, unrelenting war, Ukraine is still ready and has the capacity to defend its democracy and territory against Russia. But it cannot do so without American military assistance, which the United States had assured the Ukrainians would be there as long as it was needed.

headline: The High-I.Q. Nonsense of Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
abstract: His inflated sense of his fitness to lead isn’t just delusional. It’s dangerous.
lead_paragraph: The hubris. The narcissism. The convenient and fraudulent anti-elitism. The out-of-his-mind theories presented as out-of-the-box thinking.

headline: Donald Trump’s Insatiable Bloodlust
abstract: Marjorie and Donald, trumpeting the end times.
lead_paragraph: An earthquake. An eclipse. A bridge collapse. A freak blizzard. A biblical flood. Donald Trump leading in battleground states.

headline: Can the Left Be Happy?
abstract: Comforted by neither God nor history, and hoping vaguely that therapy can take their place.
lead_paragraph: A crucial moment in the development of modern left-wing culture arrived some time in 2013, when Ta-Nehisi Coates, reading books about the ravages and aftermath of World War II by the historians Tony Judt and Timothy Snyder, realized that he didn’t believe in God.

headline: Why Richard Serra’s Art Will Outlive Us All
abstract: The great American artist was born in 1938 and died last week, but his work transcends time.
lead_paragraph: The great American artist was born in 1938 and died last week, but his work transcends time.

headline: Russia Pounds Kharkiv in Deadly Barrage, Straining Ukraine’s Defenses
abstract: The latest assault on the eastern city killed at least seven people, local authorities said. As Kyiv waits on American aid, Moscow has stepped up bombardments, including using modified “glide bombs.”
lead_paragraph: Russian rockets slammed into residential buildings in Kharkiv before dawn on Saturday, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least seven people and injuring at least 11 more in the latest assault on Ukraine’s second-largest city.

headline: 2 Novels About Uncomfortably Close Families
abstract: People cross boundaries in Alan Hollinghurst’s “The Spell” and Penelope Lively’s “The Photograph.”
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Biden Reports Major Cash Haul in March as Trump Looks to Catch Up
abstract: The president and Democrats brought in more than $90 million in March and have more than double what Donald J. Trump and Republicans have on hand.
lead_paragraph: President Biden continued to build on his commanding financial advantage over former President Donald J. Trump, raising more than $90 million in March together with the Democratic Party and affiliated committees, his campaign said.

headline: The Economic Paradox of the Biden Presidency
abstract: Employers have been adding jobs since Joe Biden took office, but will the good news translate into votes?
lead_paragraph: One of the more puzzling aspects of the U.S. economy is that employers have been on an almost uninterrupted hiring spree since President Biden took office — and analysts see no signs that the trend will reverse any time soon.

headline: Israel says it recovered the body of a hostage who was taken from a kibbutz on Oct. 7.
abstract: Elad Katzir lived near the border with the Gaza Strip. His sister said Israel’s government should have done more to get him back alive.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military said on Saturday that it had recovered the body of a man who was taken hostage from one of the communities hardest hit during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, almost six months to the day after his abduction.

headline: Prestigious Medical Journal Ignored Nazi Atrocities, Historians Find
abstract: The New England Journal of Medicine published an article condemning its own record during World War II.
lead_paragraph: A new article in the New England Journal of Medicine, one of the oldest and most esteemed publications for medical research, criticizes the journal for paying only “superficial and idiosyncratic attention” to the atrocities perpetrated in the name of medical science by the Nazis.

headline: The Israeli hostage whose body was returned Saturday had spoken of feeling unsafe.
abstract: Elad Katzir, the Israeli hostage whose body was recovered and returned to Israel on Saturday, had long felt unprotected living along Israel’s border with Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Elad Katzir, the Israeli hostage whose body was recovered and returned to Israel on Saturday, had long felt unprotected living along Israel’s border with Gaza.

headline: Put Miso Butter on Everything
abstract: Add it to chicken thighs, crispy tofu, roasted broccoli, pan-fried mushrooms and pasta. You won’t be able to stop.
lead_paragraph: About once a week, I find myself eating miso butter off a spoon like a deer with a salt lick. (In case you’ve ever wondered what the glamorous life of a Cooking editor looks like, that’s mostly it.)

headline: A Niche Indian Actress Is Thrust Into Hollywood’s Spotlight
abstract: Sobhita Dhulipala has taken on risky roles in her acting career, outside of India’s blockbuster hits. Now, she’s starring in Dev Patel’s “Monkey Man.”
lead_paragraph: Sobhita Dhulipala considers herself an outsider — wherever she is.

headline: Battle for the House: These Are the Races to Watch
abstract: Democrats are targeting incumbent Republicans in a number of districts President Biden won in 2020 — but the general rule is, as goes the presidential race, so go House races.
lead_paragraph: Control of the U.S. House of Representatives, at this point in the election cycle, is anybody’s guess.

headline: Daniel P. Jordan, Monticello Leader in Changing Times, Dies at 85
abstract: He expanded the educational mission of Thomas Jefferson’s plantation. He also embraced research that showed Jefferson had fathered the children of one of his slaves.
lead_paragraph: Daniel P. Jordan, who as president of the foundation that owns Monticello, Thomas Jefferson’s plantation in Virginia, broadened its educational mission — and, perhaps most significant, commissioned a study that found that Jefferson had almost certainly fathered six children with Sally Hemings, one of hundreds of people he enslaved — died on March 21 in Charlottesville, Va. He was 85.

headline: Kate Coleman, Who Documented the Bay Area Counterculture, Dies at 81
abstract: She wrote about politics and the patriarchy as a left-wing writer, then alienated her compatriots with exposés critical of the Black Panthers and the environmental movement.
lead_paragraph: Kate Coleman, an iconoclastic Bay Area journalist who began her career as a left-wing radical, writing about the patriarchy, politics and polyamory, then made enemies among her erstwhile comrades when her reporting cast a harsh light on the Black Panthers and the environmental movement, died on Tuesday in Oakland, Calif. She was 81.

headline: Who Is Jorge Glas, an Ecuadorean Politician Arrested at Mexico’s Embassy?
abstract: A former vice president of Ecuador, Jorge Glas had been convicted of bribery in two separate cases. He had fled to the Mexican Embassy in Quito after facing more embezzlement charges.
lead_paragraph: Mexico has severed diplomatic relations with Ecuador after Ecuadorean police officers on Friday arrested Jorge Glas, an Ecuadorean politician who had been granted refuge in Mexico’s Embassy in Quito.

headline: Is New York City Overdue for a Major Earthquake?
abstract: Seismologists said that severe earthquakes are relatively rare around the city and cannot be predicted. But if one were to hit, it could inflict serious damage.
lead_paragraph: The earthquake that hit the Northeast on Friday morning rattled nerves but did not do much damage. Still, it left many New Yorkers wondering how afraid they should be of a bigger one hitting closer to the city.

headline: Mary Ann Zielonko, Partner of Kitty Genovese, Dies at 85
abstract: The murder of Ms. Genovese, and her neighbors’ reaction to it, generated headlines. The nature of her relationship with Ms. Zielonko was a different story.
lead_paragraph: For 60 years, Kitty Genovese has endured as a symbol of big-city apathy, the victim not only of a knife-wielding killer but also of her neighbors’ reluctance to get involved. Two weeks after a man named Winston Moseley stalked, raped and murdered her in Queens late at night in March 1964, a New York Times article reported that 38 of her neighbors had heard her cries for help, yet did nothing.

headline: High Winds Create ‘Critical’ Fire Risk in Parts of Central U.S.
abstract: Millions of people across the West were under high wind warnings or fire danger alerts. Powerful winds in Oklahoma and Colorado fueled fires.
lead_paragraph: High winds and dry conditions in Texas and New Mexico posed a critical fire risk on Sunday, the National Weather Service said, while parts of Colorado, New Mexico and Oklahoma also faced an elevated risk of fires.

headline: Double Duty
abstract: Does Tracy Gray have to repeat herself? Yes, yes she does, in this puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Hillary Clinton Returns to Wellesley, but the Homecoming Is More Complicated
abstract: Pro-Palestinian demonstrations surrounded an appearance at a new research center named after the former secretary of state and presidential nominee at her alma mater.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton returned on Saturday to her alma mater, Wellesley College, to celebrate the opening of a new research and study center that bears her name, more than half a century after she graduated and set off on the path that would make her its most famous alumna.

headline: Another Israeli Hostage’s Body Recovered, the Death Angering His Family
abstract: Like the families of other hostages, they are outraged that the Israeli government has yet to reach a deal to halt the fighting and bring home loved ones held in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Saturday that it had recovered the body of an Israeli hostage who was abducted during the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, almost six months after he was taken hostage.

headline: Pro-Russia Candidate Wins Slovakia’s Presidential Election
abstract: The victory for Peter Pellegrini, an ally of Slovakia’s populist prime minister, strengthens Central Europe’s ties to Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Slovakia on Saturday strengthened the grip of Russia-friendly political forces in Central Europe, handing victory in a presidential election to a candidate who opposes providing military and financial aid to Ukraine.

headline: Dozens of Major Bridges Lack Shields to Block Wayward Ships
abstract: The collapse of the Key Bridge in Baltimore has prompted a reassessment of critical bridges around the country that may be similarly vulnerable to a ship strike.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of the Key Bridge in Baltimore has prompted a reassessment of critical bridges around the country that may be similarly vulnerable to a ship strike.

headline: Trump Fund-Raiser Rakes In More Than $50.5 Million, Campaign Says
abstract: The event, hosted at the Palm Beach home of the hedge-fund billionaire John Paulson, follows a concerted effort by the Trump campaign to close the money gap with Democrats.
lead_paragraph: For several hours on Saturday evening, drivers on a typically scenic stretch of Palm Beach, Fla., had their views of the coast obscured by a line of luxury vehicles whose owners were mingling inside a mansion across the road.

headline: ‘Gladiator Politics’ Dominate Election Season in Polarized South Korea
abstract: This week’s parliamentary elections are widely seen as a referendum on both President Yoon Suk Yeol and his archrival, Lee Jae-myung, the opposition leader.
lead_paragraph: The elections are ostensibly about the 300 seats in Parliament, but when South Koreans go to the polls on Wednesday, they will also be signaling support for one of two leaders who are locked in what is known here as “gladiator politics.”

headline: Homecoming
abstract: A single photo captures a moment of setback for families who had tried for a better life.
lead_paragraph: For years, hundreds of thousands of Afghans fleeing the turmoil of war crossed the border into Pakistan, hoping to start over again. Many of them succeeded in doing so.

headline: Biden and Japan’s Leader Look to Bind Ties to Outlast Them Both
abstract: Hovering over a state visit to Washington is the possibility of a swing in American foreign policy if Donald Trump returns to the White House.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden welcomes Japan’s prime minister, Fumio Kishida, to Washington this week for a visit highlighted by the pomp of a state dinner, there will be an inescapable subtext to all the ceremony: Both leaders are in a fight to keep their jobs.

headline: Corrections: April 7, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about simultaneous terrorist attacks by a separatist group in Iran misidentified the location of Sistan and Baluchestan Province, where the attacks occurred. It is in the southeast, not the southwest, of Iran.

headline: A C.I.A. Black Site Remains a Touchy Subject for Lithuania
abstract: Despite rulings in European courts saying the Baltic country was home to a secret prison, the issue has been shrouded in official secrecy in a nation closely allied with the United States.
lead_paragraph: First came containers loaded with equipment for a secluded property under renovation on the edge of the forest. It had housed a horseback riding academy and a cafe, but was being reconfigured for a mysterious enterprise.

headline: Happy 20th Anniversary, Gmail. I’m Sorry I’m Leaving You.
abstract: There’s a better way to do email.
lead_paragraph: There is no end of theories for why the internet feels so crummy these days. The New Yorker blames the shift to algorithmic feeds. Wired blames a cycle in which companies cease serving their users and begin monetizing them. The M.I.T. Technology Review blames ad-based business models. The Verge blames search engines. I agree with all these arguments. But here’s another: Our digital lives have become one shame closet after another.

headline: Inside an Insurer’s Debate About Fees
abstract: Internal emails show UnitedHealthcare employees grappling with complaints about high fees. When one executive suggested limiting the amount charged New England Motor Freight, a colleague resisted.
lead_paragraph: Internal emails show UnitedHealthcare employees grappling with complaints about high fees. When one executive suggested limiting the amount charged New England Motor Freight, a colleague resisted.

headline: Fact Check: An Explanation of Benefits
abstract: Insurers sometimes suggest that a medical provider agreed to a lower payment, even when it’s not so. This patient was billed the amount that Cigna identified as savings.
lead_paragraph: Insurers sometimes suggest that a medical provider agreed to a lower payment, even when it’s not so. This patient was billed the amount that Cigna identified as savings.

headline: Kristen Wiig Hosts ‘S.N.L.’ With Help From a Few Famous Friends
abstract: Matt Damon, Ryan Gosling, Paul Rudd, Jon Hamm, Martin Short, Paula Pell, Fred Armisen and Will Forte all turned out to help induct Wiig into the show’s Five-Timers Club.
lead_paragraph: Despite her claim that her fifth time hosting “Saturday Night Live” would not be celebrated with a parade of celebrity guests and other “S.N.L.” alums wishing her well, Kristen Wiig turned her opening monologue into just that as she marked this milestone with help from Paul Rudd, Matt Damon, Ryan Gosling and other famous pals.

headline: In Battle Over Health Care Costs, Private Equity Plays Both Sides
abstract: As medical practices owned by private equity firms fuel overbilling, a payment tool also backed by such investors helps insurers boost their profits.
lead_paragraph: Insurance companies have long blamed private-equity-owned hospitals and physician groups for exorbitant billing that drives up health care costs. But a tool backed by private equity is helping insurers make billions of dollars and shift costs to patients.

headline: Insurers Reap Hidden Fees by Slashing Payments. You May Get the Bill.
abstract: A little-known data firm helps health insurers make more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.
lead_paragraph: Weeks after undergoing heart surgery, Gail Lawson found herself back in an operating room. Her incision wasn’t healing, and an infection was spreading.

headline: Tom Bodkin Believes in Form, Function and the Enduring Elegance of Design
abstract: After a 46-year career at The New York Times, Mr. Bodkin is retiring from his role as chief creative officer.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Monday in March, Tom Bodkin strolled through the sloping fields of his backyard, 150 acres of grass, quarries and forest, home to totems of his passions.

headline: The Perilous Existence of a Hamptons Day Laborer
abstract: In the shadow of opulent mansions, workmen spend their winters living in the woods. Julio Florencio Teo Gomez was one of them.
lead_paragraph: Early in the evening of Dec. 30, Julio Florencio Teo Gomez, a carpenter from Guatemala City who had shifted around different living situations on Long Island for more than a decade, went looking for money he was owed for a job he had completed before the holidays. Like so many other day laborers operating in the far reaches of Long Island, he had found the work at a roundup one morning in the parking lot of the 7-Eleven in Southampton. Throughout the final week of the year, he visited the lot several times in the late afternoons, when painters and millworkers, handymen and others in the building trades are dropped off at the end of the workday. He hoped to find the contractor who had neglected to pay him and collect what he was due.

headline: ‘The Late Hour Meant Taking a Cab Home, Something I Mostly Avoid’
abstract: A scruffy driver’s musical surprise, an unexpected lift and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Why These New Yorkers’ Favorite Soccer Team Is in Denmark: They Own It.
abstract: Some people splurge on vacations, fancy shoes and motorcycles. A group of dozens of friends, neighbors and co-workers decided to try something better (or maybe worse).
lead_paragraph: One Sunday morning last month, several dozen American soccer fans gathered inside a Brooklyn bar to cheer on a middling, minor league club from Denmark.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Health Insurers’ Lucrative, Little-Known Alliance: 5 Takeaways
abstract: A private-equity-backed firm has helped drive down payments to medical providers, drive up patients’ bills and earn billions for insurers.
lead_paragraph: Large health insurers are working with a little-known data company to boost their profits, often at the expense of patients and doctors, a New York Times investigation found. A private-equity-backed firm called MultiPlan has helped drive down payments to medical providers and drive up patients’ bills, while earning billions of dollars in fees for itself and insurers.

headline: Q: Who Found a Way to Crack the U.K.’s Premier Quiz Show?
abstract: Brandon Blackwell, a 30-year-old from Queens, helped turn London’s Imperial College into a “University Challenge” powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Blackwell sits in his apartment in the Jamaica section of Queens, training with a collection of 30,000 homemade flash cards the way weight lifters train with barbells. Each card contains an obscure fact about the world. Which country is home to Lake Assal, the largest salt reserve on earth? (Djibouti).  Which metal is smelted using the Hall-Héroult process? (Aluminum).

headline: The Connections Companion No. 301
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Gazing Skyward, and Awaiting a Moment of Awe
abstract: Millions of people making plans to be in the path of the solar eclipse on Monday know it will be awe-inspiring. What is that feeling?
lead_paragraph: The moment she saw the sun, something inside Julie McKelvey changed.

headline: Grunge: A Dull Date, the Sound of Seattle, a ‘Time Capsule’
abstract: The New York Times has a long and complicated history with the word grunge. Let’s get down and dingy in it.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times and “grunge” go way back.

headline: How Gaza Protesters Are Challenging Democratic Leaders
abstract: From President Biden to the mayors of small cities, Democrats have been trailed by demonstrators who are complicating the party’s ability to campaign in an election year.
lead_paragraph: In Detroit, a congressman’s holiday party devolved into chaos and a broken nose after demonstrators protesting the war in Gaza appeared with bullhorns.

headline: Our Reporter on a Hidden Health Insurance Alliance
abstract: A little-known data firm helps health insurers earn more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.
lead_paragraph: A little-known data firm helps health insurers earn more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.

headline: ‘University Challenge’ Questions: How Do You Stack Up?
abstract: Our adaptation of a few of the questions that Imperial College got right in its semifinal game.

headline: To Battle Wartime Hunger, Gazans Turn to a Humble Leafy Green
abstract: Palestinians have long gathered and cooked khobeza, a spinach-like wild plant that sprouts after rains. Now, it has become a lifeline.
lead_paragraph: As the Israeli military campaign to destroy Hamas pummeled his neighborhood in northern Gaza, reducing buildings to rubble and forcing residents to flee, the Palestinian laborer realized that he was running out of food.

headline: Princess Reema, Bandar’s Daughter, Navigates Rough Waters in Washington
abstract: The Saudi ambassador to the United States, the daughter of a storied figure in the kingdom’s diplomacy, is trying to steer relations at a difficult time.
lead_paragraph: She attended the elite Holton-Arms School for girls in the suburbs outside Washington. On weekends she strolled with friends on shopping trips through the Tysons Corner Center mall in Northern Virginia. Three American secretaries of state — Colin L. Powell, James A. Baker and Madeleine Albright — were regular guests in her parents’ home.

headline: Oklahoma’s Booming Film Industry Has Texas’ Attention
abstract: To attract movie and television production, states must try to offer the best incentives. The competition drives spending on Hollywood subsidies ever higher.
lead_paragraph: For a very brief moment, Taylor Sheridan’s hit television series starring Sylvester Stallone had the working title “Kansas City Mob.” But at the time, Missouri had no state funding for film subsidies.

headline: Guarding Royal Families for $1,000 a Day: Inside Executive Protection Jobs
abstract: How three women trained to work in jobs protecting prominent families and ultra-high-net-worth individuals.
lead_paragraph: Monica Duperon Rodriguez welled up with feelings of awe when she stepped off a charter flight onto the Serengeti in Africa for a job assignment.

headline: You Know Marlon James and Edwidge Danticat. Now Meet Astrid Roemer.
abstract: Roemer’s books bring Suriname, on the South American Caribbean coast, to the world. Her 2019 novel, “Off-White,” will be released in English this month.
lead_paragraph: For many readers in the United States, the literature of the Caribbean is a familiar one: Take Marlon James, Edwidge Danticat and Junot Díaz, for starters.

headline: Planning to Combine Business and Leisure Travel? You’re Not Alone.
abstract: As employees increasingly add leisure time to their business trips, companies are trying to figure out where their duty of care obligations begin and end.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday in late January, Melinda Buchmann, who lives in Florida and supervises client relations for RevShoppe, a 30-person remote company advising organizations on sales techniques and strategies, arrived in Banff, Alberta, to help set up a four-day company meeting.

headline: A Frenchwoman’s Midlife Sexual Awakening
abstract: “Playboy,” an autobiographical novel by the writer Constance Debré, follows a woman who left her husband and job in search of pleasure.
lead_paragraph: The trilogy of autobiographical novels by the French writer Constance Debré could be described — reductively — as a challenging yet empowering coming-out journey, the story of a middle-aged woman who lost everything to find herself. But Debré has no interest in portraying life as a series of events in a familiar psychological progression. She is done with the kinds of books she read as a child, “stories of a world that lived in stories,” as she writes in “Playboy” — the first book in the trilogy and the second to be translated into English by Holly James. Turning our experiences into tidy stories “ends up warping our understanding of life and what we expect from it.” The point of literature, for Debré, is to force the reader into immediate, visceral reality.

headline: The Gang That Preyed on America’s Small Museums
abstract: No one mistook them for cat burglars, but the authorities say the crew spent two decades pilfering, and in some cases destroying, art and sports treasures, including Yogi Berra’s championship rings.
lead_paragraph: The first burglary was in 1999 at Keystone College in Factoryville, Pa. One of the gang, the authorities said, sneaked onto the campus, smashed some glass display cases and walked off with memorabilia, including a baseball jersey once worn by Christy Mathewson, the legendary pitcher.

headline: Her Husband Signed Up for the Military. She Didn’t.
abstract: In “The Wives,” Simone Gorrindo tells the story of joining a behind-the-scenes sorority — and how it changed her.
lead_paragraph: “Sometimes I think about joining the military,” Simone Gorrindo’s boyfriend, Andrew, tells her early in their relationship.

headline: Rachel McAdams Is Not Afraid of the Dark
abstract: The actress makes her Broadway debut in “Mary Jane” as the single mother of a seriously ill child. She views her acting choices as expanding her orbit.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, you wouldn’t know that Rachel McAdams, the thoughtfully charming star of blockbuster rom-coms, rom-drams, a Marvel franchise and the Oscar-winning “Spotlight,” has been wondering about death.

headline: Can Minor League Baseball Survive Its Real Estate Problems?
abstract: The fight over a new stadium for the Eugene Emeralds highlights a wider challenge for cheaper alternatives to big-league live sports.
lead_paragraph: Ed Willson has a jar filled with dirt sitting on his desk.

headline: Before ‘S-Town’ Made Him Famous, Clock Lovers Knew Him Well
abstract: John B. McLemore, the brilliant and quirky star of the hit podcast “S-Town,” is the center of a show highlighting his work in the art of clock restoration.
lead_paragraph: John B. McLemore, a profanely outspoken, brilliant and troubled restorer of antique clocks, emerged a national figure in 2017 with the podcast “S-Town.” As a horologist — a repairer of devices that measure time — he restored intricate and rare pieces in a workshop at his family homestead in rural western Alabama.

headline: In Milwaukee, Restaurants and Venues Worry of Seeing Limited R.N.C. Boost
abstract: In Chicago, venues are booking fast for the Democratic convention in August. But Milwaukee, host of the Republican convention, is wondering if customers will come.
lead_paragraph: Dan Jacobs, a contestant on the newest season of “Top Chef,” is having a national star turn with his soups, cheese treats and elevated snacks — and his open struggle with a rare degenerative disease.

headline: Is Corporate America in Denial About Trump?
abstract: Despite his populist promises, many bigwigs are keeping the faith that it couldn’t really happen here.
lead_paragraph: There was anxiety in the thin mountain air when the planet’s economic leaders gathered in January at Davos for the 54th meeting of the World Economic Forum. Donald Trump had just trounced Nikki Haley in the Iowa caucuses, all but securing the Republican nomination for president. Haley was reliable, a known quantity. A resurgent Trump, on the other hand, was more worrying.

headline: Anticipation and Anxiety Build Ahead of the Total Solar Eclipse
abstract: Across parts of the United States, Mexico and Canada, would-be eclipse-gazers are on the move for what could be a once-in-a-lifetime event.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people will tilt their heads skyward on Monday, marveling at a total solar eclipse. The moon will cross the sun and block its light for a few fleeting moments, creating a communal celestial experience that will not again be so accessible to people in the United States, Canada or Mexico for decades.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘What Deathbed Visions Teach Us About Living’
abstract: Researchers are documenting a phenomenon that seems to help the dying, as well as those they leave behind.
lead_paragraph: Chris Kerr was 12 when he first observed a deathbed vision. His memory of that summer in 1974 is blurred, but not the sense of mystery he felt at the bedside of his dying father. Throughout Kerr’s childhood in Toronto, his father, a surgeon, was too busy to spend much time with his son, except for an annual fishing trip they took, just the two of them, to the Canadian wilderness. Gaunt and weakened by cancer at 42, his father reached for the buttons on Kerr’s shirt, fiddled with them and said something about getting ready to catch the plane to their cabin in the woods. “I knew intuitively, I knew wherever he was, must be a good place because we were going fishing,” Kerr told me.

headline: Thirty Years After a Genocide in Rwanda, Painful Memories Run Deep
abstract: The Central African country is marking the anniversary of a monthslong rampage by militiamen that killed some 800,000 people.
lead_paragraph: When the marauding militiamen arrived at her door on that morning in April 1994, Florence Mukantaganda knew there was nowhere to run.

headline: What Netanyahu Must Do to Bring Home the Hostages
abstract: It is evident in everything he has done that their safety is not his top priority.
lead_paragraph: If Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel were serious about securing the release of all the hostages in Gaza, they would have been home long ago.

headline: America Was Once the Country Begging Richer Allies for Help
abstract: The logic of foreign entanglement was the same then as now.
lead_paragraph: Even before they declared their independence, it was clear to the American colonies that in their struggle against Great Britain they would need a wealthy benefactor. The colonies were desperately short of men, money and materiel. There was little by way of an American Navy, and barely an engineer on the continent. In 1776, the most gifted orator in Congress called for a declaration not by choice but by necessity, “as the only means by which foreign alliance can be obtained.” In that light, our founding document nearly qualifies as an SOS.

headline: Israel Is Making the Same Mistake America Made in Iraq
abstract: The Israel Defense Forces’ military challenge is inseparable from its humanitarian obligations.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Gaza reaches its six-month mark, I’m getting a disturbing sense of déjà vu. Israel is facing many of the same challenges that America faced in Iraq, and it is making many of the same mistakes.

headline: Larry David, Philosopher King
abstract: Larry David’s long-running show was hilarious, but it also revolved around a complex view of modern philosophy.
lead_paragraph: “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” the HBO comedy series created by and starring Larry David, debuted way back in 1999 and comedy, television and the world have all changed significantly since. Yet somehow “Curb,” which comes to an end tonight after 12 seasons, remains as relevant as ever. How can that be?

headline: My Faith Forbade Eclipse Gazing. Now It Inspires My Art.
abstract: An artist ponders how his religious childhood affects the art he now creates around eclipse imagery.
lead_paragraph: As a child growing up in the Hare Krishna community in the United States, I was forbidden to be outside during a solar eclipse.

headline: Why States Have Spent Billions Subsidizing Hollywood
abstract: Inside the costly competition to attract TV and film shoots.
lead_paragraph: State governments use our tax dollars to build roads, fund schools and provide health care. In 38 states, they also ship money off to a high-gloss private industry: Hollywood.

headline: The Secret to These Shrimp Tacos Is Worcestershire
abstract: These tacos marry seafood with poblano chiles, diced onions and melted cheese on flour tortillas
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s skinned-knuckle season, the time of the year that’s all about stuck bolts and crushed washers and hydraulic fluid and bottom paint, sacrificial zincs and ceramic wax — old boats coaxed back to health so they can run us to the fishing grounds, so we can cast flies to bass.

headline: The Thinning of Oprah Winfrey
abstract: Her influence about weight and dieting and its objectives runs deep. Also: Unplugged from social media; keeping rodents away; ushering in spring.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Albert Heath, Jazz Drum Virtuoso, Is Dead at 88
abstract: He accompanied stars like John Coltrane and worked frequently with his brothers. “I’ve always thought I was a master,” he once said. Few disagreed.
lead_paragraph: Albert Heath, a virtuoso jazz drummer who collaborated with luminaries like John Coltrane, Thelonious Monk, Nina Simone and Herbie Hancock; performed and recorded with his older brothers, Percy and Jimmy; and for a few years played alongside Percy in one of the great jazz ensembles, the Modern Jazz Quartet, died on Wednesday in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 88.

headline: Missing ‘1923’ Actor, Cole Brings Plenty, Is Found Dead
abstract: Mr. Brings Plenty, 27, was found dead in Kansas days after his family reported him missing. Officials did not provide a cause of death.
lead_paragraph: Cole Brings Plenty, an actor in the television series “1923,” was found dead on Friday in Kansas after his family reported him missing earlier in the week, officials said.

headline: Casey Benjamin, Free-Spirited Saxophonist, Dies at 45
abstract: A musical voyager who wouldn’t be limited by genre, style or even instrument, he brought exuberance to the Robert Glasper Experiment and other groups.
lead_paragraph: Casey Benjamin, who brought colorfully expansive saxophone flourishes to the Grammy-winning Robert Glasper Experiment and added rich layers of texture to recordings by Solange, A Tribe Called Quest and many others, died on March 30 in Maryland. He was 45.

headline: Man Arrested After Fire Set Outside Bernie Sanders’s Vermont Office
abstract: Prosecutors and the police did not identify a possible motive for the fire, which was started on Friday. No one was injured.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Vermont arrested a man they said used an accelerant and a lighter to start a fire on Friday outside of Senator Bernie Sanders’s office in Burlington.

headline: Democratic Group to Spend $186 Million Aiming to Win Back House Majority
abstract: In an interview on Sunday, the House Majority PAC president described the group’s investment as part of “an offensive strategy” for this election year.
lead_paragraph: House Majority PAC, the Democratic super PAC allied with Representative Hakeem Jeffries of New York, the House minority leader, said on Sunday that it would spend $186 million on television and digital advertisements for this year’s elections — the largest early investment in the group’s history.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel Pulls Some Troops from Southern Gaza
abstract: Also, Mexico and Nicaragua severed diplomatic relations with Ecuador.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said it withdrew a division of ground troops from southern Gaza yesterday. The move raised questions about its plans as the war reached the six-month mark — Israeli media reported that the withdrawal meant there were no Israeli troops actively maneuvering in southern Gaza.

headline: Can’t Find Eclipse Glasses? Here’s What to Do.
abstract: You can watch a projection of the eclipse using some common household items.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates on the total solar eclipse.

headline: Carding at a Bar
abstract: Peter Gordon rises to the occasion.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Southwest Jet Makes Emergency Landing After Engine Cover Falls Off
abstract: The plane, a Boeing 737-800, returned safely to Denver on Sunday after the crew reported that the cover came apart during takeoff and struck a wing flap. No injuries were reported.
lead_paragraph: A Southwest Airlines flight safely returned to Denver International Airport on Sunday after the engine cover of a Boeing 737-800 fell off during takeoff and struck the wing flap, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

headline: Trump, at Fund-Raiser, Says He Wants Immigrants From ‘Nice’ Countries
abstract: At rallies, Donald Trump frequently laments migrants from a list of countries from Africa, Asia and the Middle East as he stokes fears around the surge at the border.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, speaking at a multimillion-dollar fund-raiser on Saturday night, lamented that people were not immigrating to the United States from “nice” countries “like Denmark” and suggested that his well-heeled dinner companions were temporarily safe from undocumented immigrants nearby, according to an attendee.

headline: At Rally for Hostages, Some Boo When Congressman Calls for Gaza Aid
abstract: A speech by Jerrold Nadler, a long-serving Jewish Democrat and supporter of Israel, was met with a mixed response at a New York rally calling for the release of hostages in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jerrold Nadler of New York was booed on Sunday at a demonstration in Manhattan calling for the release of hostages held by Hamas after he encouraged attendees to also push for humanitarian aid for Palestinians in Gaza.

headline: Israel Withdraws Troops From Southern Gaza as War Hits 6-Month Mark
abstract: With the conflict at an apparent impasse, international mediators were gathering in Cairo with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said Sunday that it had withdrawn a division of ground troops from the southern Gaza Strip, as international mediators gathered with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire six months into a war that has now become the longest involving Israel since the 1980s.

headline: Maryland Passes 2 Major Privacy Bills, Despite Tech Industry Pushback
abstract: One bill would require apps like Instagram and TikTok to prioritize young people’s safety, and the other would restrict the collection of consumer data.
lead_paragraph: The Maryland legislature this weekend passed two sweeping privacy bills that aim to restrict how powerful tech platforms can harvest and use the personal data of consumers and young people — despite strong objections from industry trade groups representing giants like Amazon, Google and Meta.

headline: A Diplomatic Spat in Ecuador May Lift Its President’s Political Fortunes
abstract: Analysts believe that President Daniel Noboa’s re-election hopes are what motivated the arrest of an Ecuadorean politician taking refuge at the Mexican Embassy.
lead_paragraph: Ecuador’s decision to send police officers into the Mexican Embassy to arrest a politician who had taken refuge there inflamed tensions between two countries that were already at odds, but it may prove a political boon for the Ecuadorean president.

headline: What Chinese Outrage Over ‘3 Body Problem’ Says About China
abstract: The Netflix series showcases one of the country’s most successful works of culture. Instead of demonstrating pride, social media is condemning it.
lead_paragraph: The first five minutes of the Netflix series “3 Body Problem” were hard to watch.

headline: Jerry Grote, Stalwart Mets Catcher on ’69 Championship Team, Dies at 81
abstract: Known for his field savvy and his powerful arm, he helped propel the New York Mets through their storied 1969 World Series run.
lead_paragraph: Jerry Grote, who was among the National League’s leading catchers of his time and guided the pitching staff that propelled the New York Mets to their astonishing 1969 World Series championship, died on Sunday in Austin, Texas. He was 81.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Israel says it withdrew troops from southern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said that it had withdrawn a division of ground troops from the southern Gaza Strip.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Grey Gardens’ and Billy Joel in Concert
abstract: TCM airs the cult classic 1975 documentary, and Joel airs his first broadcast concert at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: For those who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, April 8-14. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: cachet
abstract: This word has appeared in 88 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word cachet has appeared in 88 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 28 in “Nepo Babies Crowd the Runways” by Elizabeth Paton:

headline: Quotation of the Day: Gazing at the Sky, Awaiting a Moment of Awe
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 7, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Awe is an emotion when you encounter things you don’t understand. Wonder follows experiences of awe because you want to explain the mystery of it.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Gazans Turn to a Wild Plant to Combat Wartime Hunger
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “People survived the darkest chapters of the war on khobeza alone.”

headline: The North American Total Solar Eclipse Is Here. Are You Watching?
abstract: A place for students to share their thoughts on this cosmic event, whether they are observing in person or watching from afar.
lead_paragraph: Today, April 8, a total solar eclipse will trace a path through North America from the west coast of Mexico to the east coast of Canada. Will you be watching?

headline: No Corrections: April 8, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Housing, Crime, Climate: The Big Questions Holding Up New York’s Budget
abstract: New York lawmakers are moving closer to a deal on a state budget, but a slew of obstacles remain, including the timing of Monday’s total eclipse.
lead_paragraph: For those who say that an on-time budget in New York State is about as likely as a solar eclipse, the odds on an eclipse are about to improve.

headline: Judge in Trump Criminal Case Braces for Glare of Unprecedented Trial
abstract: Juan Merchan, a target of Donald J. Trump’s wrath, has years of experience on the Manhattan bench but will face a uniquely challenging defendant next week.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 302
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: What to Know About the Trial Donald Trump Faces in Manhattan
abstract: Prosecutors accused Mr. Trump of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal. It is the first criminal trial of a former president.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Yellen Sees ‘More Work to Do’ as China Talks End With No Breakthrough
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen was warmly received in China, but it was evident that the level of trust between the two sides does not run deep.
lead_paragraph: Four days of top-level economic meetings between the United States and China concluded in Beijing on Monday with no major breakthrough, but the world’s two largest economies agreed to hold more discussions to address rising friction over trade, investment and national security.

headline: Nicaragua Takes Germany to Court Over Supplying Arms to Israel
abstract: A new case before the International Court of Justice argues that the German government is furthering genocide in the Gaza war.
lead_paragraph: Nicaragua, a longstanding supporter of the Palestinian cause, is broadening the legal battle over the Gaza conflict at the International Court of Justice by bringing a case against Germany, a major supplier of arms to Israel.

headline: How Thin Air and Summer Snow Can Heal the Soul
abstract: Last July, a recently divorced writer who had found solace in hiking took on a towering challenge: Mount Whitney, the highest peak in the lower 48 states.
lead_paragraph: A brutish granite ridge soared above us in the moonlight. The snow that should not have been there in July seemed to go on forever. We were already short of breath, and weirdly, there were almost no other hikers. Even though I had trained for this, I felt stupidly out of my depth.

headline: When Home Is Now the Front Line
abstract: As war beat a path through southern and eastern Ukraine, most of the population fled. But other residents have hunkered down, unable — or unwilling — to leave.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the hourly artillery duels, airstrikes and pitched fighting in the country’s east and south have turned the more than 600-mile front line into a scarred frontier. Parts of it may be uninhabitable for years, if not decades. Villages and towns are destroyed. Fields are mined. Roads are barely recognizable.

headline: I Hate Running. I Trick My Brain Into Doing It Anyway.
abstract: When your mind hates running even more than your body does, you have to strategize.
lead_paragraph: It’s common knowledge in my household that Monday at 5:55 a.m. is the worst time of the week. That’s because Monday is a running day, and I hate running.

headline: Skip the Traffic: Commuters Turn to Ferries to Get Around
abstract: Ferry ridership took a hit during the pandemic. But new terminals, additional routes and faster, smaller boats are driving a new era of water transportation and development.
lead_paragraph: As remote work reshapes the way people live and travel around cities, Americans are taking to the waterways not only as part of their commute but also as part of their daily lives.

headline: She Lied, Cheated and Stole. Then She Wrote a Book About It.
abstract: In her buzzy memoir, “Sociopath,” Patric Gagne shows herself more committed to revel in her naughtiness than to demystify the condition.
lead_paragraph: That Patric Gagne is a sociopath isn’t news. She wrote about it for The New York Times’s Modern Love column, which led to a deal for a book that I have just hurled across the room like a discus, and an extensive pre-publication interview with my colleague David Marchese.

headline: The Two Men Who Wanted to Categorize ‘Every Living Thing’ on Earth
abstract: Jason Roberts tells the story of the scholars who tried to taxonomize the world.
lead_paragraph: A professor asks a student to go on a plant-collecting trip, a perilous journey from Sweden to Suriname in 1754. The devoted student agrees, which means months tossed about on a wooden ship while chased by a simmering fever. When the student returns, he still shows hints of delirium, declaring that one of his specimens can produce a harvest of pearls, refusing to turn over any of his treasures to his mentor. What’s a plant-obsessed professor to do?

headline: What Researchers Discovered When They Sent 80,000 Fake Résumés to U.S. Jobs
abstract: Some companies discriminated against Black applicants much more than others, and H.R. practices made a big difference.
lead_paragraph: A group of economists recently performed an experiment on around 100 of the largest companies in the country, applying for jobs using made-up résumés with equivalent qualifications but different personal characteristics. They changed applicants’ names to suggest that they were white or Black, and male or female — Latisha or Amy, Lamar or Adam.

headline: J Street Seeks a Middle Path on Gaza. Is That Possible Anymore?
abstract: The center-left Jewish lobby group has lost some staff members and donors who worry the organization has not been quick enough to call for a cease-fire and is alienating younger generations.
lead_paragraph: Over the last five years, the Jewish political advocacy group J Street reached new heights of influence. The center-left lobby, whose slogan upon its founding in 2008 was “pro-Israel, pro-peace,” saw five Democratic presidential candidates stump at its 2019 convention. It helped persuade 48 congressional Democrats to back a 2021 bill that would have pressured Israel to further a two-state solution. In 2022, J Street had its best fund-raising year up to that point, a spokesman confirmed.

headline: The Best True Crime to Stream: Scams, Schemes and Costly Lies
abstract: Four picks across television, film and podcast that depict the art of the con.
lead_paragraph: There are so many true crime offerings dedicated to scams, frauds and con artists that it can be overwhelming. Many of these stories are astonishing and worthy of attention, whether the deceptions are financial, medical, romantic or otherwise. Often most surprising is how relatively painless it seems to lay such traps, and how many people, regardless of personal circumstances, take the bait.

headline: A.I. Could Spot Breast Cancer Earlier. Should You Pay for It?
abstract: The new add-on to a standard mammogram can cost between $40 and $100. We asked experts to separate the sales pitch from the science.
lead_paragraph: Clinics around the country are starting to offer patients a new service: having their mammograms read not just by a radiologist, but also by an artificial intelligence model. The hospitals and companies that provide these tools tout their ability to speed the work of radiologists and detect cancer earlier than standard mammograms alone.

headline: Here Comes the Solar Eclipse
abstract: A total eclipse will be visible in parts of New York State today. In the city, we can expect a memorable spectacle, if the weather cooperates.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at a momentous day in New York: the day of the solar eclipse. Don’t forget to wear your eclipse glasses!

headline: Sometimes, to Make an Electric Car Better, You’ve Got to Make It a Little Worse
abstract: Sales of electric vehicles are sagging in part because they’re so dull to drive compared with their gas counterparts.
lead_paragraph: We’re at an inflection point in electric-car optimism. Over the past few years, as electric vehicle sales increased substantially and car companies announced an onslaught of new battery-powered models, it seemed that electric cars were a near-term inevitability. But for all the heady promise, E.V. enthusiasm seems to be cooling.

headline: After I Lost My Son, I Realized I Needed to Stop Looking for Closure
abstract: Must grief for the climate diminish you, or can it do the opposite?
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, I got the news that every parent dreads.

headline: In an Election Year, ‘Suffs’ Takes a Political Battle to Broadway
abstract: As Shaina Taub’s musical opens, the show’s team members, including Hillary Clinton, say they’re ready to give the women’s suffrage movement a bigger platform.
lead_paragraph: Shaina Taub was ready to watch Hillary Clinton win in November 2016. She had been at Harvard, doing research for an ambitious musical about the women’s suffrage movement, and was swept up in what felt like the inevitable: a woman elected president of the United States. Taub had traveled to New York City from Cambridge for election night, eager to cheer on Clinton, whom she had phone banked for.

headline: A Protest Set to Banjo: Jamar Roberts’s Dance for Hard Times
abstract: “We the People,” Roberts’s first dance for the Martha Graham Dance Company, finds the rage and resistance hidden in an upbeat score by Rhiannon Giddens.
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t fun.”

headline: Why Is Biden Struggling? Because America Is Broken.
abstract: A majority of Americans express, and have done for years, dissatisfaction with the direction of the country.
lead_paragraph: Seven months away from a rematch election pitting President Biden against former President Donald Trump, the incumbent is struggling. Mr. Biden suffers from persistently low approval ratings, he barely manages to tie Mr. Trump in national head-to-head polls and he lags behind the former president in most of the swing states where the election will be decided (despite some recent modestly encouraging movement in his direction).

headline: There Is a Way Out of MAGA Domination
abstract: What America needs is a counterestablishment dedicated to recapturing the G.O.P. from the outside.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, Mike Pence did what no other vice president in the modern era has done: He refused to endorse the re-election of the president under whom he served. When it comes to alumni of Donald Trump’s administration, Mr. Pence is hardly alone; the list of high-ranking officials who worked for Mr. Trump and have implied or outright stated that they can’t support their former boss under any circumstances has grown to an astonishing length.

headline: The Method Behind Trump’s Mistruths
abstract: A close examination of every public word from the former president during a crucial week of his campaign.
lead_paragraph: A close examination of every public word from the former president during a crucial week of his campaign.

headline: $900,000 Homes in California
abstract: A 1929 Spanish-style house in Riverside, a two-bedroom condominium in Pasadena and a midcentury ranch house in Long Beach.
lead_paragraph: This house is at the base of Mount Rubidoux, in a quiet neighborhood about five minutes from the center of the city. The sellers, who bought and renovated it last year, retained original elements wherever possible, including the quarter-sawn oak floors and the casement windows, which were removed, restored and reinstalled. The home is less than a mile from a community garden, a park with a playground and a trail winding up the mountain.

headline: Everything Is Getting Very Familiar
abstract: Avert your eyes.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Good news, bad news, Gail. The economy added just over 300,000 new jobs last month, which gives Joe Biden something to brag about. But illegal immigration is now the No. 1 concern for voters, according to a story in The Wall Street Journal, and in one February poll 65 percent of Americans disapproved of Biden’s handling of the border.

headline: Is the Era of ‘Brozempic’ Upon Us?
abstract: Some telehealth start-ups are playing up masculine stereotypes to market medications that have been more widely associated with women.
lead_paragraph: A grinning golfer with a modest belly, admiring a drive. A silver fox in a suit jacket, enjoying a glass of wine as a beautiful woman gazes into his eyes. A bearded father, cooking for his children in a sun-dappled kitchen.

headline: Anxious Parents Are the Ones Who Need Help
abstract: Today’s parents are suffering from anxiety about their children’s anxiety, and it’s not easy to persuade them that all is OK.
lead_paragraph: This month, across the country, a new cohort of students is being accepted into colleges. And if recent trends continue, the start of the school year will kick off another record-breaking season for anxiety on campus.

headline: Deepfake Porn Sites Used Her Image. She’s Fighting Back.
abstract: Nicholas Kristof on why tech companies aren’t powerless over the spread of deepfake porn.
lead_paragraph: Deepfakes — A.I.-generated imagery that often uses real people’s faces and identities — have proliferated online. A recent study found that 98 percent of deepfake videos online are pornographic, and 99 percent of those target women and girls. The activist and survivor Breeze Liu’s image was used by multiple sites. In this audio essay, she tells her story to the columnist Nicholas Kristof. They argue that search engines such as Google and Bing have the power to combat the scourge of deepfake pornography. “Google can be socially responsible when it wants to be,” Kristof explains. “But in this case, it just seems to be completely indifferent to companies that go out of their way to humiliate women and girls and make money off it.”

headline: Delmore Schwartz’s Poems Are Like Salt Flicked on the World
abstract: A new omnibus compiles the poet’s books and unpublished work, including his two-part autobiographical masterpiece, “Genesis.”
lead_paragraph: Come with me, down the rabbit hole that is the life and work of the Brooklyn-born poet Delmore Schwartz (1913-66). There are two primary portals into Delmore World. Neither involves his own verse. Reading about Schwartz is more invigorating than reading him, or so I have long thought. He was so intense and unbuttoned that he inspired two of the best books of the second half of the 20th century.

headline: Ex-Officials Urge Curbing Presidential Power to Deploy Troops on U.S. Soil
abstract: The bipartisan group says the point is not about Donald J. Trump’s desire to invoke the Insurrection Act, but rather that current law gives all presidents too much unfettered power.
lead_paragraph: A bipartisan group of former senior national security and legal officials, including veterans of the Trump administration, are urging lawmakers to impose new limits on a president’s power to deploy federal troops on domestic soil.

headline: The Invasive-Species Debate Is Not Always Simple
abstract: Where they are welcomed, wild creatures can find a way to make use of nearly everything.
lead_paragraph: Where starlings are concerned, I thought my heart was a stone.

headline: Democratic Group Aims to Spend Heavily in Wisconsin Legislative Races
abstract: After Wisconsin’s Supreme Court ordered new legislative maps, Democrats are gearing up to try to flip the State Assembly — and give President Biden a boost.
lead_paragraph: The States Project, a deep-pocketed outside group focused exclusively on state legislatures, is adding the Wisconsin State Assembly to its 2024 plans, a clear sign that Democrats are growing bullish on an opportunity to flip the chamber after the State Supreme Court ordered new maps to be drawn this year.

headline: TSMC Will Receive $6.6 Billion to Bolster U.S. Chip Manufacturing
abstract: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company plans to build an additional factory and upgrade another planned facility in Phoenix with the federal grants.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will award up to $6.6 billion in grants to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the leading maker of the most advanced microchips, in a bid to bring some of the most cutting-edge semiconductor technology to the United States.

headline: Biden Announces Student Debt Relief for Millions in Swing-State Pitch
abstract: During an appearance in Wisconsin, President Biden said 10 million borrowers could see debt relief of at least $5,000. The plan could help rally support among young voters.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Monday announced a large-scale effort to help pay off federal student loans for tens of millions of American borrowers, seeking an election-year boost by returning to a 2020 campaign promise that was blocked by the Supreme Court last year.

headline: What Solar Eclipse-Gazing Has Looked Like for the Past 2 Centuries
abstract: Millions of people on Monday will continue the tradition of experiencing and capturing solar eclipses, a pursuit that has spawned a lot of unusual gear.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, people have been clamoring to glimpse solar eclipses. From astronomers with custom-built photographic equipment to groups huddled together with special glasses, this spectacle has captivated the human imagination.

headline: Containers Are Being Removed From Ship That Hit Key Bridge
abstract: Workers are unloading the 4,700 containers on the ship, a crucial step in moving the vessel and reopening the channel in the Port of Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: Workers on Sunday began removing containers from the giant cargo vessel that remains pinned under the metal remains of Baltimore’s Key Bridge, nearly two weeks after the ship struck the bridge and caused it to collapse.

headline: Nearly 100 Die After Overloaded Boat Sinks Off Coast of Mozambique
abstract: Some of the victims were en route to a fair and others were fleeing for fear of being affected by a cholera outbreak, a local official said.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 100 people died and more than a dozen were missing after an overcrowded boat sank off the coast of Mozambique, the local authorities said on Monday.

headline: The Eclipse Chaser
abstract: As millions of Americans prepare to see a total solar eclipse, a retired astrophysicist known as “Mr. Eclipse,” discusses the celestial phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: Today, millions of Americans will have the opportunity to see a rare total solar eclipse.

headline: Israel’s Latest Troop Withdrawal, and the Problem With American Bridges
abstract: Plus, is it eclipse weather?
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Cities in the eclipse’s path are getting an economic ‘shot in the arm.’
abstract: Millions of tourists trying to experience the totality could bolster smaller economies across North America.
lead_paragraph: A vast swath of North America will soon be plunged into darkness. Though momentary, the total solar eclipse on Monday has already proved lucrative.

headline: Baruch College, an Upward-Mobility Machine
abstract: The New York school is praised as a model college in a new report on diversity in higher education.
lead_paragraph: City College of New York often serves as a nostalgic symbol of American higher education’s past. The college did not charge tuition for decades, and its students, many of them poor, went on to become Nobel laureates, chief executives, civil rights leaders and more. By contrast, higher education today can seem both less accessible and less rigorous.

headline: U.N. Inspectors Say Nuclear Plant in Ukraine Was Struck by Drones
abstract: The watchdog agency did not attribute blame, but its head said the strikes at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant “significantly increase the risk of a major nuclear accident.”
lead_paragraph: The head of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency has condemned drone strikes at the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, saying “such reckless attacks significantly increase the risk of a major nuclear accident and must be stopped immediately.”

headline: To Become Prince Andrew, He Needed More Than False Teeth
abstract: In the feature “Scoop,” streaming on Netflix, Rufus Sewell plays the disgraced royal blundering through a 2019 BBC interview.
lead_paragraph: Before filming started on “Scoop,” a Netflix feature about Prince Andrew’s notoriously misjudged 2019 interview on the BBC, the actor Rufus Sewell, who stars as the disgraced royal, turned up on set to shoot a few photographs that would appear in the background. Loaded with makeup and prosthetics, including false teeth and a feathery wig, Sewell felt leaden and self-conscious, he said, fearful that his impersonation would slip into parody.

headline: Vatican Document Casts Gender Change and Fluidity as Threat to Human Dignity
abstract: The statement is likely to be embraced by conservatives and stir consternation among L.G.B.T.Q. advocates who fear it will be used as a cudgel against transgender people.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican on Monday issued a new document approved by Pope Francis stating that the church believes that gender fluidity and transition surgery, as well as surrogacy, amount to affronts to human dignity.

headline: Jamie Dimon Issues an Economic Warning
abstract: The JPMorgan Chase chief executive used his annual letter to shareholders to flag higher-for-longer inflation, uncertain growth prospects and widening political divisions.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon’s annual letter to JPMorgan Chase shareholders has just been published. The widely read note offers a glimpse of his views on not just business, but the economy at a “pivotal moment for America and the free world,” with deep divisions at home and global uncertainty.

headline: Review: ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’ Wraps Up in Familiar Fashion
abstract: Larry David’s HBO comedy ended on Sunday after 12 seasons. Longtime fans might have noticed similarities with a certain earlier sitcom.
lead_paragraph: After 12 seasons, spread across 25 years, the HBO comedy staple “Curb Your Enthusiasm” ends with an episode that sees Larry David put on trial. Witness after witness testifies to Larry’s lifetime of selfish and antisocial behavior. The jury finds him guilty, of course.

headline: Paying Off People’s Medical Debt Has Little Impact on Their Lives, Study Finds
abstract: A nonprofit group called R.I.P. Medical Debt has relieved Americans of $11 billion in hospital bills. But that did not improve their mental health or their credit scores, a study found.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade, R.I.P. Medical Debt has grown from a tiny nonprofit group that received less than $3,000 in donations to a multimillion-dollar force in health care philanthropy.

headline: Here Are the Most Targeted Books of 2023
abstract: Amid a nationwide surge in book bans, memoirs and novels that deal with the experiences of L.G.B.T.Q. people or explore race received the most challenges.
lead_paragraph: The most challenged books in the United States in 2023 continued to focus on the experiences of L.G.B.T.Q. people or explore themes of race, according to a report released Monday by the American Library Association.

headline: Trump Says Abortion Restrictions Should Be Left to the States
abstract: After months of mixed signals, Donald Trump said that whatever states decide “must be the law of the land,” adding that he was “strongly in favor of exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said in a video statement on Monday that abortion rights should be left up to the states, remarks that came after months of mixed signals on an issue that he and his advisers have worried could cost him dearly in the election.

headline: Why a Savory English Pastry Is Beloved in a California Town
abstract: The popularity of the Cornish pasty, a meat pie eaten by hand like a sandwich, is a legacy of the gold rush.
lead_paragraph: In a charming former mining town in the Sierra Nevada foothills, you can taste pieces of California history dating back nearly 175 years.

headline: Israel’s withdrawal suggests the war has entered a new phase.
abstract: The Israeli military’s departure from southern Gaza over the weekend has left the territory without a major battlefield for the first time since a brief truce with Hamas in November, raising hopes that the two sides might reach another cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military’s departure from southern Gaza over the weekend has left the territory without a major battlefield for the first time since a brief truce with Hamas in November, raising hopes that the two sides might reach another cease-fire.

headline: Arkansas Braces for Flood of Tourists During Total Solar Eclipse
abstract: The state has miles of rugged terrain and an array of state parks, but it does not have a major professional sports team. Officials have struggled to think of an event comparable to the eclipse.
lead_paragraph: The email landed in the inbox of Dave Parker, an Arkansas government employee, in 2021: Hey, we’ve got this eclipse coming.

headline: Tayi Tibble, Maori Poet and ‘It Girl’, Trusts the Wisdom of Her Ancestors
abstract: Tibble, 28, has been hailed as the fresh, funny and immensely skilled voice of a generation.
lead_paragraph: As an Indigenous New Zealander, the poet Tayi Tibble is descended from expert Polynesian navigators who traversed thousands of miles of Pacific Ocean. When disoriented by self-doubt or impostor syndrome, she relies on their wisdom.

headline: ‘Eureka Day’ and Sondheim Revue Join Broadway’s Next Season
abstract: Bernadette Peters and Lea Salonga will star in Sondheim’s “Old Friends” in Manhattan Theater Club’s Broadway season, which also includes “Eureka Day.”
lead_paragraph: Manhattan Theater Club, one of the four nonprofit organizations that operate houses on Broadway, is planning to stage a vaccination comedy called “Eureka Day” and the Sondheim revue “Old Friends” at its Samuel J. Friedman Theater next season.

headline: Morgan Wallen Arrested, Accused of Throwing a Chair From a Bar Roof
abstract: The country superstar faces charges of reckless endangerment and disorderly conduct after the incident in Nashville on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The country singer Morgan Wallen was arrested early Monday in Nashville on charges of reckless endangerment and disorderly conduct, after he was accused of throwing a chair from the roof of a downtown bar, according to reports.

headline: Democrats in Pennsylvania Urge Biden to Branch Out Beyond Philadelphia
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris will stop in the city on Monday to promote efforts to forgive student debt. Some local officials are calling for greater outreach in more rural areas.
lead_paragraph: President Biden loves Philadelphia. And he loves campaigning there, too.

headline: Do You Know These Novels Driven by Climate Change?
abstract: Try this short quiz on recent fiction that follows characters dealing with a turbulent world.
lead_paragraph: Try this short quiz on recent fiction that follows characters dealing with a turbulent world.

headline: Leading Anti-Abortion Group Says It Is ‘Deeply Disappointed’ in Trump’s Comments
abstract: The president of Susan B. Anthony Pro-Life America said she was “deeply disappointed” in Donald J. Trump’s position that states should decide abortion rights.
lead_paragraph: After former President Donald J. Trump announced his position that abortion rights should be decided by individual states, the leading anti-abortion group supporting Republican candidates said his stance fell short.

headline: How Abortion, and I.V.F., Flipped an Alabama State House Seat
abstract: Marilyn Lands’s victory in a special election provided an early blueprint for Democrats who are eager to make reproductive rights central to their campaigns.
lead_paragraph: When Marilyn Lands, a Democrat, won an election last month for a northern Alabama State House district that Republicans had held for more than two decades, she stretched the political power of reproductive rights into the edges of Appalachia.

headline: Jonathan Majors Avoids Jail Time for Assault Conviction
abstract: Mr. Majors, a rising movie star before his conviction in December, was sentenced to a domestic violence program for assaulting an ex-girlfriend last year.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Majors, a rising movie star who was found guilty last year of assaulting and harassing his then-girlfriend, Grace Jabbari, was sentenced in Manhattan Criminal Court on Monday to 52 weeks of domestic violence programming, to take place in Los Angeles.

headline: Israel’s Account of Attack on Aid Convoy Raises Wider Legal Questions, Experts Say
abstract: The events that led to the deaths of seven World Central Kitchen workers suggest that there could be problems with the protocols used by the Israeli military, according to legal experts and aid organizations.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s account of its attack on a World Central Kitchen convoy raises significant legal questions even if the strike was the result of a series of mistakes, experts say.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Cowboy Carter’ Opens at No. 1 With the Year’s Biggest Sales
abstract: The pop superstar’s new album also reigns on Billboard’s Top Country Albums chart, the first time a Black woman has led that tally in its 60-year history.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé’s genre-bending “Cowboy Carter” has become her eighth No. 1 album, opening with the biggest sales of any release so far this year.

headline: Leigh Bardugo’s Latest Travels to Renaissance Spain
abstract: In “The Familiar,” the blockbuster fantasist conjures a world of mystical intrigue and romance.
lead_paragraph: For those unacquainted with Catholic demonology, a familiar, or “familiar spirit,” as the phrase shows up in the Bible, is an otherworldly creature indentured to a master, usually whoever’s summoned it — a witch or necromancer or, in the case of Aladdin, a lucky rube who finds a bottle in need of a shine.

headline: See the Total Solar Eclipse’s Shadow From Space
abstract: An American weather satellite is capturing the movement of the moon’s shadow across North America during the total eclipse of the sun on Monday.
lead_paragraph: An American weather satellite is capturing the movement of the moon’s shadow across North America during the total eclipse of the sun on Monday.

headline: Virgil Abloh’s Legacy Is About to Get Louder
abstract: Shannon Abloh and the Fashion Scholarship Fund unveil a new plan.
lead_paragraph: Many companies, including fashion companies, may be going silent about their diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives in the face of political change. The last round of major designer appointments may not have included a single creative director of color. But at least one group is doubling down on its commitment to broadening the style-talent pipeline.

headline: Large Scientific Review Confirms the Benefits of Physical Touch
abstract: Premature babies especially benefited from skin-to-skin contact, and women tended to respond more strongly than men did.
lead_paragraph: A hug, a handshake, a therapeutic massage. A newborn lying on a mother’s bare chest.

headline: They Came From Outer Space. Now, They’re Going Into Hiding.
abstract: Rising temperatures in Antarctica are making meteorites sink out of view before researchers can collect them.
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for meteorites, here’s a tip: Go south. All the way south. And do it soon.

headline: An Easy Mac and Cheese Worth Cheering
abstract: Genevieve Ko’s simple stovetop version comes together with just five ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the week! I’m filling in for Melissa and just as excited as she is for spring’s fresh peas and picnics. But those come around every year, and a new New York Times Cooking recipe for macaroni and cheese is a special event.
