Joining Millie Peartree’s Southern-style casserole, Eric Kim’s Stouffer’s copycat, and my so-weird-that-it-works recipe, Genevieve Ko’s new stovetop version is our first to bear the label “easy,” and it’s also creamy, classic and made from just five scratch ingredients. Welcome to the dance floor!

headline: Dr. Bob, 75, Knows Aging’s Toll. He Wonders if Biden and Trump Do.
abstract: Dr. Bob Ross cares for the aging residents of Ortonville, Minn, even as he wonders whether he, and the presidential candidates, are up to all their tasks.
lead_paragraph: He had become the local expert on what he called the “unwanted side effects of old age,” so Dr. Bob Ross, 75, rubbed arthritis cream onto his hands and walked into an exam room to see his seventh elderly patient of the day. He had been a doctor in the remote town of Ortonville, Minn., for nearly five decades, caring for most of its 2,000 residents as he aged alongside them. He delivered their children, performed their high school physicals, tended to their workplace injuries and now specialized in treating the wide-ranging symptoms of what it meant to grow old in America.

headline: PFAS ‘Forever Chemicals’ Are Pervasive in Water Worldwide, Study Finds
abstract: A global survey found harmful levels even in water samples taken far from any obvious source of contamination.
lead_paragraph: They’re in makeup, dental floss and menstrual products. They’re in nonstick pans and takeout food wrappers. Same with rain jackets and firefighting equipment, as well as pesticides and artificial turf on sports fields.

headline: Palestinians Return to an Unrecognizable City After Israelis Withdraw
abstract: “You build a home corner by corner, stone by stone,” said one man who came back to Khan Younis. “And in the end, with a press of a button, it is reduced to rubble.”
lead_paragraph: The withdrawal of Israeli ground troops from southern Gaza over the weekend allowed some Palestinians to return to the city of Khan Younis and check on their homes. But in the aftermath of a fierce, monthslong battle and Israeli bombings, some found only destruction.

headline: Google to Tone Down Message Board After Employees Feud Over War in Gaza
abstract: The company is making changes to a popular message board called Memegen that some employees say sounds a lot like censorship.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 14 years, an online message board called Memegen has served as a virtual water cooler for Google employees.

headline: Teen Girls Confront an Epidemic of Deepfake Nudes in Schools
abstract: Using artificial intelligence, middle and high school students have fabricated explicit images of female classmates and shared the doctored pictures.
lead_paragraph: Westfield Public Schools held a regular board meeting in late March at the local high school, a red brick complex in Westfield, N.J., with a scoreboard outside proudly welcoming visitors to the “Home of the Blue Devils” sports teams.

headline: Spirit Airlines Will Delay Plane Purchases and Furlough Pilots
abstract: The low-cost airline, which has been unprofitable for four years, is trying to reduce costs after a federal judge blocked a proposed deal for JetBlue to acquire Spirit.
lead_paragraph: Spirit Airlines said on Monday that it would delay delivery of new Airbus planes and furlough pilots to save money as it seeks to overcome several setbacks, including a blocked merger, engine problems and a lackluster recovery from the pandemic.

headline: Appeals Court Denies Another Trump Attempt to Delay Trial
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s lawyers sought to pause his Manhattan criminal trial as they argued that it should be moved, but a judge rejected their appeal.
lead_paragraph: Read the latest developments in Trump’s criminal trial.

headline: Yes, You Can Wash Cast Iron: 5 Big Kitchen Myths, Debunked
abstract: A veteran food journalist digs into some common misconceptions about salting pasta water, browning meat and more.
lead_paragraph: Food myths come from many sources, and American cooks (including me) have swallowed lots of them. Some of them used to be truths, like the notion that you should eat oysters only in “R” months. (Before refrigeration, shellfish were safer to eat in the winter.) Some come from restaurant kitchens, like the rule against washing mushrooms. (When you’re ready to use them, it’s perfectly fine to rinse off the dirt. Just don’t store them after washing; they will spoil once wet.) And some just derive from superstition, like the idea that brown eggs are healthier than white ones. (They are identical inside the shell; the color is usually determined by the hen’s feathers.)

headline: Solar Eclipse Could Make Some Clouds Perform a Disappearing Act
abstract: A recent study found that cumulus clouds, the small cotton ball-like ones typical for a sunny day, can dissipate once an eclipse begins. But if the skies are overcast, your view could still be obstructed.
lead_paragraph: As the eclipse begins, some view-blocking clouds could actually disappear. A recent study found that after 15 percent of the sun becomes obscured, cumulus clouds, the small cotton ball-like ones typical for a sunny day, can dissipate. Even if you are outside the path of totality, watch what happens to the clouds.

headline: ‘Is She Sure?’ How the Breeders Joined Olivia Rodrigo’s Guts Tour.
abstract: The ’90s alt-rock icons hit the Madison Square Garden stage for the first time Friday night, after the 21-year-old pop star invited them to join her on the road.
lead_paragraph: Olivia Rodrigo remembers her life in two parts: before she heard the Breeders’ “Cannonball,” and after, she told the crowd at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, when her Guts World Tour arrived in New York.

headline: Prosecutors Defend Case Against Alec Baldwin in ‘Rust’ Shooting
abstract: As the actor’s defense team seeks the dismissal of the involuntary manslaughter indictment, the prosecution detailed some of the factors that led it to seek charges.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in New Mexico defended their handling of the involuntary manslaughter case against Alec Baldwin on Friday, filing court papers in which they accused the actor of negligently failing to make sure the gun he was handed before the fatal “Rust” shooting was not loaded with live ammunition.

headline: Seeking Answers on Israel and Palestine
abstract: Responses to an essay that rejected a two-state solution. Also: The U.S. and Israel; the eclipse; end-of-life planning; the church of Trump; the peace sign.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Four Takeaways From the Vatican’s Document on Human Dignity
abstract: The document restated the Roman Catholic Church’s rejection of abortion, gender fluidity and transition surgery.
lead_paragraph: The document issued on Monday by the Vatican puts human dignity at the center of Catholic life, but in doing so, it broaches some of the most difficult and sensitive social issues, those that Pope Francis has spent his papacy avoiding.

headline: In California, Half an Eclipse Is Better Than None
abstract: Californians in the Bay Area and in Southern California braced for a favorable view of the partial eclipse as clouds dissipated on Monday morning.
lead_paragraph: The sun, or at least most of it, will keep shining in California during the eclipse.

headline: Israeli Opposition Leader Calls for Close Ties With U.S. in Visit
abstract: In the wake of President Biden’s recent warning to Israel to stop the killing of civilians in Gaza, Yair Lapid said the two countries “need to maintain this friendship.”
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken met on Monday with Israel’s opposition leader, Yair Lapid, who reaffirmed the underlying U.S.-Israel bond despite tensions between President Biden and Mr. Lapid’s chief political rival, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

headline: Biden and Other Democrats Tie Trump to Limits on Abortion Rights
abstract: The former president said he supported leaving abortion decisions to states, but political opponents say he bears responsibility for any curbs enacted.
lead_paragraph: Democrats, seeking to tie abortion restrictions to former President Donald J. Trump and Republicans, again laid the blame for limits on reproductive rights at Mr. Trump’s feet, saying the former president’s statement on Monday calling for abortion restrictions to be decided by states was part of a pattern of “extreme” lawmaking.

headline: When Your Boss Is Your Landlord
abstract: A Brooklyn hospital is trying to evict employees and retirees from staff housing, as it struggles financially, but tenants fear they will now be homeless in an unaffordable city.
lead_paragraph: A five-minute walk to work and around $600 a month in rent was hard to pass up in 1990.

headline: J. Cole Apologizes for Kendrick Lamar Diss Track
abstract: J. Cole also vowed to update the track, “7 Minute Drill,” or remove it from streaming services after it was featured on his new album, “Might Delete Later.”
lead_paragraph: The rapper J. Cole apologized on Sunday for releasing a diss track about Kendrick Lamar, saying he felt “terrible” and vowing to update the song or remove it from streaming services.

headline: Guns, Machetes and Illness: The Perils of Running the Length of Africa
abstract: Russ Cook of Britain overcame danger in a year of running from South Africa to Tunisia.
lead_paragraph: Going for a run can get a bit more difficult when it lasts for a year and is complicated by robbery, illness and men with machetes.

headline: The Economic Luminary Who Loved Solar Eclipses
abstract: Inspired by science, William Stanley Jevons strove to make economics a more rigorous field.
lead_paragraph: In 1857, William Stanley Jevons was 22 years old and was working as an assayer for the Sydney Mint. Two eclipses passed over Australia that year, and Jevons enthusiastically tracked both. “After sleepless night got up about 3:30 and started to Bellevue Hill in dark,” he wrote in his diary about one, which must have happened shortly after dawn. “About 5 a.m. commenced observations concerning eclipse.” (After the eclipse, he went to work, wrote a detailed report on it for a local newspaper, had tea with the mint’s chief engineer and in the evening caught a performance of “Much Ado About Nothing.”)

headline: Pence Attacks Trump’s Abortion Statement as a ‘Slap in the Face’
abstract: Mike Pence, an evangelical Christian who embraced abortion restrictions at the federal level shortly after Roe was overturned, called Mr. Trump’s statement a “retreat” on the matter.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence delivered a scathing rebuke to former President Donald J. Trump’s announcement on Monday that he thought abortion rights should be left to the states, calling Mr. Trump’s video statement a “slap in the face” to the anti-abortion voters who supported him in 2016 and 2020.

headline: The Eclipse Across North America
abstract: What people in the path of totality were seeing and saying as the eclipse unfolded across the continent.
lead_paragraph: What people in the path of totality were seeing and saying as the eclipse unfolded across the continent.

headline: Biden Announces New Plan for Student Debt Relief
abstract: President Biden announced a large-scale effort to help pay off federal student loans for more than 20 million borrowers.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced a large-scale effort to help pay off federal student loans for more than 20 million borrowers.

headline: Putting Abortion Question to Florida Voters Is Unlikely to End Court Fights
abstract: Though the Florida Supreme Court allowed a ballot question on expanding abortion rights, it also laid out a way for anti-abortion groups to challenge such an expansion.
lead_paragraph: Abortion-rights supporters celebrated last week when the Florida Supreme Court said voters could decide this fall whether to approve a state constitutional amendment protecting and expanding abortion rights in Florida. But the court also laid out a road map for anti-abortion groups to challenge any expansion, by raising the prospect of “fetal personhood.”

headline: When Tom Ripley Stares Into the Mirror, He Sees Us
abstract: In the new series and in five previous movies, the character serves as a blank slate to examine the mores and concerns of the time.
lead_paragraph: Tom Ripley’s background is always sketchy. Patricia Highsmith provides only a few rudimentary details in the first few chapters of “The Talented Mr. Ripley,” her 1955 novel that kicked off a series of five books about the elusive con artist. Tom lives in New York, in near-destitute circumstances. He has some friends — acquaintances, really — whom he hates, mentally labeling them “the riffraff, the vulgarians, the slobs.” He wants nothing more than to be rid of them, and after the first few chapters, he succeeds. He receives money from an aunt in Boston; she raised him after his parents drowned in the harbor there. He hates her, too.

headline: Missouri Governor Denies Clemency for Death Row Inmate Who Got Support From Guards
abstract: Dozens of correctional workers urged Gov. Mike Parson to commute the death sentence of Brian Dorsey, who pleaded guilty in the murders of Ben and Sarah Bonnie.
lead_paragraph: Mike Parson, the governor of Missouri, said on Monday that he would not commute the death sentence of Brian Dorsey, who pleaded guilty to murdering Ben and Sarah Bonnie in 2006 and is scheduled to be executed on Tuesday unless the courts intervene.

headline: Lawyer Kills His Son’s Ex-Wife and Her Current Husband at Las Vegas Law Firm
abstract: The police said that the shooting had happened during a deposition in a child custody case.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer fatally shot his former daughter-in-law and her new husband at a Las Vegas law office on Monday morning during a deposition in a child custody case, then killed himself, the authorities said.

headline: France Bracing for Cyberattacks During Summer Olympics
abstract: French officials are visiting Washington for cybersecurity consultations as President Emmanuel Macron predicts Moscow will try to target the Games.
lead_paragraph: The Summer Olympics and tensions over the war in Ukraine are likely to make Paris a tempting target for a variety of hacking attempts, including from adversarial countries, France’s top cybersecurity official said on Monday.

headline: L.A. Times Names Terry Tang as Executive Editor
abstract: Ms. Tang, who had been running the news organization on an interim basis since January, takes charge at a turbulent time for the publication.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Times on Monday named Terry Tang as its permanent executive editor, making her the first woman to lead the paper’s newsroom.

headline: ‘Curb’ Finale Shows ‘Larry’s Never Learned His Lesson’
abstract: In an interview, Jeff Schaffer and Susie Essman discuss why Larry David revived the polarizing “Seinfeld” finale. “We know what you thought of that, and we don’t care,” Schaffer said.
lead_paragraph: With a parade of callbacks and a twist a quarter-century in the making, “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” the HBO series starring Larry David as a heightened version of himself, ended its 20-plus-year run on Sunday.

headline: Col. Ralph Puckett Jr., Belated Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 97
abstract: One of the Army’s most highly decorated servicemen, he received the military’s supreme tribute for valor, for his actions in the Korean War — 71 years after the fact.
lead_paragraph: Col. Ralph Puckett Jr., who was belatedly awarded the Medal of Honor in May 2021 for his exploits seven decades earlier, commanding vastly outnumbered Army Rangers in a battle with Communist Chinese troops during the Korean War, died on Monday at his home in Columbus, Ga. One of the most highly decorated servicemen in the history of the Army, he was 97.

headline: For Nicaragua, International Case Against Germany Is Déjà Vu
abstract: Nicaragua’s accusation against Germany in the International Court of Justice comes 40 years after the country filed a claim against the United States in the same court.
lead_paragraph: For Nicaragua’s representative to the International Court of Justice, this week’s hearing before the World Court was a case of déjà vu.

headline: Ex-Ecuadorean Vice President, Arrested at Mexican Embassy, Is Hospitalized
abstract: The former vice president, Jorge Glas, had taken pills, the police said, and was taken to a hospital. He had taken refuge at the embassy after being accused of corruption.
lead_paragraph: Authorities found a former Ecuadorean vice president, Jorge Glas, in a “deep self-induced coma” in jail on Monday, just days after he was captured by the police in a dramatic arrest inside the Mexican embassy in Quito.

headline: Anthony Insolia, Who Led the Expansion of Newsday, Dies at 98
abstract: The Long Island paper won seven Pulitzer Prizes during his tenure, and he was a top editor for the Arizona Project, which investigated a reporter’s murder.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Insolia, a down-to-earth former editor of Newsday who presided over that Long Island newspaper’s expansion and several big investigative projects, died on Saturday in Philadelphia. He was 98.

headline: Biden Campaign Ad Blames Trump for Near-Death of Woman Who Was Denied Abortion
abstract: The ad encapsulates the strategy by the president’s campaign to seize on anger about the Supreme Court’s 2022 decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s re-election campaign on Monday released a searing campaign ad blaming former President Donald J. Trump for the near-death of a Texas woman who suffered infections after she was denied an abortion following a miscarriage.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: A Total Solar Eclipse
abstract: Also, the Vatican said gender changes amount to an affront.
lead_paragraph: Millions of people across North America gathered outside yesterday to behold the disorienting, disquieting wonder of darkness in the daytime.

headline: Georgia Trump Prosecutor Urges Appeals Court to Decline Disqualification Case
abstract: The prosecutor, Fani Willis, defended a judge’s recent ruling that she could continue leading the election interference case against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Fani T. Willis, the district attorney of Fulton County, Ga., filed a motion on Monday seeking to block an appeal of a ruling last month allowing her to continue leading the state election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Cash-for-Clients Scheme Lands Ex-Court Clerk and Lawyer in Prison
abstract: Dionisio Figueroa used his position in Manhattan federal court to steer defendants to Telesforo Del Valle Jr. in a long-running conspiracy, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A former federal court clerk and a New York lawyer who together operated a long-running cash-for-clients bribery scheme were sentenced to prison on Monday, prosecutors said.

headline: A Moment of Unity, on Earth as in Space
abstract: As totality approached, it felt, for a change, as if we were all rooting for the same team.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it takes an extraterrestrial event to bring this shredded country together. For a phenomenon that traversed the country from the contentious southern border to the far reaches of New England, Monday’s eclipse attracted remarkably few conspiracy theories or accusations. From where I stood, in Buffalo, the major threat to the moment was a forecast of heavy clouds.

headline: The Eclipse Brought Darkness and Fascination
abstract: Also, Donald Trump said abortion limits should be decided by states. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: In an awe-inspiring cosmic coincidence, the moon and sun perfectly aligned this afternoon, producing a total solar eclipse visible across North America. The moon’s shadow plunged daylight into darkness, carving a path from Mexico, up to Maine and into Canada. We took lots of photos.

headline: College Towns Usually Lift Democrats. Is the Picture More Complicated in 2024?
abstract: An enthusiasm gap among young voters and anger on campuses over Gaza has some Democrats wary.
lead_paragraph: If you want to be the president, you should probably win Wisconsin.

headline: Iran Pardons 4 Environmental Activists to Commemorate Eid al-Fitr, Lawyer Says
abstract: Two have been freed so far, state media said. They were among eight arrested in 2018 on charges of spying, which they have denied.
lead_paragraph: Iran has pardoned and begun freeing four environmental activists who spent several years in prison on espionage charges, Iranian state media said on Monday. The pardons were granted to commemorate Eid al-Fitr, the Islamic holiday celebrated at the end of Ramadan, according to their lawyer.

headline: Good Economy, Negative Vibes: The Story Continues
abstract: The economy is in good shape. Why are so many Americans still saying it’s bad?
lead_paragraph: When it comes to economic news, we’ve had so much winning that we’ve gotten tired of winning, or at any rate blasé about it. Last week, we got another terrific employment report — job growth for 39 straight months — and it feels as if hardly anyone noticed. In particular, it’s not clear whether the good news will dent the still widespread but false narrative that President Biden is presiding over a bad economy.

headline: Active Fighting Subsides in Gaza, but the War Is Not Over, Officials Say
abstract: Israeli troops have left southern Gaza, and some Palestinians returned to the area, where there was a sense of horror at the scope of destruction.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military’s departure from southern Gaza over the weekend has left the devastated territory in a state of suspense as active fighting there receded on Monday to its lowest ebb since a brief truce with Hamas in November.

headline: What to Know About Biden’s New Student Debt Relief Plan
abstract: The proposal would affect nearly 30 million people and would target groups that have had hardships in repaying their loans.
lead_paragraph: President Biden released details on Monday of his new student loan debt forgiveness plan for nearly 30 million borrowers.

headline: Dianne Brill, a 1980s ‘It Girl,’ Makes a Splashy Return
abstract: “I’m back,” she says at her 66th birthday party. “Maybe not everyone knows it yet, but I am.”
lead_paragraph: When Dianne Brill arrived at the Soho Grand Hotel for her 66th birthday party on Saturday night, she did so with the same sense of spectacle that made her an icon of Manhattan nightlife in the 1980s.

headline: Trump Says Abortion Will Be Left to the States. Don’t Believe Him.
abstract: His allies are planning to resurrect and enforce the 19th-century Comstock Act.
lead_paragraph: When Donald Trump was asked about the recent Florida Supreme Court decision upholding his adopted state’s abortion ban, he promised that he would announce where he stands this week — a sign of how tricky the politics of reproductive rights have become for the man who did more than any other to roll them back. Sure enough, on Monday he unveiled his latest position in a video statement that attempted to thread the needle between his anti-abortion base and the majority of Americans who want abortion to be legal.

headline: Prosecutors Ask Supreme Court to Reject Trump’s Immunity Claim in Election Case
abstract: The filing was the main submission from Jack Smith, the special counsel prosecuting the former president. The case will be argued on April 25.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Trump immunity case before the Supreme Court.

headline: Tesla Settles Lawsuit Over a Fatal Crash Involving Autopilot
abstract: A Tesla driver’s family had sought damages for the 2018 crash, which happened while the carmaker’s driver-assistance software was in use.
lead_paragraph: Tesla on Monday settled a lawsuit that blamed the automaker’s driver-assistance software for the death of a California man in 2018, averting a trial that would have focused attention on the company’s technology several months before it plans to unveil a self-driving taxi.

headline: On Abortion, Trump Chose Politics Over Principles. Will It Matter?
abstract: With his video statement on Monday, Donald Trump laid bare how faulty a messenger he had always been for the anti-abortion cause.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump ran for president in 2016, the leaders of the anti-abortion movement extracted a series of promises from him in exchange for backing his nomination.

headline: Gypsy Rose Blanchard Files for Divorce From Ryan Anderson
abstract: The couple married while Ms. Blanchard, who was found guilty of helping to kill her mother, was still in prison.
lead_paragraph: Gypsy Rose Blanchard, who was convicted of helping to kill her abusive mother in a widely covered case, filed for divorce Monday from Ryan Anderson after just under two years of marriage, according to Louisiana court records.

headline: Office Subs
abstract: Caroline Sommers and Freddie Cheng place a few orders.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Beyoncé, ‘Cowboy Carter’ and Filling in History’s Gaps
abstract: A conversation about how the pop superstar’s genre experiments explore race and power, and the implicit politics that come with them.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Beyoncé released “Cowboy Carter,” an album that tackles the whole of American music, using country, roots and Americana as jumping off points for explorations of race and power and the implicit politics that come with them. It is currently the No. 1 album in the country, with the biggest debut week of the year so far.

headline: German Business Is Tangled in Red Tape
abstract: Companies in Germany complain that the demands of bureaucracy are costing them time and money that would be better spent building their businesses.
lead_paragraph: When Markus Wingens created the position of “energy manager” for the metal heat-treatment company he runs in southwestern Germany, his idea was to increase energy efficiency and attract customers interested in sustainability.

headline: How Japan Is Trying to Rebuild Its Chip Industry
abstract: Taiwan’s semiconductor giant, TSMC, is quickly remaking a farm town in Japan into Asia’s next hub of chip manufacturing with enormous government support.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company is transforming the small Japanese farm town of Kikuyo into a key node in Asia’s chip supply chain.

headline: ‘He’s Always Been Hungry for This’: Meet Ireland’s Youngest Ever Leader
abstract: After a swift political rise, Simon Harris, 37, was confirmed as Ireland’s premier. But his time as head of the government could be short.
lead_paragraph: Simon Harris was three years into a university degree when he dropped out in 2008.

headline: A Drone Strike in Odesa Shatters a Family’s Life
abstract: Serhii Haidarzhy’s wife and son were killed when their apartment building was hit. He and their daughter survived. The tragedy has become a symbol in Ukraine of the war’s terrible toll on civilians.
lead_paragraph: In the photograph, Anna Haidarzhy and her 4-month-old son, Tymofii, are barely visible under the bloodstained blanket. They lie in the rubble, at the feet of rescue workers in black and fluorescent uniforms. Just two arms, one from the mother, 31, one from her son, can be seen sticking out of the blanket.

headline: New Method That Pinpoints Wood’s Origin May Curb Illegal Timber
abstract: The study could help identify wood from Russia, which has been banned by many countries because of the war.
lead_paragraph: Using a unique combination of old-fashioned field work and sophisticated computer modeling, scientists in Sweden have found a way to trace a single beam of lumber to the forest in Europe where it originated.

headline: Banks Made Big Climate Promises. A New Study Doubts They Work.
abstract: Using European Central Bank lending data, researchers said there was not evidence that voluntary commitments were effective in reducing emissions.
lead_paragraph: Two and half years ago, bankers and investors attended the United Nations climate summit in Glasgow, an annual event normally dominated by activists and policymakers. It was considered a milestone as the financial sector agreed to put its might into tackling climate change.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Here Comes the Sun. And There It Goes.
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It puts perspective in the universe, perspective in your life.”

headline: Corrections: April 9, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about an earthquake that struck the Northeast described incorrectly a trip to the Empire State Building by Clara Dossetter and David Dossetter. Mr. Dossetter was visiting from San Francisco, but Ms. Dossetter lives in New York.

headline: These Nine Men Voted for Biden in 2020. How Do They See Him Now?
abstract: The participants discuss their views on Biden and the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: The participants discuss their views on Biden and the 2024 election.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Eclipse day in North America.
lead_paragraph: The first total solar eclipse in seven years plunged the day into darkness in Mexico, Canada and the U.S. yesterday, reminding millions of sky gazers of our planet’s place in the cosmos.

headline: Word of the Day: sophomoric
abstract: This word has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word sophomoric has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 12 in “It’s a Birkin! No, a Dior. No, a Balenciaga. What in the World is It?” by Vanessa Friedman:

headline: Seth Meyers Slams Trump’s $50 Million Fund-Raiser
abstract: Meyers said the dinner menu at a Palm Beach campaign event for Donald Trump “had so many foreign words, I’m surprised he didn’t have it deported.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Someday, Earth Will Have a Final Total Solar Eclipse
abstract: The moon will drift far enough from Earth that it no longer fully obstructs the sun. But predicting when this will happen poses numerous challenges.
lead_paragraph: The total solar eclipse visible on Monday over parts of Mexico, the United States and Canada was a perfect confluence of the sun and the moon in the sky. But it’s also the kind of event that comes with an expiration date: At some point in the distant future, Earth will experience its last total solar eclipse.

headline: To Choose the Menu, Just Win the Masters
abstract: The winner of the most hallowed event in professional golf gets to design the menu (and pay) for the next year’s champions dinner. Jon Rahm, the 2023 winner, supplied a recipe from his grandmother.
lead_paragraph: The winner of the Masters Tournament gets a green jacket, an elegantly engraved trophy and a lifetime invitation to play one of the most revered events in professional golf.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: An Elementary School Tries a ‘Radical’ Idea: Staying Open 12 Hours a Day
abstract: A Brooklyn charter school is experimenting with a new way to help families by expanding the school day. Students can arrive at 7 a.m. and leave any time before 7 p.m. For free.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like a dream for some working parents: school for 12 hours a day, starting bright and early at 7 a.m. and ending after dinner, at 7 p.m., all completely free.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 303
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spring Cleaning
abstract: What are your favorite and least favorite household chores?
lead_paragraph: Is doing a big clean a spring ritual for you or your family? If so, what do you do? Do you look forward to this opportunity to spruce up your space each year? Or do you dread it?

headline: A Divided America Agrees on One Thing: The Eclipse Was Awesome
abstract: The solar eclipse helped unite America — or at least a very narrow band of it.
lead_paragraph: Aidan Hernandez lay on the sidewalk wearing his eclipse glasses and staring up. The day was cloudy in Eagle Pass, Texas, and for a while he was silent. Then the clouds parted and the sun appeared, obscured by the moon.

headline: How Often Do You Take Breaks From Your Phone?
abstract: What strategies do you use to have a healthier relationship with your devices?
lead_paragraph: Would you say you have a healthy relationship with your phone?

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: School Attendance, Bridge Collapse, NCAA Final
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Gazans Still Face Extreme Hardship as the Pace of Fighting Slows
abstract: Though Israel recently withdrew troops from southern Gaza, cease-fire negotiations continue and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu repeated his vow to invade Rafah.
lead_paragraph: In early March, the Muslim holy month of Ramadan began amid dashed hopes that negotiators would reach a deal for a pause in the fighting in Gaza.

headline: At U.N. Court, Germany Fights Allegations of Aiding Genocide
abstract: Nicaragua has accused Germany over its provision of military and financial aid to Israel. Germany said the case had “no basis in fact or law.”
lead_paragraph: Germany on Tuesday defended itself at the International Court of Justice against accusations that its arms shipments to Israel were furthering genocide in Gaza, arguing that most of the equipment it has supplied since Oct. 7 was nonlethal and that it has also been one of the largest donors of humanitarian aid to the Palestinians.

headline: Everything’s Fine, Potatoes in Line
abstract: In the midst of a political and environmental dispute between the Czech Republic and Poland over a coal mine, a potato salad contest is held in a small border town.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of a political and environmental dispute between the Czech Republic and Poland over a coal mine, a potato salad contest is held in a small border town.

headline: The Geopolitics of a Czech-Polish Potato Salad Competition
abstract: In the midst of a political and environmental dispute between the Czech Republic and Poland over a coal mine, a potato salad contest is held in a small border town.
lead_paragraph: In the fall of 2021, a pub in the mining town of Bogatynia, Poland, put up a sign: “We don’t serve Czechs.”

headline: The Ultimate Skin Care Routine for Your Body
abstract: Many people pay the most attention to the skin on their face, but the rest of your body needs care, too. Here’s how to give it what it needs.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’ve perfected a skin care routine for my face. Should I have something similar for the rest of my body?

headline: Is Apple Cider Vinegar Really a Cure-All?
abstract: It has been said to help with weight loss, blood sugar control, acne and more. But experts say the science is more nuanced.
lead_paragraph: On TikTok, a man swirls a tablespoon of apple cider vinegar into a cup of water, drinks it and eats two slices of pizza. Then, he tests his blood sugar. “These are the best results of all,” he says, showing a much lower spike on a blood sugar graph than when he ate the pizza without the vinegar.

headline: At Home With Doris Kearns Goodwin
abstract: It has taken the historian a while to adjust to leaving the Concord, Mass., farmhouse she shared with her husband. But Boston has its compensations.
lead_paragraph: It has taken the historian a while to adjust to leaving the Concord, Mass., farmhouse she shared with her husband. But Boston has its compensations.

headline: The Culture Warriors Are Coming for You Smart People
abstract: In Lionel Shriver’s new novel, judging intelligence and competence is a form of bigotry.
lead_paragraph: As a novelist, Lionel Shriver has made her strongest impressions selecting some hot issue of the day — school shootings, the American health care system, the ballooning of the U.S. national debt — and working it into a well-paced drama about its effects on one family. When this formula works, as it did best with “We Need to Talk About Kevin” (2003), the result can be riveting and also very popular. The intimacy of domestic politics moderates Shriver’s polemical side, which, when given free rein — as during an infamous 2016 speech she gave on cultural appropriation while wearing a sombrero — usually turns out to be smug, crude and obtuse.

headline: Two Women, United by Climate Change and the Man They Both Married
abstract: In her far-reaching latest novel, “The Limits,” Nell Freudenberger forges connections between the global and the familial.
lead_paragraph: “The future is already here,” goes a line usually attributed to William Gibson. “It’s just not very evenly distributed.” So it can seem with climate change. Floods in Libya, temperatures above 125 degrees in China and Iran, wildfires across Hawaii and Canada and Tenerife: Those of us lucky enough not to be directly affected by these multiplying events can only watch from the intimate but infinite distance of our phone screens, a peculiarly modern kind of powerlessness.

headline: Canada Wants to Regulate Online Content. Critics Say It Goes Too Far.
abstract: A bill introduced by the Canadian government to safeguard against online harms has stirred opposition from free speech advocates.
lead_paragraph: Canada has waded into the contentious issue of regulating online content with a sweeping proposal that would force technology companies to restrict and remove harmful material, especially posts involving children, that appears on their platforms.

headline: Climate Change Is Making Us Paranoid, Anxious and Angry
abstract: From dolphins with Alzheimer’s to cranky traffic judges, writes Clayton Page Aldern, the whole planet is going berserk.
lead_paragraph: We know, often with abject precision, what climate change is doing to our coasts, rainforests, wildfires and hurricanes; our immigration patterns, crop yields and insurance premiums. But what is it doing to our brains?

headline: A Father and a Daughter, Caught Up in Political Protests
abstract: In Jen Silverman’s new novel, “There’s Going to Be Trouble,” two generations of activists wrestle with the errors of the past as they strive to create a more survivable future.
lead_paragraph: I recently gave birth, and there are moments when I look at my son and feel the heavy knowledge that he will carry the burden of my mistakes. In other moments there’s lightness, for motherhood, in just a few months, has taught me that my influence is limited, despite my best attempts and biggest failures. That dichotomy is at the core of Jen Silverman’s smart, reflective new novel, “There’s Going to Be Trouble,” which follows two generations of activists wrestling with the errors of the past as they strive to draft a more survivable future.

headline: A Historian Makes Peace With Her Own History
abstract: It took Doris Kearns Goodwin a while to adjust to leaving the Concord, Mass., farmhouse she shared with her husband. But Boston has its compensations.
lead_paragraph: After Doris Kearns Goodwin’s husband died nearly six years ago, the couple’s home, a 19th-century farmhouse in Concord, Mass., no longer felt right.

headline: The Sounds That Made Her Move: ‘Music Fed My Life Force’
abstract: The choreographer Dianne McIntyre presents “In the Same Tongue,” a dance she calls “an artistic history of myself,” at the new Apollo Stages at the Victoria Theater.
lead_paragraph: It was the 1970s, and Dianne McIntyre was a dancer on a mission: to soak up live music, specifically, she said, “so-called avant-garde jazz,” free jazz or, when labels really start to irritate her, just “whatever.” Shows would end late, making this obsession a sunrise pursuit. “We’d leave at 2 a.m., get on the subway from Brooklyn or down in the Village,” she said in a video interview. “At 2 a.m., the subways came by very seldom, so we’d get home at 4 a.m., something like that. But we didn’t care. We had to go. We had to go hear the music.”

headline: What Happened When Captain Cook Went Crazy
abstract: In “The Wide Wide Sea,” Hampton Sides offers a fuller picture of the British explorer’s final voyage to the Pacific islands.
lead_paragraph: In January 1779, when the British explorer James Cook sailed into a volcanic bay known by Hawaiians as “the Pathway of the Gods,” he beheld thousands of people seemingly waiting for him on shore. Once he came on land, people prostrated themselves and chanted “Lono,” the name of a Hawaiian deity. Cook was bewildered.

headline: As Kushner’s Investment Firm Steps Out, the Potential Conflicts Are Growing
abstract: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners has invested more than $1.2 billion, much of it in firms abroad, drawing new scrutiny as his father-in-law, Donald Trump, again seeks the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Jared Kushner’s investment fund is not especially large by global finance standards. But as he gets it fully up and running, each step is bringing with it ethical issues that would only grow if his father-in-law, Donald J. Trump, should win another term as president.

headline: ‘Fallout’ Finds the Fun in an Apocalyptic Hellscape
abstract: TV’s latest big-ticket video game adaptation, from the creators of “Westworld,” takes a satirical, self-aware approach to the End Times.
lead_paragraph: The scream was just right — bloodcurdling, if also very funny — and the practical effects crew had finally found the proper volume and trajectory of the water cannon. The idea was to film what might happen if you ripped a man from the throat of a mutant salamander, exploding its guts like a giant water balloon.

headline: Election Officials Continue to Face Violent Threats
abstract: The New York Times received a file containing hundreds of violent messages against the Colorado secretary of state. Nick Corasaniti, a politics reporter for The New York Times, found that election officials across the country are facing a barrage of threatening messages.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times received a file containing hundreds of violent messages against the Colorado secretary of state. Nick Corasaniti, a politics reporter for The New York Times, found that election officials across the country are facing a barrage of threatening messages.

headline: For Jonathan Majors, a Year of Counseling
abstract: Majors, who has starred in Marvel movies, was found guilty of assaulting and harassing his then girlfriend. He avoided jail time.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the sentencing of Jonathan Majors, an actor who has appeared in Marvel movies.

headline: ‘Shogun’ Episode 8 Recap: Borrowed Time
abstract: As Toranaga trudges toward surrender, his closest allies wonder if the old samurai has really given up the fight.
lead_paragraph: Lord Toranaga is a sick man. Sick in his heart, grieving the loss of his son Nagakado, who died in a vain fight on his father’s behalf. Sick in his body, having contracted an illness on the long road back to Edo for Nagakado’s burial. The central scene of this week’s “Shogun” — perhaps the scene from the series so far — confronts vassal and viewer alike with an even more troubling question, one that it draws out for minute after excruciating minute: Is Lord Toranaga sick in his mind as well?

headline: Higher for Longer After All? Investors See Fed Rates Falling More Slowly.
abstract: Investors went into 2024 expecting the Federal Reserve to cut rates sharply. Stubborn inflation and quick growth call that into question.
lead_paragraph: Investors were betting big on Federal Reserve rate cuts at the start of 2024, wagering that central bankers would lower interest rates to around 4 percent by the end of the year. But after months of stubborn inflation and strong economic growth, the outlook is starting to look much less dramatic.

headline: The U.S. Urgently Needs a Bigger Grid. Here’s a Fast Solution.
abstract: A rarely used technique to upgrade old power lines could play a big role in fixing one of the largest obstacles facing clean energy, two reports found.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest obstacles to expanding clean energy in the United States is a lack of power lines. Building new transmission lines can take a decade or more because of permitting delays and local opposition. But there may be a faster, cheaper solution, according to two reports released Tuesday.

headline: A Conductor Who Believes That No Artist Can Be Apolitical
abstract: At Munich’s prestigious opera house, the Russian-born Vladimir Jurowski has broadened the repertoire while rooting his work in political awareness.
lead_paragraph: One by one, the singers came out to bow. They had just finished a performance of Mieczyslaw Weinberg’s little-known “The Passenger,” at the Bayerische Staatsoper, or Bavarian State Opera. Each received not just respectful, but also enthusiastic applause. The loudest cheers, though, were reserved for the conductor: Vladimir Jurowski.

headline: Fjords, Pharaohs or Koalas? Time to Plan for Your Next Eclipse.
abstract: If you can’t get enough of totality, or missed out this time, you’ll have three more chances in the next four years in destinations like Iceland, Spain, Egypt and Australia.
lead_paragraph: Are you still a little giddy from the magical moments of totality during Monday’s solar eclipse? Or did clouds swoop in to block your view? Maybe you just couldn’t make it to the path of totality this time. No matter what, the question now is “Where and when will it happen again?”

headline: Everyone Wants to Seize Russia’s Money. It’s a Terrible Idea.
abstract: The dollar is probably the most valuable strategic asset the United States has.
lead_paragraph: The Republican House speaker, Mike Johnson, has brought a glimmer of hope to supporters of the Ukrainian war effort. He suggested to Fox News on March 31 that he would try to rally his divided party behind the REPO Act. That piece of legislation would allow President Biden, working with European allies, to seize Russian currency reserves frozen in the West and use them to aid Ukraine.

headline: These Scientists Rock. Literally.
abstract: The Pasteur Institute in Paris, known for its world-altering scientific research, has been making advancements in another field: the musical arts.
lead_paragraph: The Pasteur Institute, since opening in the 15th Arrondissement in Paris in the late 1880s, has been recognized for world-altering scientific discoveries. The institute, named for Louis Pasteur, the pioneering French scientist who founded it, has contributed to the production of vaccines for tetanus and the flu and was at the forefront of discovering the virus that causes AIDS.

headline: The 25 Best Restaurants in Chicago Right Now
abstract: We scouted the city’s vast food scene, from stellar hot dogs and renowned Italian beefs to refined tasting menus. (And we’re here for your comments.).
lead_paragraph: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.

headline: The Fidelity of ‘Originalist’ Justices Is About to Be Tested
abstract: Will the court’s conservatives flinch in the face of two polarizing gun cases?
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court reputedly has a long-awaited conservative majority committed to enforcing the meaning of the Constitution as it was understood when it was adopted. This commitment to originalist interpretation will soon be tested in two cases now before the court that have what lawyers call bad optics.

headline: What’s Next for Jane Goodall? An Immersive Spectacle in Tanzania.
abstract: “Dr. Jane’s Dream” is going up in East Africa, where visitors can experience the primatologist’s scientific breakthroughs (complete with termite mound).
lead_paragraph: Are you ready for the Jane Goodall Experience?

headline: Parents of Michigan School Shooter Sentenced to 10 to 15 Years in Prison
abstract: Jennifer and James Crumbley, whose son killed four people, each faced up to 15 years in prison for involuntary manslaughter convictions.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer and James Crumbley, who were convicted of involuntary manslaughter for failing to prevent their teenage son from killing four fellow students in the deadliest school shooting in Michigan’s history, were each sentenced on Tuesday to 10 to 15 years in prison.

headline: The Man Who Snuffed Out Abortion Rights Is Here to Tell You He Is a Moderate
abstract: He landed a major blow against legal abortion during his first term. If given a second, he will land another.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump does not speak from conviction. He does not speak from belief or at least any belief other than self-obsession. He certainly does not speak from anything we might recognize as reason; when he’s holding forth at a microphone, even the most careful students of Trump the rhetorician will struggle to find the light of complex thought.

headline: How a ‘Nerdy’ Prosecutor Became the First to Try Trump
abstract: Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan D.A., campaigned as the best candidate to go after the former president. Now he finds himself leading Trump’s first prosecution — and perhaps the only one before the November election.
lead_paragraph: Reporters vied for seats in the briefing room, some even crouching on the floor. They all knew, on this Tuesday in early April 2023, that Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, was about to announce something momentous: the first criminal charges against a former American president.

headline: 50 Years After Historic Home Run, Hank Aaron Gets a Stamp and a Statue
abstract: The baseball legend hit his record-breaking home run on April 8, 1974. His statue will be unveiled at the Baseball Hall of Fame in May.
lead_paragraph: Hank Aaron, the celebrated baseball player who faced down racism as he broke the Major League Baseball record for most career home runs, was honored on Monday with a United States Postal Service Forever stamp and a statue at baseball’s Hall of Fame.

headline: In Landmark Climate Ruling, European Court Faults Switzerland
abstract: Experts said it was the first time an international court determined that governments were legally obligated to meet their climate targets under human rights law.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s top human rights court said on Tuesday that the Swiss government had violated its citizens’ human rights by not doing enough to stop climate change, a landmark ruling that experts said could bolster activists hoping to use human rights law to hold governments to account.

headline: How Tesla Planted the Seeds for Its Own Potential Downfall
abstract: Elon Musk’s factory in China saved his company and made him ultrarich. Now, it may backfire.
lead_paragraph: When Elon Musk set up Tesla’s factory in China, he made a bet that brought him cheap parts and capable workers — a bet that made him ultrarich and saved his company.

headline: Trump’s Calculus on Abortion, and Iran’s Secret Smuggling Network
abstract: Plus, the fight against “deepnudes.”
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Iran Smuggles Arms to West Bank, Officials Say, to Foment Unrest With Israel
abstract: The covert operation, described by U.S., Iranian and Israeli officials, is heightening concerns that Iran is seeking to turn the West Bank into a flashpoint in its shadow war with Israel.
lead_paragraph: Iran is operating a clandestine smuggling route across the Middle East, employing intelligence operatives, militants and criminal gangs, to deliver weapons to Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, according to officials from the United States, Israel and Iran.

headline: Looking Up, Together
abstract: We cover the solar eclipse that captivated the U.S.
lead_paragraph: As the moon crossed over the sun yesterday, millions of people from Mazatlán to Maine stopped to gaze upward in a profound experience of awe. The solar eclipse tapped into a primal emotion. It evoked for many a mystical moment, as awareness of the celestial encompassed the earth. It revealed the close dance between spirituality and science.

headline: Greene Escalates Threat Against Johnson, Making the Case for His Ouster
abstract: In a letter to Republicans, the far-right lawmaker from Georgia said the speaker had presided over a “complete and total surrender” to Democrats and President Biden, and must change course or be unseated.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene on Tuesday escalated her threat to oust Speaker Mike Johnson, distributing a scathing letter that made the case for his removal and took Republicans to task for tolerating his leadership.

headline: Should Alcoholic Beverages Have Cancer Warning Labels?
abstract: Ireland will require them starting in 2026, and there are nascent efforts elsewhere to add more explicit labeling about the health risks of drinking.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen words are roiling the global alcohol industry.

headline: Xi Meets With Russia’s Foreign Minister, Reaffirming Ties
abstract: The visit came days after the U.S. threatened new sanctions against Chinese companies if they aided Russia’s war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, and Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, met in Beijing on Tuesday, in a session seen as laying the groundwork for an expected visit to China by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and pushing back against mounting pressure from the United States and its allies.

headline: Fortune Magazine Names a New C.E.O.
abstract: Anastasia Nyrkovskaya, who was the chief financial officer and chief strategy officer, is the first woman to run the company.
lead_paragraph: Fortune named Anastasia Nyrkovskaya as its next chief executive on Tuesday, making her the first woman to lead the 95-year-old business publication.

headline: How Low Will They Go? Wall Street’s Big Rethink on Interest Rate Cuts
abstract: Investors see Wednesday’s Consumer Price Index report as a pivotal report card on inflation and the Federal Reserve’s next move.
lead_paragraph: The mood music on rate cuts has changed again. Inflation hasn’t fallen as quickly as expected and the economy is performing strongly. All eyes now are focused on the upcoming Consumer Price Index data for clues on when the Fed might finally start cutting interest rates.

headline: Want to See This Film? Movie Studios Won’t Let You.
abstract: As in the case of ‘Coyote vs. Acme,’ sometimes an entertainment company sees more value in not selling you its products.
lead_paragraph: In early February, strange news appeared about Warner Brothers Discovery’s plans for one of its films, a live-action-with-animation spin on Looney Tunes called “Coyote vs. Acme.” The studio did not plan to release the movie. It had tried to sell it to a third party — one industry report said Netflix, Amazon and Paramount were all interested — but no deal materialized. Audiences seemed unlikely to ever see the thing.

headline: To Cut Cancer Risks, E.P.A. Limits Pollution From Chemical Plants
abstract: The new regulation is aimed at reducing the risk of cancer for people who live close to plants emitting toxic chemicals.
lead_paragraph: More than 200 chemical plants across the country will be required to curb the toxic pollutants they release into the air under a regulation announced by the Biden administration on Tuesday.

headline: How Ozempic Turned a 1970s Hit Into an Inescapable Jingle
abstract: The diabetes drug has become a phenomenon, and “Oh, oh, oh, Ozempic!” — a takeoff of the Pilot song “Magic” — has played a big part in its story.
lead_paragraph: In February 2023, David Paton, guitar case in hand, strode across the most famous pedestrian walkway in rock history and into London’s Abbey Road Studios.

headline: California Is in Bloom Again
abstract: Wildflowers are beginning to spring to life across the state after another wet winter.
lead_paragraph: Spring has sprung in the Golden State.

headline: Heartbreak and Family Love on the International Booker Prize Shortlist
abstract: Books by Jenny Erpenbeck and Hwang Sok-yong are among six nominees for the prestigious award for translated fiction.
lead_paragraph: A novel about a woman grieving her twin and another tracing North and South Korean history through a family of railway workers are among the six titles nominated for this year’s International Booker Prize, the prestigious award for fiction translated into English.

headline: Downtown Los Angeles Places Another Big Bet on the Arts
abstract: The pandemic was tough on city centers and cultural institutions. What does that mean for Los Angeles, whose downtown depends on the arts?
lead_paragraph: For decades the effort to revitalize downtown Los Angeles has been tied to arts projects, from the construction of the midcentury modern Music Center in 1964 to the addition of Frank Gehry’s soaring stainless steel Walt Disney Concert Hall in 2003.

headline: Norfolk Southern Settles Derailment Suit for $600 Million
abstract: The railroad company will pay residents and businesses in East Palestine, Ohio, and the surrounding area after a derailment last year.
lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to pay $600 million to settle a class-action lawsuit stemming from a February 2023 derailment of a train carrying hazardous materials in East Palestine, Ohio.

headline: A Heartland Godmother of Installation Art, No Longer in the Shadows
abstract: She is a trailblazer of the architectural sculpture movement, and her diaries rival Frida Kahlo’s. Are we ready for the unsettling clarity of Donna Dennis?
lead_paragraph: One of Donna Dennis’s architectural installations — a false tunnel entrance installed on the Mad River — so confounded local Ohioans that one morning in August 1981, someone pipe-bombed it. New York’s bomb squad confiscated part of another structure, a cabin occupying City Hall Park, in 1986. The works by Dennis are so faithful to existing vocabularies of infrastructure that they defy classification as art objects.

headline: A day after Trump’s abortion statement, Arizona awaits a key ruling.
abstract: A day after former President Donald J. Trump dominated headlines with a statement declaring that abortion policies should be left to the states, the issue will continue to be at the forefront of the nation’s political conversation.
lead_paragraph: A day after former President Donald J. Trump dominated headlines with a statement declaring that abortion policies should be left to the states, the issue will continue to be at the forefront of the nation’s political conversation.

headline: Nonprofit Theaters Are in Trouble. Lawmakers Are Proposing Help.
abstract: Proposed legislation would allocate $1 billion annually for an industry coping with rising expenses and smaller audiences.
lead_paragraph: The financial crisis facing nonprofit theaters in America has captured the attention of Congress, where a group of Democratic lawmakers is introducing legislation that would direct $1 billion annually to the struggling industry for five years.

headline: Turkey Restricts Exports to Israel in Protest of War in Gaza
abstract: Turkey announced limits on dozens of products, including cement and jet fuel, prompting Israel to threaten retaliatory trade measures.
lead_paragraph: Turkey said on Tuesday that it would restrict exports to Israel until there is a cease-fire in Gaza, prompting threats of a tit-for-tat response from a government with which it has long had tense relations.

headline: Security Increased for Champions League Games After ISIS Threats
abstract: Online messages urged violent attacks on four matches, prompting the police in England, France and Spain to step up precautions.
lead_paragraph: Public safety officials in England, France and Spain said Tuesday that they would step up security for matches this week in the Champions League, Europe’s marquee soccer competition, after ISIS-related groups called for violent attacks on the contests.

headline: Another Red-Blue Divide: Money to Feed Kids in the Summer
abstract: Congress passed bipartisan legislation to provide families that rely on subsidized school meals with help buying food over the summer. Nearly half of Republican-led states have yet to sign on.
lead_paragraph: The governor was firm: Nebraska would reject the new federal money for summer meals. The state already fed a small number of children when schools closed. He would not sign on to a program to provide all families that received free or cut-rate school meals with cards to buy groceries during the summer.

headline: Is This Maternity Hospital Haunted, or Is It All a Pregnant Metaphor?
abstract: In Clare Beams’s eerie new novel, “The Garden,” nefarious things are afoot.
lead_paragraph: THE GARDEN, by Clare Beams

headline: Internet Traffic Dipped as Viewers Took in the Eclipse
abstract: Internet traffic dropped by 40 percent or more during the eclipse in states in the path of totality, including Maine, New Hampshire and Ohio, Cloudflare found.
lead_paragraph: As the moon blocked the view of the sun across parts of Mexico, the United States and Canada on Monday, the celestial event managed another magnificent feat: It got people offline.

headline: ‘Fire Shut Up in My Bones’ Review: A Met Milestone Returns
abstract: After making history as the Metropolitan Opera’s first work by a Black composer, Terence Blanchard’s “Fire” is back — with its showstopping step dance.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera premiere of “Fire Shut Up in My Bones,” on Sept. 27, 2021, was a momentous event. Doubly so: “Fire” was the company’s first staged opera after an 18-month pandemic closure, and it was, after 138 years, its first work by a Black composer.

headline: Rut-Busting Recipes for Freezer Staples
abstract: Spicy ground turkey with snap peas, broccoli-walnut pesto pasta and sazón chicken breasts make frozen standbys sing.
lead_paragraph: Hi, all! This is Krysten, filling in for Emily, who’s back next week after a glorious spring break.

headline: Beeper Messaging App Is Acquired as a Bet on a Regulatory Shift
abstract: Automattic, the company behind WordPress.com, bought Beeper in an effort to build a system that works across Android and Apple devices.
lead_paragraph: Beeper, the app that brought iPhone messaging features to Android smartphones, has been acquired by Automattic, the company behind WordPress.com, to support the development of a single service for sending and receiving chats from WhatsApp, Signal, LinkedIn and others.

headline: Seriously, Now Is the Time to Stop Kissing Sick Birds
abstract: A citizen-science collaboration in New York has turned up a half-dozen birds infected with the avian flu virus.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers, beware: If you come across a bird or animal that is sick, dead or behaving strangely, keep yourself and your pets at a safe distance. The bird flu virus, H5N1, is present in at least some small fraction of New York City birds, according to a new study.

headline: Beut Takes a Modern Approach to Korean Royal Court Cuisine
abstract: Sawa brings Lebanese dishes to Park Slope, Brooklyn; Zaab Burger combines smash burgers and Thai flavors at Essex Market and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Korean Royal Court cuisine from the Joseon Dynasty (1392 to about 1900) inspired this tasting-menu restaurant owned by Sarah Kang, the pastry chef here and formerly of Joomak Banjum, the now-closed, Michelin-starred restaurant. An eight-course menu ($125) reflects the opulence of the bygone era through a modern lens by the executive chef, Sang Hoon Jeong. Lobster and Wagyu, not necessarily palace fare in the past, share the menu with more typical abalone with rice porridge, and a royal hot pot with scallops. Lobster three ways using meat, shells and offal demonstrates a tradition of letting nothing go to waste. The dining room is done in muted grays with several seating areas. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: What Happened When a German Car Factory Went All Electric
abstract: Volkswagen’s plant in Zwickau stopped producing Golfs and switched to electric vehicles, illuminating the risks and opportunities for factory towns and cities.
lead_paragraph: Zwickau, a city in Germany’s east, may not be as famous as Detroit, but its economy has revolved around internal combustion engines since August Horch established Audi here at the beginning of the 20th century.

headline: F.A.A. Investigates Claims by Boeing Whistle-Blower About Flaws in 787 Dreamliner
abstract: The whistle-blower, an engineer, says that sections of the plane’s body are being assembled in a way that could weaken the aircraft over time. Boeing says there is no safety issue.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating claims made by a Boeing engineer who says that sections of the fuselage of the 787 Dreamliner are improperly fastened together and could break apart mid-flight after thousands of trips.

headline: Workers Search for Bodies After Israel’s Withdrawal from Al-Shifa
abstract: Palestinian crews at Al-Shifa Hospital recovered human remains amid the rubble.
lead_paragraph: Palestinian crews at Al-Shifa Hospital recovered human remains amid the rubble.

headline: Biden’s Trade Moves Raise Tensions Abroad but Draw Cheers in Swing States
abstract: The president’s efforts to restrict Chinese imports and block a Japanese steel merger have pleased labor unions and sent a message to rival Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has intensified efforts to shield American industries from foreign competition in an election year, as he courts blue-collar workers and attempts to avoid being outflanked on trade by his Republican rival, former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Swing-State Republicans Embrace Trump’s New Abortion Stance
abstract: Several of the party’s candidates, particularly those in battleground states, said they favored letting states regulate the procedure instead of having a national ban.
lead_paragraph: Multiple Republican candidates in swing-state races aligned themselves with former President Donald J. Trump after he said abortion access should be left up to the states, avoiding mention of a national ban and laying bare the party’s rift over the issue.

headline: Herbert Kroemer, 95, Dies; Laid Groundwork for Modern Technologies
abstract: He shared a Nobel Prize in Physics for discoveries that paved the way for high-speed internet communication, mobile phones and bar-code readers.
lead_paragraph: Herbert Kroemer, a German-born American physicist who was awarded the Nobel Prize for his part in discoveries that paved the way for the development of many trappings of modern life, including high-speed internet communication, mobile phones and bar-code readers, died on March 8. He was 95.

headline: Trump’s Attempt to Delay Trial Is Denied by Appeals Court Judge
abstract: Donald Trump could try to have his request reviewed by a full judicial panel, but the opening of his case remains scheduled for Monday.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Mount Etna Puffs Perfect Smoke Rings Into Sicilian Sky
abstract: The volcano, one of Europe’s most active, has been spewing volcanic vortex rings at a rapid pace. But that doesn’t mean a big explosion is on the way, one expert says.
lead_paragraph: For just over a week, Mount Etna, one of Europe’s most active volcanoes, has been spewing circular, mostly white smoke rings into the skies over Sicily.

headline: Peter Higgs, Nobelist Who Predicted the ‘God Particle,’ Dies at 94
abstract: The Higgs boson was named for him. It was a key element of the Standard Model, which encapsulated all human knowledge so far about elementary particles.
lead_paragraph: Peter Higgs, who predicted the existence of a new particle that came to be named after him (as well as God) and sparked a half-century, worldwide, billion-dollar search for it culminating in champagne in 2012 and a Nobel Prize a year later, died on Monday at home in Edinburgh, Scotland. He was 94.

headline: A New Film Examines the Godfather of Modern Conservatism
abstract: The PBS documentary “The Incomparable Mr. Buckley” implicitly and explicitly asks: What would William F. Buckley think of today’s Republican Party?
lead_paragraph: William F. Buckley Jr., widely considered the godfather of modern conservatism, defended Joseph McCarthy and his communist witch hunts. He praised the “restraint” of Alabama law enforcement officers who brutally assaulted civil rights marchers on the Edmund Pettus Bridge in 1965. He was also a silver-tongued intellectual who abhorred boorish thinking and behavior and savored debates with the sharpest minds of his era.

headline: Arizona Reinstates 160-Year-Old Abortion Ban
abstract: The state’s highest court said the law, moribund for decades under Roe v. Wade, was now enforceable, but it put its decision on hold for a lower court to hear other challenges to the law.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s highest court on Tuesday upheld an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions, a decision that could have far-reaching consequences for women’s health care and election-year politics in a critical battleground state.

headline: Trump’s New Stance on Abortion
abstract: Readers discuss his statement that abortion policy should be left to the states. Also: J Street; student “brands”; GPS satellites; alternatives to social media.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: TV Networks to Urge Biden and Trump to Debate, Wading Into a Fraught Topic
abstract: Speculation has swirled in the political world about whether the presumptive candidates will agree to the traditional face-to-face events, a campaign staple since 1976.
lead_paragraph: In an unusual move, the five major broadcast and cable news networks have prepared a joint open letter that urges President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump to participate in televised debates ahead of Election Day, according to two people with direct knowledge of their plans.

headline: The Magnetic Fields Wrote ‘69 Love Songs.’ Here’s 11 of the Best.
abstract: A primer on the indie-rock band’s triple album, now celebrating its 25th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: I hope everyone who was in the path of Monday’s eclipse enjoyed the view! I confess I didn’t acquire eclipse glasses in time and couldn’t see anything too spectacular from where I was in Brooklyn, but at least Friday’s Amplifier playlist gave me a soundtrack for imagining some awe-inspiring grandeur.

headline: Why Oil Prices Have Been Rising Recently
abstract: The increase this year, prompted by geopolitical worries and supply constraints, has sent gasoline prices higher and could hamper efforts to tame inflation.
lead_paragraph: Oil prices have climbed in recent weeks, spurred by concerns over supplies and geopolitical risks, including wars in Ukraine and the Middle East. Analysts say the momentum could carry prices higher.

headline: More Voters Shift to Republican Party, Closing Gap With Democrats
abstract: The trend toward the Republican Party among white voters without a college degree has continued, and Democrats have lost ground among Hispanic voters, too.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the 2020 election, more voters across the country identified as Democrats than Republicans. But four years into Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidency, that gap has shrunk, and the United States now sits almost evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans.

headline: Stumbling Into Goldilocks
abstract: How America avoided recession (so far).
lead_paragraph: The U.S. economy has been far more successful at recovering from the Covid shock than it was in dealing with the aftermath of the housing bubble of the 2000s. As I noted in my latest column, four years after the 2007-9 recession began, employment was still five million below its pre-recession peak. This time it’s up by almost six million.

headline: Comics Artist Dies After Sexual Misconduct Accusations
abstract: Ed Piskor, 41, was known for his detailed “Hip Hop Family Tree” and “X-Men: Grand Design.” A Pittsburgh gallery didn’t open an exhibition of his work after the initial allegation.
lead_paragraph: The comics artist Ed Piskor, who was best known for his multivolume “Hip Hop Family Tree,” died last week after posting a lengthy note to social media about an accusation of sexual misconduct that led a gallery in Pittsburgh to indefinitely postpone an exhibition of his work.

headline: Food Aid Program for Mothers and Children Will Provide More Fruits and Vegetables
abstract: The Agriculture Department updated the WIC program to more closely align with nutrition guidelines. The changes also reduce assistance for milk and juice.
lead_paragraph: The Agriculture Department said on Tuesday that low-income women and children eligible for a food aid program would receive more cash for purchases of fruits and vegetables, with less assistance available for milk.

headline: Michigan Vascular Clinics Shutting Down After Scrutiny
abstract: The clinics’ owner, Dr. Jihad Mustapha, who called himself the “leg saver” but whose procedures sometimes preceded amputations, was a focus of a Times investigation last year.
lead_paragraph: A doctor who called himself the “leg saver” is shutting down his vascular clinics in Michigan, where he performed thousands of lucrative procedures that have come under scrutiny for being unnecessary and potentially dangerous.

headline: Woman Sentenced to Month in Prison Over Theft of Ashley Biden’s Diary
abstract: Aimee Harris sold the diary to Project Veritas, a right-wing group, in what prosecutors said was a brazen plot to damage Joseph R. Biden Jr. in the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a Florida woman on Tuesday to one month behind bars for her role in a brazen scheme to steal the diary of President Biden’s daughter and sell it to a right-wing group in the hope of disrupting the 2020 election.

headline: Capitol Police Hire Special Prosecutors to Handle Rise in Threats Against Congress
abstract: The police department charged with protecting lawmakers has brought in new attorneys specially responsible for prosecuting people who make violent threats against members of Congress.
lead_paragraph: The Capitol Police, facing a flood of violent threats against members of Congress that is expected to rise with the upcoming November elections, have begun hiring prosecutors dedicated to going after people who threaten lawmakers.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Are You Your Father’s Daughter?’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: In the yellow house on San Marco Drive, my father did my taxes. “Do you have your receipts from the move?” he asked. That was a fake question. The real questions were stacked behind it: Are you your father’s daughter? Are your affairs — is your life — in order? “Yes,” I said proudly, producing an envelope of gasoline and fast-food receipts from my drive south, Pennsylvania to Florida. A financial diary of my fresh start. “Good girl,” he said. With him 20 years gone, I repeat those words to myself when I need his gentle hand on my back. — Maggie Galehouse

headline: Abortion Jumps to the Center of Arizona’s Key 2024 Races
abstract: Democrats quickly aimed to capitalize on a ruling by the state’s highest court upholding an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.
lead_paragraph: Democrats seized on a ruling on Tuesday by Arizona’s highest court upholding an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions, setting up a fierce political fight over the issue that is likely to dominate the presidential election and a pivotal Senate race in a crucial battleground state.

headline: How the Solar Eclipse Affected Eid Timing
abstract: Some Muslim communities rely on a centuries-old method to determine when Ramadan ends: a crescent moon. That method was harder to follow this year.
lead_paragraph: For centuries, the sighting of a crescent moon has signaled the end of Ramadan, the holy month of fast and prayer for Muslims.

headline: Read the Arizona Supreme Court’s Abortion Ruling
abstract: The state’s highest court on Tuesday upheld an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.
lead_paragraph: The state’s highest court on Tuesday upheld an 1864 law that bans nearly all abortions.

headline: Austin Pushes Back on Claims of Israel Carrying Out Genocide in Gaza
abstract: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III made the comments during a hearing that was disrupted several times by protests of U.S. support for Israel’s assault on Hamas.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III told a Senate committee on Tuesday that the Pentagon had no evidence that Israel was carrying out a genocide against Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Biden Condemns Arizona’s Abortion Ban as ‘Cruel’ and ‘Extreme’
abstract: President Biden, who promised to continue to fight for the restoration of Roe v. Wade, said the ban was first enacted “well before women had secured the right to vote.”
lead_paragraph: President Biden condemned a decision by Arizona’s Supreme Court on Tuesday to uphold an 1864 ban on nearly all abortions as “cruel” and “extreme,” saying the law was first enacted well before women even had the right to vote.

headline: Three Greenhouse Gases, Three All-Time Highs
abstract: Why atmospheric concentrations hit record levels last year.
lead_paragraph: The extreme weather. The melting glaciers. The weirdly warm oceans. They’re all the product of global warming, which is being driven by the release of the three most important heat-trapping gases: carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide.

headline: Cameron, on U.S. Trip, Takes a Risk and Meets With Trump
abstract: David Cameron, the British foreign secretary, said he spoke with Donald Trump, the former, and possibly future, president, about Ukraine and the Israel-Gaza conflict.
lead_paragraph: When Britain’s foreign secretary, David Cameron, went to Washington on Tuesday, he made all the usual stops, from the State Department to Capitol Hill. But it was his pilgrimage to Palm Beach, Fla., where he met former President Donald J. Trump for dinner on Monday evening at Mar-a-Lago, that grabbed most of the attention.

headline: Biden Courts Caregivers, Pledging to Expand Support if He Is Re-elected
