lead_paragraph: In August 2018, Svetlana Dotsenko and Fabián Alejandro Poliak were visiting the Peterhof palace complex in St. Petersburg, Russia, when Mr. Poliak decided to make a move.

headline: Corrections: April 12, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, April 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about an Israeli airstrike that killed the three sons of a senior Hamas official paraphrased incorrectly a Hamas official’s comments about a possible hostage exchange. The official said Hamas sent a message to international mediators that the group did not have hostages who met the criteria for an exchange under a proposed cease-fire agreement with Israel being negotiated. He did not say that Hamas could not locate them in a message sent directly to Israel.

headline: Quotation of the Day: A Battle for the White House, Fought With Beading and Silk
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Dr. Biden and Mrs. Trump are two supporting actors in a TV show that will run from now through November.”

headline: ‘Catching Feelings’ After a Steamy Encounter on the Dance Floor
abstract: Elena Bauer and Joshua Fagel weren’t looking for anything serious when they first met at a fraternity party at Stanford. A month after meeting, they had a change of heart.
lead_paragraph: Elena Isabel Bauer and Joshua Daniel Fagel’s relationship started as what they both refer to as a “D.F.M.O.,” or a “dance floor make out.” They met April 15, 2016, on the “gross, grimy dance floor” at Mr. Fagel’s fraternity house, Sigma Nu, on Stanford’s campus. “Our feet were sticking to the floor,” Mr. Fagel said. “It was straight out of a movie.”

headline: Europe’s A.I. ‘Champion’ Sets Sights on Tech Giants in U.S.
abstract: Mistral, a French start-up considered a promising challenger to OpenAI and Google, is getting support from European leaders who want to protect the region’s culture and politics.
lead_paragraph: Arthur Mensch, tall and lean with a flop of unkempt hair, arrived for a speech last month at a sprawling tech hub in Paris wearing jeans and carrying a bicycle helmet. He had an unassuming look for a person European officials are counting on to help propel the region into a high-stakes match with the United States and China over artificial intelligence.

headline: Indigenous Authors and the Challenge of Telling Their Own Story
abstract: A university program seeks to improve cross-cultural understanding in Australia’s publishing industry.
lead_paragraph: Eyes closed, head raised, leaning back against the polished stone of the Old Physics Building on the campus of the University of Melbourne, Marie Elena Ellis paused briefly to breathe in the sunshine before heading back indoors to resume talking about publishing.

headline: Teaching Patients How to Heal
abstract: A simple yet radical approach in Asia is equipping medical patients and their loved ones with the knowledge they need to heal themselves.
lead_paragraph: By around 2 p.m., just after lunch, activity at the critical care unit of the Jayadeva hospital in Bengaluru, India, is at an ebb. No one is running down the halls with X-rays, bills or samples of body fluids to be tested. The morning rounds are over. The doctors are gone, and the nursing shift has just changed.

headline: O.J. and the Monster Jealousy
abstract: I always thought of the Simpson case as a great American tragedy, with its echoes of “Othello.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, I went over to South Bundy Drive in Brentwood, where the double murder happened. O.J. Simpson was dead at 76. And that famous scene of violence was eerily quiet on a shimmering spring day in Los Angeles.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: A U.S. general goes to Israel.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. sent its top military commander for the Middle East to Israel to discuss a widely expected retaliatory attack from Iran, officials said.

headline: Late Night Mocks Trump for Failed Efforts to Delay Trial
abstract: “You know what they say: If at first, second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh, eighth, ninth or tenth you don’t succeed, cry, cry again,” Jimmy Kimmel said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: succinctly
abstract: This word has appeared in 54 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word succinctly has appeared in 54 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 4 in “Why Is There No Oscar for Best Choreography?” by Margaret Fuhrer:

headline: Even Before the Olympics, a Victory Lap for a Fast-Moving French Mayor
abstract: Karim Bouamrane, the Socialist mayor of St.-Ouen, a Paris suburb that will host the athletes’ village for the 2024 Games, is leading a rapid transformation of the long-struggling city.
lead_paragraph: The mayor grew up in a building so decrepit — filthy hallways, no private toilets, no showers — that his friends in nearby concrete towers pitied him.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Can a Christian Community Close the Beach on Sunday Mornings?
abstract: In Ocean Grove, N.J., a conservative religious organization sets the rules. The state has challenged its right to keep sunbathers off the sand.
lead_paragraph: Along the Atlantic coast, about 60 miles south of Manhattan, is a beach town that defies the rowdy image of the Jersey Shore.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Battle Over Zaza Waza: A Lifelong Liberal Joins New York’s Weed War
abstract: When an illegal smoke shop opened across the street, Gale Brewer, a local councilwoman, vowed to close it. What happened next was “like a Fellini movie.”
lead_paragraph: The informal walking tour came to a pause on Amsterdam Avenue, outside a brick building where a beloved Upper West Side pizzeria had recently been replaced by yet another rogue weed shop.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 306
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Sexism, Hate, Mental Illness: Why Are Men Randomly Punching Women?
abstract: Conversation about the attacks on the streets of New York have centered on mental illness, but the offenses seem to have their roots in hatred of women.
lead_paragraph: Before her trip to New York a few weeks ago, Lisa Pires, a South African living in Amsterdam, encountered a series of videos on TikTok in which young women had filmed themselves after getting attacked on the street in New York. Most were punched in the face — unprovoked, at random — in Manhattan south of Midtown and during the day. “I remember thinking it sounded so absurd that it couldn’t really have been a thing,” Ms. Pires, who comes to the city often, told me recently.

headline: Tiny House
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Can Poetry Make a Difference in Our Lives and in the World?
abstract: April is National Poetry Month. What role does poetry play in your life?
lead_paragraph: How important is poetry in your life? Do you read or write it? Do you ever turn to poems when you are feeling lost or overwhelmed? When you need comfort or direction?

headline: How the War in Gaza Mobilized the American Left
abstract: As the death toll in Gaza climbed, the pro-Palestinian movement grew into a powerful, if disjointed, political force in the United States. Democrats are feeling the pressure.
lead_paragraph: Support for Palestinians, a cause once largely championed on college campuses and in communities with ties to the region, has transformed into a defining issue of the Democratic left, galvanizing a broad swath of groups into the most significant protest movement of the Biden era.

headline: Road Trips: How to Plan an Accessible Getaway
abstract: If you have a disability, you’ll want to review route planning, lodging options, food requirements and finding the right rental vehicle.
lead_paragraph: Planning an accessible road trip is getting a little easier for people with disabilities. There are more resources created by and for the disability community, and the tourism industry is starting to recognize the value of accessible travel. As a disabled, chronically ill, neurodivergent person, I take road trips every year and have learned some tips and tricks along the way.

headline: Different Styles, Different Stories in April’s Graphic Novels
abstract: Minimalist landscapes, maximalist extraterrestrials and schlock movie stars populate this month’s diverse offerings.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, design is everything. In SPIRAL AND OTHER STORIES (New York Review Comics, 208 pp., $24.95), by Aidan Koch, the cartoonist’s assured minimalism focuses on details — a grape, the contour of a face — that might also be a part of her book’s rich natural landscapes. The collection’s construction is appropriately elliptical: It begins with its longest and most complex story, “Spiral,” which is drawn in watercolor and pencil and written in koan-like realistic dialogue and poetic narration that bleed into each other. One beautiful sequence shows the narrator’s thoughts occupying different positions in a series of large, otherwise blank panels. “Clouds,” Koch writes at the top corner of one panel; “I miss her” in the middle. It’s subtle, but ultimately realistic.

headline: Ghost Kitchens Are Disappearing, Squeezed by Demand and Complaints
abstract: Delivery-only operations boomed during the pandemic. Now Wendy’s, Kroger and mom-and-pop food businesses are rethinking their operations.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the kitchen inside a Denny’s in the Jackson Heights neighborhood of Queens was bustling.

headline: A Child’s-Eye View of One Black Family’s Covered-Wagon Journey
abstract: Lesa Cline-Ransome’s new novel in verse adds female voices to the late-19th-century Black homesteaders movement.
lead_paragraph: From a history book released in paperback in 1992, during my freshman year of college, I learned about the thousands of Black people who left the South in the late 19th century to move to the West, pursuing freedoms promised by the Homestead Act of 1862. The feminist Nell Irvin Painter’s “Exodusters: Black Migration to Kansas After Reconstruction,” originally published in 1977, was one of the first detailed studies of this mass movement by an African American historian.

headline: A ‘Missionary for Opera’ Steps Down in Chicago
abstract: Anthony Freud is leaving Lyric Opera of Chicago on good terms, though the company faces challenges in a strained environment for the performing arts.
lead_paragraph: In 1975, Anthony Freud went to a performance that changed his life.

headline: Audiobooks to Lull You to Sleep
abstract: No, they’re not boring. But the charm and magic of these audiobooks make them the ideal bedtime stories for adults.
lead_paragraph: As any insomniac knows, the world can be a lonely place when you’re the last one awake. Why not download an audiobook for company? The breezy appeal of these mellifluous romances and fantastical adventures can whisk the widest-eyed night owl straight to dreamland.

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in Athens
abstract: A two-level penthouse on the Athens Riviera, an industrial-flavored loft with Acropolis views, and a custom-built villa just south of central Athens.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom, three-bath apartment is on the top two floors of a modern five-story building midway between Glyfada and Voula, two development hot spots on the 37-mile strip dubbed the Athens Riviera for its Aegean coast setting. Its neighbors include high-end projects like the new One&Only Aesthesis resort, the Four Seasons Astir Palace Hotel Athens, and 91 Athens Riviera, the area’s first private members’ club. Along with bars, cafes and dining, there are supermarkets, schools, gyms and pharmacies within walking distance of the apartment.

headline: With State Bans on D.E.I., Some Universities Find a Workaround: Rebranding
abstract: Welcome to the new “Office of Access and Engagement.” Schools are renaming departments and job titles to try to preserve diversity programs.
lead_paragraph: At the University of Tennessee, the campus D.E.I. program is now called the Division of Access and Engagement.

headline: Her Arm Was Unbearably Swollen and Painful. What Was Causing It?
abstract: A persistent ache had spread throughout her shoulder, down to her elbow. Was her tennis-playing responsible?
lead_paragraph: “Hell, no!” the man exclaimed as he saw his 49-year-old wife enter the kitchen. Her right arm was huge, swollen. “You have to go to the E.R.,” he said. She was wearing a strapless summer dress, and her bare tanned shoulders made it easy to see that her entire arm, from wrist to clavicle, was much larger than her left, as if somehow it had been pumped full of air.

headline: V.A. Loans Don’t Cover Commissions. How Will Veterans Afford New Fees?
abstract: The V.A. loan prohibits borrowers from paying commissions to real estate agents — a rule that could put veterans at a great disadvantage when buying a house.
lead_paragraph: A recent landmark settlement that could significantly change how real estate agents are paid could also have an adverse effect on a sector of potential home buyers who often rely on government-backed mortgages: military veterans.

headline: Where Kamala Harris Lives, a Little-Known History of Enslavement
abstract: The vice president’s official residence is in a quiet Washington enclave once home to 34 enslaved people. Ms. Harris has sought to reconnect the property to its Black heritage.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago this month, Vice President Kamala Harris moved into her official residence in northwest Washington, a quiet 73-acre enclave where the U.S. Navy keeps an observatory as well as the nation’s master clock. Early in her stay she saw evidence of digging near her house, and after asking around, learned that an archaeological team had recently found part of a foundation of an Italianate villa, known as North View, that had been there more than a century and a half before.

headline: Flaco Is Gone. For Some Fans, His Legacy Lives On in Ink.
abstract: A tattoo shop in Brooklyn offered original designs of the owl. Flaco admirers who got them said the bird was a symbol of freedom.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a tattoo parlor in Brooklyn that offered original designs of Flaco the Eurasian eagle-owl at a discounted rate.

headline: The Troubling Trend in Teenage Sex
abstract: Choking has moved from porn to pop culture to the dorm room. And the consequences for young women could be very serious.
lead_paragraph: Debby Herbenick is one of the foremost researchers on American sexual behavior. The director of the Center for Sexual Health Promotion at Indiana University and the author of the pointedly titled book “Yes, Your Kid,” she usually shares her data, no matter how explicit, without judgment. So I was surprised by how concerned she seemed when we checked in on Zoom recently: “I haven’t often felt so strongly about getting research out there,” she told me. “But this is lifesaving.”

headline: Abortion Is Dividing the ‘Religious’ From the ‘Right’
abstract: Does God have to be Republican?
lead_paragraph: This week, the “Matter of Opinion” hosts debate how religious voters will react to Donald Trump’s betrayal of anti-abortion positions, the evolution of Christianity as the domain of the right and whether religion is actually as powerful as it seems in modern U.S. politics.

headline: A Hollywood Remake of Your Fast Food Memories
abstract: In Los Angeles, the restaurant Chain taps into a feverish nostalgia for burgers and pizza from the 20th century.
lead_paragraph: The air smelled of yeast and cheese and weed, and though what I had in front of me looked like a personal pan pizza from Pizza Hut, it was in fact a more expensive dupe.

headline: This ‘Sympathizer’ Star Wasn’t Sure He Was Right for the Job
abstract: Hoa Xuande had only one Hollywood credit when he was chosen to lead this starry HBO adaptation of a prize-winning novel. He needed all the encouragement he could get.
lead_paragraph: Some three months into shooting “The Sympathizer,” Robert Downey Jr. sat Hoa Xuande down. He had something to show him.

headline: Tell Us About the Mother Figures in Your Life
abstract: With Mother’s Day around the corner, we’re looking for stories about the various ways you have mothered or been mothered.
lead_paragraph: Maybe it was a beloved aunt who cheered for you at every game, concert or graduation ceremony. Perhaps it was a teacher who sensed when you needed extra emotional support. Or it could have been a friend who gradually became your chosen family.

headline: What if Dario Amodei Is Right About A.I.?
abstract: Anthropic’s co-founder and C.E.O. explains why he thinks artificial intelligence is on an “exponential curve.”
lead_paragraph: Back in 2018, Dario Amodei worked at OpenAI. And looking at one of its first A.I. models, he wondered: What would happen as you fed an artificial intelligence more and more data?

headline: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about even if you’re not planning to see them.
lead_paragraph: Alex Garland’s “Civil War” is set in a near-future when the United States is at war with itself and something called the Western Forces, made up of Texas and California, is fighting the federal government.

headline: Kamala Harris, Traveling to Arizona, Will Slam Trump Over Abortion
abstract: The vice president is set to lean into a partywide attack on Donald Trump and fellow Republicans, who are newly on the defensive over the issue.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris will travel to Arizona on Friday to assail former President Donald J. Trump over abortion restrictions, with plans to blame him for bans in the state and across the country.

headline: The O.J. Simpson White Bronco Is Now a Museum Piece. In Tennessee.
abstract: The vehicle that Simpson fled in as 95 million Americans watched on television is on display at the Alcatraz East Crime Museum in Pigeon Forge, Tenn.
lead_paragraph: Tyler Starrett was on vacation with his family in Pigeon Forge, about 35 miles from Knoxville in eastern Tennessee, when they learned on Thursday that O.J. Simpson had died.

headline: Biden’s Plan B on Inflation: Turn It Against Trump
abstract: Price pressures aren’t easing fast enough to guarantee the interest-rate cuts the president hoped to see by November, so his message is evolving.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his economic team had high hopes about how two years of rapid inflation would play out in the months leading to the November presidential election. Price growth would continue to cool. The Federal Reserve would cut interest rates. Mortgage rates and other borrowing costs would fall. Consumer moods would improve, and so would Mr. Biden’s re-election prospects.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Civil War.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Civil War.

headline: ‘Civil War’ and Its Terrifying Premonition of American Collapse
abstract: Alex Garland’s film isn’t nearly as apolitical as its critics say.
lead_paragraph: Going into Alex Garland’s astonishing new film, “Civil War,” I expected to be irritated by the implausibility of its premise. I’m not talking about the idea that America could devolve into vicious internecine armed conflict. That seems possible, if not probable. In one 2022 poll, 43 percent of Americans said they thought a civil war within the next decade was at least somewhat likely. I wouldn’t go that far, but I won’t be surprised if political violence spikes after the upcoming election and eventually spirals out of control. I’m pretty confident, however, that if the sort of war Garland depicts ever actually broke out in this beleaguered nation, California and Texas wouldn’t be on the same side.

headline: O.J. Was an Earthquake. We’re Still Living With His Aftershocks.
abstract: He tried to shed his Blackness, but his all-consuming murder trial put the historically lurid American psyche on full display.
lead_paragraph: When our Great Americans go, we know how to mourn them. Their lives were so grand, so architectural, infrastructural, awesome, admired, adventurous, outsize, so representative of some (or many) of this country’s ideals that the elegies come gushing. But there’s a Great American subset — where the adventure rocks the infrastructure and the life leaves a gash. Our Seismic Americans. That was O.J. Simpson. What’d he register? Almost a 9?

headline: There’s More to a Home Bar Than Liquor. Here’s What Else You Need.
abstract: An artful display tells your guests you care about them — and it’s easier to create than you may think.
lead_paragraph: Even if you’re not a big drinker, it’s worth taking the time to set up a home bar.

headline: Democratic Coalition Sends Biden a Demand on Military Aid to Israel
abstract: In a letter, a dozen groups and labor unions called on the president to enforce a law that bars military support from going to any nation that restricts the delivery of humanitarian aid.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of a dozen liberal organizations and labor unions sent a letter to the White House on Thursday night demanding that President Biden end military aid to Israel until its government lifts restrictions on humanitarian aid to Gaza, the latest indicator of shifting mainstream Democratic opinion on the war.

headline: J.D. Vance: The Math on Ukraine Doesn’t Add Up
abstract: Ukraine needs more men than it can field, even with draconian conscription policies. And it needs more material than the United States can provide.
lead_paragraph: President Biden wants the world to believe that the biggest obstacle facing Ukraine is Republicans and our lack of commitment to the global community. This is wrong.

headline: The O.J. Simpson Trial: What Happened to the Main Figures
abstract: Some, like Marcia Clark and Mark Fuhrman, gained fame in other arenas. Others lived quieter lives.
lead_paragraph: Almost 30 years ago, over 100 million people tuned in to watch the live telecast of the verdict in O.J. Simpson’s murder trial. The former football star had been charged with the double murder of his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman. After a nine-month jury trial, Mr. Simpson was acquitted, though questions about the verdict and the crime never went away.

headline: ‘Brandy Hellville’: A New Twist for Cult Documentaries
abstract: The film examines the retailer’s tactics and is surprisingly similar to exposés about cults.
lead_paragraph: What’s most provocative about “Brandy Hellville & the Cult of Fast Fashion” (streaming on Max), and about the horror show it contends is behind the immensely popular cheap-clothing retailer Brandy Melville, isn’t necessarily its content. Other documentaries have tread similar ground with similar methods — the Netflix documentary “White Hot: The Rise & Fall of Abercrombie & Fitch,” for instance — which is to say that everything in “Brandy Hellville” has been reported before.

headline: How to Create a Home Bar: Jessica Schuster’s Dos and Don’ts
abstract: Interior designer Jessica Schuster offers advice on how to set up a home bar.
lead_paragraph: Interior designer Jessica Schuster offers advice on how to set up a home bar.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, April 12, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 3 Decluttering Projects You Can Do in Half an Hour or Less
abstract: Organizing your home can be daunting, but small jobs can have a major effect.
lead_paragraph: Some parts of my house are neat, others are not — like the cabinet under my kitchen sink. A few months ago, when it was so stuffed that I couldn’t shut the doors, I finally decided to do something about it. That’s when I realized that the sink had sprung a leak and that all of the paper towels, boxes, bottles and rags below had congealed into a large, square-shaped loaf.

headline: When Politicians Invoke the Founding Fathers, Remember This
abstract: The Electoral College as we know it is less a product of the insight or design of the framers and more a contingent adaptation to the political world.
lead_paragraph: As things stand now, 48 states are set to allocate their electors this November according to the winner of the popular vote in their state. Whoever gets the most votes — no matter the margin — gets all the electors.

headline: China Feels Boxed In by the U.S. but Has Few Ways to Push Back
abstract: China seeks to project military power in the seas around its coastline, yet also faces pressure to mend relations with neighbors for the good of its economy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s effort to build American security alliances in China’s backyard is likely to reinforce the Chinese leader Xi Jinping’s view that Washington is leading an all-out campaign of “containment, encirclement and suppression” of his country. And there is not much Mr. Xi can do about it.

headline: A.I.’s Data Wall, a Surprise Privacy Bill, and What Happened to the TikTok Ban?
abstract: I’d rather not tell you what’s in this episode. It’s private.
lead_paragraph: This week, the companies building artificial intelligence are facing a limit to what training data is publicly available on the internet. Will that stop them from building God? Then, a new bipartisan national privacy law proposal just dropped. We ask what’s in it. And finally, ByteDance is building new apps instead of fighting Congress’s TikTok ban.

headline: War or No War, Ukrainians Aren’t Giving Up Their Coffee
abstract: Coffee shops and kiosks are everywhere in Ukraine’s capital, their popularity both an act of wartime defiance and a symbol of closer ties to the rest of Europe.
lead_paragraph: When Russian tanks first rolled into Ukraine more than two years ago, Artem Vradii was sure his business was bound to suffer.

headline: Fatal Shooting of Driver by Chicago Police Is Under Investigation
abstract: Chicago police officers stopped Dexter Reed Jr. last month and fired 96 shots after he fired first and wounded an officer, investigators said.
lead_paragraph: Chicago police officers killed a 26-year-old man during a traffic stop last month, firing an estimated 96 shots after he fired first and wounded an officer, according to the city’s Civilian Office of Police Accountability.

headline: The U.S. issues new travel guidelines, warning that Iran will avenge the killings of senior commanders.
abstract: The State Department has barred its employees from traveling to large parts of Israel. Iran has repeatedly vowed to strike back over the deadly bombing this month of an Iranian Embassy complex in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Several countries including the United States have issued new travel guidelines for Israel and the surrounding region, as the Israeli military said its forces were “highly alert” for a possible Iranian strike in retaliation for the killings of several commanders.

headline: Immigrants in Maine Are Filling a Labor Gap. It May Be a Prelude for the U.S.
abstract: A wave of rapid immigration is taxing local resources around the country and drawing political ire. But it might leave America’s economy better off.
lead_paragraph: Maine has a lot of lobsters. It also has a lot of older people, ones who are less and less willing and able to catch, clean and sell the crustaceans that make up a $1 billion industry for the state. Companies are turning to foreign-born workers to bridge the divide.

headline: How One Family Lost $900,000 in a Timeshare Scam
abstract: A Mexican drug cartel is targeting seniors and their timeshares.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of violence.

headline: Israel Braces for Iranian Retaliation, and O.J. Simpson Dies
abstract: Plus, A.I. lands on Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Myanmar Rebels Take Key Trading Town, but Counteroffensive Looms
abstract: The fall of Myawaddy, on the Thai border, was one of the most significant gains by resistance forces since a 2021 military coup.
lead_paragraph: Resistance forces seeking to oust Myanmar’s military regime captured a key trade town on the Thai border this week, one of their most significant gains since the junta seized power in a coup more than three years ago. But thousands of residents were fleeing on Friday as the regime’s troops prepared to mount a counteroffensive.

headline: The New Great-Power Politics
abstract: How an emerging alliance is shaping the world.
lead_paragraph: The Houthis, the Iran-backed militia that controls much of Yemen, have disrupted the global economy by firing on commercial ships traveling through the Red Sea. But the Houthis have made some exceptions: Ships from China and Russia are allowed to pass without being attacked, according to Bloomberg.

headline: ‘Civil War’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: The writer and director Alex Garland narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Alex Garland narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Watch a Sniper Scene From ‘Civil War’
abstract: Alex Garland, the film’s writer and director, narrates a sequence from his movie.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Dimon Warns of ‘Unsettling’ Pressures That Could Weigh on JPMorgan Earnings
abstract: Warnings from the chief executive of the nation’s largest bank have been consistently at odds with heady financial markets.
lead_paragraph: Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, on Friday warned of an “unsettling” global landscape, highlighting a cascade of pressures, including war, rising geopolitical tensions and inflation, that threaten the economy and could weigh on the performance of the nation’s largest bank.

headline: Inflation Comes for the Housing Market
abstract: Prices and mortgage rates are climbing as Wall Street bets that interest rates will remain higher for longer.
lead_paragraph: The higher-for-longer inflation predicament has hit the U.S. housing market like a thunderbolt. Home prices and mortgage rates are climbing again, dashing hopes that financing costs would fall this year and adding another economic question that could hang over the presidential election campaign.

headline: Trump or Biden? The Stock Market Doesn’t Care.
abstract: Prediction markets say former President Donald J. Trump has a good chance of winning. So far, the stock market is fine with that.
lead_paragraph: The markets assume that former President Donald J. Trump has an even chance of winning the November election.

headline: That Giant College ‘Sticker’ Price Isn’t What Most Students Pay
abstract: The share of those paying the full advertised cost has declined over the last couple of decades, a new report found. Yet many don’t understand how much they’ll really pay.
lead_paragraph: Families with college-bound students may well have shuddered when they heard that the official, full cost of a year at some four-year private schools will soon hit six figures.

headline: Mistaken Autopsy Report Compounds Grief After a Balloon Pilot’s Death
abstract: The pilot, Cornelius van der Walt, died in a crash in Arizona that also killed three others. While the autopsy found he had ketamine in his system, it had been administered by medics after the crash.
lead_paragraph: Cornelius van der Walt, a lover of the sky, was as adventurous as he was responsible. Everything needed to be safe, and done in a particular way. He was the guy to trust, said John Vanca, his best friend and business partner.

headline: Angelenos Reflect on a ‘Big Moment in American History’
abstract: The murder trial of O.J. Simpson was a defining part of a turbulent era in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: In Los Angeles, where the murder trial of O.J. Simpson was a defining part of a turbulent era, news of his death rippled through families and friend groups Thursday as a collection of vivid images or half-forgotten personal connections.

headline: In Barcelona, Her Dream of a Spanish Husband Came True
abstract: Sarah Wood was not interested in a long-distance relationship with Gustavo González. That changed after they met at a cafe in Spain.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Kristine Wood moved to Barcelona, Spain, in February 2022 to live her dream.

headline: Speaker Johnson Gets Lifeline From Trump Amid Threat to His Job
abstract: Mr. Johnson met with former President Donald J. Trump at Mar-a-Lago, where they found common cause in stoking unfounded fears of election fraud.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson had a difficult week. He is facing a revolt from one of the most conservative members of his caucus that could cost him his job. The prospect of providing additional aid to Ukraine continues to meet opposition. And it took three tries for the House to renew a warrantless surveillance bill.

headline: House Passes 2-Year Surveillance Law Extension Without Warrant Requirement
abstract: Speaker Mike Johnson scaled back the measure to two years from five after Donald J. Trump had urged Republicans to “kill” it. An effort to require warrants to search for Americans’ messages failed on a tie.
lead_paragraph: In a major turnaround, the House on Friday passed a two-year reauthorization of an expiring warrantless surveillance law that had stalled this week amid G.O.P. resistance stoked by former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Bank of England Will Overhaul Its Forecasting After Inflation Surprises
abstract: The review, which was led by Ben S. Bernanke, a former Federal Reserve chair, came after the central bank had been criticized for underestimating inflation.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England said on Friday that it would overhaul the way it forecast its outlook for the British economy as part of a “once-in-a-generation” review of its process after it was criticized for underestimating inflation.

headline: Ocasio-Cortez Never Steered Money to a Key Arm of Her Party. Until Now.
abstract: Her contribution to the campaign arm of House Democrats is a symbolic moment in the New York lawmaker’s own evolution inside the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has made her first-ever contribution to the campaign arm of House Democrats — a $260,000 donation that is a milestone in the New York Democrat’s long and complicated relationship with her own party’s political establishment.

headline: ‘Player Kings’ Review: Ian McKellen’s Juicy Assignment as Falstaff
abstract: In Robert Icke’s adaptation of Parts 1 and 2 of “Henry IV,” the veteran stage actor’s performance belies his age.
lead_paragraph: There are two shows for the price of one at “Player Kings,” in which the director Robert Icke has combined both of Shakespeare’s “Henry IV” history plays into a self-contained whole.

headline: D.N.C. Helped Pay Biden’s Legal Bills in Special Counsel Investigation
abstract: The money spent paled in comparison to the amount Donald J. Trump has used in supporters’ donations to pay his own legal bills, but it was laid out even as aides for Mr. Biden attacked Mr. Trump for the practice.
lead_paragraph: Even as some of President Biden’s top campaign officials were attacking Donald J. Trump’s campaign for soliciting donations to pay his legal fees, the Biden-aligned Democratic National Committee was helping pay for lawyers in the special counsel investigation into Mr. Biden’s handling of classified documents.

headline: Coaches Have to Be Salesmen, Too
abstract: David Moyes has established West Ham as a fixture in the top half of the Premier League and a regular presence in Europe. So why do so many fans want him out?
lead_paragraph: West Ham, in the end, could not quite withstand the barrage. Bayer Leverkusen’s first goal — a Jonas Hofmann shot that picked its way through a thronged penalty area — broke its resistance. The second, a late, artful header from Victor Boniface, shattered its hopes. The club’s Europa League adventure will likely extend no further than the quarterfinals.

headline: Biden Wipes Out Another $7.4 Billion in Student Loan Debt
abstract: President Biden is hoping to shore up support with young voters who are disproportionately affected by soaring education costs. So far, he has canceled $153 billion in debt.
lead_paragraph: President Biden canceled $7.4 billion in student loan debt on Friday as he tries to shore up support with young voters who are disproportionately affected by soaring education costs, but who may be drifting away over his policy on Israel and the war in Gaza.

headline: Complications From Alcohol Use Are Rising Among Women
abstract: New research shows that alcohol-related liver disease and other health problems increased even more than expected among women ages 40 to 64 during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A new study adds to a mounting body of evidence showing that rising alcohol consumption among women is leading to higher rates of death and disease. The report, published Friday in the journal JAMA Health Forum, examined insurance claims data from 2017 to 2021 on more than 14 million Americans ages 15 and older. Researchers found that during the first year and a half of the coronavirus pandemic, women ages 40 to 64 were significantly more likely than expected to experience serious complications like alcohol-related cardiovascular and liver disease, as well as severe withdrawal.

headline: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
abstract: In this month’s sci-fi picks, cruise through dreams, hook a right at multiverses, turn left at portals, then put it in reverse for some time travel.
lead_paragraph: In 2021, this column featured a Canadian movie about multiverses called “Parallel.” Now here comes an American movie about multiverses called “Parallel,” based on a Chinese movie about multiverses called “Parallel Forest.” Déjà vu all over again?

headline: No ‘Hippie Ape’: Bonobos Are Often Aggressive, Study Finds
abstract: Despite their peaceful reputation, bonobos act aggressively more often than their chimpanzee cousins, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1900s, primatologists noticed a group of apes in central Africa with a distinctly slender build; they called them “pygmy chimpanzees.” But as the years passed, it became clear that those animals, now known as bonobos, were profoundly different from chimpanzees.

headline: Primavera Deserves Fresh Pasta
abstract: The first vegetables of the season — asparagus, peas and spring onions — shine atop Melissa Clark’s easy egg pasta dough.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I’m telling you to make your own pasta this weekend and I understand that, for some, the command will lead to rolled eyes, to sighs and protestations. Fresh pasta seems like such a pain.

headline: What Makes Tiny Tardigrades Nearly Radiation Proof
abstract: New research finds that the microscopic “water bears" are remarkably good at repairing their DNA after a huge blast of radiation.
lead_paragraph: To introduce her children to the hidden marvels of the animal kingdom a few years ago, Anne De Cian stepped into her garden in Paris. Dr. De Cian, a molecular biologist, gathered bits of moss, then came back inside to soak them in water and place them under a microscope. Her children gazed into the eyepiece at strange, eight-legged creatures clambering over the moss.

headline: National Sciences Academy Asks Court to Strip Sackler Name From Endowment
abstract: Millions in Sackler donations sat dormant, rising in value as the opioid epidemic raged and as other institutions distanced themselves from the makers of a notorious painkiller.
lead_paragraph: The National Academy of Sciences is asking a court to allow it to repurpose about $30 million in donations from the wealthy Sackler family, who controlled the company at the center of the opioid epidemic, and to remove the family name from the endowment funds.

headline: The ‘Golden Bachelor’ Is Getting a Divorce
abstract: The “Golden Bachelor” couple, Gerry Turner and Theresa Nist, said they are getting a divorce, just three months after getting hitched.
lead_paragraph: Gerry Turner and Theresa Nist were the first couple to meet and marry on “The Golden Bachelor,” ABC’s spinoff of “The Bachelor” featuring cast members 60 and older.

headline: Cries of Sexism Greet a Nike Olympic Reveal
abstract: The sporting giant offered a sneak peek at its track and field outfits for Team U.S.A., and an unexpected backlash ensued.
lead_paragraph: Ever since the Norwegian women’s beach handball team turned the fact that they were required to wear teeny-tiny bikini bottoms for competition into a cause célèbre, a quiet revolution has been brewing throughout women’s sports. It’s one that questions received conventions about what female athletes do — or don’t — have to wear to perform at their very best.

headline: Academic Freedom and the Israel-Gaza War
abstract: Responses to an Opinion guest essay by two N.Y.U. professors. Also: Biden-Trump debates; Rosie the Riveter; never enough money.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Alain Delon at His Very Best: Ravishing, Yes, but Also Destabilizing
abstract: The French star is the subject of a series at Film Forum focusing on movies from the ’60s and ’70s, when he became an international sensation.
lead_paragraph: When Luchino Visconti first saw Alain Delon, he is said to have cried out, “It’s him!” Visconti had found his Rocco, the tragic, tender soul of his next film, the 1960 family drama “Rocco and His Brothers.” One of the founders of Italian neorealism, Visconti apparently didn’t bother introducing himself to the young French actor. Perhaps he was tending to the tears that I like to think fell from his eyes when he saw his future star. I like to think that’s how everyone reacts when they initially see Delon, whose beauty has long inspired paroxysms of rapture.

headline: Thursday Ends a 13-Year Break From New Music With a Pointed Song
abstract: “Application for Release From the Dream,” which the band released Friday, marks the beginning of a fresh era for a group that helped bring emo to the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Thursday, the band once described as the “great screamo hope” for helping break the shouty punk subgenre into the mainstream with its 2001 album “Full Collapse,” has returned with its first new song in 13 years on Friday, “Application for Release From the Dream.” The title alone underscores just how drastically things have changed for Thursday and its peers over the past two decades: Emo has evolved from a niche concern to a form of classic rock, and the artists who put it on the map are now in their late 40s, navigating a very different kind of life.

headline: Back From Ukraine, a House Republican Makes the Case for More Aid
abstract: Representative Chuck Edwards, a first-term North Carolinian, has emerged as a vocal proponent for U.S. aid to Ukraine in a party that has grown hostile to it. He recently saw the war up close.
lead_paragraph: Knowing a vote on another aid package for Ukraine loomed in his future, Representative Chuck Edwards, a freshman Republican, spent part of last week traveling across the country to see for himself how American dollars would be used in the nation’s fight to fend off Russian invaders.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including titles by Cecile Pin, Elizabeth Graver, Aimee Nezhukumatathil and more.
lead_paragraph: Including titles by Cecile Pin, Elizabeth Graver, Aimee Nezhukumatathil and more.

headline: Overlooked No More: Lizzie Magie, the Unknown Inventor Behind Monopoly
abstract: Magie’s creation, The Landlord’s Game, inspired the spinoff we know today. But credit for the idea long went to someone else.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Tell Us: Has Elon Musk’s Behavior Affected How You View Tesla?
abstract: Mr. Musk, the chief executive of Tesla, has turned off many people with polarizing remarks on social media, and it may be affecting the automaker’s sales.
lead_paragraph: Endorsing an antisemitic post on X. Withholding Starlink satellite internet service from Ukraine to prevent a drone attack on Russian forces. Reposting conspiracy theorists who claim that the Biden administration’s immigration policies are part of a plot to increase the number of people who vote Democrat.

headline: For Filmmakers, O.J. Simpson’s Trial Was a Powerful Case Study
abstract: In 2016, both an FX mini-series and an ESPN documentary re-examined the polarizing criminal accusations against Simpson and the nation’s divided conversation about race.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years after the O.J. Simpson trial, long after the headlines had faded and the news cycle had moved on to other scandals, the polarizing saga was thrust back into the national conversation thanks to two very different projects.

headline: Review: Dance Theater of Harlem Is in New (and Capable) Hands
abstract: The company performed its first New York City Center season under the direction of Robert Garland in a program including George Balanchine’s “Pas de Dix.”
lead_paragraph: It was, as Robert Garland said from the stage, a momentous occasion for him. Greeting the crowd at his first New York City Center season as the artistic director of Dance Theater of Harlem, he spoke warmly of the company’s co-founder: “Arthur Mitchell was my mentor, my hero, and he’s watching down from upstairs saying, ‘Get it right, Robert.’”

headline: Biden Administration Raises Costs to Drill and Mine on Public Lands
abstract: For the first time since 1920, the government has raised the rates that companies pay. The fossil fuel industry says it will hurt the economy.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday made it more expensive for fossil fuel companies to pull oil, gas and coal from public lands, raising royalty rates for the first time in 100 years in a bid to end bargain basement fees enjoyed by one of the country’s most profitable industries.

headline: Campaign Puts Trump and the Spy Agencies on a Collision Course
abstract: As president, Donald Trump never trusted the intelligence community. His antipathy has only grown since he left office, with potentially serious implications should he return to power.
lead_paragraph: Even as president, Donald J. Trump flaunted his animosity for intelligence officials, portraying them as part of a politicized “deep state” out to get him. And since he left office, that distrust has grown into outright hostility, with potentially serious implications for national security should he be elected again.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Ending Text Messages With Periods
abstract: A father and daughter disagree about how punctuation should be used on phones.
lead_paragraph: Enno writes: I have a dispute with my daughter, Emily. She refuses to use proper punctuation in text messages. She says that everyone understands her, and people who end a text with a period are psychotic. I think punctuation is essential in conveying tone. If nothing else, it will help me understand what “I’m fine” actually means!

headline: Robert MacNeil, Earnest News Anchor for PBS, Dies at 93
abstract: With his longtime co-host Jim Lehrer, he delivered thoughtful reports that stood in stark contrast to the commercial networks’ ever more sensational newscasts.
lead_paragraph: Robert MacNeil, the Canadian-born journalist who delivered sober evening newscasts for more than two decades on PBS as the co-anchor of “The MacNeil/Lehrer Report,” later expanded as “The MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour,” died early Friday in Manhattan. He was 93.

headline: 2 School Districts to Testify as Congress Expands Antisemitism Inquiry
abstract: A congressional committee that questioned college presidents about how they have handled protests over the Israel-Hamas war is now focusing on K-12 school districts.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of public schools in New York City and Montgomery County, Md., will testify about how their districts are handling antisemitism before a congressional committee next month. It will be the first time that K-12 districts have taken center stage in the House hearings focused on how schools are responding to a wave of student protests since Hamas’s attacks against Israel on Oct. 7.

headline: The Big Number: 5.3%
abstract: Economists had been expecting the Federal Reserve to cut rates sharply this year. But stubborn inflation and strong growth may change the narrative.
lead_paragraph: Economists had been expecting the Federal Reserve to cut rates sharply this year. But stubborn inflation and strong growth may change the narrative.

headline: The O.J. Joke: How the Simpson Case Changed Comedy’s Boundaries
abstract: Norm Macdonald and Jay Leno made the double homicides such a constant topic that refraining from jokes the way David Letterman did was noticeable.
lead_paragraph: The weekend after a jury found O.J. Simpson not guilty of murder, the comedian Norm Macdonald opened Weekend Update on “Saturday Night Live” at his desk next to a photo of the defendant. “Well, it is finally official,” he said. “Murder is legal in the state of California.”

headline: Sabrina Carpenter Drops a Perky Bop, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by girl in red, Margo Guryan, Phish and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The late-night hosts started the week by talking about the total solar eclipse before moving on to political news — including former President Trump’s failed bids to delay his criminal hush-money trial and Arizona reinstating a 160-year-old abortion ban.
lead_paragraph: The late-night hosts started the week by talking about the total solar eclipse before moving on to political news — including former President Trump’s failed bids to delay his criminal hush-money trial and Arizona reinstating a 160-year-old abortion ban.

headline: Iran Likely Will Strike Israel, Not U.S. Forces, U.S. and Iranian Officials Say
abstract: Retaliation by Iran is expected on Israeli soil in the next few days, but officials say Iran does not want to draw the United States deeper into the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Iran is expected to mount an attack soon on Israel, but not on the United States or its military forces, when Tehran retaliates for an Israeli bombing in Damascus, Syria, that killed several senior Iranian commanders, U.S. and Iranian officials said on Friday.

headline: Three Interpretations of ‘The Three-Body Problem’
abstract: A geopolitical allegory whose meaning shifts from version to version.
lead_paragraph: Having watched some (though not quite all) of “3 Body Problem,” Netflix’s hit adaptation of “The Three-Body Problem,” the first book in a science-fiction saga by the Chinese author Liu Cixin, I’m struck by the unusual geopolitical weight this particular piece of pop entertainment carries. At a time when Chinese-American relations are notable for a lack of sustained cultural exchange, here is a best-selling work written within our leading rival, carrying various clash-of-civilizational themes, translated into popular television for an American audience. There aren’t a lot of other cases where a major piece of pop culture is so clearly working along the fault lines that have led to great-power conflict and could one day lead to war.

headline: The Biden Administration Raised the Rent to Drill on Public Lands. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The fossil fuel industry says higher rates will harm the economy. The administration says they will pay for the environmental costs of drilling and mining.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration raised the royalty rates that fossil fuel companies pay the government in order to drill and mine on public lands, the first time since 1920 that those fees have increased. And it raised by tenfold the size of bonds that companies must secure before they can drill, the first time they went up since 1960.

headline: The Ultimate Judee Sill Primer
abstract: A new documentary puts a spotlight on the ’70s musician. Listen to 10 of her essential songs.
lead_paragraph: I first encountered the music of Judee Sill a little over a decade ago, when, on a whim at a record store, I blind-bought a reissue of her 1973 album, “Heart Food.” It’s since become a favorite of mine — an LP that somehow marries the searching spirit of Laurel Canyon folk with the technical grandeur of Bach. Finding it impossible to settle on a single descriptor of her music, Sill once called it “occult holy Western baroque gospel.” In an interview featured in the new documentary “Lost Angel: The Genius of Judee Sill” (which is now playing in New York and available to rent on various streaming platforms), she says that what she aims to capture in her songs is “that moment of redemption, where the lowest thing and the highest thing meet.”

headline: At Berkeley, a Protest at a Dean’s Home Tests the Limits of Free Speech
abstract: Pro-Palestinian supporters disrupted a dinner for law students. There was a tussle over the microphone and conflicting claims of harm.
lead_paragraph: The dean of Berkeley’s law school is known as a staunch supporter of free speech, but things became personal for him when pro-Palestinian students disrupted a celebratory dinner party for some 60 students at his home.

headline: 1 Killed and 13 Injured in ‘Intentional’ Truck Crash Into Building in Texas
abstract: The authorities said that a man driving a semitrailer truck crashed into a Department of Public Safety office in Brenham, Texas, after he had been denied a commercial driver’s license.
lead_paragraph: A man stole a semitrailer in Texas on Friday and, after a police pursuit, crashed it into a state government office where he had been denied a commercial driver’s license the day before, killing one person and injuring 13 others, the authorities said.

headline: Iran’s Retaliation Likely to Be Limited, but Errors Could Lead to War, Experts Say
abstract: After Israel killed several top Iranian commanders, Iran wants to respond without provoking further escalation, military analysts say, but there is a dangerous risk of miscalculation.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces were on high alert on Friday in anticipation of a retaliatory strike by Iran or its proxies, which analysts and officials warned could spur an Israeli reaction and potentially provoke a broader conflict in the region.

headline: Pro-Palestinian Protesters Complicate Democrats’ Ability to Campaign
abstract: Lisa Lerer, a political correspondent for The New York Times, explains how protests over the Biden administration’s handling of the Israel-Hamas war are disrupting the activities of Democratic officials from city halls to Congress to the White House.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Lerer, a political correspondent for The New York Times, explains how protests over the Biden administration’s handling of the Israel-Hamas war are disrupting the activities of Democratic officials from city halls to Congress to the White House.

headline: 100 Years of Simon & Schuster
abstract: The publisher has gone through a lot of changes since its founding in 1924. Its current chief executive, Jonathan Karp, talks about the company’s history and its hopes for the future.
lead_paragraph: Simon & Schuster is not growing old quietly.

headline: Nicole Brown Simpson Called for Help 5 Days Before She Was Killed. It Was Not Enough.
abstract: Nicole Brown Simpson’s death shook an entire nation into recognition that domestic abuse crosses all bounds of race and class.
lead_paragraph: For years now, I’ve had advocates who work with survivors of domestic violence tell me that two events in 1994 changed entirely the landscape for victims’ services in their field: the passage of the Violence Against Women Act and the murder of Nicole Brown Simpson.

headline: Our Inability to Predict Inflation Is an Embarrassment to Economics
abstract: Academic theories of inflation have proved of little use to policymakers.
lead_paragraph: We were surprised when inflation rose. We were surprised when inflation fell. And we were surprised again when inflation stopped falling. The message of all these surprises is that we — including professional economists — really don’t have a strong grasp on why prices go up and down.

headline: Roberto Cavalli, Designer Who Celebrated Excess, Dies at 83
abstract: From the mid-1990s onward he was one of the biggest names in fashion, with stores around the world and celebrity admirers like Lenny Kravitz and Cindy Crawford.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Cavalli, the Italian fashion designer who celebrated glamour and excess, sending models down the runway and actresses onto red carpets wearing leopard-print dresses, bejeweled distressed jeans, satin corsets and other unapologetically flashy clothes, has died. He was 83.

headline: Gen Z Wanted a Scrabble More Conducive to Hanging Out. Mattel Was Happy to Oblige.
abstract: Will Classic Scrabble devotees object? You bet.
lead_paragraph: The release of Scrabble Together in Europe this week marks the first time that the game’s rules have changed since it was patented in 1948. While Mattel owns the rights to the game in much of the world, Hasbro owns the rights to Scrabble in the United States and has no plans at this time to expand the game.

headline: A Look at Iran’s Military Capabilities
abstract: The direct military confrontation between Iran and Israel has brought renewed attention to Iran’s armed forces. What are they capable of?
lead_paragraph: The start of a direct military confrontation between Iran and Israel has brought renewed attention to Iran’s armed forces. Early this month, Israel attacked a building in Iran’s diplomatic compound in the Syrian capital, Damascus, killing seven of Iran’s senior commanders and military personnel.

headline: Pennsylvania and West Virginia Brace for More Flooding
abstract: Up to four inches fell in less than 24 hours across broad sections of both states, and officials were watching rising waterways warily.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rainfall in parts of Western Pennsylvania and West Virginia prompted warnings of overflowing rivers and creeks on Friday, as authorities dealt with the aftermath of a storm that had forced road closures and rescues of people stranded in flooded streets.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, April 13, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: U.S. Targets Unlikely to Be on List in Possible Iranian Attack, Officials Say
abstract: In anticipation of the Iranian strikes, several countries, including the United States, issued new guidelines to their citizens about travel in Israel and the surrounding region.
lead_paragraph: American intelligence analysts and officials said on Friday that they expected Iran to strike multiple targets inside Israel within the next few days in retaliation for an Israeli bombing in the Syrian capital on April 1 that killed several senior Iranian commanders.

headline: Argentine Court Says Iran Was Behind Israeli Embassy and Jewish Center Attacks
abstract: The ruling opens the possibility for relatives of victims of the 1992 and 1994 attacks to make claims against Iran in international tribunals.
lead_paragraph: A high court in Argentina ruled on Thursday that Iran was the mastermind of the 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires that killed 85 people, potentially paving the way for relatives of victims to make claims against the country in international tribunals.

headline: Richard Leibner, Savvy Agent for Top Broadcast Journalists, Dies at 85
abstract: His negotiations led to Dan Rather’s elevation from “60 Minutes” to anchor of the “CBS Evening News” and sent Diane Sawyer from “60 Minutes” to ABC.
lead_paragraph: Richard Leibner, a powerful agent whose firm brokered contracts for many of the biggest names in television news, including Dan Rather, Diane Sawyer, Anderson Cooper, Ed Bradley, Morley Safer and Steve Kroft, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: Rumi Missabu, Avant-Garde Drag Performer Who Glittered, Dies at 76
abstract: He was one of the stars of the Cockettes, a psychedelic collective formed at the turn of the 1970s in San Francisco, that was short-lived but inspired generations.
lead_paragraph: Rumi Missabu, an avant-garde drag performer who was best known as a member of the anarchic, glitter-encrusted, hippie-drag troupe known as the Cockettes, which bloomed briefly at the turn of the 1970s in San Francisco, died on April 2 at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 76.

headline: My Girlfriend Said She Loved Me. Should I Say It Back Even if I’m Not Sure?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether it’s OK to profess love if you’re uncertain you feel it.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been dating my girlfriend for more than six months now, and we’ve been going along really well ever since we first met. Time together is always of quality, and I care a lot about her.

headline: Stocks Suffer Sharpest Weekly Decline of 2024
abstract: Investors had been put on edge by a stronger-than-expected inflation report earlier in the week. Rising tension in the Middle East heading into the weekend gave them another reason to retreat.
lead_paragraph: Stocks slumped to a second consecutive weekly loss on Friday, as intensifying tension in the Middle East prompted caution among investors, adding to concerns about lingering inflation that had set off a retreat earlier in the week.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Dario Amodei
abstract: The April 12, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Dario Amodei. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Anti-Violence Activist Says N.Y.P.D. Leaders Defamed Her Over Criticism
abstract: Dana Rachlin, who filed a federal defamation lawsuit against the Police Department, said the string of recent attacks by high-level officials against critics was not surprising.
lead_paragraph: For years, Dana Rachlin, an anti-violence activist from Brooklyn, was included in high-level meetings with top officials in the New York Police Department. She attended galas and fund-raising events with Jeffrey Maddrey, now the chief of the department, and won the praise of Mayor Eric Adams, a former police captain, for her efforts to strengthen ties between the police and the community.

headline: Roberto Cavalli, a Life Out Loud
abstract: The fashion designer who made maximalism cool.
lead_paragraph: Roberto Cavalli, the Italian designer who made a name for himself as the couturier to the rock ‘n roll St. Tropez set and who died this week at age 83, lived as he designed: in his own Wild Kingdom of parrots, Persian cats, monkeys, racehorses and assorted toys (Ferraris, a helicopter). He founded his own brand in 1970 and almost from the beginning loved zebra, giraffe, leopard and lynx; tiger stripes and leopard spots, and put them not just on the runway but on his poolside loungers and motorcycle seats — often all at the same time.

headline: Haiti in Crisis Sets Up Ruling Council, Clearing Way for an Acting Leader
abstract: A governing council was finalized after a month of negotiations. It is tasked with restoring law and order by appointing an acting prime minister.
lead_paragraph: A new transitional ruling council was finalized in Haiti on Friday to try to bring political stability to a country wracked by escalating gang violence and a worsening humanitarian crisis.

headline: Sean Combs Sold Share of Tequila Brand for $200 Million
abstract: Mr. Combs, who was accused of sexual assault in several lawsuits, made the sale as he ended his long-term partnership with the liquor giant Diageo. He has denied wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the music mogul whose business empire has been upended by recent lawsuits accusing him of sexual assault and a federal investigation, sold his half of the tequila brand DeLeón for about $200 million this year, according to a public report for investors.

headline: The Mechanics of Covering Trump’s Manhattan Criminal Trial
abstract: Beginning on April 15, Times reporters will provide up-to-the-minute updates on the trial.
lead_paragraph: The first-ever criminal trial of a U.S. president begins in Manhattan on Monday, April 15.

headline: German Police Stop Pro-Palestinian Conference
abstract: The German police shut down a pro-Palestinian conference in Berlin, citing the risk that one of the speakers invited might make antisemitic comments or incite violence.
lead_paragraph: The German police shut down a pro-Palestinian conference in Berlin, citing the risk that one of the speakers invited might make antisemitic comments or incite violence.

headline: Bennett Braun, Psychiatrist Who Fueled ‘Satanic Panic,’ Dies at 83
abstract: He diagnosed dozens of patients with what he said were suppressed memories of being tortured by cults. He later lost his license.
lead_paragraph: Bennett Braun, a Chicago psychiatrist whose diagnoses of repressed memories involving horrific abuse by devil worshipers helped to fuel what became known as the “satanic panic” of the 1980s and ’90s, died on March 20 in Lauderhill, Fla., north of Miami. He was 83.

headline: Former U.S. Ambassador Is Sentenced to 15 Years for Acting as Cuban Agent
abstract: Manuel Rocha pleaded guilty to two charges, including conspiring to defraud the United States as a foreign agent, under an agreement with the U.S. government.
lead_paragraph: A former United States ambassador accused of working for decades as a secret agent for Cuba in one of the biggest national security breaches in years pleaded guilty on Friday and was sentenced to 15 years in prison.

headline: The House Passed an Extension of a Surveillance Law
abstract: Also, the U.S. made it more expensive to drill on public land. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: In a major turnaround, the House passed a two-year reauthorization of a controversial program that allows the government to collect the communications of targeted foreigners abroad without warrants. It must still clear the Senate.

headline: Republican Women Are Divided on Abortion as Bans Spread
abstract: Across the country, fractures are emerging among conservative and centrist women, as they confront a steady drumbeat of new abortion restrictions and court rulings.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Gau, a self-described “reasonable Republican” in Mesa, Ariz., is conflicted about many things that her party promotes. But she knows exactly what she thinks about Arizona’s new — or rather, very old — Civil War-era abortion ban. And about the idea that Republicans like her might be happy with the outcome.

headline: Salman Rushdie Is Again the Toast of Literary Manhattan
abstract: Nearly two years after he was stabbed, he was in fine form as he greeted his fellow writers at a party celebrating his candid memoir, “Knife.”
lead_paragraph: Three security guards stood along a leafy street in the West Village of Manhattan on Thursday evening, watching as a procession of writers, editors and publishing industry veterans entered the Waverly Inn restaurant for a book party.

headline: Trump Says He Intends to Testify in His Manhattan Criminal Case
abstract: Jury selection begins Monday in the prosecution of Donald J. Trump on charges of covering up a sex scandal. He said he would try to sway jurors personally, though he has backed away in the past.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: ‘Climate-Controlled’ Sausage? Courts Crack Down on ‘Greenwashing’
abstract: From airlines to pork sellers, corporate brands face legal and regulatory challenges for misleading the public with lofty climate claims.
lead_paragraph: A “climate-controlled” sausage. New trousers labeled “recycled.” A “sustainable” airline ticket.

headline: Governing the Ungovernable
abstract: House Speaker Mike Johnson has problems in Washington. Trump can help, and hurt.
lead_paragraph: When members of Congress return to Washington from their home districts, they often trudge to Capitol Hill for a tally known as a “bed check,” a low-stakes vote series that is mostly aimed at taking attendance.

headline: Harris Blasts Trump on Abortion in Arizona
abstract: During a campaign rally, Vice President Kamala Harris blamed former President Donald J. Trump for the Arizona Supreme Court’s ruling to uphold a near-total ban on abortion.
lead_paragraph: During a campaign rally, Vice President Kamala Harris blamed former President Donald J. Trump for the Arizona Supreme Court’s ruling to uphold a near-total ban on abortion.

headline: Harris Blasts Trump on Abortion at Arizona Campaign Stop
abstract: At a rally in Tucson, Ariz., days after the state’s top court upheld a near-total ban on abortion, Vice President Kamala Harris placed the blame directly on former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris laid into former President Donald J. Trump over abortion rights at a campaign rally in Arizona on Friday, accusing him of being directly responsible for a court decision this week that upheld the state’s 160-year-old near-total ban on abortion.

headline: Trump Co-Defendants Argue for Dismissal of Charges in Documents Case
abstract: The judge did not rule on motions by lawyers for Walt Nauta and Carlos De Oliveira, who are accused of helping the former president obstruct government efforts to recover classified material.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for co-defendants of former President Donald J. Trump argued in federal court in Florida on Friday to dismiss charges of aiding in the obstruction of efforts to recover classified documents.

headline: Eleanor Coppola, Who Chronicled Her Family’s Filmmaking, Dies at 87
abstract: She made documentaries of her husband Francis Ford Coppola’s “Apocalypse Now” and her daughter Sofia Coppola’s “The Virgin Suicides” and recalled their lives in books.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Coppola, a documentary filmmaker and artist who called herself “an observer at heart” — a description borne out through works chronicling the cinematic triumphs and ordeals of her husband, Francis Ford Coppola, and their daughter, Sofia Coppola — died on Friday at her home in Rutherford, Calif. She was 87.

headline: What Is the Powerful Surveillance Law That Divided Lawmakers?
abstract: Under Section 702, the government is empowered to collect, without a warrant, the messages of Americans communicating with targeted foreigners abroad.
lead_paragraph: The House on Friday passed a two-year reauthorization of an expiring warrantless surveillance law known as Section 702, reversing course after the bill collapsed days earlier when former President Donald J. Trump urged his allies to “kill” it.

headline: Frank Olson, Executive Who Linked O.J. Simpson With Hertz, Dies at 91
abstract: He negotiated Mr. Simpson’s star turn in commercials, tapping into his football fame, and formed a social bond with him — until there were murder charges. They died on the same day.
lead_paragraph: Frank A. Olson, who as a top executive of Hertz cast the running back O.J. Simpson as the star of the company’s commercials — a corporate marriage that shined up both parties and that lasted two decades, until Mr. Simpson was charged in a double homicide in 1994 — died at his home in Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday, the same day Mr. Simpson died. Mr. Olson was 91.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Defends Contentious Arrests of ‘Violence Interrupters’
abstract: The arrests, which led one of the men to be hospitalized, heightened tensions between officers and outreach workers trained to intervene in street conflicts.
lead_paragraph: The New York Police Department continued on Friday to defend its arrests of two conflict mediators in Brooklyn in February, releasing body-camera and surveillance videos of the episode that police officials said showed one of the workers striking an officer.

headline: Johnson Floats Voting on Senate Ukraine Bill, With Conservative Policies as Sweeteners
abstract: The Republican speaker has weighed bringing up a $95 billion Senate-passed bill to aid Ukraine and Israel in tandem with a separate package geared toward mollifying G.O.P. critics.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after congressional leaders met with Japan’s prime minister in Speaker Johnson’s ceremonial office in the Capitol on Thursday morning, the conversation turned to Ukraine aid.

headline: Police Who Killed Bronx Man Won’t Face Punishment
abstract: The officers, Brendan Thompson and Herbert Davis, were previously cleared of criminal wrongdoing in the fatal 2019 shooting of Kawaski Trawick.
lead_paragraph: Two New York City police officers involved in the fatal shooting of a 32-year-old Bronx man in his kitchen in 2019 acted within the law and will not be punished, the city’s police commissioner said on Friday.

headline: Judge Rejects Hunter Biden Claim of Selective Prosecution in Gun Case
abstract: Judge Maryellen Noreika declined to dismiss the charges against the president’s son, saying Mr. Biden’s lawyer failed to show prosecutors had been motivated by animus.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge presiding over Hunter Biden’s gun case in Delaware on Friday rejected Mr. Biden’s claim that he was being subjected to selective prosecution, saying it was “nonsensical” that the Biden Justice Department would target the president’s son.

headline: Biotech Exec Gets 7 Years in Prison for False Claims About Rapid Covid-19 Test
abstract: Prosecutors said Keith Berman falsely claimed he had invented a blood test that could detect Covid-19 in 15 seconds. His lawyer said he had put “genuine effort” into developing such a test.
lead_paragraph: The former chief executive of a biotechnology company who, during the early days of the pandemic, falsely claimed that he had invented a blood test that could detect Covid-19 in 15 seconds was sentenced on Friday to seven years in prison for securities fraud, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Like Some Smiles and Winks
abstract: Even in her first Times puzzle, Jess Rucks knows what everyone needs on a Saturday: a ray of sunshine.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you’re hoping for one of those themeless solves that are a breath of fresh air, full of crowd-pleasing trivia and accessible humor, then you’ve come to the right place. This is a polished crossword by a seasoned constructor who’s debuting at The New York Times.

headline: New Zealanders Are Crazy for This Fruit. It’s Not the Kiwi.
abstract: Like the kiwi fruit, the feijoa, or pineapple guava, is not native to the island nation, but it has become something of a national obsession.
lead_paragraph: Autumn in New Zealand heralds the arrival of a green, egg-size fruit that falls off trees in such abundance that it is often given to neighbors and colleagues by the bucket or even the wheelbarrow load. Only in cases of extreme desperation do people buy any.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Coffee Means Connection, Even in War
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Despite the war, people were still thinking about coffee. They could leave their homes, their habits. But they could not live without coffee.”

headline: Corrections: April 13, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, April 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A theater review on Friday about the musical version of “The Outsiders” in one instance misidentified the folk duo that wrote the score for “The Outsiders.” It is Jamestown Revival, not Johnstown Revival.

headline: A Soccer Bridesmaid Wears the Crown, and Germany (Mostly) Likes the Look
abstract: As Bayer Leverkusen sealed its first Bundesliga title, the real joy for its rivals came in seeing Bayern Munich lose it.
lead_paragraph: Executives at Bayer Leverkusen, the longstanding but habitually middleweight German soccer team, have been fielding the messages since at least February. Some were delivered in person, a quiet blessing after yet another victory. Others came via WhatsApp, unsolicited and unexpected notes from peers and acquaintances and, to their occasional surprise, foes.

headline: In the Nigeria Pavilion, Criticism Meets Optimism
abstract: The group show “Nigeria Imaginary” will be one of the most ambitious African presentations ever at the Venice Biennale.
lead_paragraph: People in Lagos, Nigeria’s largest city, are hardly shy. The stereotype runs toward boisterousness, worn as a point of pride. But when the artist and poet Precious Okoyomon recorded interviews with some 60 city residents in January for an art project, the unusual questions — like “Who was responsible for the suffering of your mother?” — proved disarming.

headline: China Had a ‘Special Place’ in Modi’s Heart. Now It’s a Thorn in His Side.
abstract: As Narendra Modi seeks a third term as prime minister, India’s rupture with China looms over a pillar of his campaign: making his country a major power.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi once looked up to China. As a business-friendly Indian state leader, he traveled there repeatedly to attract investment and see how his country could learn from its neighbor’s economic transformation. China, he said, has a “special place in my heart.” Chinese officials cheered on his march to national power as that of “a political star.”

headline: Pittsburgh Reopens Bridge After 26 Barges Break Loose on Ohio River
abstract: The barges, some carrying coal, damaged a marina. One barge, which likely sank, remained missing on Saturday, an official said.
