lead_paragraph: The authorities in Pittsburgh reopened a bridge that had been closed as a precaution after 26 barges broke loose on the Ohio River late on Friday, drifting miles downstream and damaging a marina.

headline: Most N.Y.C. Drivers Who Honk Are Breaking the Law. Can They Be Stopped?
abstract: The city’s noise code has limited the use of vehicle horns for almost a century. Enforcing the law is another matter.
lead_paragraph: Hardly a second had passed since the light turned green, but there was already a symphony of honks and beeps and toots urging traffic forward on Columbus Avenue. About a minute later, a deep, foghorn-like honk rumbled from a dump truck as it turned onto 89th Street.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a Raunchy Lounge Singer Spends His Sundays
abstract: Dani Lubnitzki, who is better known as Dani Luv, puts his own spin on Sinatra during the week, but on Sundays he shops for his grandchildren and has a jam session with friends.
lead_paragraph: For more than two decades, Dani Lubnitzki was the resident lounge singer and pianist at Sammy’s Roumanian Steakhouse on the Lower East Side, where bottles of vodka were served lodged in blocks of ice and the entertainment was as schmaltzy as the chopped liver.

headline: How a Reality TV Show Turned the U.F.C. From Pariah to Juggernaut
abstract: The Ultimate Fighting Championship, whose 300th numbered pay-per-view fight card is this weekend, was once effectively banned on television because of its violence.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, the Ultimate Fighting Championship was on life support. Broadcasters scoffed at the idea of televising half-naked men pummeling each other inside a caged octagon, engaged in a sport where broken bones and dislodged teeth were common. Venues closed their doors and advertisers their wallets.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: $17,000 to Watch the Masters? How Sports Entice Deep-Pocketed Fans.
abstract: Teams, leagues and event organizers are pursuing enthusiasts with the promise of luxury and exclusivity, in hopes of bigger profits and lasting loyalty.
lead_paragraph: The oysters and shrimp cocktail emerge by midmorning, nestled neatly on ice. The pastries look as if they were overnighted from Paris, even as the signature breakfast sandwich — a biscuit with fried chicken, pimento cheese and hot honey — showcases Southern cuisine. An Augusta National Golf Club green jacket hangs on the wall, and 81 televisions show the theatrics and athletic brilliance unfolding on the emerald grounds that host the Masters Tournament.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 307
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Protests, Traffic, Crowds: Court Braces for a Trump Trial Like No Other
abstract: Strict security measures — and plenty of headaches — are expected as the first criminal trial of a former U.S. president gets underway in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: You Ask, We Answer: How The Times/Siena Poll Is Conducted
abstract: The New York Times/Siena College Poll has earned a reputation for accuracy and transparency. But as with any poll, there are limits to just how much you can derive.
lead_paragraph: Polls can give us important insight into how people’s views on the issues, the state of the country and the candidates may affect how they vote. Polls have helped us understand how motivating issues like abortion and immigration are for Americans, how the war in Gaza is perceived by Democrats and Republicans, and how many voters believe misinformation.

headline: A Modern California Dream, Still Haunted by Hippie Darkness
abstract: Cult leaders, curdled 1960s idealism and outsider art collide in Max Ludington’s prismatic novel, “Thorn Tree.”
lead_paragraph: For every idyllic image of the 1960s there exists its dark inverse, a symbol of menacing chaos. Give me your flower crowns at Woodstock, your free love in Haight-Ashbury, and I’ll hand you the murdering Manson family, or the 5-year-old in Joan Didion’s “Slouching Toward Bethlehem,” high on the LSD her mother gave her. This slippage of the utopian into the dystopian lies at the heart of “Thorn Tree,” Max Ludington’s ominous second novel.

headline: Finding Comfort in a Haircut
abstract: A good cut is hard to find no matter where you live. But some hairstylists know it holds more weight for their transgender clients.
lead_paragraph: Xavier Cruz and JP Gomez, a married gay couple, knew discrimination against the L.G.B.T.Q. community had become widespread. But as owners of Barba Grooming Boutique, a salon in Manhattan, they thought their industry was largely immune.

headline: It’s Not Just a Wedding Cake, It’s ‘Edible Haute Couture’
abstract: Bastien Blanc-Tailleur, a luxury cake designer based in Paris, creates opulent confections for high-profile clients, including European royalty and American socialites.
lead_paragraph: Bastien Blanc-Tailleur, a Parisian pâtissier, has always had a passion for confections. “I’ve been obsessed by pastry since I was a little boy,” he said. Since opening his namesake business in 2015, Mr. Blanc-Tailleur has become one of the most prestigious creators of wedding and special-occasion cakes in France.

headline: In a Global Cycling Capital, Riders Fear Becoming Crime Victims
abstract: In Bogotá, a city with more than 1.1 million bicycles and a strong riding culture, a number of high-profile crimes have rattled cyclists.
lead_paragraph: Bicycles are an essential part of the Colombian identity — ubiquitous, cheaper and, in some urban communities, often a faster way to get around.

headline: A.I. Made These Movies Sharper. Critics Say It Ruined Them.
abstract: Machine-learning technologies are being used in film restoration for new home video releases. But some viewers strongly dislike the results.
lead_paragraph: In 1998, Geoff Burdick, an executive at James Cameron’s Lightstorm Entertainment, was hunched in front of a 12-inch monitor at a postproduction house, carefully preparing “Titanic” for release on LaserDisc and VHS. A state-of-the-art computer process had made it possible for Burdick and his team to scour the film frame by frame, removing tiny imperfections embedded in the original negative: little scratches, flakes of dirt, even water stains that smeared the image. The computer could erase these blemishes using a kind of copy-paste tool, concealing the defects with information from another frame.

headline: ‘Civil War’ Is Designed to Disturb You
abstract: Here’s why you should watch it anyway.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, “Civil War” was released in theaters across the United States and Britain. Written and directed by Alex Garland, the film imagines a future in which America is at war with itself and four journalists must risk their lives to travel to the White House and interview the president.

headline: What if K-Pop Stars Are Actually Just Like Us?
abstract: In the debut novel “The Band,” a burned-out pop idol meets a disillusioned professor, raising the question: What if the dangers of fame resemble white-collar ennui?
lead_paragraph: K-pop idols, the international megastars of Korean music, inhabit a strange, fascinating place in the ecosystems of modern culture. In some ways, they’re just like the stars of generations past, like the Beatles or the Backstreet Boys: worshiped for their youth; admired as sex objects; lauded for voices and songs that millions can’t forget; raised up, and sometimes crushed, by a fickle public and a corporate machine.

headline: Bowen Yang Thinks This Artist Nails What It’s Like Living in New York
abstract: The “S.N.L.” comedian talked about his Audible series “Hot White Heist” and solitude — a state of being he senses in Edward Hopper’s paintings.
lead_paragraph: Bowen Yang had just played an overcompensating straight guy opposite Sydney Sweeney on “Saturday Night Live.” But in a video call from his Brooklyn apartment, he was all about “Hot White Heist,” his queer action-comedy audio series on Audible.

headline: How America Is Picking Up the Pieces of a Broken Global Order
abstract: In “New Cold Wars,” David E. Sanger tracks the shifts in U.S. foreign policy as competition among the great powers re-emerges in the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, the human toll of disease and war has been heartbreaking. But geopolitical upheaval and the return of great-power competition have also brought a fascinating revival of first-order questions: How does deterrence work? Does economic interdependence make countries less likely to fight? Does rising prosperity force authoritarian regimes to reform?

headline: Review: In ‘Symphony of Rats’ Revival, a Darkness Goes Underexplored
abstract: The Wooster Group’s staging of Richard Foreman’s play operates like a delightful love letter from one giant of experimental theater to another.
lead_paragraph: A president losing grip with reality. Warnings of environmental disaster and apocalypse. An early reference to the Covid vaccine.

headline: Do Ground-Floor Co-op Apartments Really Have to Carpet Their Floors?
abstract: Carpeting rules are common. But housing laws protect residents with disabilities, to a point.
lead_paragraph: Q: My mother has bad allergies and had to remove all of the carpets from her home many years ago. Now she’s looking to downsize, and we found a ground-floor apartment in a co-op in Nassau County. But the house rules require wall-to-wall carpeting, with padding, in every room except bathrooms and kitchens — even in ground-floor units, where no one lives below you. We put a deposit on the apartment, which has beautiful hardwood floors that had never been carpeted, and we know of at least two other apartments that also don’t have carpet. There’s a $500 monthly fine for noncompliance. We’re afraid that if we raise the issue, they will deny us the apartment. What should we do?

headline: The Landline’s Not Dead (at Least at the Masters)
abstract: Augusta National Golf Club has long forbidden cellphones for almost anyone at its hallowed tournament, but patrons delight in making free calls the old-school way.
lead_paragraph: They call to check in with their bosses or spouses. They call to brag. They call to offer up weather reports, food reviews, golf commentaries, celebrity sightings, souvenir spending confessions, legal advice and trips down memory lane. This year, they called to talk about the solar eclipse.

headline: Philip Johnson’s Brick House and Its Hidden Boudoir, Exposed
abstract: The Glass House in Connecticut has its 75th anniversary, followed by the reopening of its long-mute twin, “warmer and toastier and sexier.”
lead_paragraph: Diptych, dyad, dialectic: The relationship between the first pair of buildings Philip Johnson designed for his estate in New Canaan, Conn., has taxed the metaphorical imaginations of critics and architectural historians since the structures were completed, just months apart, in 1949.

headline: How Gen Z Made the Crossword Their Own
abstract: A younger generation of constructors is using an old form to reflect their identities, language and world.
lead_paragraph: 30-Across: “___ and dry food (categories I will now be using to describe human food. Oh, so suddenly it’s weird?)”

headline: Biden’s Student Loan Repayment Plan Is Being Challenged. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: The income-driven plan known as SAVE has reduced payments for millions of borrowers. Lawsuits by Republican-led states are seeking to upend it.
lead_paragraph: When President Biden announced his plan to provide student debt relief for 43 million borrowers nearly two years ago, there was a piece to his program that attracted less attention: a new student loan repayment program that would cut monthly payments in half for millions.

headline: Lewis Hamilton, Swizz Beatz and Nine Inch Nails Toast Influential Artists
abstract: This week, the Brooklyn Museum honored the work of Titus Kaphar at their Artists Ball, and GQ hosted an awards show in the Financial District.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, as joggers wove down Eastern Parkway toward Prospect Park, art world fixtures stepped out of black cars and filed past blossoming trees into the Brooklyn Museum.

headline: But I’m All Grown Up With a Job of My Own
abstract: Caring colleagues might mean well, but your taking on new and more projects is none of their concern.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: New York’s Hottest Club Is a Literary Event
abstract: These days, readings in the city can require tickets and be just as hard to get into as a trendy restaurant.
lead_paragraph: When the writer and professor Amitava Kumar invited the book scout Erin Edmison to his reading at McNally Jackson Books’ Seaport location in February, Ms. Edmison penciled it into her calendar and “didn’t think twice about it,” she said, “because I am old, and that’s the way things used to work.”

headline: O.J. Simpson Trial Served as a Landmark Moment for Domestic Violence Awareness
abstract: His acquittal in the infamous trial involving Nicole Brown Simpson’s death prompted powerful backlash that helped change the perception around domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: In December 1994, investigators from the Los Angeles County prosecutor’s office drilled open a safe deposit box that had belonged to Nicole Brown Simpson. In it, they found Polaroids of her with a battered face and letters from O.J. Simpson apologizing for abusing her.

headline: In Ukraine’s West, Draft Dodgers Run, and Swim, to Avoid the War
abstract: With Russia seizing the initiative on the battlefield in recent months, Ukraine’s ability to defend itself hinges on replenishing its arsenal of weaponry and mobilizing troops.
lead_paragraph: The roiling water can be treacherous, the banks are steep and slick with mud, and the riverbed is covered in jagged, hidden boulders.

headline: Biden Shrinks Trump’s Edge in Latest Times/Siena Poll
abstract: The president’s popularity has ticked up slightly, though voters still view Donald J. Trump more favorably and have dour views of the economy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has nearly erased Donald J. Trump’s early polling advantage, amid signs that the Democratic base has begun to coalesce behind the president despite lingering doubts about the direction of the country, the economy and his age, according to a new survey by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: Ohtani’s Dizzying 3 Weeks End in Exoneration by Authorities
abstract: At times, baseball’s biggest star seemed in danger of being tainted by a gambling scandal, before his longtime interpreter was charged with fraud.
lead_paragraph: In the clubhouse after the Los Angeles Dodgers won their season opener in Seoul last month, Shohei Ohtani’s longtime interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, made a stunning admission to the team: He was a gambling addict, and Ohtani had paid his debts to a bookmaker.

headline: Cross-Tabs: April 2024 Times/Siena Poll of the Likely Electorate
abstract: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 47 percent to 46 percent, among the likely electorate.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 47 percent to 46 percent, among the likely electorate.

headline: A Closer Look at a Slight Shift in the Polls
abstract: An average of recent surveys, including the Times/Siena poll, finds President Biden inching closer to Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: Is President Biden gaining in the polls? There have been signs of it ever since his State of the Union address last month, and a New York Times/Siena College poll released Saturday morning is the latest hint.

headline: Toplines: April 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
abstract: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,059 registered voters from April 7 to 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Results of a nationwide New York Times/Siena College poll conducted among 1,059 registered voters from April 7 to 11, 2024.

headline: Cross-Tabs: April 2024 Times/Siena Poll of Registered Voters Nationwide
abstract: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 46 percent to 45 percent, among registered voters.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump leads Joe Biden, 46 percent to 45 percent, among registered voters.

headline: 3 Facts That Help Explain a Confusing Economic Moment
abstract: The path to a “soft landing” doesn’t seem as smooth as it did four months ago. But the expectations of a year ago have been surpassed.
lead_paragraph: The economic news of the past two weeks has been enough to leave even seasoned observers feeling whipsawed. The unemployment rate fell. Inflation rose. The stock market plunged, then rebounded, then dropped again.

headline: Why a Liberal Premier Wants to Pause a Carbon Tax Increase
abstract: Andrew Furey, Canada’s only Liberal premier, recently asked the Liberal federal government to suspend the scheduled increases.
lead_paragraph: When Canadians debate the place of the country’s oil industry in a carbon-constrained future, the conversation usually focuses on Alberta and, to a lesser extent, Saskatchewan. Often overlooked is Newfoundland and Labrador, where offshore drilling accounts for 5 percent of all of Canada’s oil production and just under a quarter of its light oil.

headline: Bondi Junction, Site of Stabbing Attack, Is a Popular and Busy Hub
abstract: As well as a major mall, the area contains cafes and yoga studios. It’s a gateway from central Sydney, Australia, to eastern suburbs and several popular beaches.
lead_paragraph: Tourists wandering the sprawling mall for gifts. Beachgoers picking up sunscreen before heading to the water. Friends meeting for coffee.

headline: The Gen Z Crossword Era
abstract: Solving a crossword puzzle today feels more like a spirited conversation with modern culture.
lead_paragraph: My 20-year-old niece, Emma, texted the other day to tell me she’s addicted to The Times’s game Connections; she and her friends play every day, along with the Mini and Strands. “The people who make the games need to make more fun games,” she declared.

headline: Some Words Feel Truer in Spanish
abstract: To me, a maleta meant family had arrived from Peru, carrying flavors, textures and memories of my birthplace.
lead_paragraph: My earliest relationship with language was defined by rules. As an immigrant who came to this country from Peru at age 4, I spent half of my days in kindergarten occupied with learning the rules of the English language. There was the tricky inconsistency of pronunciation to navigate and, once I learned to speak it, the challenge of translating what I’d learned into reading skills.

headline: The Age of the Open Letter Should End
abstract: The open letter, as a genre, is far too limited. We speak with conviction, and then what?
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, it is often suggested, people with starkly different viewpoints were able to convene and compromise and find hallowed common ground. This all happened in a “better time,” one invoked in fraught political discussions in which the discourse is not happening in exactly the way the invoker prefers. If only we could get back to that place, we could solve all our problems. We could overcome our differences. We could create lasting change.

headline: How to Reduce Student Absenteeism
abstract: Readers discuss the reasons for the spike since the pandemic and how to lure students back.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Harvard Is Bringing Back Standardized Tests. Other Schools Should, Too.
abstract: Emi Nietfeld didn’t have access to lacrosse or advanced placement classes, but she did have standardized tests.
lead_paragraph: Harvard University is among the latest institutions to announce it is reversing its test-optional policy and requiring students to submit test scores in their applications. For the writer Emi Nietfeld, it’s a positive sign. Growing up homeless and in the foster care system, she didn’t have a lot of control over her education or resources that would bolster her college applications. But one thing she did have control over was studying for standardized tests. In this audio essay, Nietfeld explains how Scantron sheets helped her unlock a better life.

headline: Who Cares if Supreme Court Justices Get Along?
abstract: What really matters is what the court does or doesn’t do.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court is hurting.

headline: You Don’t Have to Take Every Tax Deduction, and You Shouldn’t
abstract: Many exemptions are very hard, perhaps impossibly hard, to defend on either practical or moral grounds.
lead_paragraph: Alejandro Narváez is OK taking less. He hires only contractors who pay their workers a living wage, even if that means a larger bill. A Seattle-based dentist, he’s promoted cost-effective practices to expand dental care to the underserved, even if those practices cut into his bottom line. And when it comes to paying taxes, he forgoes many deductions afforded him.

headline: What Martin Luther King Jr. Knew About Crime and Mental Illness
abstract: Mental illness isn’t a crime, and jail isn’t the answer for those experiencing it.
lead_paragraph: In September 1958, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was stabbed with a seven-inch steel letter opener. He had been autographing copies of his first book in Blumstein’s department store in Harlem. The woman who stabbed him was named Izola Ware Curry.

headline: Military Aid to Israel Cannot Be Unconditional
abstract: Israel’s leader has turned his back on America’s entreaties.
lead_paragraph: The suffering of civilians in Gaza — tens of thousands dead, many of them children; hundreds of thousands homeless, many at risk of starvation — has become more than a growing number of Americans can abide. And yet Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his ultranationalist allies in government have defied American calls for more restraint and humanitarian help.

headline: Why Can’t Biden Triangulate Like Trump?
abstract: There’s a difference between being aware of your base and being its prisoner.
lead_paragraph: For anyone with sincere and absolute convictions on abortion, pro-life or pro-choice, Donald Trump’s attempts to reposition himself this week should be somewhere between depressing and infuriating.

headline: Too Soon?
abstract: A look back at O.J. Simpson’s attempt to reboot his media career, and more stories.
lead_paragraph: A look back at O.J. Simpson’s attempt to reboot his media career, plus more stories about knowing the right moment for something to happen.

headline: Cable Car Drops Passengers Onto Mountain in Turkey, Killing One
abstract: Scores of people were stranded, some overnight, after an accident on a rocky hillside above the city of Antalya.
lead_paragraph: A cable car ferrying passengers in a mountainous area of southern Turkey broke apart after colliding with part of the metal structure supporting it on Friday, sending its eight terrified occupants plummeting to the rocky hillside below.

headline: Witnesses to Sydney Mall Stabbing Describe Harrowing Scenes
abstract: People who were at the scene told of chaos, screaming, wounded victims and a resolute attacker. Many struggled to process the shock hours afterward.
lead_paragraph: Witnesses to the stabbings at a mall in a Sydney, Australia, on Saturday described a scene of terror as shoppers fled from the knife-wielding man or huddled in stores as panic spread through the shopping center.

headline: 2 Books About Other People’s Money
abstract: A tax manifesto by Edmund Wilson and a money-themed story collection.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Golf’s Big Deal Veers Off Course
abstract: The Masters tournament should be all about sport, but the unresolved fight between the PGA Tour and LIV Golf looms over the competition.
lead_paragraph: The Masters is a tournament steeped in tradition and hosts one of sports’ most storied gatherings: the champions dinner, when former winners meet at Augusta National Golf Club, and the previous year’s winner sets the menu.

headline: Death of 14-year-old Ignites More Violence in West Bank
abstract: Dozens of Israelis and Palestinians were wounded during clashes at several locations across the West Bank on Saturday after a missing teenage boy was found dead.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli teenager whose disappearance had led to riots by Israeli settlers in the West Bank was found dead on Saturday, the Israeli authorities said, threatening to further inflame tensions in the Israeli-occupied territory.

headline: As ‘Sex and the City’ Ages, Some Find the Cosmo Glass Half-Empty
abstract: As the show became more widely available on Netflix, younger viewers have watched it with a critical eye. But its longtime millennial and Gen X fans can’t quit.
lead_paragraph: Most weeks, hundreds of people board a “Sex and the City” themed bus in Manhattan that takes them to the show’s most recognizable sites: Carrie Bradshaw’s apartment, her favorite brunch spot, a sex shop in the West Village. The tour usually ends with — what else? — a Cosmopolitan.

headline: Mall Attack Was Australia’s Worst Mass Violence in Years
abstract: Saturday’s stabbing attack in Sydney horrified a country not used to such acts.
lead_paragraph: The stabbing attack in a Sydney shopping center that left at least six people dead on Saturday was Australia’s worst act of mass violence since 2017, when a driver killed six people by deliberately plowing his car into pedestrians in Melbourne.

headline: For Many Western Allies, Sending Weapons to Israel Gets Dicey
abstract: As civilian casualties in Gaza spiral, some nations are suspending sales amid accusations of abetting genocide and war crimes.
lead_paragraph: For months, Western governments have provided military support for Israel while fending off accusations that their weapons were being used to commit war crimes in Gaza. But as a global outcry over the growing death toll in Gaza mounts, maintaining that balance is becoming increasingly difficult, as was clear on a single day this past week.

headline: Iran Seizes Commercial Ship Linked to Israel
abstract: Directly and through proxy groups like the Houthis in Yemen, Iran has been disrupting commercial shipping in the Persian Gulf for years.
lead_paragraph: Iranian forces seized a container ship with links to Israel in the Persian Gulf on Saturday, as leaders in the Middle East and beyond watched for a retaliatory strike by Iran against Israel.

headline: Wyoming Democratic Caucus Results
abstract: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Wyoming Democratic presidential caucus.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Wyoming Democratic presidential caucus.

headline: Lawmaker Presses Luxury Designer After Reports of Exploiting Indigenous Workers
abstract: A freshman congressman is demanding answers from the fashion house Loro Piana, which sources wool from his native Peru and faces accusations of exploiting workers there.
lead_paragraph: A $9,000 designer sweater made out of the ultrarare fur of a South American animal called a vicuña is not exactly a typical area of focus for a member of the U.S. Congress.

headline: Banana Bread, Always and Forever
abstract: As long as we have bananas that go brown, we will have Julia Moskin’s perfect banana bread.
lead_paragraph: My relationship with bananas can best be described by paraphrasing Katy Perry’s 2008 song: We’re hot then we’re cold, we’re yes then we’re no, we’re in then we’re out, we’re up then we’re down. I’ll bring home a Donkey Kong-size haul of them on a Sunday, craving their starchy sweetness. On Monday and Tuesday I’ll proudly peel some for my breakfasts and lunches. But by Friday, I’ll have a pile of forgotten soft crescents streaked with black.

headline: What Are the Stakes of ‘Civil War,’ Really?
abstract: Alex Garland’s new film is most interested in the experience of living through an armed conflict.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of the release of “Civil War,” the new alt-history action-drama from the director Alex Garland, A24, the studio that produced the film, released a map of the United States showing the lines of the conflict. There was the “New People’s Army” of the Pacific Northwest, the Mountain West and some of the Great Plains. There were the “Western Forces” of Texas and California. And there was the “Florida Alliance,” encompassing most of the Southeast. What remained was labeled “the Loyalist States.”

headline: Protesters in Niger Call for U.S. Military Exit as Russian Force Arrives
abstract: Trainers and equipment from Russia landed in the West African nation this week, putting the continued presence of 1,000 U.S. military personnel there in doubt.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of protesters gathered in the capital of Niger on Saturday called for the withdrawal of U.S. armed forces personnel stationed in the West African nation, only days after Russia delivered its own set of military equipment and instructors to the country’s military.

headline: Fritz Peterson, Yankee Pitcher in an Unusual ‘Trade,’ Dies at 81
abstract: He was a leading light on an undistinguished team. But he became known less for his achievement on the field than for exchanging wives with a teammate.
lead_paragraph: Fritz Peterson, who was a stalwart pitcher for the ineffectual Yankees of the late 1960s and early ’70s, but whose lingering renown derived more from one of baseball’s most notorious “trades” — his exchange of wives with a teammate — has died at his home in Winona, Minn. He was 81.

headline: When O.J. Simpson ‘Confessed’ to Murder
abstract: Years after Mr. Simpson was acquitted, he wrote a book and gave a shocking interview. The whole endeavor cost the publisher, Judith Regan, her job.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, O.J. Simpson pleaded not guilty to murdering his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald Goldman. He was acquitted by a jury. But a little more than a decade later, he more or less confessed to the crimes.

headline: Election Workers Face Flood of Threats, but Charges Are Few
abstract: The Justice Department has a task force focused on the thousands of threats against state and local officials who oversee voting, but most are protected by the First Amendment.
lead_paragraph: One week after the 2020 presidential election, Tina Barton, who as the clerk of Rochester Hills, Mich., oversaw voting there, sat down at her desk, coffee in hand, and listened to her voice mail messages.

headline: Stabbing Attack in Sydney Kills at Least Six People
abstract: Shoppers hid in backrooms or ran screaming from the scene, while others stayed with injured victims. The police said they believed the attack was not a “terrorism incident.”
lead_paragraph: A man killed six people and injured at least 12 others during a stabbing rampage at a popular shopping mall in Sydney, Australia, on Saturday afternoon, in one of the country’s deadliest acts of mass violence in recent decades.

headline: Don Wright, Editorial Cartoonist With a Skewer for a Pen, Dies at 90
abstract: He won two Pulitzers for Florida newspapers, commenting wryly on war, segregation, church scandals and more while reaching readers nationwide through syndication.
lead_paragraph: Don Wright, a two-time Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial cartoonist whose pointed work punctured duplicity and pomposity and resonated with common-sense readers, died on March 24 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 90.

headline: The Sydney Mall Stabbing Rampage: What We Know
abstract: The attack happened in a busy center for tourists and beachgoers in the eastern suburbs, an affluent area of Sydney.
lead_paragraph: A stabbing attack on Saturday afternoon at a crowded mall in Sydney, Australia, left six people dead and at least 11 others injured, including a 9-month-old girl. The rampage was the deadliest act of mass violence in the country since 2017.

headline: State Dept. Is Sending Its Top Diplomat for East Asia to China
abstract: The announcement comes days after President Biden met jointly with the leaders of Japan and the Philippines to discuss Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific region.
lead_paragraph: The top U.S. diplomat for East Asia will travel to China on Sunday, the State Department announced, just days after President Biden met with the leaders of Japan and the Philippines in Washington as part of a broad diplomatic outreach in the region to counter China’s aggression.

headline: Four South Dakota Tribes Bar Gov. Kristi Noem, Trump V.P. Contender, From Lands
abstract: The tribes barred the Republican governor from their reservations after she told lawmakers that Mexican drug cartels had a foothold there and were committing murders.
lead_paragraph: Four of South Dakota’s federally recognized Native American tribes have barred the state’s governor, Kristi Noem — a Republican whose name has been floated as a potential running mate for former President Donald J. Trump — from their reservations. The latest blocked Ms. Noem on Thursday.

headline: Inside Donald Trump’s Embrace of the Jan. 6 Rioters
abstract: The former president initially disavowed the attack on the Capitol, but he is now making it a centerpiece of his general election campaign.
lead_paragraph: Two days before former President Donald J. Trump was booked at an Atlanta jail on his fourth indictment, he held an event at his golf club in New Jersey for another group of people facing criminal charges: rioters accused of storming the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Hudson Yards ‘Vessel’ Sculpture Will Reopen With Netting After Suicides
abstract: The 150-foot-high tourist attraction, which closed in 2021, will be fitted with mesh to stop people from jumping.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three years after a series of suicides shut down the Vessel, the 150-foot-tall centerpiece of the Hudson Yards complex in Manhattan, the project’s developer said on Friday that it would reopen this year with new safety measures.

headline: Faith Ringgold Dies at 93; Wove Black Life Into Quilts and Children’s Books
abstract: A champion of Black artists, she explored themes of race, gender, class, family and community through a vast array of media and later the written word.
lead_paragraph: Faith Ringgold, a multimedia artist whose pictorial quilts depicting the African American experience gave rise to a second distinguished career as a writer and illustrator of children’s books, died on Saturday at her home in Englewood, N.J. She was 93.

headline: Indigenous Artists Are the Heart of the Venice Biennale
abstract: Here are highlights of the range of work produced by Native artists in the pavilions and a central exhibition that proudly calls itself “Foreigners Everywhere.”
lead_paragraph: Before visitors step into any gallery at the 2024 Venice Biennale, which opens April 20, Indigenous artists will have made their presence known.

headline: Representing the U.S. and Critiquing It in a Psychedelic Rainbow
abstract: Jeffrey Gibson’s history-making turn at the Venice Biennale brings the gay and Native American artist center stage with works of struggle and freedom.
lead_paragraph: People in Venice might hear the jingle dress dancers before they see them. On April 18, some 26 intertribal Native American dancers and singers from Oklahoma and Colorado will make their way through the winding streets and canals of the Italian city. Wearing brightly colored shawls, beaded yokes and dresses decorated with the metal cones that give the dance its distinctive cshh cshh rattling sound, they’ll make their way to the Giardini, one of the primary sites of the Venice Biennale. There, they’ll climb atop and surround a large red sculpture composed of pedestals of different heights and perform.

headline: Stacks of Cash at Menendez Home Were Not From His Bank, Prosecutors Say
abstract: The senator has said that money found in his house was from his own savings account. But prosecutors said that at least some of it came from “another person.”
lead_paragraph: When Senator Robert Menendez was charged last year with corruption after investigators found $486,000 in cash stashed around his house in New Jersey, he offered a simple, “old-fashioned” explanation: It had been his custom to withdraw cash from a personal savings account to keep at home, a habit he learned from his Cuban immigrant parents.

headline: Savings Plan
abstract: John Rippe and Jeff Chen collaborate on a puzzle with a big heart.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Tensions Flare in West Bank After Israeli Teenager Is Found Dead
abstract: The killing, which Israel called a “terrorist attack,” prompted rioting by Israeli settlers that killed one Palestinian and raised fears of a broader escalation.
lead_paragraph: The disappearance and death of an Israeli teenager, whose body was found on Saturday in the West Bank, spurred deadly rioting by Israeli settlers in Palestinian villages, ratcheting up tensions even further in the occupied territory.

headline: Iran Launches Aerial Attack on Israel
abstract: Air-raid sirens sounded across Israel and the West Bank as the night sky lit up with incoming missiles and interceptions.
lead_paragraph: Air-raid sirens sounded across Israel and the West Bank as the night sky lit up with incoming missiles and interceptions.

headline: What Happened to Damages That O.J. Simpson Owed to the Victims’ Families?
abstract: In 1997, a jury in a civil trial awarded the families of Ronald Goldman and Nicole Brown Simpson $33 million. Today, the amount still owed has more than tripled.
lead_paragraph: More than 25 years ago, O.J. Simpson was found liable in civil court for the deaths of his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, her friend, and was ordered to pay more than $33 million to their families.

headline: U.S. Intercepts Dozens of Iranian Drones and Missiles Aimed at Israel
abstract: Britain’s defense secretary said British jets were prepared to intercept Iranian attacks. France and Germany expressed support.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. military said that it had shot down dozens of the drones and missiles that Iran fired at Israel on Saturday, a strong demonstration that despite recent criticism of Israel’s conduct of the war in Gaza, Washington was firmly committed to protecting a key ally from Iran, a mutual adversary.

headline: She Was Kidnapped a Decade Ago With 275 Girls. Finally, She Escaped.
abstract: Their capture set off a global campaign to “Bring Back Our Girls.” But many are still missing, and kidnappings in Nigeria have proliferated.
lead_paragraph: Saratu Dauda had been kidnapped. It was 2014, she was 16, and she was in a truck packed with her classmates heading into the bush in northeastern Nigeria, a member of the terrorist group Boko Haram at the wheel. The girls’ boarding school in Chibok, miles behind them, had been set on fire.

headline: Should We Change Species to Save Them?
abstract: When traditional conservation fails, science is using “assisted evolution” to give vulnerable wildlife a chance.
lead_paragraph: For tens of millions of years, Australia has been a playground for evolution, and the land Down Under lays claim to some of the most remarkable creatures on Earth.

headline: In Final Rally Before New York Trial, Trump Again Casts Himself as Political Victim
abstract: Campaigning in Pennsylvania on Saturday, Donald J. Trump once more falsely asserted that his criminal charges were an attempt by Democrats to keep him from the White House.
lead_paragraph: Two days before his first criminal trial was set to begin in Manhattan, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday again framed the charges he faces as a broad attempt by Democrats to keep him from the White House, and he criticized a gag order placed on him by the judge in the New York case.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Thousands Try to Run, or Swim Across ‘Death River,’ to Dodge the Draft
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody is afraid to die, but we try to make them look at it from a different perspective.”

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Can’t Keep it Together
abstract: Ryan Gosling hosted an episode that included appearances by Caitlin Clark, Emily Blunt and Kate McKinnon, another Ken song and multiple sketches full of people laughing at their own jokes.
lead_paragraph: If an entire Oscars ceremony full of Barbenheimer jokes and a killer Ryan Gosling performance of “I’m Just Ken” didn’t give you sufficient opportunity to say goodbye to the pop cultural phenomenon of “Barbie,” “Saturday Night Live” is here to make sure that you’ve had Kenough.

headline: Corrections: April 14, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, April 14, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about Bran­don Blackwell, who excelled on the British quiz show “University Chal­lenge,” misstated the name of the Los Angeles neighborhood where the College Bowl Company has its office. It is Woodland Hills, not Wild Hills.

headline: Israel Faced a Sophisticated Attack From Iran
abstract: The weapons Iran employed this weekend travel farther and are more precise than those Hamas and other allies have used against Israel in the past six months.
lead_paragraph: Late Saturday, Iran began firing hundreds of drones and missiles at Israel, including weapons that experts say are more sophisticated than anything Israel had encountered until now in six months of fighting with Hamas and its allies in the region.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘I Opened the Book App on My Tablet and Began Reading’
abstract: Bonding over Homer on the 1 train, giving a dashboard gift and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 308
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Why Heat Pumps Are the Future, and How Your Home Could Use One
abstract: The highly efficient devices are the darlings of the environmental movement. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: Heat pumps, which both warm and cool buildings and are powered by electricity, have been touted as the answer to curbing greenhouse gas emissions produced by homes, businesses and office buildings, which are responsible for about one-third of the emissions in New York State.

headline: A Portrait Fit for a Publisher
abstract: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr. steered The Times during an era of great change. His likeness now hangs at the organization’s headquarters.
lead_paragraph: A portrait of Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The New York Times from 1992 through 2017, was unveiled April 4 at The New York Times headquarters in Manhattan. The subject himself tugged a crushed velvet drape off the painting, by Katy Schneider, to applause from several dozen guests.

headline: At the Masters, Champions Past, Present and Future
abstract: Golf enthusiasts regard a trip to the Masters Tournament as the stuff of dreams. Here are photos from this year’s tournament.
lead_paragraph: Seventy-five years ago this past week, Sam Snead won the Masters Tournament and became the first champion to receive one of Augusta National Golf Club’s green jackets.

headline: As Trial Looms, Trump Plays to a Jury of Millions
abstract: Donald J. Trump and his lawyers realize his chances in the courtroom are dicey. He intends to make whatever happens a political triumph.
lead_paragraph: The first criminal trial of Donald J. Trump will begin on Monday, and the 45th president thinks he can win — no matter what the jury decides. Mr. Trump will aim to spin any outcome to his benefit and, if convicted, to become the first felon to win the White House.

headline: After Stabbing Rampage, Australia Struggles With How and Why
abstract: The police have yet to determine a motive for Saturday’s attack, which left six people dead, but said the assailant had mental-health problems.
lead_paragraph: On a perfect mid-autumn day, the scene at an upscale suburban mall in Sydney, Australia, was as humdrum as it was idyllic: mothers pushing strollers, gaggles of teenagers being young, families whiling away the weekend afternoon.

headline: Fashion’s Favorite Farm
abstract: What is Sky High Farm? A brand? An art project? A business? A charity? It wants to be all of the above.
lead_paragraph: There are certain things the fashion industry will always love: The young and beautiful. Art and money. Nostalgia. A comeback. From time to time, it also loves to throw itself behind a cause.

headline: S’mores Kits? Saunas? Short-Term Rental Hosts Scramble to Stand Out.
abstract: More hosts are fighting over guests, driving down prices and forcing the hosts to find creative ways to entice renters.
lead_paragraph: In Scottsdale, Ariz., where the sunny weather lures bachelorette party revelers year-round, short-term rental owners are ready and waiting.

headline: Dana White, Donald Trump and the Rise of Cage-Match Politics
abstract: White, chief executive of the bloody and beloved Ultimate Fighting Championship, has shot to the peak of Trump-era culture and political influence. What does he want?
lead_paragraph: Dana White’s diplomatic ambitions were clear, if complicated: Un-cancel Bud Light.

headline: For Caleb Carr, Salvation Arrived on Little Cat’s Feet
abstract: As he struggled with writing and illness, the “Alienist” author found comfort in the feline companions he recalls in a new memoir, “My Beloved Monster.”
lead_paragraph: J. Alfred Prufrock measured his life out in coffee spoons. Caleb Carr has done so in cats.

headline: Netflix’s New Film Strategy: More About the Audience, Less About Auteurs
abstract: Dan Lin, the streaming service’s new film chief, wants to produce a more varied slate of movies to better appeal to the array of interests among subscribers.
lead_paragraph: Back in, say, 2019, if a filmmaker signed a deal with Netflix, it meant that he or she would be well paid and receive complete creative freedom. Theatrical release? Not so much. Still, the paycheck and the latitude — and the potential to reach the streaming service’s huge subscriber base — helped compensate for the lack of hoopla that comes when a traditional studio opens a film in multiplexes around the world.

headline: This Prosecutor Pledged to Change George Floyd’s City. Her Critics Are Circling.
abstract: Mary Moriarty, a former chief public defender, became the top prosecutor in Minneapolis, promising an overhaul. Now she faces criticism, including from fellow Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Mary Moriarty, a former public defender, became Minneapolis’s top prosecutor last year after persuading voters shaken by the murder of George Floyd that she could improve public safety by reining in police misconduct and making the criminal justice system less punitive.

headline: Jan. 6 Obstruction Case at Supreme Court Could Help Trump and Many Others
abstract: The justices will hear arguments on Tuesday in a case that could alter hundreds of prosecutions for the assault on the Capitol and help define its meaning.
lead_paragraph: At first blush, the case the Supreme Court will hear on Tuesday seems technical, requiring the justices to parse a decades-old statute mainly concerned with the destruction of business records.

headline: At Milan Design Week, a Smorgasbord of Tables and Table Toppers
abstract: The annual festival of furnishings and household objects features a variety of items that can be turned into tables.
lead_paragraph: At Alcova, an annual Milan Design Week exhibition that celebrates the unconventional, an aptly named San Francisco studio named Surfacedesign is showing tables and other furniture pieces made from boulders. There is no end to the movable feast of materials that can be turned into tables, just as there is no end to the things you can put on them. The seemingly infinite options are further amplified by an urge to give new life to old, overlooked or discarded stuff.

headline: Queer Women Behaving Badly: These Movies Scrap the Coming-Out Story
abstract: “Love Lies Bleeding,” “Bottoms” and “Drive-Away Dolls” are leading a wave of stories about lesbians living their lives, committing crimes along the way.
lead_paragraph: To a queer woman going to the movies, it may seem as if there has been something in the ether for the past year. First, in August, there was “Bottoms.” Then “Drive-Away Dolls” arrived in February. “Love Lies Bleeding” joined the fray in March. This cluster of relatively mainstream films about queer women, deliciously frothy and fun to watch, feels unprecedented.

headline: Undergarments for the Ultrawealthy
abstract: Cadolle, a maker of corsets favored by designers like John Galliano and labels like Dior, is known for custom underpinnings that can cost thousands of dollars.
lead_paragraph: In a subterranean workroom of a building on Rue Saint-Honoré in Paris, there are cabinets filled with bags of Chantilly lace in myriad shades: Yves Klein blue, sherbet orange, a silvery periwinkle. Nestled between the furniture are some half-dozen sewing machines, at which a small staff of seamstresses works while constructing corsets for Cadolle, a company that has been making custom lingerie for almost 140 years.

headline: Lincoln’s Murder Is Often Re-enacted, but Not at Ford’s Theater
abstract: The theater says that allowing the assassination to be recreated there would undermine the gravity and significance of Abraham Lincoln’s death.
lead_paragraph: Since Ford’s Theater reopened as an active theater in 1968, it has rarely been the scene of a dramatic re-enactment of Abraham Lincoln being shot to death there on April 14, 1865.

headline: As Trump Ponders V.P. Contenders, He Asks: Can They Help Me Raise Cash?
abstract: Donald Trump’s concerns about money may have entered his vice-presidential calculations, along with political considerations and which contenders he likes the look of.
lead_paragraph: As former President Donald J. Trump sifts through potential running mates, he has peppered some advisers and associates with a direct question: Which Republican could best help him raise money for the rest of the presidential campaign?

headline: How Women at One Arizona Clinic Are Grappling With the Abortion Ruling
abstract: Inside Acacia Women’s Center, patients described a mix of fear, anger and anxiety after the State Supreme Court’s decision to reinstate a law that bans nearly all abortions.
lead_paragraph: Leah found out she was five weeks pregnant on the same day that the Arizona Supreme Court upheld an 1864 law banning nearly all abortions in the state.

headline: Iran’s Attacks Bring Long Shadow War With Israel Into the Open
abstract: The volley of drones and missiles was the first time that Tehran directly attacked Israel from its own territory, one expert said.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Israeli military strikes in Iran.

headline: Four Years Out, Some Voters Look Back at Trump’s Presidency More Positively
abstract: A new poll by The New York Times and Siena College finds that voters think highly of the former president’s record on the economy, but memories of his divisiveness largely remain intact.
lead_paragraph: Views of Donald J. Trump’s presidency have become more positive since he left office, bolstering his case for election and posing a risk to President Biden’s strategy of casting his opponent as unfit for the presidency, according to a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College.

headline: Immigrant Detention Should Have No Place in Our Society
abstract: The nation’s detention and prison systems have grown side by side, buttressed by the same logic and practice.
lead_paragraph: In May 2018, Fernando Arredondo and his 12-year-old daughter, Andrea, reached the U.S.-Mexico border. The two had fled Guatemala after gang members killed his son, Marco, and threatened the rest of the family.

headline: Stormy Daniels and the Comeuppance of Donald Trump
abstract: Trump has long treated women as objects, targets, supplicants. I suspect he never thought they would be the ones to hold him accountable.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes I lie awake at night wondering whether Donald Trump is afraid.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘What I Saw Working at The National Enquirer During Donald Trump’s Rise’
abstract: Inside the notorious “catch and kill” campaign that now stands at the heart of the former president’s legal trial.
lead_paragraph: At the center of the criminal case against former President Donald Trump in Manhattan is the accusation that Trump took part in a scheme to turn The National Enquirer and its sister publications into an arm of his 2016 presidential campaign. The documents detailed three “hush money” payments made to a series of individuals to guarantee their silence about potentially damaging stories in the months before the election. Because this was done with the goal of helping his election chances, the case implied, these payments amounted to a form of illegal, undisclosed campaign spending. And because Trump created paperwork to make the payments seem like regular legal expenses, that amounted to a criminal effort at a coverup, argued Alvin Bragg, the district attorney of Manhattan. Trump has denied the charges against him.

headline: The Most Famous Golfer at the Masters Is Black. Why Aren’t There More Players Like Him?
abstract: Tiger Woods said he owes his career to Charlie Sifford, the first Black member of the P.G.A. But the golf world has done far too little to promote Black players.
lead_paragraph: When the Masters Tournament commenced on Thursday, featuring 89 competitors, there was exactly one Black golfer in the field: the one we all know, Tiger Woods. Beyond that, the field for the 88th Masters didn’t look all that different from the previous 87.

headline: What Weapons Did Israel Use to Block Iran’s Attack?
abstract: Israel’s Iron Dome defense system intercepts rockets that fly in high arcs, while its Arrow 3 system can stop ballistic missiles outside the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces used two main defensive weapons, the Iron Dome and the Arrow 3, to shoot down most of the more than 300 drones, ballistic missiles and cruise missiles fired at its territory by Iran, while others were shot down by the United States and other allies.

headline: Biden Seeks to Head Off Escalation After Israel’s Successful Defense
abstract: The president told Israel that the interception of nearly all of the Iranian drones and missiles used to attack it constituted a major victory, and so further retaliation might not be necessary, U.S. officials said.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his team, hoping to avoid further escalation leading to a wider war in the Middle East, are advising Israel that its successful defense against Iranian airstrikes constituted a major strategic victory that might not require another round of retaliation, U.S. officials said on Sunday.

headline: Iran Attacks Israel
abstract: What we know about the assault — and what it means.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s missile attack on Israel has ended, for now, and virtually none of the missiles reached their targets.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 15, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Iran’s Strikes on Israel Open a Dangerous New Chapter for Old Rivals
abstract: Experts say Tehran does not want a broader war. But it is far from clear whether Iran or Israel will choose to escalate a conflict that has become more direct and out of the shadows.
lead_paragraph: Iran has retaliated directly against Israel for the killings of its senior generals in Damascus, Syria, with an onslaught of more than 300 drones and missiles aimed at restoring its credibility and deterrence, officials and analysts say.

headline: What We Know About Iran’s Attack on Israel and What Happens Next
abstract: Israel is deciding how to respond to an attack by Tehran in which it fired hundreds of drones and missiles. Its allies are urging restraint.
lead_paragraph: World leaders are urging Israel to act with restraint after Iran launched a large aerial attack over the weekend, firing at least 300 drones and missiles. Israel’s war cabinet has not yet said how it will respond to the first such direct assault launched from Iranian territory after decades of shadow warfare between the two countries.

headline: The Atmosphere of the ‘Manosphere’ Is Toxic
abstract: Struggling men need to leave the gurus behind.
lead_paragraph: To understand the state of men in this country, it’s necessary to know three things.

headline: Do You Have a Family Story That Defines Who You Are?
abstract: History isn’t just learned through textbooks; everybody has a story, big or small, that tells us about America.
lead_paragraph: American history is often recounted through major events. But every family has its own stories, moments that were perhaps never recorded in a history book — the purchase of a home, a hometown disaster, a death, a move — yet speak to the events that define the United States.

headline: Rico Wade, an Architect of Atlanta Hip-Hop, Dies at 52
abstract: As one-third of the production team Organized Noize, he nurtured the careers of Outkast, Goodie Mob and Future from the confines of his mother’s basement, known as the Dungeon.
lead_paragraph: Rico Wade, an architect of Southern hip-hop who produced albums for rap acts including Outkast, Goodie Mob and Future, died on Saturday in Atlanta. He was 52.

headline: An Unexpected Player in Israel’s Defense: Jordan, Home to Many Palestinians
abstract: The Arab kingdom said it took military action to defend its territory against Iranian drone and missile strikes. Critics assailed the country as having helped defend Israel.
lead_paragraph: The response by Israel and other nations to Iran’s aerial attack kept the majority of its drones and missiles from landing in Israel, ensuring they caused only light damage and a handful of injuries, Israeli officials said.

headline: News Outlets Urge Trump and Biden to Commit to Presidential Debates
abstract: In an unusual statement, the news organizations said “there is simply no substitute” for a face-to-face debate, a campaign staple since 1976.
lead_paragraph: A group of major news organizations — including The Associated Press and the five big broadcast and cable networks — issued an unusual joint statement on Sunday urging President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump to commit to participating in televised debates before Election Day.

headline: Spring Cleaning to Refresh; Bacon and Egg Don to Comfort
abstract: Eric Kim’s recipe combines soft scrambled eggs, crisped bacon and furikake-flecked rice for a fantastic breakfast-for-dinner dish.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. The birds are back in town, chirping at dawn, flitting to and from the feeders set up out back, firing up the cat at the window. There’s no languorous idyll in bed before breakfast these days; there’s much to be done. Daylight’s burning. Time for spring cleaning.

headline: The Beautiful World of Birding
abstract: Readers discuss the hobby’s many benefits. Also: Friends in the court; politicians’ health; testing the candidates; banning plastic foam.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Strikes Upend Israel’s Belief About Iran’s Willingness to Fight It Directly
abstract: Israel had grown used to targeting Iranian officials without head-on retaliation from Iran, an assumption overturned by Iran’s attacks on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s unprecedented strikes on Israel this weekend have shaken Israel’s assumptions about its foe, undermining its long-held calculation that Iran would be best deterred by greater Israeli aggression.

headline: American Pizazz Meets the Staid Traditions of Sumo
abstract: At Madison Square Garden, New Yorkers got a rare look at an ancient Japanese sport, cheering and booing as though they were watching a Yankees game.
lead_paragraph: Two giant, shirtless men bow respectfully and then hurl themselves at each other in a violent pas de deux that ends with a victory in seconds.

headline: At Carnegie Hall, Weimar Is Irresistible but Vaguely Defined
abstract: Carnegie’s intermittently illuminating festival “Fall of the Weimar Republic” has suffered from interjections of too much standard repertory.
lead_paragraph: In the middle of Erich Wolfgang Korngold’s suite of incidental music for “Much Ado About Nothing,” there’s a march meant to accompany Dogberry, Shakespeare’s comic constable, and his fellow watchmen.

headline: Iran Attack Tests Netanyahu’s Political Staying Power
abstract: In a deeply polarized country that has again come under attack, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s fate may depend on what happens next.
lead_paragraph: In a deeply divided Israel, even the dramatic scene above the country’s skies on Sunday is open to political interpretation.

headline: Review: Under Manfred Honeck, the Philharmonic Becomes One
abstract: In a program of Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff, a guest conductor coaxes a sumptuous sincerity from the orchestra’s musicians.
lead_paragraph: In a thrilling concert of Russian staples on Friday night, the conductor Manfred Honeck unified the players of the New York Philharmonic using something we don’t often hear from the stage of David Geffen Hall: a distinct point of view.

headline: Prince Harry Hits the Polo Field in Front of Netflix Cameras
abstract: The Duke of Sussex competed in a match in South Florida the day after the announcement that he will be working on a new polo-related Netflix project.
lead_paragraph: In front of rolling cameras and a crowd of nearly 300 guests, Prince Harry, Duke of Sussex, barreled toward one end of a polo field in South Florida on Friday.

headline: The Dystopian ‘Civil War’ Reaches No. 1 at the Box Office
abstract: Alex Garland’s movie, starring Kirsten Dunst, surpassed “Godzilla x Kong,” with an estimated $25.7 million in North American ticket sales on its first weekend.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood executives — not all, but most — have insisted for years that uncomfortable, thought-provoking, original movies can no longer attract big audiences at the box office.

headline: Johnson Says the House Will Vote on an Israel Bill in the Coming Days
abstract: Speaker Mike Johnson left unclear whether the vote on the security package, coming after Iranian attacks on Israel, would also include aid for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Mike Johnson said on Sunday after Iran’s overnight attack on Israel that the House would vote in the coming days on aid for Israel, and he suggested that aid for Ukraine could be included in the legislation.

headline: Sununu Says Trump ‘Contributed’ to Insurrection, but Still Has His Support
abstract: The New Hampshire governor, who has been critical of the former president and supported Nikki Haley in the primary, said he wanted a Republican in the White House.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire said on Sunday that former President Donald J. Trump “absolutely contributed” to an insurrection and that Mr. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election were “absolutely terrible” — but that nothing, not even felony convictions, would stop him from voting for Mr. Trump because the economy, border security and “culture change” were more important.

headline: Iran Just Made a Big Mistake. Israel Shouldn’t Follow.
abstract: There now needs to be a large, sustained, global initiative to isolate Iran.
lead_paragraph: It would be easy to be dazzled by the way Israeli, American and other allied militaries shot down virtually every Iranian drone, cruise missile and ballistic missile launched at Israel on Saturday and conclude that Iran had made its point — retaliating for Israel’s allegedly killing a top Iranian commander operating against Israel from Syria — and now we can call it a day.

headline: For Israel, Revenge Should Be a Dish Served Cold
abstract: Israel has the right to retaliate against Iran’s missile barrage. It should bide its time.
lead_paragraph: After several days during which Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei repeatedly vowed that “the evil Zionist regime” would be punished for its April 1 attack on Iran’s embassy complex in Damascus that killed seven Iranian military advisers, including three top commanders, the Islamic Republic struck. More than 300 drones and missiles launched from Iranian soil took aim at Israel on Saturday. Nearly all of them were intercepted, mainly by Israeli or American defenses, with a report of just one Israeli casualty, a girl from a Bedouin community wounded by shrapnel.

headline: ‘Sunset Boulevard,’ Heading to Broadway, Wins Big at Olivier Awards
abstract: The musical, which stars Nicole Scherzinger, won seven awards at Britain’s version of the Tonys. And Sarah Snook won best actress for “The Picture of Dorian Gray.”
lead_paragraph: A reimagining of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Sunset Boulevard,” starring Nicole Scherzinger as Norma Desmond, the long forgotten silent movie star who descends into madness, was the big winner at this year’s Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel Weighs a Response to Iran
abstract: Also, the Australian authorities are searching for a motive in the deadly stabbing attack.
lead_paragraph: Calm mostly prevailed in Israel yesterday after Iran fired more than 300 missiles and drones at the country overnight. Nearly all were intercepted, Israeli military officials said, and those that made an impact caused only minor damage.

headline: A 7-Year-Old Girl Is the Lone Serious Casualty of Iran’s Barrage
abstract: The girl, who lives in a Negev desert community that is home to Arab Bedouins, was clinging to life in a hospital after the attack.
lead_paragraph: The hospital waiting room was quiet on Sunday: There was no crowd of relatives, no flood of patients. Israel’s air defenses had just fended off a large-scale Iranian attack, with only one serious casualty recorded.

headline: Brightly Colored Rock
abstract: Amanda Winters makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Palestinians Trying to Return to Northern Gaza Say Israeli Troops Fired on Them
abstract: An emergency worker and two people who tried to make the journey said Israeli troops shot into the crowd, forcing people to turn back in panic.
lead_paragraph: As thousands of displaced Palestinians tried to return to their homes in northern Gaza on Sunday, Israeli troops shot into the crowd, forcing people to turn back in panic, according to an emergency worker and two people who tried to make the journey.

headline: He Was Blinded in One Eye, but Salman Rushdie’s Vision Is Undiminished
abstract: The author’s new memoir, “Knife,” addresses the attack that maimed him in 2022, and pays tribute to the wife who saw him through. “I wanted to write a book which was about both love and hatred — one overcoming the other,” he says.
lead_paragraph: Last May, nine months after the knife attack that nearly killed him, Salman Rushdie made a surprise appearance at the 2023 PEN America literary gala. His voice was weak and he was noticeably thinner than usual; one of his eyeglass lenses was blacked out, because his right eye had been blinded in the assault. But anyone wondering whether the author was still his old exuberant self would have been immediately reassured by the way he began his remarks, with a racy impromptu joke.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Kidnapped With 275 Girls, She Finally Escaped
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “The only crime of these girls was to go to school.”

headline: No Corrections: April 15, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Review: It’s No Sunday in the Park With ‘Lempicka’
abstract: A musical about the groundbreaking Art Deco painter is vocally thrilling but historically a blur.
lead_paragraph: Having dismissed her work as merely decorative, a fierce Italian gives harsh advice to an ambitious young painter: “You need to be a monster,” he brays. “Or a machine.”

headline: Far Right’s Ties to Russia Sow Rising Alarm in Germany
abstract: As cases proliferate, opponents fear the Alternative for Germany party is becoming a tool of Russian influence operations to undermine support for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: To enter a secret session of Germany’s Parliament, lawmakers must lock their phones and leave them outside. Inside, they are not even allowed to take notes. Yet to many politicians, these precautions against espionage now feel like something of a farce.

headline: Four Wild Ways to Save the Koala (That Just Might Work)
abstract: To protect Australia’s iconic animals, scientists are experimenting with vaccine implants, probiotics, tree-planting drones and solar-powered tracking tags.
lead_paragraph: It was spring in Queensland, Australia, a season when many wild animals find themselves in trouble, and the Currumbin Wildlife Hospital was a blur of fur and feathers.

headline: After Iran’s Barrage, Israel Questions What Might Be Next for the Gaza War
abstract: Military analysts are divided on whether a more direct confrontation with Iran might alter the war or affect a decision to invade the southern city of Rafah.
lead_paragraph: Within moments of Israel and its allies shooting down a fusillade of Iranian missiles and drones this weekend, many began wondering what the latest exchange between Israel and Iran would mean for the war in the Gaza Strip.

headline: On Himalayan Hillsides Grows Japan’s Cold, Hard Cash
abstract: A shrub in impoverished Nepal now supplies the raw material for the bank notes used in Asia’s most sophisticated financial system.
lead_paragraph: The views are spectacular in this corner of eastern Nepal, between the world’s highest mountains and the tea estates of India’s Darjeeling district, where rare orchids grow and red pandas play on the lush hillsides.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: After Iran’s attack, Israel weighs its options.
lead_paragraph: Israel showed signs that it would not immediately retaliate for the hundreds of exploding drones and missiles that Iran fired at it over the weekend, nearly all of which Israel and its allies intercepted.

headline: With Iran’s Strikes, Arab Countries Fear an Expanding Conflict
abstract: The Iranian attack on Israeli territory made the Middle East’s new reality undeniable: Clashes are getting harder and harder to contain.
lead_paragraph: Arab countries, from the United Arab Emirates and Oman to Jordan and Egypt, have tried for months to tamp down the conflict between Israel and Hamas, especially after it widened to include armed groups backed by Iran and embedded deep within the Arab world. Some of them, like the Houthis, threaten Arab governments as well.

headline: Word of the Day: foolhardy
abstract: This word has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word foolhardy has appeared in 26 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 31 in the book review “All That Glitters: A Fresh Look at the California Gold Rush” by W. M. Akers:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: What to Know About Jury Selection in Trump’s Manhattan Criminal Case
abstract: As Donald J. Trump’s prosecution begins, lawyers must winnow a pool of hundreds to 12 jurors who will decide his fate.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Prosecutors’ Error Exposes Potential Scope of Disgraced Detective’s Harm
abstract: The Brooklyn district attorney’s office didn’t mean to send opposing lawyers an unredacted file about Louis Scarcella, a former N.Y.P.D. detective whose overturned cases have cost New York millions.
lead_paragraph: In court papers they are called the “Scarcella Lists” — compilations of cases involving a retired New York City homicide detective whose problematic work on homicides in the 1980s and 1990s was cited in numerous wrongful convictions that have cost the city and state millions.

headline: Roses Are Red, Love Is True. Here’s Why This Bouquet Costs $72.
abstract: A dozen red roses is timeless. But its price tag is not. At Ditmars Flower Shop in Queens, where costs have soared in recent years, a bouquet is $72, up from $60 in 2019.
lead_paragraph: To gather every last stem and ribbon, Mr. Patrikis is on the phone constantly, negotiating with 15 distributors to get the best deals.

abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 309
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Who Are Key Players in the Trump Manhattan Criminal Trial?
abstract: The first criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump is underway. Take a closer look at central figures related to the case.
lead_paragraph: The first criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump is underway. Take a closer look at central figures related to the case.

headline: Here are the latest developments.
abstract: Israel’s war cabinet met again on Monday as it faced growing international pressure not to retaliate against Iran for its missile and drone attack over the weekend, even as some far-right members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government called for an aggressive response.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s war cabinet met again on Monday as it faced growing international pressure not to retaliate against Iran for its missile and drone attack over the weekend, even as some far-right members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government called for an aggressive response.

headline: 2 Police Officers Are Killed in Shootout Near Syracuse, New York
abstract: A suspect fired at the officers on Sunday evening as they investigated a stolen vehicle in the upstate town of Salina, the authorities said. The suspect died in the shootout.
lead_paragraph: Two police officers, who had been following up on a traffic violation, were killed in a shooting ambush on Sunday evening outside a house in an upstate New York town near Syracuse, the authorities said.

headline: Three Daughters, Three New Memoirs About Mothers
abstract: Genevieve Kingston, Susan Lieu and Kao Kalia Yang explore the complicated lives of the women who raised them.
lead_paragraph: Mothers rarely reveal themselves fully to their growing children. Who would it serve, after all, to pull back the curtain on the woman-in-charge and reveal a fumbling human? Like the Wizard of Oz, moms don’t always know how things work, but let’s not scare the kids.

headline: The Sex Lives and War Deaths of Soldier Poets
abstract: In “Muse of Fire,” Michael Korda depicts the lives and passions of the soldier poets whose verse provided a view into the carnage of World War I.
lead_paragraph: It is chillingly plain that the young, fashionable English poet Rupert Brooke had romanticized the great bloodletting that was about to happen. “Come and die,” he wrote to a friend in 1915, during the first winter of World War I. “It will be great fun.”

headline: Why Better Times (and Big Raises) Haven’t Cured the Inflation Hangover
abstract: Frustrated by higher prices, many Pennsylvanians with fresh pay raises and solid finances report a sense of insecurity lingering from the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: In western Pennsylvania, halfway through one of those classic hazy March days when the worst of winter has passed, but the bare trees tilting in the wind tell everyone spring is yet to come, Darren Mattern was putting in some extra work.

headline: Beyond Pizza and Yale: What to See, Eat and Do in New Haven
abstract: Though the academic scene continues to imbue this coastal Connecticut city with a certain gravitas, surrounding neighborhoods are showing off their own cultural capital in the realms of art, food, music and more.
lead_paragraph: The 75-foot-long brontosaurus at the newly reopened Yale Peabody Museum in New Haven, Conn., is the same dinosaur that the natural history museum has had on display since 1931. Yet it looks different. A fresh pose. New front ribs. The head is repositioned at a more inquisitive angle. The museum’s four-year renovation not only refreshed the nearly 100-year-old building, but also included an overhaul of the fossil mounts that research has proved to be inaccurate.

headline: The U.S. Has Received a Rare Invitation From China. There Is Only One Right Answer.
abstract: Should the U.S. forswear launching nukes first in combat?
lead_paragraph: In the middle of the last century, as the United States and Russia rapidly amassed thousands of nuclear weapons, China stayed out of the arms race, focusing its energy on growing its economy and broadening its regional influence.

headline: What Elective Do You Wish Your School Offered?
abstract: A program at a high school in Missouri teaches students how to bring food from the farm to the table. What nontraditional classes would you like to take?
lead_paragraph: Does your school offer elective classes? Have you taken any? If so, which have been your favorite? Why?
