abstract: The relatively limited scope of the attack, as well as a muted response from Iranian officials, may have lowered the chances of an immediate escalation, analysts said.
lead_paragraph: The relatively limited scope of Israel’s overnight strikes on Iran, and a subdued response from Iranian officials, may have lowered the chances of an immediate escalation in fighting between the two countries, analysts said on Friday.

headline: A Union Vote at Volkswagen Is a Big Test for Organized Labor
abstract: If workers at a plant in Tennessee agree to unionize, it would reflect the growing power of groups like the U.A.W. at a crucial political moment.
lead_paragraph: After a “summer of strikes” last year that stretched from Detroit to Hollywood, unions are on a roll, flexing their growing might. Friday will bring a new test of that power as workers at a Volkswagen factory in Tennessee vote on whether to join the United Automobile Workers.

headline: Zaslav Receives $50 Million for Leading Struggling Warner Bros. Discovery
abstract: The chief executive’s 2023 pay package rose 26 percent from the year before, while the company’s losses totaled $3 billion.
lead_paragraph: David Zaslav, the chief executive of Warner Bros. Discovery, received $49.7 million in compensation last year, a 26 percent increase from the previous year, according to a proxy statement filed on Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Inflation, Interest Rates and Oil Prices Have Jolted the Markets
abstract: Euphoria has been replaced by a much more somber mood, changing the value calculations in a host of markets, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: The markets are mercurial but their tone has thoroughly changed — from the sky-is-the-limit bullishness that dominated only a month ago to a mood of heightened uncertainty and measured self-restraint.

headline: How a New Reparations Effort Changed an Expert’s Understanding of History
abstract: Don Tamaki was integral to getting redress for Japanese Americans. He says serving on a California task force transformed his view on racism in America.
lead_paragraph: When California set up a reparations task force in 2020 to study the generational effects of slavery and other racist policies in the state and propose specific policy ideas for restitution, it was the first such statewide effort in the nation.

headline: Some Older Women Need Extra Breast Scans. Why Won’t Medicare Pay?
abstract: Mammography can miss tumors in women with dense breasts, so their doctors often include ultrasound or M.R.I. scans. Patients often wind up paying the bill.
lead_paragraph: Mammograms can miss tumors in women with dense breast tissue. So for these patients, doctors often include a second scan — ultrasound, for example, or an M.R.I. — which is more likely to turn up cancers at early stages.

headline: Thousands Are Eligible for Tax Refunds From 2020
abstract: The I.R.S. estimates that 940,000 people who didn’t file their returns for that year are due back money. The deadline for filing to get it is May 17.
lead_paragraph: Who wouldn’t grab an income tax refund if they had one coming?

headline: R.F.K. Jr.’s Environmental Colleagues Urge Him to Drop Presidential Bid
abstract: Nearly 50 leaders and activists who worked with Mr. Kennedy at an environmental nonprofit group will run ads calling on him to “Honor our planet, drop out.”
lead_paragraph: As an independent candidate for the White House, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. claims he would be the “best environment president in American history,” drawing on his past as a crusading lawyer who went after polluters in New York.

headline: E.P.A. Will Make Polluters Pay to Clean Up Two ‘Forever Chemicals’
abstract: The step follows an extraordinary move that requires utilities to reduce the levels of carcinogenic PFAS compounds in drinking water to near-zero.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is designating two “forever chemicals,” man-made compounds that are linked to serious health risks, as hazardous substances under the Superfund law, shifting responsibility for their cleanup to polluters from taxpayers.

headline: ‘It’s Clearly Bleak’: Stocks Notch Longest Losing Streak in Months
abstract: A rally at the start of the year has given way to worries on Wall Street about economics and geopolitics.
lead_paragraph: Stocks suffered their longest losing streak of the year, as geopolitical turmoil rattled Wall Street and investors slashed their bets on the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates any time soon.

headline: Tesla Will Recall Cybertruck in Latest Setback
abstract: A federal auto safety agency said the accelerator pedal on the pickup truck, sales of which began in late 2023, could become stuck, increasing the risk of accidents.
lead_paragraph: Tesla has agreed to recall nearly 4,000 of its Cybertruck pickups to fix an accelerator pedal that can get stuck, raising the risk of crashes, a federal safety agency said on Friday.

headline: Will Trump Go to Prison if He Is Convicted?
abstract: The former president faces dozens of felony charges stemming from hush-money payments to a porn star. He would undoubtedly appeal any conviction, and the presiding judge has leeway on sentencing.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Thomas Friedman on Iran, Israel and Preventing a ‘Forever War’
abstract: “It’s the worst story I’ve ever covered.”
lead_paragraph: The columnist Thomas L. Friedman joined the hosts of “Matter of Opinion” this week to unpack Israel’s and Iran’s latest attacks, what they mean for Gaza and the implications for the region writ large.

headline: Israel Has Used Exploding Drones in Previous Attacks on Iran
abstract: Iranian officials said that an attack Friday used small drones possibly launched from inside Iran, and that radar systems had not detected unidentified aircraft entering Iranian airspace.
lead_paragraph: Iranian officials said that the Israeli strike on Friday morning was carried out by small exploding drones, a tactic that would follow a well-established pattern in Israeli attacks on Iranian military targets.

headline: When It’s Time for an Aging Driver to Hit the Brakes
abstract: The “car key conversation” can be painful for families to navigate. Experts say there are ways to have it with empathy and care.
lead_paragraph: Sherrie Waugh has been yelled at, insulted and wept upon in the course of her job administering driving tests. Typically these extreme reactions happen when she is forced to render an upsetting verdict: It’s time to hang up the car keys.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Strange First Date Choice
abstract: 3 years later, a couple is still at odds about his move at the end of the night.
lead_paragraph: Joshua writes: Allie and I went on our first date three years ago. At dinner we were nervous, but the conversation flowed easily. Afterward, I suggested we walk down to the ocean. We explored tide pools as the sun set. Before parting, I told Allie to wait while I went back inside the restaurant to use the restroom. To this day, Allie thinks this was insane. I say I earned the right as a customer. Who’s right?

headline: Columbia University Arrests Student Pro-Palestinian Protesters
abstract: The police arrested more than 100 students demonstrators at a tent encampment set up on the campus of Columbia University in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested more than 100 students demonstrators at a tent encampment set up on the campus of Columbia University in New York City.

headline: Where to Buy Plants Online
abstract: We tested several options to find the best.
lead_paragraph: We tested several options to find the best.

headline: On ‘The Tortured Poets Department,’ Taylor Swift Could Use an Editor
abstract: Over 16 songs (and a second LP), the pop superstar litigates her recent romances. But the themes, and familiar sonic backdrops, generate diminishing returns.
lead_paragraph: If there has been a common thread — an invisible string, if you will — connecting the last few years of Taylor Swift’s output, it has been abundance.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include competing assassins, a mysterious hitchhiker, a stoic bricklayer and more.
lead_paragraph: Yuri (Joey Iwanaga) and Makoto (Tatsuomi Hamada) are silly but deadly cleanup men, who are so disregarded they’re often handed the messiest assignments: In the film’s opening scene, the two are tasked with annihilating a lone dealer. But they are not told about the goons accompanying their target. The mix-up leads to a jarring, chaotic, but rapturously executed shootout. Yuri and Makoto are tired of these dead-end gigs; they want to move up to the big time. With all the full-time assassin roles filled, they need to create an opening by murdering two employed killers. They just happen to be Chisato (Akari Takaishi) and Mahiro (Saori Izawa), the stars of the first “Baby Assassins” film, reprising their roles.

headline: Mental Health and Substance Use Disorders Often Go Untreated for Parents on Medicaid
abstract: Among those with substance use disorders who have been referred to child welfare, less than half received medication or counseling.
lead_paragraph: For parents struggling with mental health or substance use disorders, access to treatment can often mean the difference between keeping and losing their children. But a new analysis of health and child welfare records found that a significant portion of those who were eligible for Medicaid coverage for such treatment were not getting it.

headline: Bring on the Brisket
abstract: And the chicken with artichokes and lemon, the whole cauliflower roasted with pistachio pesto and the matzo ball soup.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Passover begins on Monday and, for those observing, Joan Nathan has given us her family recipe for brisket (above), which you could prepare on the day itself, but please don’t. It’s much better cooked this weekend and chilled in the refrigerator for a day or two so the flavors have time to set up — and so you can skim the excess fat from the top of the braise more easily.

headline: How Eight Feet Jolted A $180 Million Real Estate Deal
abstract: A landowner named Hezekiah Beers Pierrepont started selling plots of his Brooklyn land in the 1820s restricted by eight-foot setbacks still in effect today, rankling modern developers.
lead_paragraph: A landowner named Hezekiah Beers Pierrepont started selling plots of his Brooklyn land in the 1820s restricted by eight-foot setbacks still in effect today, rankling modern developers.

headline: Shadow War Between Iran and Israel: A Timeline
abstract: A recent round of strikes has brought the conflict more clearly into the open and raised fears of a broader war.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Israel and Iran have fought a shadow war across the Middle East, trading attacks by land, sea, air and in cyberspace. A recent round of strikes — mainly an aerial barrage by Iran against Israel last weekend — has brought the conflict more clearly into the open and raised fears of a broader war.

headline: Outside Court, Trump is the Center of Attention. Inside, He Has a Rival.
abstract: Fame creates its own gravity and Donald J. Trump is usually the center of it. But in his courtroom, Justice Juan M. Merchan also has pull.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere in our universe, a basic physical law applies: the greater the mass of an object, the stronger its gravitational field.

headline: Why Don’t More People Resent Manchester City?
abstract: Out of the Champions League but on top of the Premier League, Manchester City shows that it takes more than trophies to make a villain.
lead_paragraph: Silence swept from one end of the Etihad Stadium to the other, a wave of dawning realization. The background noise that a crowd cannot help but generate — the rumble and murmur of 20,000 separate conversations — fell away. Calculations were made. Conclusions were drawn.

headline: Ukraine Aid Bill Clears Critical Hurdle in the House as Democrats Supply the Votes
abstract: Democrats stepped in to support bringing the aid package to the floor, in a remarkable breach of custom on a key vote that paved the way for its passage.
lead_paragraph: The House took a critical step on Friday toward approving a long-stalled package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and other American allies, as Democrats supplied the crucial votes to push the legislation past Republican opposition so that it could be considered on the floor.

headline: What to Know About China’s Export Dominance
abstract: From cars to solar panels to furniture, China is using lavish bank lending and enormous investments in robotics to cement its global leadership in manufacturing.
lead_paragraph: China’s car shipments to foreign markets have quintupled in the past four years. Its solar panels dominate global markets. Even exports in labor-intensive industries like furniture making, which China was once expected to lose to lower-wage countries, are surging.

headline: Chinese Export Surge Clouds U.S. Hopes of a Domestic Solar Boom
abstract: The decision by a Massachusetts solar company to abandon plans to build a $1.4 billion U.S. factory highlights the risks amid a flood of Chinese clean energy exports.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year ago, CubicPV, which manufactures components for solar panels, announced that it had secured more than $100 million in financing to build a $1.4 billion factory in the United States. The company planned to produce silicon wafers, a critical part of the technology that allows solar panels to turn sunlight into electrical energy.

headline: Beverly LaHaye, Soldier of the Christian Right, Dies at 94
abstract: A pastor’s wife, she formed Concerned Women for America to oppose the Equal Rights Amendment. Ronald Reagan called her “one of the powerhouses on the political scene.”
lead_paragraph: Beverly LaHaye, a pastor’s wife whose recoil from 1970s feminism led her to build an organization advancing conservative views of the family, Concerned Women for America, which became a pillar of the Christian right, waging battles against abortion, gay rights and the Equal Rights Amendment, died on Sunday in hospice in El Cajon, Calif., near San Diego. She was 94.

headline: Review: Thomas Adès Meets the Profound Beauty of Schubert
abstract: The Danish String Quartet returned to Carnegie Hall with its Doppelgänger project, pairing Schubert’s String Quintet and a premiere by Adès.
lead_paragraph: Franz Schubert and Thomas Adès are two composers whose works are capable of touching the cosmos — in different centuries, and often in different ways.

headline: The Big Number: $76,535
abstract: A look at why Caitlin Clark, the star women's basketball player, will be paid so little as a player for the Indiana Fever.
lead_paragraph: A look at why Caitlin Clark, the star women's basketball player, will be paid so little as a player for the Indiana Fever.

headline: Behind the Scenes of the 2024 Venice Biennale
abstract: The Venice Biennale, a historic and influential exhibition, is underway this week, showcasing works from hundreds of artists in an attempt to track the direction of where art is going. Jason Farago, a critic at large for The New York Times, disentangles the complex relationship between art and politics in a time when governments are meddling more in culture, and ultra-rich collectors have their own strong views.
lead_paragraph: The Venice Biennale, a historic and influential exhibition, is underway this week, showcasing works from hundreds of artists in an attempt to track the direction of where art is going. Jason Farago, a critic at large for The New York Times, disentangles the complex relationship between art and politics in a time when governments are meddling more in culture, and ultra-rich collectors have their own strong views.

headline: The Vatican Transforms a Prison Into a Gallery
abstract: For its offering at this year’s Venice Biennale, the Holy See chose an unusual venue: the Giudecca women’s prison.
lead_paragraph: An early version of “Dovecote,” a short, nearly wordless film directed by Marco Perego for exhibition at the Biennale, has a scene that tracks a man in uniform as he drives a motorboat through a morning in Venice. The city is showing off its glories, with palazzos and domed churches reflected in the canals, a blue sky above. The film shifts to black and white as the action moves inside a building less adorned than the ones the man has boated past, but grand, even so. It’s his workplace, the Giudecca women’s prison.

headline: The Ingredient Your Chocolate Chip Cookies Are Missing
abstract: Rich piloncillo, used in place of brown sugar, adds unparalleled depth to baked goods and even savory dishes.
lead_paragraph: Eleven years ago, La Rifa Chocolatería in Mexico City introduced a dizzyingly dark, dense chocolate and cream tamal to its menu. Run through with the sultry flavors of caramel, butterscotch and molasses, the dish would quickly become one of its most popular to date.

headline: Ukrainians Wait, Nervously, to See if U.S. Will Provide Critical Aid
abstract: From the battlefield to battered cities, soldiers and civilians are counting on Congress to approve $60 billion in military support. Without it, Ukrainian officials say, prospects in the war are grim.
lead_paragraph: From the bloody trenches of the battlefield to crowded cities battered by Russian bombardments, millions of Ukrainians waited in nervous anticipation as the United States Congress prepared, after months of delay, to decide if America will resume providing their country with critical military support.

headline: Watch the Lyrid Meteor Shower Reach Its Peak
abstract: A nearly full moon could interfere with the shower during its peak. It is forecast to be active until near the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: Our universe might be chock-full of cosmic wonder, but you can only observe a fraction of astronomical phenomena with your naked eye. Meteor showers, natural fireworks that streak brightly across the night sky, are one of them.

headline: A Brief Guide to Who’s Who on Taylor Swift’s ‘Tortured Poets’
abstract: Ex-boyfriends may be alluded to. Travis Kelce, too, fans believe. And some actual poets.
lead_paragraph: When Taylor Swift released “The Tortured Poets Department,” on Friday at midnight, her fan base quickly got to work decoding the album, looking for layers of meaning and insight into Ms. Swift’s life. Of course, that includes the pop singer’s romantic history.

headline: A Photographer in Search of Forgotten Burial Sites
abstract: An African American burial ground project in South Carolina is just one subject in Caroline Gutman’s search for a history hiding in plain sight.
lead_paragraph: I first heard about the unmarked African American burial sites in Charleston, S.C., in November 2021, while visiting the city to research an entirely different topic: I was there to photograph the legacy of indigo in the United States and its role in slavery.

headline: Campus Turmoil: The Gaza Protests at Columbia
abstract: Readers discuss the arrests of demonstrators and the university president’s congressional testimony. Also: The Israel-Iran airstrikes; the Mayorkas impeachment.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Taylor Swift and Post Malone’s Regretful Duet, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Arooj Aftab, Cigarettes After Sex, Claire Rousay and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Columbia, Free Speech and the Coddling of the American Right
abstract: If Columbia can’t protect free speech, what hope is there for America’s institutions?
lead_paragraph: ​​​​As a journalist, you usually go to the front line to find the news. But sometimes the front line finds you. This happened to me not once but twice on Thursday, as an epic battle over freedom of expression on college campuses unfolded from one end of Manhattan to another.

headline: This G.O.P. Senate Candidate Says He Grew Up on a Family Farm. Not Exactly.
abstract: David McCormick has often spoken about his modest upbringing on a farm in Pennsylvania. A close look at his past tells a different story.
lead_paragraph: David McCormick’s origin story goes something like this: He grew up in rural Pennsylvania, southwest of Scranton. He baled hay, trimmed Christmas trees and otherwise worked on his family’s farm. And from those humble beginnings, he rose to achieve the American dream.

headline: To Fight ‘Shrinkflation,’ France Will Force Retailers to Warn Shoppers
abstract: Merchants will be required to put signs in front of all products that have been reduced in size without a corresponding price cut.
lead_paragraph: For months, the shelves of Carrefour, France’s biggest supermarket chain, have been dotted with bright orange signs placed in front of Pepsi bottles, Lays potato chips and a variety of other foods whose packages are suspiciously smaller than they used to be.

headline: 4 Disqualified from Beijing Race After 3 Let Chinese Runner Pass
abstract: A strange finish at the Beijing Half Marathon on Sunday led to an investigation and penalties.
lead_paragraph: The top finishers in the Beijing Half Marathon have been disqualified after three runners from Africa appeared to step aside to let a Chinese competitor win the race on Sunday.

headline: Voice of America Will Get a New Director
abstract: Michael Abramowitz, a former Washington Post journalist who is currently the president of the nonprofit Freedom House, is expected to start in the role this summer.
lead_paragraph: Michael Abramowitz will be the next director of the federally funded broadcaster Voice of America, its parent, the U.S. Agency for Global Media, announced on Friday.

headline: Is the Internet the Enemy of Progress?
abstract: Revisiting Michael Crichton’s prophecy of cultural stagnation.
lead_paragraph: It’s unusual when you find a strong dose of pessimism about the future of technological progress highlighted by one of the world’s leading techno-optimists. But if you follow the combative venture capitalist Marc Andreessen on X, you would have seen him giving wide circulation to this passage from Michael Crichton’s 1995 “Jurassic Park” sequel “The Lost World,” in which Crichton’s ever-prescient Dr. Ian Malcolm warns that the internet will put an end to human progress:

headline: Mandisa Hundley, Gospel Singer Seen on ‘American Idol,’ Dies at 47
abstract: Her Christian-themed music made her a fan favorite on ‘Idol’ and won her a Grammy Award in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Mandisa Hundley, a gospel singer whose strong vocals were applauded on “American Idol” and who later won a Grammy Award for best contemporary Christian music album, was found dead at her home in Nashville on Thursday. She was 47.

headline: Menendez Corruption Trial Delayed for One Week
abstract: The senator’s trial will start May 13, a week later than planned, to give defense lawyers more time to prepare.
lead_paragraph: The corruption trial of Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey was pushed back a week on Friday to May 13, after defense lawyers said they needed more time to review voluminous exhibits and witness statements that prosecutors were only now turning over to them.

headline: Faculty Group at Columbia Says It Has ‘Lost Confidence’ in the President
abstract: The campus chapter of a faculty organization said it would “fight to reclaim our university.” Students were undeterred by the crackdown on their protest.
lead_paragraph: Scores of student protesters at Columbia University gathered outside on Friday, just across from where their tent encampment had been demolished by university officials the day before. Some students had been there through the night. Others, including a few who had been arrested Thursday, had only recently arrived.

headline: Man Sets Himself on Fire Near Courthouse Where Trump Is on Trial
abstract: Onlookers screamed as fire engulfed the man, who had thrown pamphlets in the air before he set himself aflame. He was taken to a hospital and died hours later.
lead_paragraph: A man set himself on fire on Friday afternoon near the Lower Manhattan courthouse where jurors were being chosen for the criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: What We Know About Columbia University’s President, Nemat Shafik
abstract: Dr. Shafik, who also goes by Minouche, is facing criticism from multiple sides over how she is handling protests over the war in Gaza on her campus.
lead_paragraph: The president of Columbia University, Nemat Shafik, is grappling with the fallout over her handling of student protests against the war in Gaza.

headline: 7 Songs That Reference Tortured Poets
abstract: Taylor Swift said she channeled them; Patti Smith, Lana Del Rey, the Smiths and others cited them.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps you have heard that Taylor Swift has a new album out today — just a wild guess! — and that it is called “The Tortured Poets Department.” That title alone generated chatter before anyone had heard a note, and it got me thinking about some of my favorite songs that reference poets. And so I filled my inkwell, put a quill pen to my chin and cried, “A playlist is in order!”

headline: Lawmaker Accused of Forging Voters’ Names Resigns From Turning Point Action
abstract: Austin Smith, a Republican in the Arizona House, also withdrew from his re-election bid on Thursday as his candidate petitions drew scrutiny in a constituent’s court complaint.
lead_paragraph: A senior director for the pro-Trump group Turning Point Action resigned from his post on Thursday and abruptly withdrew his re-election bid in Arizona, three days after being accused in a court complaint of forging voters’ signatures.

headline: Scotland Made Big Climate Pledges. Now They’re ‘Out of Reach.’
abstract: Despite significant progress, Scotland was falling short on cutting vehicle emissions, switching to heat pumps and even restoring peatland, the government said.
lead_paragraph: Climate promises are hard to keep. Scotland is the latest, perhaps most surprising example.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, there was one topic top of mind for the hosts, and one topic only: the start of former President Trump’s criminal hush-money trial in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: This week, there was one topic top of mind for the hosts, and one topic only: the start of former President Trump’s criminal hush-money trial in Manhattan.

headline: What Would the Economy Look Like Under a Second Trump Term?
abstract: Much would depend on Congress and the cabinet, but financial forecasters aren’t optimistic.
lead_paragraph: Speculating about how the economy would perform under a second Donald Trump presidency normalizes the candidacy of a deeply flawed human being. But we’ll all have to live in Trump’s world if he’s elected. So it seems important to talk about the economic outlook under another Trump term.

headline: Like Moths to a Flame? We May Need a New Phrase.
abstract: Over time researchers have found fewer of the insects turning up in light traps, suggesting they may be less attracted to some kinds of light than they once were.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that you could put a black light at the edge of a cornfield at night and expect a bountiful harvest of moths the next morning. For entomologists, such light traps have provided an invaluable record of moth numbers. But in recent decades, light traps have shown dwindling catches of insects of all kinds. Some have interpreted these empty traps as evidence of a documented decline in insect numbers around the world.

headline: Prosecutors Want to Ask Trump About Attacks on Women
abstract: Prosecutors are seeking to cross-examine the former president, should he take the stand, about lawsuits he has lost, including a civil jury’s finding last year that he was liable for sexually abusing the writer E. Jean Carroll.
lead_paragraph: If Donald J. Trump takes the stand at his criminal trial in Manhattan, prosecutors want to cross-examine him about recent lawsuits he’s lost, attacks he’s made on women and a judge’s opinion that his sworn statements in a civil case rang “hollow and untrue.”

headline: Mariinsky Dancers Barred From Youth Ballet Gala in New York
abstract: Two dancers from the Russian company were set to perform at a benefit for a prestigious competition for young dancers, but they were sidelined after protests by pro-Ukrainian activists.
lead_paragraph: Two dancers from the Mariinsky Theater in Russia were barred from performing at a youth ballet gala in New York this week after their participation drew criticism from pro-Ukrainian officials and activists.

headline: Start-Up Founder Sentenced to 18 Months in Prison for Fraud
abstract: Manish Lachwani, who founded the software start-up HeadSpin, is the latest tech entrepreneur to face time in prison in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Another start-up founder is going to prison for overstating his company’s performance to investors.

headline: Greece Announces New Plan to Protect Some of Its Pristine Beaches
abstract: The government has pledged to crack down on rapid development, and on seaside businesses seeking to take advantage of a tourist boom. But some residents and conservationists are unimpressed.
lead_paragraph: The Greek government on Friday published a list of 198 “untrodden beaches” that it said are now off limits to bars, restaurants and large public gatherings in its latest attempt to contain development and address the backlash to the throngs of tourists that descend on the country’s coastlines each year.

headline: Harvard’s Taylor Swift Scholars Have Thoughts on ‘Tortured Poets’
abstract: The students taking Harvard University’s class on the singer are studying up. Their final papers are due at the end of the month.
lead_paragraph: Fans of Taylor Swift often study up for a new album, revisiting the singer’s older works to prepare to analyze lyrics and song titles for secret messages and meanings.

headline: Neo-Nazi Who Threatened Journalist With Death Is Sentenced to Prison
abstract: Nicholas Welker admitted posting the death threat, which was meant to silence coverage of the extremist group he led, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The leader of a white supremacist group who admitted posting an online death threat targeting a Brooklyn journalist in a bid to silence coverage of the group was sentenced to around three and a half years in prison on Friday, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Frederick Celani, Who Made a Career as a Con Man, Dies at 75
abstract: His serial frauds included a waterfront development in Buffalo, a civil rights law firm in California and a package delivery company in Springfield, Ill.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Celani was more than a decade into a rollicking, relentless career as a con man when he bamboozled city officials and employees in Springfield, Ill., into believing that he would make the city the hub of an overnight package delivery service.

headline: I’m Pregnant, and My Husband Says We Can’t Tell Anyone About the Donor Egg
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to honor a spouse’s seemingly irrational request about privacy and assisted reproduction.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are thrilled to be welcoming our first child this spring, after an arduous I.V.F. journey lasting nearly two years. We ended up needing an anonymous egg donor, whom we found through an egg bank, to conceive our child.

headline: In Trump Trial, Old Social Posts Haunt the Proceedings
abstract: Over the past week, some potential jurors who were confronted with their old posts seemed sheepish, if not outright embarrassed.
lead_paragraph: “Are these your posts?” the judge asked.

headline: Israel Launched Missiles as Well as Drones at Iran, Officials Say
abstract: Though it was not immediately clear if the missiles struck targets inside Iran, their use would mean more sophisticated firepower was involved in the attack than first reported.
lead_paragraph: Israeli warplanes fired missiles on Iran during a retaliatory strike early Friday morning, one Western official and two Iranian officials said, suggesting that the attack included more advanced firepower than initial reports indicated.

headline: Daniel C. Dennett, Widely Read and Fiercely Debated Philosopher, 82, Dies
abstract: Espousing his ideas in best sellers, he insisted that religion was an illusion, free will was a fantasy and evolution could only be explained by natural selection.
lead_paragraph: Daniel C. Dennett, one of the most widely read and debated American philosophers, whose prolific works explored consciousness, free will, religion and evolutionary biology, died on Friday in Portland, Maine. He was 82.

headline: Rough Seas for Blinken and Co. as Israel, Iran and Ukraine Cloud G7 Meeting
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and his counterparts, who met on the Italian island of Capri, welcomed signs that tensions between Iran and Israel might not worsen.
lead_paragraph: Rough seas were a fitting symbol for this week’s meeting of Group of 7 foreign ministers on the Italian island of Capri. Coast Guard ships that ferried V.I.P.s across the Gulf of Naples to the island on Wednesday swayed precariously, leaving the passengers reaching for their motion-sickness medicine — and, in some cases, their sick bags.

headline: Final Members of Trump Jury Chosen as Trial Races Ahead
abstract: Just after the last selections of alternate jurors were made, a man set himself on fire outside the courthouse, horrifying onlookers. But the case was not delayed.
lead_paragraph: The final jurors for Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial were selected on Friday, with lawyers preparing to offer opening statements on Monday in a landmark proceeding that was suddenly overshadowed at midday by the spectacle of a man setting himself aflame outside the courthouse.

headline: F.A.A. Will Require More Rest for Air Traffic Controllers
abstract: The agency announced new rules to address the dangers of exhaustion for controllers, who often work grueling round-the-clock schedules.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Friday that it was taking significant steps to mitigate the risks posed by exhaustion among air traffic controllers, after a series of close calls last year raised alarms about the safety of the U.S. air travel system.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, April 20, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Arrests of Europeans for Aiding Russia Raise Fears of Kremlin’s Reach
abstract: A string of arrests, including two Poles accused of attacking a Navalny aide and a third for ties to a possible plot against Ukraine’s president, have amplified worries of Russian infiltration.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Poland and Germany have arrested at least five of their citizens in recent days and accused them of spying for Russia or of offering to help Moscow commit violence on European soil, including a “possible attack” on the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky.

headline: Good Luck Getting Your Hands on Buldak Carbonara Ramen
abstract: With its bright pink packaging and spicy contents, these Korean-made instant ramen packs are going viral online and flying off shelves.
lead_paragraph: What kind of gift could make a little girl cry tears of joy at her very pink birthday party? A puppy? A Stanley cup? A ticket to Disney World?

headline: The 10 Best Things We Saw at Salone del Mobile
abstract: From an exhibition in a 1940s-era Modernist house to a blood-red sofa, the highlights of Milan’s annual design fair.
lead_paragraph: The annual Salone del Mobile furniture fair has always been big — it’s the event of the year for the international design world, drawing hundreds of thousands of makers, curators, editors and buyers to Milan each April for a week’s worth of inspiration, shop talk and aperitivi. Even more so than fashion week, the fair consumes the city. But this year’s edition seemed to buzz with a new level of excitement, with more people from outside the design industry joining the throngs and hourlong lines forming outside events like the launch of the French luxury brand Hermès’s interiors collection, the annual installation by the Milanese architecture firm Dimorestudio and the satellite fair Alcova’s takeover of the Modernist architect Osvaldo Borsani’s former home — this despite the house being a 45-minute drive north of the city center. Luckily, there were so many interesting presentations on view that braving the crowds felt well worth it. Here, 10 standouts.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Malala Yousafzai Toast Their New Broadway Show
abstract: Dozens of theater, film and media stars turned out on Thursday night for the opening of “Suffs,” a new musical about women’s suffrage.
lead_paragraph: “This is thrilling,” Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, said on a chilly Thursday night outside the Music Box Theater on 45th Street, as women in strapless gowns walked a purple carpet.

headline: The House Is Set to Approve Ukraine Aid This Weekend
abstract: Also, the Israeli military struck Iran. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The House took a critical step today toward approving a long-stalled package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and other American allies. A majority of Democratic and Republicans lawmakers voted to advance the bills past a procedural hurdle, setting up the legislation to pass the House tomorrow.

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Raises New Uncertainty for Biden in Michigan
abstract: Mr. Kennedy’s success in landing on the battleground state’s ballot guarantees that he will shape the race this November. Both parties are racing to define him.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. threatening to upend the presidential race went from an idea to a reality in one of the country’s most consequential battlegrounds on Thursday, when Mr. Kennedy qualified for the ballot in Michigan.

headline: Denny Walsh, Reporter Who Tussled With Mayors and Editors, Dies at 88
abstract: He won a Pulitzer Prize for investigative reporting in 1969 and later joined The New York Times, which eventually fired him.
lead_paragraph: Denny Walsh, a Pulitzer Prize-winning investigative reporter who was a consummate nuisance to mobsters, corrupt politicians and his editors — especially at The New York Times, which fired him — died on March 29 at his home in Antelope, Calif., a suburb of Sacramento. He was 88.

headline: William F. Pepper, 86, Dies; Claimed the Government Killed Dr. King
abstract: He represented James Earl Ray and the King family in efforts to prove that Dr. King was the victim of a conspiracy, becoming a celebrity among the conspiracy-minded.
lead_paragraph: William F. Pepper, who was the central figure in a decades-long effort to prove that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther Jr. was killed not by a lone gunman but by a vast government plot, a controversial stance that made him something of a celebrity among the country’s teeming subculture of conspiracy theorists, died on April 7 in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Liberal Democrats Urge ‘No’ Vote on Israel Aid to Pressure Biden on Gaza
abstract: Progressives in the House who oppose unfettered military aid to Israel are pressing their colleagues to vote against the $26 billion bill, which is likely to pass, to send a message to President Biden.
lead_paragraph: A group of left-leaning House Democrats is urging its colleagues to oppose the $26 billion aid package for Israel, hoping to maximize the number of “no” votes from the party and send a warning to President Biden about the depth of his political coalition’s discontent over his support for Israel’s tactics in Gaza.

headline: The Ex-Bernie Sanders Pollster Raising Alarms About R.F.K. Jr.’s Appeal Among Latinos and Young Voters
abstract: A Democrat warns that the independent could siphon crucial support from Biden.
lead_paragraph: Happy Friday! Today, we’re looking at younger voters and other demographic groups who are generally crucial for Democratic victories in presidential elections — but who may back other candidates or sit out this year’s election in greater numbers than usual. I’ve asked my colleague Shane Goldmacher to kick things off. — Jess Bidgood

headline: As Press Reports Some Juror Details, Polarized Reactions Take Over
abstract: Journalists covering the trial face a tricky balancing act: inform the public while keeping its participants out of harm’s way.
lead_paragraph: Opening arguments in former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial will not start until next week, but media coverage of the proceedings has already been met with partisan furor.

headline: Where Jurors in Trump Hush-Money Trial Say They Get Their News
abstract: Prosecutors and defense lawyers tried to divine the political leanings of prospective jurors in the former president’s Manhattan criminal trial from their answers to questions about what media they consume.
lead_paragraph: The 18 New Yorkers selected to serve as jurors and alternates in the Manhattan criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump this week were each asked the same series of 42 questions, from which lawyers hoped to divine how prospective jurors might feel about the case.

headline: Day 4 of Trump’s Criminal Trial: Five Takeaways
abstract: A full jury is seated, a horrifying incident shocks the court and opening statements are set to begin on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The first week of the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump ended with a disturbing jolt: a 37-year-old man set himself on fire outside the courthouse, an event that overshadowed the legal proceedings inside.

headline: Israel’s Strike on Iran: A Limited Attack but a Potentially Big Signal
abstract: Israel hit a strategic city with carefully measured force, but made the point that it could strike at a center of Iran’s nuclear program.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Israel has rehearsed, time and again, bombing and missile campaigns that would take out Iran’s nuclear production capability, much of it based around the city of Isfahan and the Natanz nuclear enrichment complex 75 miles to the north.

headline: Saddling Up and Feeling Spry at Martha Graham
abstract: Under the banner “American Legacies,” the Martha Graham Dance Company dusted off a classic, “Rodeo,” premiered a companion piece and welcomed FKA twigs for a guest solo at City Center.
lead_paragraph: The Martha Graham Dance Company won’t turn 100 until 2026, but evidently it’s not too early to start celebrating. The company is commemorating the milestone with not one, but three New York seasons, the first of which opened on Wednesday at New York City Center.

headline: Scientists Fault Federal Response to Bird Flu Outbreaks on Dairy Farms
abstract: Officials have shared little information, saying the outbreak was limited. But asymptomatic cows in North Carolina have changed the assessment.
lead_paragraph: In the month since federal authorities announced an outbreak of bird flu on dairy farms, they have repeatedly reassured the public that the spate of infections does not impact the nation’s food or milk supply, and poses little risk to the public.

headline: U.S. Military to Withdraw Troops From Niger
abstract: The status of a $110 million air base in the desert remains unclear as the West African country deepens its ties with Russia.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,000 American military personnel will leave Niger in the coming months, Biden administration officials said on Friday, upending U.S. counterterrorism and security policy in the tumultuous Sahel region of Africa.

headline: U.S.C. Cut the Valedictorian’s Graduation Speech. Now, the Celebrities Are Out, Too.
abstract: Jon M. Chu, the director of “Crazy Rich Asians,” and Billie Jean King were set to be among the featured guests.
lead_paragraph: The University of Southern California, reeling after a controversy over its valedictorian selection, announced Friday that its main commencement program would eliminate outside speakers and honorees, including the director of “Crazy Rich Asians,” Jon M. Chu, and the tennis star Billie Jean King.

headline: Ex-Police Officer Pleads Guilty to Murder in Shooting of 12-Year-Old Boy
abstract: Edsaul Mendoza, a former Philadelphia police officer, could face up to 40 years in prison after pleading guilty to third-degree murder.
lead_paragraph: A former Philadelphia police officer pleaded guilty on Friday to third-degree murder in the shooting of a fleeing 12-year-old boy in 2022, according to the Philadelphia District Attorney’s Office.

headline: Explosion Damages Iraqi Base Used by Iran-backed Group
abstract: It was unclear who carried out the attack in Babylon Province, south of Baghdad.
lead_paragraph: Iraq’s joint military command says one person was killed and eight were injured in an explosion early Saturday at a base used by an Iranian-backed armed group, Harakat al Nujaba, in Iraq’s Babylon Province.

headline: Taylor Swift’s New Album Reviewed
abstract: Our pop music critic on “The Tortured Poets Department.”
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Taylor Swift released her 11th studio album, “The Tortured Poets Department.” Two hours after the initial release at midnight, she announced a second volume of the album, bringing the number of new songs to 31.

headline: Israel Strikes an Iranian Military Base, but Damage Appears Limited
abstract: The drone attack may have been launched from inside Iran, once again demonstrating Israel’s ability to carry out clandestine operations there.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military struck Iran early on Friday in retaliation for an aerial attack on Israel last weekend, according to two Israeli and three Iranian officials, but the strike appeared to be limited in scope and the reaction from both Israel and Iran was muted.

headline: A Life Overtaken by Conspiracy Theories Explodes in Flames as the Public Looks On
abstract: Friends of Max Azzarello, who set himself on fire outside Donald J. Trump’s trial, said he was a caring person whose paranoia had led him down a dark path.
lead_paragraph: The journey that ended with a man setting himself on fire on Friday outside the Manhattan courthouse where Donald J. Trump was being tried seemed to have begun in Florida, with a series of increasingly bizarre outbursts.

headline: Sentimental Feelings
abstract: Garrett Chalfin and Andrew Kingsley’s puzzle is inviting without being too forward.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is neat; it’s Garret Chalfin and Andrew Kingsley’s third daily Times collaboration, after a Monday grid in January and a Tuesday puzzle in March. That’s a blistering pace and implies a level of closeness that I think I can sense in today’s clues. There’s a kind of riffing humor throughout. A single pun about mingling, say, spins off into other relevant jokes about love and marriage. There’s also a lot of interesting trivia and a meta touch, a clue that solved to the name of a type of wordplay that I like. This surprised me (which I also liked).

headline: VW Workers in Tennessee Vote for Union, a Labor Milestone
abstract: The Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga is set to become the first unionized auto factory in the South not owned by one of Detroit’s Big Three.
lead_paragraph: In a landmark victory for organized labor, workers at a Volkswagen plant in Tennessee have voted overwhelmingly to join the United Automobile Workers union, becoming the first nonunion auto plant in a Southern state to do so.

headline: ‘Stereophonic’ Review: Hitmakers Rendered in Sublime Detail
abstract: In David Adjmi’s new play, with songs by Will Butler, a ’70s band’s success breeds tension, and punches up the volume on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Peering behind the mystique of rock ’n’ roll has undeniable voyeuristic appeal. So there is an immediate thrill to seeing the mahogany-paneled control room and glassed-in sound booth that fill the Golden Theater stage, where “Stereophonic” opened on Friday. But David Adjmi’s astonishing new play, with songs by the former Arcade Fire member Will Butler, delivers more than a dishy glimpse inside the recording studio during rock’s golden age.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Being Friends May Manifest as Winning on the Court
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “We low-key hate each other, but we like each other.”

headline: It Introduced Ozempic to the World. Now It Must Remake Itself.
abstract: Novo Nordisk’s factories work nonstop turning out Ozempic and Wegovy, its blockbuster weight-loss drugs, but the Danish company has far bigger ambitions.
lead_paragraph: Lars Fruergaard Jorgensen has a problem: Too many people want what he’s selling.

headline: A Ragtag Resistance Sees the Tide Turning in a Forgotten War
abstract: Rebel fighters have handed Myanmar’s army defeat after defeat, for the first time raising the possibility that the military junta could be at risk of collapse.
lead_paragraph: The night Ma Suu Kyi thought she would die of her wounds on the front lines of a forgotten war, a crescent moon hung overhead. A pendant of the Virgin Mary dangled around her neck. Maybe those augurs saved her. Or maybe, she said, it was not yet time for her to die.

headline: How Ozempic Is Transforming a Small Danish Town
abstract: In Kalundborg, population under 17,000, Novo Nordisk is making huge investments to increase production of its popular diabetes and weight-loss drugs, Ozempic and Wegovy.
lead_paragraph: As the sun sets over the harbor in Kalundborg, a small town about 60 miles west of Copenhagen, light streams through the glass walls of Shaun Gamble’s cafe and bathes his afternoon customers in a warm glow. It’s an enviable location — on the water, next to a large playground — except for the fact that little else is nearby.

headline: A Turbocharged Croissant Delights (and Disturbs) Paris
abstract: Stéphane Louvard married one of his signature croissants with a chocolate chip cookie to come up with what he called the “crookie.” It took off after it became a TikTok phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: All it took for the pastry to take shape was a baker looking for a diversion, his time-tested croissant recipe and a few cookies for inspiration. It took TikTok to make it go viral.

headline: A Trip to the Front Lines of a Forgotten War
abstract: A new generation of democracy fighters has taken up arms in Myanmar. If they push into the nation’s heartland, the rebels could unseat a military that’s had the country in its grip for decades. Hannah Beech, a New York Times reporter, embedded with one of the rebel groups on the front lines in Karenni State, where resistance forces said they held more than 90 percent of the territory.
lead_paragraph: A new generation of democracy fighters has taken up arms in Myanmar. If they push into the nation’s heartland, the rebels could unseat a military that’s had the country in its grip for decades. Hannah Beech, a New York Times reporter, embedded with one of the rebel groups on the front lines in Karenni State, where resistance forces said they held more than 90 percent of the territory.

headline: Inside Novo Nordisk’s Headquarters
abstract: Ozempic and Wegovy, the diabetes and weight-loss drugs, have soared to celebrity status in the U.S. But Novo Nordisk, the Danish company behind them, can’t make enough of them. The New York Times reporter Eshe Nelson went to the drugmaker’s headquarters to see how the company is transforming to deal with the global fame and demand.
lead_paragraph: Ozempic and Wegovy, the diabetes and weight-loss drugs, have soared to celebrity status in the U.S. But Novo Nordisk, the Danish company behind them, can’t make enough of them. The New York Times reporter Eshe Nelson went to the drugmaker’s headquarters to see how the company is transforming to deal with the global fame and demand.

headline: Do Tanks Have a Place in 21st-Century Warfare?
abstract: As explosive drones gain battlefield prominence, even the mighty U.S. Abrams tank is increasingly vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: The drone combat in Ukraine that is transforming modern warfare has begun taking a deadly toll on one of the most powerful symbols of American military might — the tank — and threatening to rewrite how it will be used in future conflicts.

headline: Why Myanmar’s War Matters, Even if the World Isn’t Watching
abstract: A devastating, yearslong civil war is heating up, but it still hasn’t attracted broad international notice.
lead_paragraph: An escalating civil war threatens to break apart a country of roughly 55 million people that sits between China and India. That has international consequences, but the conflict hasn’t commanded wide attention.

headline: Time Is Running Out for Rahul Gandhi’s Vision for India
abstract: But in this year’s elections, the scion of India’s most storied political family is still trying to unseat Modi — and change the nation’s course.
lead_paragraph: Rahul Gandhi stood in a red Jeep, amid a churning crowd in Varanasi, trying to unseat the Indian government with a microphone in his hand. “The mic isn’t good,” he said. “Please quiet down and listen.” It was the morning of Feb. 17 — Day 35 of a journey that began in the hills of Manipur, in India’s northeast, and would end by the ocean in Mumbai, in mid-March. In total, Gandhi would cover 15 states and 4,100 miles, traveling across a country that once voted for his party, the Indian National Congress, almost by reflex. No longer, though. For a decade, the Congress Party has been so deep in the political wilderness, occupying fewer than a tenth of the seats in Parliament, that even its well-wishers wonder if Gandhi is merely the custodian of its end.

headline: What’s Happening In Myanmar’s Civil War?
abstract: Questions you may have about the ongoing war in Myanmar, explained with graphics.
lead_paragraph: Questions you may have about the ongoing war in Myanmar, explained with graphics.

headline: Senate Passes Two-Year Extension of Surveillance Law Just After It Expired
abstract: The law lapsed only briefly after a late-night deal that allowed votes on privacy advocates’ proposed changes, all of which were defeated.
lead_paragraph: The Senate early on Saturday approved an extension of a warrantless surveillance law, moving to renew it shortly after it had expired and sending President Biden legislation that national security officials say is crucial to fighting terrorism but that privacy advocates decry as a threat to Americans’ rights.

headline: Top Chinese Swimmers Tested Positive for Banned Drug, Then Won Olympic Gold
abstract: The case, involving multiple swimmers who seven months later won medals at the 2021 Games, prompted accusations of a cover-up and concerns over why antidoping regulators chose not to intervene.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three top Chinese swimmers tested positive for the same powerful banned substance seven months before the Tokyo Olympic Games in 2021 but were allowed to escape public scrutiny and continue to compete after top Chinese officials secretly cleared them of doping and the global authority charged with policing drugs in sports chose not to intervene.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How a Dating Show Host Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Stef Dag, host of “Hot & Single,” goes cafe-hopping with friends, boxes in the park and gets ready for a comedy set at The Stand.
lead_paragraph: Stef Dag, a 28-year-old comedian, is slightly cynical but also hopeful about finding love in New York.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 314
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: This Therapy Helps Victims of Violent Crime. Who Will Pay for It?
abstract: “Trauma recovery centers” are favored by law-and-order officials and progressive activists alike for one big reason: They work. But to stay open in New York, they need more funding.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, Randy White was shot in the stomach when he was caught in the crossfire of a gunfight at an Atlanta gas station. The injury kept him in the hospital for a week, but his mental state was paid little consideration. Discharged with no meaningful plan to deal with the psychological fallout that would inevitably come, he found himself adrift.

headline: Capturing the Celtics’ Tunnel Walk
abstract: Players from Boston’s team arrive at basketball’s most exclusive private runway.
lead_paragraph: Players from Boston’s team arrive at basketball’s most exclusive private runway.

headline: Capturing Special Moments, While Creating Inclusive Weddings
abstract: Shannon Collins, a “queer, awkward, anxious photographer,” wants to change the way disabled people are viewed, one picture at a time.
lead_paragraph: The last five years for Shannon Collins, a wedding photographer who identifies as nonbinary, have been filled with survival and self-discoveries, all while Mx. Collins, captured celebrants’ most intimate and revealing moments.

headline: The ‘Amityville’ Horrors Keep Coming
abstract: The famed “Amityville Horror” film has spawned at least 45 sequels. A look at why the Amityville name has endured in the horror genre.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to large film franchises, a few titans emerge: Godzilla, James Bond, Spider-Man.

headline: That Time Europe Tried to Bring Monarchy Back to Mexico
abstract: In “Habsburgs on the Rio Grande,” Raymond Jonas’s story of French-backed nation building in Mexico foreshadows the proxy battles of the Cold War.
lead_paragraph: In October 1863, a Mexican delegation arrived in Trieste, a polyglot city in southern Europe on the borderlands of the Hapsburg Empire. In a turreted castle on the Adriatic coast, the delegates — many of them Europhile bankers and industrialists — offered the crown of Mexico to Maximilian, a Hapsburg prince, and his wife, Charlotte, daughter of the king of Belgium.

headline: A Sugary Bonbon of a Novel From a Legendary Foodie
abstract: In “The Paris Novel,” Ruth Reichl is a glutton for wish fulfillment.
lead_paragraph: Stella St. Vincent’s estranged mother dies and leaves her with an unusual bequest: She is to take her modest inheritance and go to Paris.

headline: Alfred Molina on the Museum He Never Misses When He’s in New York
abstract: “Every time I’m in the city, I make a visit,” said the actor, who is performing on Broadway in “Uncle Vanya.”
lead_paragraph: After more than 30 years in Los Angeles, Alfred Molina is enjoying his newly minted status as an Upper West Sider.

headline: Distracted at the Tea Ceremony
abstract: It’s not easy to find serenity when memories come flooding in.
lead_paragraph: My fiancée, Meredith, and I were sitting crossed-legged on cushions around a low wooden table with the tea ceremonialist and two other young women. Now and then, a gray cat jumped onto our laps.

headline: Review: In ‘Still,’ Confessions Doom Two Reunited Lovers
abstract: Despite a juicy premise, this Colt Coeur production, starring Tim Daly and Jayne Atkinson, never manages to take off.
lead_paragraph: In her essay “The Carrier Bag Theory of Fiction,” the novelist Ursula K. Le Guin hymned the bag as the proper shape for stories: it “is full of beginnings without ends, of initiations, of losses, of transformations and translations, and far more tricks than conflicts.”

headline: Lasers, Inflatable Dancers and the Fight to Fend Off Avian Flu
abstract: Some poultry growers are turning to innovative tactics to protect their flocks, deploying deterrents like drones, air horns, balloons and decoy predators.
lead_paragraph: Loren Brey, a poultry grower in Minnesota, walked onto the farm where his egg-laying turkeys nest in November to discover a handful of hens, dead from the highly pathogenic avian flu.

headline: Peter Morgan Turns His Pen From ‘The Crown’ to the Kremlin
abstract: His new play “Patriots,” now on Broadway, follows Putin’s rise to power and the Russian oligarchs who mistakenly thought he’d be their puppet.
lead_paragraph: Going from Princess Diana, a lovely icon who generated waves of sympathy, to Vladimir Putin, an icy villain who generates waves of disdain, might be difficult for some writers.

headline: Co-op Assessments: Do You Have to Pay What They Say?
abstract: Courts allow co-op boards significant power over building finances, including assessments — if the fees are in ‘good faith.’
lead_paragraph: Q: I am a shareholder in a Riverdale co-op, and the board recently announced a $500,000 assessment that must be paid over the next three years. Based on my calculation, on average, each shareholder will be charged $5,000. The board said the assessments were needed to cover repairs and new city mandates, but was vague about how the $500,000 figure was calculated. The proprietary lease and bylaws don’t give the board specific authority to impose assessments, but they do allow the board to set maintenance payments and cash requirements. Is there any way to challenge this assessment?

headline: Judith Hill Sang With Pop Royalty. Now She Is Composing Her Own Story.
abstract: The singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist was close to Michael Jackson and Prince. After their deaths, her world crumbled and she had to rebuild on her own.
lead_paragraph: The first time the musician Judith Hill performed her anguished requiem “Black Widow” for an audience, she wept, right onstage.

headline: A Man Hailed as Cindy Birdsong’s Rescuer Is Accused of Exploiting Her
abstract: The son of the former Supreme says in court papers that the man who sought to help his mother after she became incapacitated also took advantage of her financially.
lead_paragraph: Just last year, Brad Herman, a longtime behind-the-scenes aide to celebrities, drew praise from the family of Cindy Birdsong, an ailing former member of the Supremes. He was credited with helping to rescue her from what they described as a friend’s undue influence over her care and finances.

headline: Lily Gladstone and Riley Keough Investigate a Chilling Murder
abstract: In a joint interview, the actors discuss “Under the Bridge,” their new true-crime series based on a teenager’s brutal killing in British Columbia.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve been teenage girls,” Lily Gladstone said. Which means that Gladstone and her co-star, Riley Keough, know what teenage girls can do.

headline: ‘Aging in Place, or Stuck in Place?’
abstract: Homeownership is not the boon to older Americans that it once was.
lead_paragraph: When it came to housing, Susan Apel and Keith Irwin thought they had planned adroitly for later life. They bought a four-bedroom house on two acres in Lebanon, N.H., 24 years ago, and “we made sure to pay off the mortgage before we retired,” said Ms. Apel, 71.

headline: Carbon Dioxide Levels Have Passed a New Milestone
abstract: There’s 50 percent more carbon dioxide in the air than before the Industrial Revolution.
lead_paragraph: There’s 50 percent more carbon dioxide in the air than before the Industrial Revolution.

headline: Americans’ New TV Habit: Subscribe. Watch. Cancel. Repeat.
abstract: Many more people are jumping from one streaming subscription to another, a behavior that could have big implications for the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: Early last year, Josh Meisel and his wife wanted to watch a new buzzy Peacock drama, “Poker Face,” starring Natasha Lyonne.

headline: No, Your Spaghetti Doesn’t Have to Be al Dente: 5 Pasta Myths, Debunked
abstract: A veteran food journalist settles some long-simmering disputes on a slippery subject.
lead_paragraph: After publishing an article debunking five commonly held kitchen myths last week, I got questions — and a surprising number of pleas — about pasta. I was asked to settle long-simmering disputes between grandparents and grandchildren, roommates, and husbands and wives of 50-plus years.

headline: It’s 4/20. These Restaurants Know You Have the Munchies.
abstract: The stoner celebration is becoming a national food holiday, thanks in part to marketing initiatives from Jimmy John’s, KFC, Wingstop and others.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, Alamo Drafthouse Cinemas across the country, temporarily renamed Alamo Dankhouse, are mixing Chex cereal, cheese balls and ranch seasoning with buttered popcorn. The snack is the first of three courses in a special menu that will be served during screenings of stoner classics like “Inherent Vice” and “The Beach Bum.”

headline: Bucking Trump, Anti-Abortion Movement Shows Deep Roots in Arizona
abstract: Even as abortion rights ballot issues have had some striking successes, anti-abortion forces have stood firm in state legislatures like Arizona’s where they have deep convictions and positions of power.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Ben Toma walked off the floor of the Arizona House of Representatives, resolute — if stressed — after he cast the pivotal vote to again block an effort to repeal the state’s 1864 abortion ban.

headline: You Finished I.V.F. and Want to Donate Embryos. Is There a Tax Benefit?
abstract: Some people may consider donating embryos to researchers in light of Alabama’s I.V.F. ruling and in advance of other state actions. Would it be considered a charitable gift?
lead_paragraph: The Alabama Supreme Court’s in vitro fertilization ruling this year, which held that frozen embryos should be considered children, raised a long list of questions for people worried about their future fertility treatments. My colleague Tara Siegel Bernard and I attempted to answer many of them in February.

headline: G.O.P. Intensifies Scrutiny of Voting: ‘We’re Keeping a Close Eye on You’
abstract: The Trump campaign and the Republican Party plan to dispatch over 100,000 volunteers and lawyers to monitor elections in battleground states — and work in concert with conservative activists.
lead_paragraph: On a Monday in mid-March, the Wisconsin Republican Party gathered about 50 conservative activists on a Zoom call to train them in how to become poll workers, helping oversee and monitor the casting and counting of votes.

headline: How R.F.K. Jr. Got on the Michigan Ballot, With Only Two Votes
abstract: The independent candidate persuaded a tiny party to give him its line on the ballot in a key 2024 battleground state, sparing him a costly, arduous organizing effort.
lead_paragraph: In January, when Doug Dern, the state chairman of the Natural Law Party of Michigan, got an email from a top strategist for Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential campaign, he sensed it could be a star turn for his tiny political group.

headline: House Approves $95 Billion Aid Bill for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
abstract: After months of delay at the hands of a bloc of ultraconservative Republicans, the package drew overwhelming bipartisan support, reflecting broad consensus.
lead_paragraph: The House voted resoundingly on Saturday to approve $95 billion in foreign aid for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, as Speaker Mike Johnson put his job on the line to advance the long-stalled aid package by marshaling support from mainstream Republicans and Democrats.

headline: Strike Was Meant to Show Iran that Israel Could Paralyze Its Defenses
abstract: This attack used a fraction of the fire power Iran deployed last week when it launched hundreds of drones and missiles at Israel.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike on Iran on Friday damaged an air defense system, according to Western and Iranian officials, and appeared calculated to deliver a message that Israel could bypass Iran’s defensive systems undetected and paralyze them.

headline: A Bill to Limit Canada’s Trade Negotiators on Farm Goods Edges Nearer to Law
abstract: The measure from a member of the Bloc Québécois would ban changes to the supply management system for dairy, poultry and eggs.
lead_paragraph: Private members’ bills, particularly those from members of the Bloc Québécois, rarely make their way through the parliamentary process. But after passing the House of Commons with strong support from members of all parties, a bill from Yves Perron, who speaks for the Bloc on farming, handily passed a second vote in the unelected Senate on Tuesday.

headline: Bedtime Stories for Grown-Ups
abstract: For those past the age of a parental tuck-in, audiobooks might provide a soothing analogue.
lead_paragraph: If I’m not working or around other people, more often than not, I want to be reading. The rise in availability of audiobooks has made this easier to achieve. One can read a physical book when stationary, then listen to an audiobook when driving, tidying up, walking or otherwise in motion. I like to get the same book in both formats for complete immersion: read the book over breakfast, switch to the audiobook on the stereo while getting ready for work, listen on headphones during my commute.

headline: Behind Our Investigation Into a Chinese Doping Case
abstract: Months before the Tokyo 2021 Olympics, 23 Chinese swimmers tested positive for the same powerful banned substance. Michael Schmidt, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: Months before the Tokyo 2021 Olympics, 23 Chinese swimmers tested positive for the same powerful banned substance. Michael Schmidt, an investigative reporter at The New York Times, explains.

headline: What Began as a War on Theater Won’t End There
abstract: The current politically-driven suppression of theater productions in high schools has a grim historical precedent.
lead_paragraph: Productions of plays in America’s high schools have been increasingly under attack. In 2023, Anton Chekhov’s “Three Sisters” was rejected in Tennessee (since it deals with adultery); “August: Osage County,” the Pulitzer Prize-winning play by Tracy Letts, was canceled in Iowa after rehearsals had begun (the community was deemed not ready for it); and in Kansas, students were not even allowed to study, let alone stage, “The Laramie Project,” a play by Moisés Kaufman and members of the Tectonic Theater Project about the murder of a gay student, Matthew Shepard.

headline: A Planetary Crisis Awaits the Next President
abstract: The return of Trump to the White House would be disastrous for the planet.
lead_paragraph: In the 12 years it took me to write “The Deluge,” my novel of the climate crisis, I watched as chaotic weather, record temperatures and shocking political events outpaced my imagination. The book depicts the human tipping point, when the damage becomes irreversible and the foundations of our economy, our politics and our world begin to crack. The plot points I was concocting in 2010 would become a constant drumbeat of headlines into 2024.

headline: Should Kidney Donors Be Paid?
abstract: A guest essay argued in favor of payments. Readers, including donors, offer divergent views.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Say Hello to Your Addiction Risk Score — Courtesy of the Tech Industry
abstract: A number of new tech companies want to solve the opioid crisis with algorithms. It’s a flawed and potentially harmful proposition.
lead_paragraph: Before Dr. Bobby Mukkamala — an ear, nose, and throat specialist in Michigan — prescribed postsurgical opioids recently, he checked state records of his patient’s existing controlled substance prescriptions, as legally required. A score generated by a proprietary algorithm appeared on his screen. Known as NarxCare (now used by most state prescription monitoring databases, major hospitals and pharmacy chains), the algorithm indicated his patient had an elevated risk of developing an addiction to opioid painkillers.

headline: A Cheat Sheet to the Middle East’s Web of Friends and Enemies
abstract: As the conflict between Israel and Hamas spills over, we sketched out a social network of the alliances and enmities at play.
lead_paragraph: As the conflict between Israel and Hamas spills over, we sketched out a social network of the alliances and enmities at play.

headline: The Most Important Thing I Teach My Students Isn’t on the Syllabus
abstract: Humility can be a bulwark against arrogance, absolutism, purity and zeal, and an antidote in our age of grievance.
lead_paragraph: I warn my students. At the start of every semester, on the first day of every course, I confess to certain passions and quirks and tell them to be ready: I’m a stickler for correct grammar, spelling and the like, so if they don’t have it in them to care about and patrol for such errors, they probably won’t end up with the grade they’re after. I want to hear everyone’s voice — I tell them that, too — but I don’t want to hear anybody’s voice so often and so loudly that the other voices don’t have a chance.

headline: How New Wars Have Brought Back Old American Divisions
abstract: Both parties experience echoes of decades past.
lead_paragraph: For all the ways that our political coalitions have changed over the last few generations — Southern Democrats joining the G.O.P., Northeastern Republicans turning Democrat, “Reagan Democrats” moving right, suburban Republicans voting for Joe Biden — there are patterns that persist across the generations.

headline: Mike Pence: Donald Trump Has Betrayed the Pro-Life Movement
abstract: Here’s how America should build on the end of Roe v. Wade
lead_paragraph: Serving as vice president in the most pro-life administration in American history was one of the greatest honors of my life. Of all our accomplishments, I am perhaps most proud that the Supreme Court justices we confirmed voted to send Roe v. Wade to the ash heap of history, ending a travesty of jurisprudence that led to the death of more than 63 million unborn Americans.

headline: Melania’s Trials
abstract: The former first lady is swept back into the Stormy cyclone.
lead_paragraph: Outside my office, there is a picture of the Slovenian Sphinx visiting the Egyptian Sphinx, taken during a 2018 photo shoot in Giza, nine months after Melania Trump was blindsided by the steamy news about her husband and Stormy Daniels.

headline: Most Major Crimes Are Down. Why Are Assaults Up?
abstract: Homicides, rapes and shootings in New York City have decreased, but the number of assaults has remained stubbornly high.
lead_paragraph: Just before noon last Saturday, a 9-year-old girl was with her mother at Grand Central Terminal when a man strode up to the child and, without warning, punched her in the face, according to the police.

headline: 2 Books That Capture New York
abstract: A stroll around the city with a great stylist; a comic novel of love and real estate.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Takeaways From Our Chinese Swimming Investigation
abstract: A doping case involving Olympic swimmers has left unanswered questions and raised new concerns about the actions of a global antidoping regulator.
lead_paragraph: In the first days of 2021, seven months before the pandemic-delayed Tokyo Olympics, 23 of China’s best swimmers tested positive for the same banned drug at a domestic meet.

headline: Seemed Like a Good Idea at the Time
abstract: Stories that begin full of hope — then take a turn.

headline: Can the W.N.B.A. Make Money?
abstract: A wave of star power has lifted hopes that viewership will pick up for the women’s league.
lead_paragraph: After the Indiana Fever made Caitlin Clark the W.N.B.A.’s No. 1 draft pick this week, the team’s ticket prices soared. The basketball star’s long-distance shots and huge following have landed her on “Saturday Night Live,” attracted interest from sponsors like Nike and sold out jerseys at a rapid pace.

headline: Archie Moore, Australian Artist, Wins Top Prize at Venice Biennale
abstract: Moore, an Indigenous Australian artist, won the Golden Lion for “kith and kin,” which draws on what he says is 65,000 years of family history.
lead_paragraph: Archie Moore, an Indigenous Australian artist who has created an installation including a monumental family tree, won the top prize at the Venice Biennale on Saturday.

headline: The Town at the Center of a Supreme Court Battle Over Homelessness
abstract: A lawsuit by a group of homeless residents of a small Oregon town could reshape the way cities across the country deal with homelessness.
lead_paragraph: Inside a warming shelter, Laura Gutowski detailed how her life had changed since she became homeless two and a half years ago in Grants Pass, a former timber hub in the foothills of southern Oregon.

headline: Could the Union Victory at VW Set Off a Wave?
abstract: Some experts say the outcome at a plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., may be organized labor’s most significant advance in decades. But the road could get rockier.
lead_paragraph: By voting to join the United Automobile Workers, Volkswagen workers in Tennessee have given the union something it has never had: a factory-wide foothold at a major foreign automaker in the South.

headline: Lawsuit Puts Fresh Focus on Eric Hovde’s Comments About Older Voters
abstract: Pressed on his claims of 2020 election irregularities, the Republican candidate for Senate in Wisconsin has questioned the mental capacity of nursing home residents to vote.
lead_paragraph: Eric Hovde, the Republican banking executive challenging Senator Tammy Baldwin in Wisconsin, may be developing a problem with older voters.

headline: Columbia Students Arrested Over Campus Rally May Face Other Consequences
abstract: Students who camped in tents to protest the war in Gaza, including the daughter of Representative Ilhan Omar, may be barred from finishing the semester.
lead_paragraph: Many of the more than 100 Columbia University and Barnard College students who were arrested after refusing to leave a pro-Palestinian encampment on campus on Thursday woke up to a chilly new reality this week: Columbia said that their IDs would soon stop working, and some of them would not be able to finish the semester.

headline: Nevada G.O.P. Senate primary heats up as the long shot goes after the front-runner.
abstract: The Army veteran Sam Brown remains the favorite, but the wealthy former ambassador Jeff Gunter, with a pro-Trump message, is trying to shake up the race.
lead_paragraph: Nevada’s once-sleepy Republican primary for Senate, which has been dominated by Sam Brown, a U.S. Army veteran, was jolted to life in the past week, when a deep-pocketed rival took aim at the front-runner.

headline: Donald Trump’s rally in North Carolina is called off for weather.
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump was due to hold a campaign rally on Saturday in Wilmington, N.C., in a battleground state that he won by just more than 1 percent of the vote in the 2020 presidential election. But it was called off late in the day because of weather.
