headline: Palestinian Baby Delivered After Mother Killed in Israeli Strike
abstract: The baby was born 10 weeks premature and weighed three pounds, a doctor said. Her father and sister also died.
lead_paragraph: Doctors in Gaza delivered a baby on Saturday from a Palestinian woman who had been killed alongside her husband and daughter in an Israeli strike in the city of Rafah, where more than one million people have fled during Israel’s war in Gaza.

headline: David Pecker Is the First Witness of Trump’s Criminal Trial
abstract: Mr. Pecker, the longtime publisher of The National Enquirer, is first on the stand at the former president’s trial.
lead_paragraph: The first witness in Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial is David Pecker, who was the publisher of The National Enquirer, and had traded favors with Mr. Trump since the 1990s.

headline: Britain Memorializes a Queen, With Smiles and Bronze Corgis
abstract: Sculptors have immortalized past British monarchs with imposing, stern-faced statues. For Queen Elizabeth II, they’re taking a different approach.
lead_paragraph: It looked like a corgi convention.

headline: How Tabloids Used ‘Catch-and-Kill’ to Trade on Secrets of Celebrities
abstract: The term was coined by tabloid editors for buying the rights to stories for the purpose of ensuring the information never becomes public. Donald J. Trump was a beneficiary.
lead_paragraph: “Catch-and-kill” is a term coined by old-time tabloid editors for buying the exclusive rights to stories, or “catching” them, for the specific purpose of ensuring the information never becomes public. That’s the “killing” part.

headline: TikTok Faces E.U. Inquiry Over ‘Addictive’ Features
abstract: European officials threatened to fine TikTok and force it to remove some features, the latest regulatory challenge for the Chinese-owned social media app.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators on Monday threatened to fine TikTok over potentially addictive features on a version of its app called TikTok Lite, which was released to work more smoothly on slower wireless networks.

headline: Ukraine War Helped Push World Military Spending to 35-Year High, Study Says
abstract: The outlay reached $2.4 trillion last year, a research group found, 6.8 percent up on 2022. Tensions in Asia and the Middle East also contributed.
lead_paragraph: The world spent more on military costs and weapons in 2023 than it had in 35 years, driven in part by the war in Ukraine and the threat of an expanded Russian invasion, according to an independent analysis released on Monday.

headline: Israel Hasn’t Offered Evidence Tying Many U.N. Workers to Hamas, Review Says
abstract: The review did not address whether some employees of a U.N. agency, UNRWA, took part in the Oct. 7 attack, but it said no evidence had emerged that many UNRWA workers belonged to militant groups.
lead_paragraph: Israel has not provided evidence to support its accusations that many employees of the main U.N. agency for Palestinian refugees are members of terrorist organizations, according to an independent review commissioned by the United Nations that was released on Monday.

headline: Huw Edwards, a Top BBC Anchor, Resigns After 40 Years
abstract: Mr. Edwards had been off the air since July, when he was accused of paying for sexually explicit images, and he cited medical reasons for his decision to quit.
lead_paragraph: Huw Edwards, one of the BBC’s highest-profile anchors, who was suspended last year over allegations of paying for explicit images, resigned from the broadcaster on Monday.

headline: Lori and George Schappell, Long-Surviving Conjoined Twins, Die at 62
abstract: They were distinct people who pursued different lives. “Get past this already, everybody,” Lori said, “get past it and learn to know the individual person.”
lead_paragraph: Lori and George Schappell, conjoined twins whose skulls were partly fused but who managed to lead independent lives, died on April 7 in Philadelphia. They were 62.

headline: Inside Trump’s Complicated Relationship With Law Enforcement
abstract: The former president has put forth a law-and-order candidacy while also criticizing the legal system when it comes to himself and making exceptions for his supporters.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 19, 2021, as part of a series of pardons on his last full day in office, President Donald J. Trump commuted the sentence of a man who had spent almost 30 years of a life sentence in federal prison for what prosecutors said was his role in the murder of an undercover police officer in upstate New York.

headline: The Stark Reality of Israel’s Fight in Gaza
abstract: Israel has failed to achieve its two primary goals of the war, while the suffering of Palestinians erodes support even among its allies.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military operations in Gaza have weakened Hamas. Most Hamas battalions have been degraded and are scattered. Thousands of its members have been killed, and at least one senior military leader has been eliminated.

headline: Summer Lee Has Been a Vocal Israel Critic. Will It Matter in Her Primary?
abstract: The race in Pennsylvania once seemed primed to become a major test of Democratic attitudes about the Middle East. But in much of the district, an expected ideological battle has not arrived.
lead_paragraph: As a progressive insurgent in her last primary campaign, Summer Lee barely eked out a victory in a Pittsburgh-area congressional race, facing fierce opposition from local Democratic leadership and an onslaught of spending from outside groups.

headline: Trump and Attorney General Agree on Minor Changes to $175 Million Bond
abstract: Letitia James had asked a court to reject the bond that Donald J. Trump posted in his civil fraud case. A deal on Monday will keep the terms of the bond largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: The New York attorney general’s office and representatives for Donald J. Trump agreed in court on Monday to slightly modify the terms of a $175 million bond posted by the former president in his civil fraud case after the state questioned the qualifications of the company that provided it and sought to have it rejected.

headline: Three Places Changing Quickly to Fight Climate Change
abstract: Paris is becoming a city of bikes. Across China, people are snapping up $5,000 electric cars. On Earth Day, a look at a few bright spots for emission reductions.
lead_paragraph: Glaciers are shrinking, coral reefs are in crisis and last year was the hottest on record. Atmospheric concentrations of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas, have passed a dangerous new threshold as people continue to burn fossil fuels. Is anyplace making progress on climate change?

headline: What to Know About Victoria Beckham’s 50th Birthday
abstract: Posh Spice had a party involving tequila, Tom Cruise, Salma Hayek — and a rare performance by all five Spice Girls.
lead_paragraph: A 50th birthday is a major milestone in any woman’s life — though not everyone has to step into it like Victoria Beckham, who not long ago broke her foot in a gym accident. Still, Mrs. Beckham was determined to celebrate in style in London on Saturday, when, at least for one night, she replaced the medical boot she has been wearing for months with pointed toe stilettos, visible panties and a long sheer sea-foam-green gown from her own label.

headline: A Passover Pleasure: Matzo Pizza
abstract: While matzo takes many forms during the holiday, some say it is most delightful when pizza-fied.
lead_paragraph: During Passover, Jews move culinary mountains with matzo: cheesy lasagna with layers of the unleavened bread instead of noodles; peanut and caramel brittle; homemade pasta; and even pizza.

headline: Crafting Shoes Never Meant to Be Walked In
abstract: In Venice, a coterie of craftspeople reinterpret Tod’s driving shoes.
lead_paragraph: Last week at the Venice Biennale, the milliner Giuliana Longo wore gold earrings in the shape of hats as she showed off a hat sculpture made of natural agave. Ms. Longo, who has worked as a milliner since 1969, said through a translator that she fell in love with hats because “if you wear a hat, you become a different person.”

headline: Networks Covering Trump’s Trial Are Forced to Get Creative
abstract: TV networks began the challenging assignment on Monday of covering former President Trump’s trial without the luxury of cameras inside the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: A little after 10:30 a.m., just as a prosecutor began delivering his opening statement in Donald J. Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial, CNN’s chief legal correspondent, Paula Reid, had a live on-air update.

headline: Elon Musk Wouldn’t Be the First Car Company Founder to Flame Out
abstract: The world is not always kind to visionaries with self-control issues.
lead_paragraph: Before there was Elon Musk, there was William Crapo Durant. Billy Durant, as he was known, built one of the world’s biggest makers of horse-drawn carriages, bought control of Buick, co-founded General Motors, was forced out of General Motors, co-founded Chevrolet, regained control of General Motors, speculated on stocks, lost control of General Motors a second time, started Durant Motors, went bankrupt in the Depression, opened a bowling alley, suffered a stroke and died penniless in 1947.

headline: Opening Statements in Trump’s Criminal Trial: Five Takeaways
abstract: Prosecutors signaled a sweeping case and Donald J. Trump’s lawyers began their assault on witnesses’ credibility. The judge seems intent on expediting the first trial of an American president.
lead_paragraph: Monday marked another key moment in the criminal trial of Donald J. Trump: opening statements, during which the former president listened quietly to the prosecution’s allegations of crimes, and the defense’s counterargument that he was a simple man, wrongly accused.

headline: Scenes of Protests at College Campuses
abstract: The crackdown at Columbia this month led to more campus demonstrations and hundreds of arrests so far.
lead_paragraph: Protests and arrests spread across some of America’s most influential universities this month, as administrators struggled to defuse tensions on campuses over pro-Palestinian demonstrations.

headline: How to Age Fingernails, and Other Tips From a Movie Makeup Book
abstract: Emily Schubert has done makeup and prosthetics on movies like “The Sweet East” and “Good Time.” She shares her tricks in a new book with A24.
lead_paragraph: Two girls on the street pointed and laughed at me. My Uber driver stared at me suspiciously. My neighbor’s eyes popped out of his head, and when my husband saw me, he begged me to remove it before date night.

headline: Maps: Earthquakes Shake Eastern Taiwan
abstract: View the location of each quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of each quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: An Unprecedented Trial Opens With Two Visions of Trump
abstract: The prosecution’s opening statement sketched a seamy scheme meant to further the election of Donald J. Trump. His lawyer said the government’s case is merely “34 pieces of paper.”
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors delivered a raw recounting of Donald J. Trump’s seamy past on Monday as they debuted their case against him to jurors, the nation and the world, reducing the former president to a co-conspirator in a plot to cover up three sex scandals that threatened his 2016 election win.

headline: As Floods Beckoned, Many of New York’s Catch-Basin Trucks Were Offline
abstract: A report by the New York City comptroller’s office found “big gaps” in how the administration of Mayor Eric Adams handles emergency preparations.
lead_paragraph: Seven months after New York City was inundated by more than eight inches of rain, an investigation found that the city’s public communications were, in some cases, “woefully limited” and its infrastructure inadequate to the challenges of extreme weather.

headline: Top Biden Official Calls for Inquiry Into Chinese Doping Case
abstract: The administration’s top drug official, Rahul Gupta, said he would bring up the handling of Chinese swimmers’ positive tests at a meeting of sports officials this week.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s top drug official called on Monday for an independent investigation into how Chinese and global antidoping authorities decided to clear 23 elite Chinese swimmers who tested positive for a banned drug months before the Summer Olympics in 2021.

headline: Generative A.I. Arrives in the Gene Editing World of CRISPR
abstract: Much as ChatGPT generates poetry, a new A.I. system devises blueprints for microscopic mechanisms that can edit your DNA.
lead_paragraph: Generative A.I. technologies can write poetry and computer programs or create images of teddy bears and videos of cartoon characters that look like something from a Hollywood movie.

headline: Here’s What Is Happening on Some Other Campuses Across the Country
abstract: Demonstrations appeared to be unfolding mainly at universities in the Northeast, although protests spread to some other campuses.
lead_paragraph: The fallout from last week’s heated congressional hearing and subsequent arrests at Columbia University continued to reverberate at several colleges and universities on Monday, as students erected tents and staged their own rallies and sit-ins.

headline: Joel Breman, Who Helped Stop an Ebola Outbreak in Africa, Dies at 87
abstract: Part of a team flown in to fight the deadly virus in 1976, Dr. Breman also worked to stamp out tropical diseases like smallpox, malaria and Guinea worm.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Joel Breman, a specialist in infectious diseases who was a member of the original team that helped combat the Ebola virus in 1976, died on April 6 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 87.

headline: PEN America Cancels Literary Awards Ceremony Amid Gaza War Fallout
abstract: The event had been set for April 29, but weeks of escalating criticism of the organization’s response to the war had led nearly half of the prize nominees to withdraw.
lead_paragraph: The free expression group PEN America has canceled its 2024 literary awards ceremony following months of escalating protests over the organization’s response to the war in Gaza, which has been criticized as overly sympathetic to Israel and led nearly half of the prize nominees to withdraw.

headline: The Circus Trump Wanted Outside His Trial Hasn’t Arrived
abstract: With support from demonstrators in Lower Manhattan spotty so far, Donald Trump issued a call to “rally behind MAGA,” and suggested the poor turnout was a result of a plot against his supporters.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump was evidently not happy with what he saw out the window of his chauffeured S.U.V. as he rode through Lower Manhattan on Monday morning for the beginning of opening arguments in his first criminal trial.

headline: Clashing Visions of Trump
abstract: The prosecution and the defense presented their opening statements.
lead_paragraph: After a year of legal skirmishes and a week of jury selection, today marked the true beginning of the first prosecution of a former American president — a courtroom drama complete with lawyerly broadsides, a no-nonsense judge and 12 Manhattanites sitting in judgment.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: The Trump Trial Opens
abstract: Also, a top Israeli general resigned.
lead_paragraph: In an opening statement, the prosecution gave a sweeping synopsis of the case against Donald Trump — a pivotal moment in the first criminal prosecution of a former American president.

headline: F.T.C. Sues to Block $8.5 Billion Fashion Merger
abstract: The deal between Coach’s owner, Tapestry, and the parent of Michael Kors, Capri Holdings, is intended to create a U.S. luxury group to compete with the European industry giants.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday sued to block Tapestry’s $8.5 billion acquisition of Capri, a blockbuster fashion tie-up that would bring together Coach, Kate Spade, Michael Kors and Versace.

headline: ‘Blair Witch Project’ Actors Push for Retroactive Royalties
abstract: The cast behind the 1999 horror classic was paid mere thousands for a movie that grossed almost $250 million. Now, it’s being rebooted, which was news to the actors.
lead_paragraph: The creative team behind the 1999 hit horror film “The Blair Witch Project” is calling for increased retroactive compensation for the movie’s three stars, as well as “meaningful consultation” on an upcoming reboot.

headline: New Group Joins the Political Fight Over Disinformation Online
abstract: The group intends to fight what its leader, Nina Jankowicz, and others have described as a coordinated campaign by conservatives and their allies to undermine researchers who study disinformation.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Nina Jankowicz briefly led an agency at the Department of Homeland Security created to fight disinformation — the establishment of which provoked a political and legal battle over the government’s role in policing lies and other harmful content online that continues to reverberate.

headline: A City Tries to Measure the Violence It’s Preventing
abstract: In Baton Rouge, a public safety experiment could help to answer a critical question: Do community efforts to reduce street violence work?
lead_paragraph: In Baton Rouge, a public safety experiment could help to answer a critical question: Do community efforts to reduce street violence work?

headline: Phyllis Pressman, Luxury Superstore Matriarch, Is Dead at 95
abstract: She started working at Barneys to be closer to her husband. Then, she became the architect of the Chelsea Passage, the home goods bazaar that helped make it an enticing destination.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Pressman, the matriarch of the family that founded Barneys New York, the discount men’s wear store turned luxury emporium — and the creator of Chelsea Passage, the store’s home goods bazaar, a pivot point in its evolution from a suit merchant to an elite lifestyle behemoth — died on Tuesday in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 95.

headline: Columbia’s President May Face a Censure Resolution
abstract: The university senate is expected to vote as early as Wednesday on a resolution censuring Nemat Shafik, a reaction to her testimony before Congress and the arrests of student protesters.
lead_paragraph: In February, Nemat Shafik, the president of Columbia University, told the school’s senate that she sensed a “low level of trust” in the administration.

headline: ‘Patriots’ Review: What Happened to the Man Who Made Putin?
abstract: Michael Stuhlbarg and Will Keen shine as a kingmaker and his creature. But in Peter Morgan’s cheesy-fun play, it’s not always clear which is which.
lead_paragraph: “In the West you have no idea.”

headline: The First Prosecution of a President Was Laid Out in Court
abstract: Also, pro-Palestinian protests disrupt top college campuses. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: A New York prosecutor today debuted the state’s case against Donald Trump to the jury of Manhattan residents that will be asked to render a verdict in about six weeks. During a 45-minute opening statement, the prosecutor detailed a scandalous story in which he accused the former president of engaging in a “criminal conspiracy” to cover up three sex scandals that threatened Trump’s 2016 campaign.

headline: Trump Was Warned to Return Records to Archives, Unsealed Documents Say
abstract: “Don’t give them a noble reason to indict you, because they will,” an unnamed associate told Donald J. Trump, according to an interview the person gave the F.B.I. in the classified documents case.
lead_paragraph: In late November 2021, as officials at the National Archives were trying to persuade former President Donald J. Trump to return a trove of records he had taken from the White House when he left office, one of Mr. Trump’s associates advised him in the sharpest terms possible to give the materials back, newly unsealed documents show.

headline: Eddie Redmayne and Angela Bassett Journey to Berlin at ‘Cabaret’ Opening
abstract: A party for the buzzy revival of the Broadway musical was held at a theater that has been transformed to look like a 1930s-era nightclub.
lead_paragraph: “I’m so ready for this,” said the actress Bernadette Peters on Saturday afternoon as she stood on the red carpet outside the August Wilson Theater on 52nd Street, which had been styled to look like a Berlin nightclub in the 1930s.

headline: Beloved Ostrich Dies at Kansas Zoo After Swallowing Worker’s Keys
abstract: Karen, a 5-year-old known for her playful antics, reached beyond her enclosure, grabbed a staff member’s keys and swallowed them, the zoo said. Attempts to save her were unsuccessful.
lead_paragraph: A beloved ostrich died last week after reaching beyond the confines of her Kansas zoo enclosure to grab and swallow the keys of a staff member, according to the Topeka Zoo & Conservation Center.

headline: Man Charged With Hate Crime After Destructive Break-In at Islamic Center
abstract: Jacob Beacher is accused of stealing a Palestinian flag and causing $40,000 in damage to religious artifacts at Rutgers University during the Eid-al-Fitr holiday.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man was charged on Monday with a federal hate crime after a Palestinian flag was stolen and $40,000 worth of damage was done to religious artifacts at an Islamic student center at Rutgers University during the Eid-al-Fitr holiday, officials said.

headline: Everything You Need to Know About the 2024 Met Gala
abstract: What’s the dress code, who’s hosting, who’s going and how to watch.
lead_paragraph: First things first: What is the Met Gala?

headline: Can Biden make Trump seem like Mitt Romney?
abstract: The president may be making a similar case against his wealthy rival that Obama made against the G.O.P. nominee in 2012.
lead_paragraph: President Biden made a populist case for re-election during his swing through Pennsylvania over three days last week, laying out plans on tariffs and taxes and seeking to burnish his working-class bona fides as a son of Scranton.

headline: Dozens of Yale Students Arrested as Campus Protests Spread
abstract: The police arrested students at a pro-Palestinian protest encampment at Yale University, days after more than 100 student demonstrators were arrested on the campus of Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: The police arrested students at a pro-Palestinian protest encampment at Yale University, days after more than 100 student demonstrators were arrested on the campus of Columbia University.

headline: Trump Criminal Trial Day 5: Opening Statements and a Brisk Pace
abstract: Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives the major takeaways from the opening statements and the first witness of Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan. An earlier version of this video misstated that it’s the sixth day of the Trump hush-money trial. It is Day 5.
lead_paragraph: Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives the major takeaways from the opening statements and the first witness of Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan. An earlier version of this video misstated that it’s the sixth day of the Trump hush-money trial. It is Day 5.

headline: U.K. Approves Bill That Would Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
abstract: Britain’s Parliament passed contentious legislation to allow the deportation of asylum seekers to the African country, a political victory for Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Conservative government finally won passage of its flagship immigration policy on Monday, enshrining a Rwanda deportation bill that human-rights campaigners say is inhumane, immigration experts say is unworkable and legal critics say has corroded the country’s reputation for rule of law.

headline: Cleveland to Pay $4.8 Million to Family of Teenager Killed in Police Pursuit
abstract: Tamia Chappman, 13, died in 2019 when she was struck by a stolen car driven by a youth who was trying to evade officers.
lead_paragraph: The city of Cleveland will pay $4.8 million to the family of a 13-year-old girl who was killed in December 2019 when she was struck by a stolen car driven by a teenage carjacker during a police pursuit, the city said on Monday.

headline: For Biden, Aid Package Provides a Welcome Boost on the World Stage
abstract: The congressional breakthrough on security assistance to Ukraine and Israel will let the president finally deliver arms to match his words. But it could be only a temporary respite.
lead_paragraph: Finally, President Biden had good news to share with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine. When Mr. Biden picked up the telephone at his home in Wilmington, Del., to call Mr. Zelensky on Monday, the two rejoiced over the congressional breakthrough that will result in the first significant new U.S. military aid for Ukraine in 16 months.

headline: On Columbia’s Campus, a Protest Encampment Grows and Tensions Flare
abstract: On a day the university president asked students to stay home, a tent city on a campus lawn kept growing, protesters met in tense confrontations and police and politicians converged to weigh in.
lead_paragraph: With a light blue academic robe tucked under her arm, Professor Marianne Hirsch hurried to get through a security line at a Columbia University entryway on Monday morning. To pass the gates, everyone had to scan IDs, in compliance with an announcement from the university’s administration that only students and faculty would be allowed on campus.

headline: Review: It’s All Right to Groove to Huey in ‘The Heart of Rock and Roll’
abstract: The new musical doesn’t take itself too seriously and has many winning moments — almost enough to eclipse the weaknesses of its story.
lead_paragraph: It’s 2024, and Huey Lewis is having a moment. Just let that sink in.

headline: Mistrial Declared in Case of Arizona Rancher Accused of Murdering Migrant
abstract: George Alan Kelly is accused of fatally shooting Gabriel Cuen-Buitimea, an unarmed migrant from Mexico, on his 170-acre ranch in Kino Springs, Ariz., last year.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Monday declared a mistrial in the case of an Arizona rancher who was accused of murdering an unarmed migrant on his property after he crossed the U.S.-Mexico border last year, in a case that inflamed people on both sides of the national debate over immigration.

headline: San Francisco Mayor Gives Panda Diplomacy a Try
abstract: In a city still struggling to recover from the pandemic, Mayor London Breed hopes giant pandas will lift the spirits — and the economy — of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Facing a tough re-election fight in San Francisco, Mayor London Breed has already proposed building a soccer stadium in place of an underused mall, adding a college to the hollowed-out downtown and filling the city’s quiet streets with lively night markets.

headline: As College Students Protest, Harris Keeps Her Focus on Abortion
abstract: “When we think about what is at stake, it is absolutely about freedom,” Vice President Kamala Harris said during a visit to Wisconsin.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris, campaigning on Monday in Wisconsin, again took sharp swipes at former President Donald J. Trump for his actions on abortion, a hot topic across the country. But she stayed silent on the war in Gaza, another issue erupting elsewhere among the critical bloc of young voters she has been courting.

headline: Strong Aftershocks From Deadly Quake Rattle Taiwan
abstract: No injuries or deaths were immediately reported, but four buildings partially collapsed in the tremors, which followed a powerful April 3 quake that killed 17 people.
lead_paragraph: Taiwan was shaken by a series of earthquakes on Monday and early Tuesday, the strongest with a magnitude of 6.3, partially toppling four buildings and keeping frightened residents up overnight. The tremors were aftershocks from the magnitude 7.4 quake that killed 17 people three weeks ago, the authorities said.

headline: A Night Different From Others as Campus Protests Break for Seder
abstract: Pro-Palestinian protesters, many of whom are Jewish, prepared Seder dinners at college protest encampments, even as other Jewish students sought community in more traditional settings.
lead_paragraph: On the first night of Passover, the singsong of the Four Questions echoed from Jewish homes and gatherings around the world, including from unlikely, contested spaces: the center of pro-Palestinian protests at Columbia and other universities where demonstrations are taking place.

headline: Voices Below Sopranos
abstract: Judy Bowers makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Universities Struggle as Pro-Palestinian Demonstrations Grow
abstract: Dozens were arrested Monday at N.Y.U. and Yale, but officials there and at campuses across the country are running out of options to corral protests that are expected to last the rest of the school year.
lead_paragraph: At New York University, the police swept in to arrest protesting students on Monday night, ending a standoff with the school’s administration.

headline: Corrections: April, 23, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the possibility of the U.S. imposing sanctions on Israeli military  battalions misstated a title once held by Charles Blaha. He is a former director of an office in the State Department’s bureau of democracy, human rights and labor, not a former director of the bureau.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Asia Heat Wave Bakes Millions, Disrupting Work and Agriculture
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 23, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I haven’t experienced heat like this before. Every year gets hotter, but this year is extreme.”

headline: Earthquakes in Taiwan Damage Buildings
abstract: A series of earthquakes in the city of Hualien on Monday were aftershocks from a deadly quake in early April, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A series of earthquakes in the city of Hualien on Monday were aftershocks from a deadly quake in early April, the authorities said.

headline: Trapped and Starving, 2 Families in Gaza Try to Keep Their Children Alive
abstract: The United Nations says famine is likely to set in by May. For those living under Israel’s attacks and a crippling blockade, every day is a race against time.
lead_paragraph: Born in wartime, the baby had not eaten in more than a day, his father said — no formula, no nothing. His parents had already spent the last of their money on food, sold his mother’s gold jewelry to buy milk and begged water from other evacuees to mix the powdered formula. Now even that was gone.

headline: Slide Over, Auntie: Young Chinese Find Tasty Meals in Senior Canteens
abstract: The community canteens, offering huge plates for a dollar or two, have become popular among penny-pinching young professionals.
lead_paragraph: Inside a canteen for seniors in downtown Shanghai, a worker brandishing a sponge inched closer to Maggie Xu, 29, as she was finishing her rice and garlic-and-oil-soaked broccoli. Ms. Xu ignored her.

headline: A Gen Z Resistance, Cut Off From Data Plans
abstract: Even through the Myanmar army’s communications blackout, residents of a conflict zone find moments of grace, and occasional connectivity, away from the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: In the night, the mountain air not quite chill enough to still the insects, young people gathered around a glow. The light attracting them was not a phone screen, that electric lure for people almost everywhere, but a bonfire.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The opening of Donald Trump’s Manhattan trial.
lead_paragraph: The first criminal trial of a former U.S. president began yesterday, with lawyers from each side presenting divergent visions of Donald Trump in their opening statements.

headline: My Country Knows What Happens When You Do a Deal With Russia
abstract: Moldova is a cautionary tale for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: More and more people, including Pope Francis, are asking Ukraine to drop its defense and sit at the negotiation table with Russia. Citing the stalemate on the battlefield and Russia’s superior resources, they urge Ukraine’s leadership to consider a deal. What exactly that would involve is largely left unsaid. But it would clearly involve freezing the conflict, resigning Ukraine’s occupied territory to Russia in exchange for an end to the fighting.

headline: Microsoft Makes a New Push Into Smaller A.I. Systems
abstract: The company that has invested billions in generative A.I. pioneers like OpenAI says giant systems aren’t necessarily what everyone needs.
lead_paragraph: In the dizzying race to build generative A.I. systems, the tech industry’s mantra has been bigger is better, no matter the price tag.

abstract: This word has appeared in 72 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

abstract: “Are you trying to make this O.J.? It’s not a chase — he’s commuting,” Stewart said on Monday’s “Daily Show.”

headline: A Restaurant Critic’s Full Plate Encroaches on His Palate
abstract: Pete Wells’s first guide to New York’s restaurants was based on a decade of eating. To write a second, did he bite off more than he could chew?
lead_paragraph: At first, I thought it would be easy enough to update my list of the 100 best restaurants in New York City.

headline: Yellowstone’s Wolves: A Debate Over Their Role in the Park’s Ecosystem
abstract: New research questions the long-held theory that reintroduction of such a predator caused a trophic cascade, spawning renewal of vegetation and spurring biodiversity.
lead_paragraph: In 1995, 14 wolves were delivered by truck and sled to the heart of Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming, where the animal had long been absent. Others followed.

headline: Could Trump Go to Prison? If He Does, the Secret Service Goes, Too
abstract: Officials have had preliminary discussions about how to protect the former president in the unlikely event that he is jailed for contempt during the trial.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Secret Service is in the business of protecting the president, whether he’s inside the Oval Office or visiting a foreign war zone.

headline: Old and Young
abstract: How many intergenerational relationships do you have? What do you get from them?
lead_paragraph: Do you have any meaningful relationships with people significantly older or younger than you are? What do you get from those relationships that you might not get from those with people your own age?

headline: Malaysian Navy Helicopters Collide Midair, Killing All 10 People Aboard
abstract: The two helicopters were rehearsing for a parade to celebrate the navy’s 90th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Two Malaysian Navy helicopters collided midair during a training session in the northwestern state of Perak on Tuesday, killing all 10 people on board, at least the second accident involving government aircraft in the Southeast Asian country in as many months.

headline: Baltimore Says Owner of Ship That Hit Key Bridge Was Negligent
abstract: The owner and manager of the cargo ship that downed the Francis Scott Key Bridge asked a judge to exonerate them from liability. The city argued otherwise.
lead_paragraph: The City of Baltimore has said that the owner and manager of the cargo ship that brought down the Francis Scott Key Bridge last month are directly responsible for the accident and should not be allowed to avoid legal liability, according to court documents filed on Monday.

headline: Roaches’ Lullaby
abstract: In the 1970s, the filmmakers Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes interviewed New Yorkers across the city about their unwanted roommates: roaches.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, the filmmakers Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes interviewed New Yorkers across the city about their unwanted roommates: roaches.

headline: New Yorkers vs. Cockroaches: ‘It’s Them or Me.’
abstract: In the 1970s, the filmmakers Claudia Weill and Eli Noyes interviewed New Yorkers across the city about their unwanted roommates: roaches.
lead_paragraph: It was the early 1970s, and we had set up our little company, Cyclops Films, at 1600 Broadway. We were equipped with a newly purchased Éclair NPR, a Nagra recorder and our infatuation with cinéma vérité.

headline: The Fastest Way to Boost Your Fitness
abstract: Sprinting, at least for short distances, can be a great way to level up your workout routine.
lead_paragraph: When was the last time you sprinted?

headline: A Guide of American Museums to Visit This Year
abstract: Siblings, parents and grandparents are collaborators and muses in a variety of upcoming shows around the country that highlight family traditions and bonds.
lead_paragraph: The value of family in the lives and work of artists is being showcased at museums across the United States this spring.

headline: As Museums’ Missions Expand, So Too Does Their Physical Space
abstract: Creative approaches to landscaping and a post-pandemic interest in outdoor activities are driving institutions to make better use of their grounds.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, a museum garden was a pretty straightforward proposition: an ornamental space — often a manicured lawn or stone plaza, sprinkled with flower beds and sculpture — serving as a complement to, and respite from, the elite institution next door.

headline: You Can Sit There. Really.
abstract: At the Denver Art Museum, a furniture exhibition lets visitors experience museum fare as more than just pretty objects.
lead_paragraph: The first thing that greets visitors at the Denver Art Museum’s new exhibition of contemporary furniture is a rather large sign announcing the show’s name. “Have a Seat: Mexican Chair Design Today,” it reads in uppercase letters rendered in an eye-popping, pink font.

headline: A St. Louis Museum Revisits a Famous but Complex World’s Fair
abstract: A new exhibit at the Missouri History Museum examines “the triumphant side and the tragic side” of the 1904 spectacle to present a fuller story.
lead_paragraph: In the final scene of the 1944 musical film “Meet Me in St. Louis,” the Smith family, dressed in fancy attire, wanders the grounds of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, better known as the 1904 World’s Fair. Daylight fades, the electric lights flash on and the group stops in its tracks.

headline: Jane Smiley’s Folk Music Novel Hits Some Bum Notes
abstract: “Lucky” features a 1970s singer-songwriter who finds improbable success.
lead_paragraph: Fictional folk singers have generally been the butt of the joke, holy fools or total idiots: Think of “National Lampoon’s Animal House” when John Belushi’s Bluto brutally smashes the guitar of the young man whose only offense is singing “I gave my love a cherry…,” the sincere saps of “A Mighty Wind” or the Coen brothers’ prickly, unattractive Llewyn Davis. With the glorious late-career renaissance of Joni Mitchell and the eye-opening recent Joan Baez documentary “I Am a Noise,” however, perhaps the time is right for Jodie Rattler, the protagonist of Jane Smiley’s new novel, “Lucky.”

headline: I Thought the Bragg Case Against Trump Was a Legal Embarrassment. Now I Think It’s a Historic Mistake.
abstract: It’s not the crime; it’s the cover-up. But it’s still a highly flawed case.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, when Alvin Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney, indicted former President Donald Trump, I was critical of the case and called it an embarrassment. I thought an array of legal problems would and should lead to long delays in federal courts.

headline: Abortion Data Wars: States and Cities Debate How Much Information to Collect
abstract: Some states with Republican-controlled legislatures want more data, while some controlled by Democrats want less, fearing it could be used to target patients or providers.
lead_paragraph: In the fierce debate over abortion in the United States, the subject of data collection might seem wonky and tangential. But the information that state and city governments collect about abortion patients is becoming another flashpoint in the country’s bitter divide over the issue.

headline: Her Father Was a Hippie Dropout. He Was Also an Aristocrat (Sort Of).
abstract: In “The Whole Staggering Mystery,” Sylvia Brownrigg explores her mysterious parent’s past, and finds more than she bargained for.
lead_paragraph: In the opening pages of “The Whole Staggering Mystery,” Sylvia Brownrigg makes a case for memoir in the age of the genome. Now that mysteries of lineage can be solved via quick DNA test, “family secrets,” she writes, “aren’t what they used to be.”

headline: One Walk-in Shower Is as Good as Any Other, Right? Wrong.
abstract: Here’s how to make your morning shower more luxurious.
lead_paragraph: A utilitarian walk-in shower works just as well as something nicer, so why spend the time and effort — and the money — to upgrade it?

headline: Is Nasal Spray Addictive?
abstract: Some versions can lead to dependence. Here’s what we know about the risks.
lead_paragraph: Q: Nasal sprays help with my seasonal allergies, but I’ve heard they can be addictive. Is that true? And what should I do if I think I’m hooked?

headline: Costuming a Small Army of Virgins for the Met Opera’s ‘El Niño’
abstract: The challenge for Montana Levi Blanco, the Tony-winning costume designer for John Adams’s oratorio, was how to keep straight so many Marys.
lead_paragraph: In the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of “El Niño,” which reimagines the story of Jesus’ birth and early childhood, there are singing and dancing Virgin Marys, Marys of the land and sea; there’s an Indigenous Mary, a Tropical Mary, a Golden Mary.

headline: Reincarnating a Treasured Design Store in Minneapolis
abstract: The Walker Art Center looks to the past to bring back its long-admired flair for modern design and contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: At the Walker Art Center here, Felice Clark sits on a sofa that looks like it crawled off the set of the 1988 Tim Burton film “Beetlejuice.”

headline: ‘Shogun’ Finale Recap: Mask Off
abstract: Lord Toranaga’s true plan is finally revealed.
lead_paragraph: Take a look at any of FX’s promotional material for “Shogun,” and one image will stare back: Lord Toranaga (Hiroyuki Sanada), in full samurai armor, his sword drawn as he charges into battle on a white horse. Tattered red banners and a cavalry provide the backdrop. It doesn’t require close reading to determine that he has cried havoc and let slip the dogs of war.

headline: The Sinking Arizona Town Where Water and Politics Collide
abstract: Democrats see an opening to win back rural Trump voters fed up with their groundwater being pumped by huge farms.
lead_paragraph: In Arizona’s deeply conservative La Paz County, the most urgent issue facing many voters is not inflation or illegal immigration. It is the water being pumped from under their feet.

headline: 460 Years Ago, Shakespeare Was Born Here. Or Somewhere.
abstract: Every year, millions flock to Stratford-upon-Avon, England, to visit the house known as Shakespeare’s Birthplace. But was he really born there? A whole industry depends on it.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the late 18th century, a sign appeared outside a shambly butcher’s hut in the English town of Stratford-upon-Avon: “The Immortal Shakspeare was born in this house,” it announced, using a then common spelling of his name. Devotees began making pilgrimages — dropping to their knees, weeping, singing odes: “Untouched and sacred be thy shrine, Avonian Willy, bard Divine!”

headline: Kamasi Washington Wants to Remain Unstoppable
abstract: Nine years after the release of the album that changed his life, the saxophonist is bringing new collaborators and new parts of himself into his work.
lead_paragraph: Before Kamasi Washington unveiled his breakthrough opus, he admits, he second-guessed it.

headline: In Silicon Valley, You Can Be Worth Billions and It’s Not Enough
abstract: Andreas Bechtolsheim, the first investor in Google, has an estimated $16 billion fortune. He recently settled charges that he engaged in insider trading for a profit of $415,726.
lead_paragraph: Andreas Bechtolsheim doesn’t like to waste time. The entrepreneur made one of the most celebrated investments in the history of Silicon Valley — the initial $100,000 that bankrolled a search engine called Google in 1998 — while on the way to work one morning. It took just a few minutes.

headline: Danielle Dutton’s Surreal Take on Human Existence
abstract: “Prairie, Dresses, Art, Other,” the author’s new collection, ranges from a playful one-act drama set in a lake to short fiction rife with apocalyptic anxiety.
lead_paragraph: Aspiring writers now get M.F.A.s in creative writing, instead of studying literature, and novelists end up teaching these people rather than attending to their own work. Almost any other day job would be preferable, since editing students’ literary efforts not only pays badly, it sucks exactly the same imaginative energy out of you that you need to write your own stuff. Once neutralized in this way, some writer-teachers compound the misstep by mining academe for material. Big mistake.

headline: What Is a Cowboy, Anyway?
abstract: Cowboy style means something different for every group and era — from the vaqueros to Buffalo Bill, Madonna to the Marlboro Man, Lil Nas X to Louis Vuitton.
lead_paragraph: Every few years, it rides into town on a glossy white horse with the whole mixed-up mythology of frontier America crammed into its saddle bags: cowboy-core. We saw it most recently in late March, when Beyoncé turned country music on its head with the release of “Cowboy Carter.” That country-inflected album, still holding firm at No. 1 on the Billboard charts, not only lit up the BeyHive but simultaneously loosed a torrent of tropes and memes and posts and pictorials about cowboy style.

headline: Hey, New Yorkers: Do You Live Next to an Elevated Train Line?
abstract: Love or hate the elevated train right outside your window? Tell us about your experience.
lead_paragraph: For an upcoming project, The New York Times is hoping to learn more about New Yorkers who live in apartments or homes adjacent to elevated subway tracks.

headline: How the Squad and Like-Minded Progressives Have Changed Their Party
abstract: The left’s position on Israel has now become the Democratic Party’s, hinting at greater influence to come.
lead_paragraph: When the far-left politicians Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Ayanna Pressley were first elected to Congress roughly half a decade ago, many moderate Democrats saw their unapologetically progressive vision for America as an albatross around the neck of the Democratic Party.

headline: When Edgar Allan Poe Lived, and Loved, in the Bronx
abstract: The manuscript of Poe’s poem “For Annie,” written while he was living in a Bronx cottage after his wife’s death, is up for auction.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll look at the manuscript of “For Annie,” a poem that Edgar Allan Poe wrote when he lived in a cottage in the Bronx. Annie was married, but that didn’t stop him. We’ll also look at a report that found “big gaps” in the way City Hall prepares for extreme weather.

headline: This Conversation Made Me a Sharper Editor
abstract: The venerated editor Adam Moss walks through how to make good work great.
lead_paragraph: In our recent series on artificial intelligence, I kept returning to a thought: This technology might be able to churn out content faster than we can, but we still need a human mind to sift through the dross and figure out what’s good. In other words, A.I. is going to turn more of us into editors.

headline: He’s Music’s Mr. Adjacent, Connecting Minimalism to Disco
abstract: Peter Gordon, who studied with Terry Riley, has always made music that is surprising but accessible. Now he’s starting his own record label.
lead_paragraph: For 45 years, Peter Gordon has held onto a reel-to-reel tape of a show he performed in 1979 at the Mudd Club in New York City with a trio called the Blue Horn File. Gordon, the violinist Laurie Anderson and the percussionist David Van Tieghem — a group of new music all-stars — did a short set with the playful and unshackled feel of cartoon music. It was one of only three shows the Blue Horn File played.

headline: ‘Pay Later’ Lenders Have an Issue With Credit Bureaus
abstract: Firms like Experian and TransUnion say it is time for “buy now, pay later” loans to appear on consumer credit reports. The lenders aren’t ready to sign on.
lead_paragraph: Shoppers in recent years have embraced “buy now, pay later” loans as an easy, interest-free way to purchase everything from sweaters to concert tickets.

headline: Searching for the Real ‘Anna O.’
abstract: As described by Gabriel Brownstein, the basis for one of Freud’s most famous cases posed as many questions as it answered.
lead_paragraph: Bertha Pappenheim stopped eating and sleeping. She lost her language and ability to move. Her eyes crossed and her muscles spasmed.

headline: Cha Cha Tang Will Serve Its Take on Hong Kong Diner Food Starting Mother’s Day
abstract: Onion Tree Pizza offers chicken tikka masala and saag paneer  pies, Burmese Bites opens in Midtown East and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Opening on Mother’s Day, May 12, this pop-up rendition of a Hong Kong diner with white tablecloths will serve Cobb salad with roast pork, a Cantonese roast duck sandwich, macaroni soup with fried Spam, Cantonese French toast with taro cream and more. It’s the work of Wilson Tang, who grew up in the Manhattan Chinatown and visited Hong Kong often, and John McDonald, the owner of Hancock Street. Mr. Tang is known for restoring Nom Wah Tea Parlor in Chinatown (no longer involved, he owns other Nom Wah outlets and the brand). It runs Sundays and Mondays until early June; the chefs Doron Wong and Akiko Thurnauer will be in the kitchen. (Opens May 12)

headline: In San Francisco, a Home Renovation Can Become a Battle Royale
abstract: Neighbors have multiple opportunities to raise objections, and some disputes can only be resolved by the city’s top governing body.
lead_paragraph: San Francisco’s top governing body spent time on Tuesday discussing what most residents surely would not consider a major priority for the city: whether Julie Park and Tom McDonald can raise the roof of their $2.1 million Victorian home by 7 feet and 3 inches.

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Find Local Fish (Even by the Water)?
abstract: Seafood caught in nearby waters has long been left out of the farm-to-table movement. But these people have set out to get it into stores and restaurants.
lead_paragraph: On a cold, windy February morning on Shinnecock Bay, on the South Fork of Long Island, N.Y., Ricky Sea Smoke fished for clams from the back of his 24-foot boat. The fisherman, whose real name is Rick Stevens, expertly sorted through haul after haul as they were dumped onto the sorting rack.

headline: How Do We Know What Animals Are Really Feeling?
abstract: Animal-welfare science tries to get inside the minds of a huge range of species — in order to help improve their lives.
lead_paragraph: What makes a desert tortoise happy? Before you answer, we should be more specific: We’re talking about a Sonoran desert tortoise, one of a few species of drab, stocky tortoises native to North America’s most arid landscapes. Adapted to the rocky crevices that striate the hills from western Arizona to northern Mexico, this long-lived reptile impassively plods its range, browsing wildflowers, scrub grasses and cactus paddles during the hours when it’s not sheltering from the brutal heat or bitter cold. Sonoran desert tortoises evolved to thrive in an environment so different from what humans find comfortable that we can rarely hope to encounter one during our necessarily short forays — under brimmed hats and layers of sunblock, carrying liters of water and guided by GPS — into their native habitat.

headline: Sydney Sweeney and Glen Powell on How ‘Anyone but You’ Beat the Rom-Com Odds
abstract: Here are their takeaways after the film, debuting on Netflix, went from box office miss to runaway hit.
lead_paragraph: As Sydney Sweeney and Glen Powell promoted their romantic comedy, “Anyone but You,” last year, life appeared to be imitating art: The co-stars posed cheek to cheek while sightseeing in Australia. Powell dipped a gleeful Sweeney in his arms. Sweeney cast longing gazes up at Powell on red carpets. The pair flirted and giggled in interviews.

headline: Why Is the Supreme Court Making an Easy Case Related to Jan. 6 Rioters Hard?
abstract: Will the court go out of its way to disregard statutory language and create ambiguity where none exists?
lead_paragraph: Imagine that during a Supreme Court argument, protesters angry about the case storm the court building. The mob breaks doors and windows and assaults security officers while forcing its way into the chamber. Some shout that they want to hang the chief justice. The justices and attorneys are forced to flee for their lives. It’s several hours before law enforcement secures the building and the argument can resume.

headline: 6 Smart Tips for Building a Better Grocery Budget
abstract: With a few simple steps, you can rein in your spending at the supermarket.
lead_paragraph: Shrinking products, rising prices at the market and beyond: Shoppers have been feeling the pinch at the register for some time now. And whether it’s a new feeling or a long-lasting one, creating a grocery budget can help you feel more in control over your finances.

headline: Are You Too Critical of Yourself?
abstract: Do you feel pressure to be the best or to never make mistakes?
lead_paragraph: Think of a time when something didn’t go as well as you had hoped — a time, for example, when you made a mistake, did poorly on a test or were cut from a team.

headline: A Very Famous Model Stars in a Very Pixelated Book of Wigs
abstract: With the model Kaia Gerber, the hairstylist Guido Palau created a “low-fi” project about the transformative power of hair.
lead_paragraph: Guido Palau was sitting in an airport lounge in Miami, on his way to New York. Kaia Gerber was sitting in a car in Los Angeles, on her way to the airport.

headline: In Ukraine, New American Technology Won the Day. Until It Was Overwhelmed.
abstract: Project Maven was meant to revolutionize modern warfare. But the conflict in Ukraine has underscored how difficult it is to get 21st-century data into 19th-century trenches.
lead_paragraph: The idea triggered a full-scale revolt on the Google campus.

headline: The Small-Business Tyrant Has a Favorite Political Party
abstract: It has never been more obvious that the Republican Party is the party of the boss.
lead_paragraph: Despite the blue-collar affectations of some of its most visible leaders or the populist rhetoric of its most vocal cheerleaders, it has never been more obvious that the Republican Party is the party of the boss, and in particular the party of the small-business tyrant.

headline: Cait Bailey Can’t Avoid the Spotlight
abstract: The publicist is by the side of famous people like Zayn Malik, Alex Cooper and Alix Earle. She’s dating a famous chef. But she’d prefer to keep a low profile.
lead_paragraph: “Not tonight,” Cait Bailey told a photographer trying to take her picture inside an area cordoned off for special guests at a Louis Vuitton party at the Miami Beach Convention Center. “Not this time.”

headline: New York Is Turning 400. We Should Celebrate. But How?
abstract: We need history to support our foundations. But it can only do that with integrity if it exposes the failings.
lead_paragraph: This spring is the 400th anniversary of the founding of New York — or, to be precise, of the Dutch colony that became New York once the English took it over. It’s a noteworthy milestone. That settlement gave rise to a city unencumbered by old ways and powered by pluralism and capitalism: the first modern city, you might say.

headline: Biden Campaigns on Abortion Rights in Florida, Tying State Ban to Trump
abstract: The Biden campaign has made abortion one of its top issues, as polling shows it is one of the few subjects in which voters place more trust in President Biden than Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday strongly condemned a six-week abortion ban that will soon take effect in Florida, saying it would force women to endure “unbearable pain and cruelty” and blaming former President Donald J. Trump for their suffering.

headline: Senate Approves Aid for Ukraine and Israel, Sending It to Biden’s Desk
abstract: The overwhelming bipartisan vote for the long-stalled $95.3 billion aid package capped a tortured journey for the legislation on Capitol Hill. President Biden is expected to quickly sign it.
lead_paragraph: The Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday night to give final approval to a $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, sending it to President Biden and ending months of uncertainty about whether the United States would continue to back Kyiv in its fight against Russian aggression.

headline: Trump Is Owed an Extra $1 Billion Stake in Truth Social
abstract: The former president is in line for a windfall after the stock price of Trump Media hit performance targets in its first few weeks of trading, raising the value of his already sizable stake.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s already sizable stake in his social media company is set to jump by more than $1 billion, as he’s rewarded with additional shares in the parent of Truth Social — the result of its stock price staying high in recent weeks.

headline: U.S. universities struggle to calm campuses torn by the Gaza war.
abstract: Administrators at some of the most influential American universities — including New York University, Yale and Columbia — were struggling, and largely failing, on Monday to calm campuses torn by the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Administrators at some of the most influential American universities — including New York University, Yale and Columbia — were struggling, and largely failing, on Monday to calm campuses torn by the war in Gaza.

headline: A Salacious Conspiracy or Just 34 Pieces of Paper?
abstract: Inside the criminal trial of former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The prosecution and the defense both opened their cases on Monday in the first criminal trial of Donald Trump.

headline: Campus Antiwar Protests Grow, and Trump Fights Attempts to Silence Him
abstract: Plus, “Blair Witch” actors push for royalties.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Why Did Modi Call India’s Muslims ‘Infiltrators’? Because He Could.
abstract: The brazenness of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s vilification of India’s largest minority group made clear he sees few checks at home or abroad on his power.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, his power at home secured and his Hindu-first vision deeply entrenched, has set his sights in recent years on a role as a global statesman, riding India’s economic and diplomatic rise. In doing so, he has distanced himself from his party’s staple work of polarizing India’s diverse population along religious lines for its own electoral gain.

headline: Germany Arrests Aide to E.U. Lawmaker on Suspicion of Spying for China
abstract: The move came just hours after the authorities detained three other people suspected of passing secrets to Beijing.
lead_paragraph: An aide to a German far-right European Parliament lawmaker has been arrested on suspicion of spying for China, Germany’s federal prosecutor’s office said Tuesday, the latest in a series of cases that have intensified concerns about foreign interference in European Union politics weeks before bloc-wide elections.

headline: Donald Trump on Trial
abstract: Highlights from the first big day of the former president’s New York criminal case.
lead_paragraph: A criminal trial is often a contest between competing stories. In the trial of Donald Trump that’s just begun, prosecutors used their opening statement yesterday to tell a story about a man they say lied — and broke the law — to get elected president.

headline: Donors Stay Largely Silent Amid New Wave of Campus Protests
abstract: Robert Kraft, an alumnus of Columbia, suggested he would withhold donations to the school. Other alumni are keeping quiet.
lead_paragraph: Top American colleges are in turmoil, with dozens of pro-Palestinian student protesters having been arrested at N.Y.U. and Yale amid new worries about antisemitism on campus.

headline: At Least 5 Die Trying to Cross English Channel, Including a Young Girl
abstract: British and French authorities have struggled to find ways to deter people from making the perilous journey.
lead_paragraph: At least five people died at sea off the coast of northern France on Tuesday during an attempt to cross the English Channel, as governments on both sides of the waterway struggle to deter migrants from making the dangerous voyage to Britain.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Dubai, College Protests, Caitlin Clark
abstract: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to current events recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Why David Beckham Is Suing Mark Wahlberg and F45 for Millions
abstract: The former soccer star entered into a promotional agreement with the gym franchise that is co-owned by the actor, but things quickly soured.
lead_paragraph: The former English soccer star David Beckham is entangled in a court battle against F45, a popular global fitness brand co-owned by the actor and entrepreneur Mark Wahlberg.

headline: What Is the Rwanda Policy? U.K.’s Plan for Asylum Seekers Explained
abstract: The plan has been in the works for years, but the passage of a contentious bill by Britain’s Parliament puts the country closer to sending asylum seekers to the African nation.
lead_paragraph: After a prolonged battle in the courts and in Parliament, Britain’s Conservative government secured passage of legislation on Monday that is intended to allow the country to send asylum seekers to Rwanda.

headline: Why an Oregon Case Before the Supreme Court Matters So Much to California
abstract: A challenge to a small Oregon city’s law that imposes fines on homeless people for sleeping outdoors could have big implications for the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court began hearing a case yesterday that could have profound implications for how the United States deals with its escalating homelessness crisis.

headline: New York Court System to Publish Daily Transcripts of Trump’s Trial
abstract: A government website will also contain relevant documents for the landmark trial, which is not televised.
lead_paragraph: If you want to follow Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in detail but can’t make it to the Lower Manhattan courthouse in person, you can still read every word of the proceedings.

headline: G.M. Reports Big Jump in Profit on Gasoline Car Sales
abstract: General Motors has struggled with electric vehicles and in foreign markets but it is selling lots of combustion engine cars and trucks in North America.
lead_paragraph: General Motors on Tuesday reported a big jump in profits for the first three months of the year, based on the strength of its gasoline vehicle business, and raised its outlook for the rest of the year.

headline: Supreme Court Seems to Side With Starbucks’ Challenge to Labor Ruling
abstract: The case seeks to limit the National Labor Relations Board’s ability to obtain court intervention in labor cases.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court justices on Tuesday appeared willing to side with Starbucks in the company’s challenge to a federal judge’s order to reinstate workers who were attempting to unionize a store in Memphis.

headline: Pennsylvania Holds Its Primaries Today. Here’s What to Watch.
abstract: The Democratic primary for Representative Summer Lee, a vocal Israel critic, is the contest getting the most attention on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvanians are heading to the polls on Tuesday, with a handful of House primary races in the spotlight.

headline: Planned Parenthood Plans $10 Million Boost for Democrats in North Carolina
abstract: The party is banking on abortion access as an issue to animate the state’s competitive race for governor and, they hope, galvanize voters for President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Aiming to bring the national fight over abortion access to a key battleground state, a political arm of Planned Parenthood will spend $10 million on organizing efforts in North Carolina this year, its largest-ever investment in a single state.

headline: Judge Approves $418 Million Settlement That Will Change Real Estate Commissions
abstract: Home sellers will no longer be required to offer commission to a buyer’s agent when they sell their property, under an agreement with the National Association of Realtors.
lead_paragraph: A settlement that will rewrite the way many real estate agents are paid in the United States has received preliminary approval from a federal judge.

headline: What to Watch: ‘Baby Reindeer,’ an Astonishing Stalker Drama
abstract: The Netflix series is based on the real-life experience of its creator, Richard Gadd, who also stars in the show.
lead_paragraph: Richard Gadd created and stars in the mesmerizing, complex drama “Baby Reindeer” (on Netflix), which is based on his experience of being stalked. Here he plays Donny Dunn, an aspiring comedian and miserable bartender, living with his ex-girlfriend’s mother and stewing in regret.

headline: Winner, Winner, Hot Honey Chicken Dinner
abstract: Vallery Lomas’s new recipe for hot honey chicken is easy, delicious and already earning rave reviews.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes we publish a recipe on New York Times Cooking that aligns so perfectly with this newsletter and our cause — food for busy people who still want something good to eat — that I get excited to tell you about it. That’s the case with Vallery Lomas’s new roasted chicken thighs with hot honey and lime. The ingredients are minimal; the flavors are maximal. It’s easy to put together, makes clever use of staples (garlic and onion powders, honey, hot sauce), and it’s already racking up rave reviews. And really, I just want to have it for dinner as soon as possible, spritzed with lime.

headline: Kathleen Hanna’s Music Says a Lot. There’s More in the Book.
abstract: In “Rebel Girl,” the punk frontwoman reveals the story of her life — the men who tried to stop her, the women who kept her going and the boy who made her a mother.
lead_paragraph: The first draft of Kathleen Hanna’s memoir, “Rebel Girl: My Life as a Feminist Punk,” was 600 pages long. As she worked to cut the manuscript, Hanna found herself excising page after page of male violence. “It’s pretty sad, if you read the book, because there’s still a lot in there,” she told me. “I had a joke with my editor about it.” Like, she’d already removed a rape and a kidnapping and a guy who threw a wine glass at her head! “What more do you want from me?”

headline: Celebrity Bag Designer Sentenced to Jail for Smuggling Exotic Skins
abstract: Nancy Gonzalez, whose clients included Britney Spears and Sofia Vergara, smuggled purses from her native Colombia to the United States using couriers. She will serve 18 months.
lead_paragraph: The handbag designer Nancy Gonzalez built a cult following among celebrities and the South American superrich thanks to her use of brilliantly dyed precious skins. Once one of the largest purveyors of crocodile skin accessories in the world, her namesake brand sold totes and clutches in lime green alligator and lavender python skin for thousands of dollars, often through big-name retailers like Saks and Bergdorf Goodman.

headline: Did the Israel-Hamas War Influence Your Seder Rituals? Tell Us.
abstract: We want to know if the war changed the rituals or the tenor of your Seder.
lead_paragraph: For an article later today, The New York Times is hoping to learn more about how the Israel-Hamas war may have affected Seders last night, or preparations for Seders tonight or later.

headline: In a Pair of ‘Macbeth’ Productions, Only One Does Right by the Lady
abstract: One of Shakespeare’s most coveted roles for women gets different interpretations onstage in New York and Washington.
lead_paragraph: “Macbeth” isn’t one of Shakespeare’s so-called “problem plays,” and yet, the vast contradictions and reversals of the central couple often present a problem for those staging it.

headline: ‘Tortured Poets’ Has Shifted the Taylor Swift Debate. Let’s Discuss.
abstract: The superstar’s 11th album is a 31-song excavation of her recent relationships that is not universally loved. Our pop team dissects its sound, themes and reception.
lead_paragraph: BEN SISARIO Hey, have you guys seen my antique typewriter? I think I left it at someone’s apartment. I swear, I’m so absent-minded …

headline: Tesla’s Profit Fell 55%, Adding to Concerns About Its Strategy
abstract: The first-quarter results are likely to fuel worries that competitors will continue grabbing a bigger slice of a market dealing with slowing electric car sales.
lead_paragraph: Tesla reported on Tuesday that it made significantly less money in the first three months of the year because of its tepid car sales, reinforcing concern among investors that the company led by Elon Musk is losing ground in the market for electric vehicles.

headline: Hezbollah Claims Drone Attack 10 Miles Inside Israel
abstract: The Israeli military later said that no bases had been hit and no casualties reported.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah on Tuesday claimed that it had made its deepest attack into Israel since October, striking a barracks north of the city of Acre with drones and setting off sirens across the country’s northern coastline.

headline: The Gaza Protests Engulfing Columbia and Other Campuses
abstract: Readers, including parents of suspended students, discuss the unrest. Also: Responses to Liz Cheney on the Supreme Court and Donald Trump’s immunity claim.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Gag Order Hearing Is Heated as Judge Considers Citing Trump for Contempt
abstract: Justice Juan M. Merchan, overseeing Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, warned the former president’s lawyer that he was losing credibility.
lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s trial in Manhattan held a fiery hearing on Tuesday about whether to find Mr. Trump in criminal contempt for repeatedly violating the provisions of a gag order.

headline: A Brewery Worker’s Drunken Driving Defense: His Stomach Made the Alcohol
abstract: A 40-year-old man was acquitted of a drunken driving offense after doctors confirmed he had a rare condition: auto-brewery syndrome.
lead_paragraph: One man was charged with drunken driving after crashing his truck and spilling 11,000 salmon onto a highway in Oregon. Another was secretly recorded by his wife, who was convinced he was a closet alcoholic. And in Belgium, a brewery worker was recently pulled over and given a breathalyzer test, which said that his blood alcohol level was more than four times the legal limit for drivers.

headline: To Justify His Immunity Defense, Trump Flips the Prosecution Script
abstract: The former president’s claim ahead of a pivotal Supreme Court hearing that he was protecting the election system rather than subverting it is part of a pattern of shaping his own reality.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Trump immunity case before the Supreme Court.

headline: How G.M. Tricked Millions of Drivers Into Being Spied On (Including Me)
abstract: This privacy reporter and her husband bought a Chevrolet Bolt in December. Two risk-profiling companies had been getting detailed data about their driving ever since.
lead_paragraph: Automakers have been selling data about the driving behavior of millions of people to the insurance industry. In the case of General Motors, affected drivers weren’t informed, and the tracking led insurance companies to charge some of them more for premiums. I’m the reporter who broke the story. I recently discovered that I’m among the drivers who was spied on.

headline: Prosecutors Call Trump’s Echo of Fox News Host Remarks ‘Troubling’
abstract: Donald J. Trump amplified a false assertion by the commentator Jesse Watters that activists were infiltrating the jury in his criminal trial.
lead_paragraph: As prosecutors argued Tuesday that former President Donald J. Trump had repeatedly broken a gag order, they called one episode “very troubling” — his sharing of a commentator’s quote disparaging prospective jurors as clandestine operators for the left.

headline: Why Are Younger Adults Developing This Common Heart Condition?
abstract: New research suggests that A-fib may be more prevalent, and more dangerous, in people under 65 than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: Atrial fibrillation, a common cardiac condition that raises the risk of stroke, is increasingly affecting the health of people under the age of 65.

headline: Pennsylvania Democratic Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania Democratic primary.

headline: Pennsylvania Republican Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania Republican primary.

headline: Pennsylvania 12th Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania primary election.

headline: Pennsylvania 14th Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania primary election.

headline: U.N. Calls for Inquiry Into Mass Graves at 2 Gaza Hospitals
abstract: Palestinian officials said scores of bodies had been found, some shot in the head, at one hospital after Israeli forces withdrew. Israel said it had dug up and reburied some bodies in a search for hostages.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations’ human rights office on Tuesday called for an independent investigation into two mass graves found after Israeli forces withdrew from hospitals in Gaza, including one discovered days ago over which Israeli and Palestinian authorities offered differing accounts.

headline: Pennsylvania Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Pennsylvania primary elections.

headline: Who Can Be Trusted for Retirement Advice? New Rules Strengthen Protections.
abstract: More investment professionals will be required to act in their customers’ best interest when providing advice about their retirement money.
lead_paragraph: When you walk into a financial adviser’s office, you expect them to put your best interests above all else — in the same way a doctor would, rather than, say, a car salesman. But many people don’t realize that the rules financial professionals must follow vary, depending on where they work and what products they’re selling.

headline: Our Reporter on the Fate of a Gazan University Class
abstract: These university graduates in Gaza finished training just one week before the war began. We reached out to everyone in the class WhatsApp group to find out what happened to them.
lead_paragraph: These university graduates in Gaza finished training just one week before the war began. We reached out to everyone in the class WhatsApp group to find out what happened to them.

headline: Terry Carter, Barrier-Breaking Actor and Documentarian, Dies at 95
abstract: He was a rare Black presence on “Combat!” and “The Phil Silvers Show,” then made well-regarded documentaries on luminaries like Duke Ellington and Katherine Dunham.
lead_paragraph: Terry Carter, who broke color barriers onstage and on television in the 1950s and ’60s and later produced multicultural documentaries on the jazz luminary Duke Ellington and the dancer-choreographer Katherine Dunham, died on Tuesday at his home in Midtown Manhattan. He was 95.

headline: Justice Dept. Reaches $138.7 Million Settlement Over F.B.I.’s Failures in Nassar Case
abstract: The settlement likely signifies the end of a yearslong effort by U.S. Olympic gymnasts to seek justice for early failures by the F.B.I. to investigate Lawrence G. Nassar, the team’s doctor.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Tuesday it would pay $138.7 million to resolve claims by young women and girls, including many top female gymnasts, of sexual abuse by the former U.S.A. Gymnastics doctor Lawrence G. Nassar.

headline: Italy’s New Abortion Law Is a Lesson in How Meloni Governs
abstract: The measure, largely restating existing law, shows the prime minister’s skill at reassuring her right-wing base without sacrificing her increasingly mainstream image.
lead_paragraph: At a family counseling center in Verbania, a leafy lakefront town in northern Italy, employees not only explain to women the rules for getting abortions, they have also distributed leaflets supplied by a local anti-abortion group.

headline: Woman Charged With Murder After Driving Into a Party, Killing 2 Children
abstract: The driver, Marshella Chidester, 66, was also charged with operating a vehicle while intoxicated. The crash injured 15 other people on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A woman in Michigan was charged with second-degree murder after driving her vehicle into a building where a birthday party was taking place on Saturday, killing two children and injuring 15 other people, prosecutors announced on Tuesday.

headline: David Pecker, Ex-National Enquirer Publisher, Details How He Aided Trump
abstract: Testifying for the prosecution, Mr. Pecker spoke about the mutually beneficial relationship between Donald J. Trump and the supermarket tabloid.
lead_paragraph: David Pecker, a former publisher of The National Enquirer, on Tuesday testified about the mutually beneficial relationship between Donald J. Trump and the supermarket tabloid that started decades ago and buoyed Mr. Trump’s 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: 8 Songs From the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame’s Class of 2024
abstract: Listen to soon-to-be inductees Cher, Foreigner, A Tribe Called Quest and more.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame announced its 2024 inductees. And while I find this year’s class a tad less exciting than last year’s, there are still quite a few names I was pleased to see: A Tribe Called Quest, Kool & the Gang, Ozzy Osbourne, Mary J. Blige and the artist who would have been at the top of my ballot, if I were a Rock Hall voter: Cher.*

headline: Inside the Week That Shook Columbia University
abstract: In a Washington war room, Columbia’s president, Nemat Shafik, decided to call police officers to arrest protesting students. The backlash now threatens her leadership.
lead_paragraph: Just after 2 p.m. last Wednesday, Nemat Shafik, the president of Columbia University, stepped out of an office building on Capitol Hill and into an idling black SUV.
