headline: National Enquirer’s Help for Trump Broke Norms Even in the Tabloid World
abstract: The tabloid’s parent company was fined for breaking federal election laws after spending money to buy and bury stories that could have harmed Donald J. Trump’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: The National Enquirer was more than a friendly media outlet for Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign in 2016. It was a powerful, national political weapon that was thrust into the service of a single candidate, in violation of campaign finance law.

headline: These Voters Haven’t Missed an Election in at Least 50 Years
abstract: A relatively small share of voters participate in off-year elections, and even fewer make a habit of it. Counties in Pennsylvania honor voters who show up every time.
lead_paragraph: In 1963, Leola Hubbard voted for the first time. She was 21, and she sent her absentee ballot home from college in Georgia to be counted in Montgomery County, Pa.

headline: Trump’s Trial Features Fierce Debate Over What He Can Say: 5 Takeaways
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s lawyer was harshly questioned as he tried to avoid a contempt citation. And a publisher testified about how he put The National Enquirer to work for Mr. Trump’s campaign.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s session of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial began with a heated clash between Justice Juan M. Merchan and Mr. Trump’s lead lawyer over a gag order. It ended with an insider’s look into a tabloid newspaper practice known as “catch and kill.”

headline: Adams Defends His Pick for Top Lawyer Despite City Council Opposition
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams praised Randy Mastro’s “impressive” career as he moves to hire him as New York City’s top lawyer. A majority of the Council is believed to oppose his nomination.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday said he intended to press forward with his expected nomination of Randy Mastro as New York City’s top lawyer despite mounting opposition from the City Council.

headline: Russian Court Orders American Journalist to Stay in Prison
abstract: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter, has been held for more than a year, awaiting trial on spying charges that he, his publisher and the United States vehemently reject.
lead_paragraph: A court in Moscow rejected an appeal on Tuesday by the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich against his detention, more than a year after he became the first American journalist arrested on spying charges in Russia since the Cold War.

headline: Ukraine Aid in the Light of History
abstract: Lessons of Lend-Lease for the current crisis.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday the House of Representatives finally overcame MAGA opposition and approved a new aid package for Ukraine. The Biden administration presumably had matériel ready to ship, just waiting for congressional authorization, so the effects of this legislative breakthrough will be quick.

headline: Publisher Describes Quashing Doorman’s Claim Trump Had Child Out of Wedlock
abstract: The former publisher of The National Enquirer testified at Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial that he used a so-called catch-and-kill deal to silence the doorman.
lead_paragraph: David Pecker, the former publisher of The National Enquirer, revealed during Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial on Tuesday how a team of reporters chased down a potentially explosive news tip called into the publication in 2015 that evolved into a catch-and-kill deal.

headline: Your most pressing climate questions
abstract: Introducing Ask NYT Climate, where we’ll explore how climate intersects with your everyday life.
lead_paragraph: Are traffic circles better for the environment than four-way stops? Will the oceans be too hot for fish to survive? Is green hydrogen a thing?

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘The Problem Was He Smelled Really Good’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: My high school friends restart a group text. Basic holiday wishes turn to cheering on professional accomplishments and then to art, music and book recommendations. We send memes, pictures, Spotify links. Most of us have not seen one another in nearly two decades, yet we remember the smell of each other’s childhood homes, how NPR was always playing. There is a sturdiness here, not just in our friendships enduring, but in the reminder that we existed before all this — the babies, the career ambitions, the illnesses. And that, so far, we’ve survived it all. — Kathleen Donahoe

headline: New Study Bolsters Idea of Athletic Differences Between Men and Trans Women
abstract: Research financed by the International Olympic Committee introduced new data to the unsettled and fractious debate about bans on transgender athletes.
lead_paragraph: A new study financed by the International Olympic Committee found that transgender female athletes showed greater handgrip strength — an indicator of overall muscle strength — but lower jumping ability, lung function and relative cardiovascular fitness compared with women whose gender was assigned female at birth.

headline: F.T.C. Issues Ban on Worker Noncompete Clauses
abstract: The rule would prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals, a change that could increase competition and boost wages.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday said employers could no longer, in most cases, stop their employees from going to work for rival companies.

headline: I’m a Columbia Professor. The Protests on My Campus Are Not Justice.
abstract: I do not believe that the Columbia demonstrators are driven by antisemitism, but their actions have gone way too far.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, in the music humanities class I teach at Columbia University, two students were giving an in-class presentation on the composer John Cage. His most famous piece is “4'33",” which directs us to listen in silence to surrounding noise for exactly that amount of time.

headline: 20 Years Later, a Jury Weighs Claims of Abuse at Abu Ghraib
abstract: Three men who were detained at the notorious prison in Iraq are suing a defense contractor, saying its interrogators told U.S. soldiers to “soften up” prisoners.
lead_paragraph: The journalist said he was left naked overnight in a cold prison cell with a bag over his head, chained by his wrists to a pipe.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Adam Moss
abstract: The April 23, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Adam Moss. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: To Be (Visibly) Jewish in the Ivy League
abstract: Behavior that would be scandalous if aimed at other minorities is treated as understandable or even commendable when directed at Jews.
lead_paragraph: Netanel Crispe, from Danby, Vt., is a 21-year-old junior studying American history at Yale. He is also, to his knowledge, the university’s only Hasidic undergraduate. When he chose Yale, he told me this week, he was “looking for an institution that asserted its position in terms of maintaining and protecting free expression while not backing down on its principal values.”

headline: Student Editorial Boards Rebuke College Officials for Protest Decisions
abstract: Around the nation, editorial boards at college newspapers have defended free speech and pro-Palestinian protesters in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: As protests over the Israel-Hamas war have erupted at U.S. universities in recent months, student journalists have been reporting daily on campus debates over free speech, university investments and America’s involvement in the conflict.

headline: Judge Questions Credibility of Trump’s Lawyer as Witness Details Coverup Allegations
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan is off to an ominous start for the former president, and it might not get any easier in the days ahead.
lead_paragraph: The judge questioned his defense lawyer’s credibility. The prosecution accused him of orchestrating a criminal conspiracy to influence the 2016 presidential election. And his former friend corroborated that accusation, delivering hours of gripping testimony about their secret plot to protect his campaign.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Senate Votes on Ukraine Aid
abstract: Also, a former tabloid publisher testifies against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Senate is on track to pass the $95 billion package of foreign aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. A final vote is expected in the next few hours, and President Biden plans to sign it.

headline: Biden Will Speak at Morehouse and West Point Graduations
abstract: President Biden will deliver the commencement addresses in May as U.S. support for Israel fuels protests on other campuses.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will deliver commencement addresses next month at Morehouse College in Georgia and the U.S. Military Academy at West Point at a time when anger over U.S. foreign policy has led to an eruption of student protests at several campuses.

headline: Biden Says Trump Is Responsible for ‘Nightmare’ State Abortion Laws
abstract: President Biden tied a six-week abortion ban that will soon take place in Florida to former President Donald J. Trump and Republican efforts to ban abortion nationwide.
lead_paragraph: President Biden tied a six-week abortion ban that will soon take place in Florida to former President Donald J. Trump and Republican efforts to ban abortion nationwide.

headline: Beyoncé Showed Her Hair Being Washed. Here’s Why It Matters.
abstract: In a video on Instagram, the singer provided fans a rare glimpse of her routine.
lead_paragraph: First, she gave us Disco Beyoncé. Then she gave us Cowboy Beyoncé. And now? Get-Ready-With-Me Beyoncé.

headline: ‘It Is Desolate’: China’s Glut of Unused Car Factories
abstract: Manufacturers like BYD, Tesla and Li Auto are cutting prices to move their electric cars. For gasoline-powered vehicles, the surplus of factories is even worse.
lead_paragraph: On the outskirts of Chongqing, western China’s largest city, sits a huge symbol of the country’s glut of car factories. It’s a complex of gray buildings, nearly a square mile in size. The thousands of employees who used to work there have moved on. Its crimson loading docks are closed.

headline: Howie Schwab, ESPN Researcher and Trivia Star, Dies at 63
abstract: He stepped out of his behind-the-scenes role in 2004 when he was cast as the ultimate sports know-it-all on the game show “Stump the Schwab.”
lead_paragraph: Howie Schwab, a sports nerd who parlayed his love of statistics into a long stint at ESPN that was most notable for his starring role as the ultimate trivia expert on the game show “Stump the Schwab,” died on Saturday in Aventura, Fla. He was 63.

headline: Trump’s ‘eyes and ears’ for scandal
abstract: A tabloid publisher testified how he helped Trump’s 2016 campaign.
lead_paragraph: If last week’s process of selecting jurors was a kind of prologue to the criminal trial of Donald Trump, today marked the robust beginning of the first act, complete with introduction of the plot and foreshadowing of future drama.

headline: Here’s What’s in the Foreign Aid Package That Is About to Become Law
abstract: Assistance for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan is paired with legislation to impose fresh rounds of sanctions on Iran and Russia and a measure that could lead to a ban on TikTok in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Tuesday approved a $95.3 billion foreign aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan that had been stalled in Congress for months.

headline: Fragments of Bird Flu Virus Discovered in Milk
abstract: The milk poses virtually no risk to consumers, experts said. But the finding suggests that the outbreak in dairy cows is wider than has been known.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators said on Tuesday that samples of pasteurized milk from around the country had tested positive for inactive remnants of the bird flu virus that has been infecting dairy cows.

headline: Ukraine Could Receive Some U.S. Aid ‘Within Days’
abstract: Also, the F.T.C. banned noncompete clauses. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The Senate today overwhelmingly approved a critical procedural move to tee up the final passage of the long-stalled $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. Senators are expected to pass the package as early as tonight, and President Biden said he would quickly sign it.

headline: Israel Plans to Expand ‘Humanitarian Zone’ if It Invades Rafah
abstract: An oceanside area currently crowded with displaced Gazans is among the sites being eyed for a larger safe zone for evacuees, a military official said.
lead_paragraph: If Israel were to begin an invasion in the southern Gaza city of Rafah, where a million displaced Palestinians are sheltering, an Israeli-designated “humanitarian zone” along the coast would be expanded to take in more civilians, an Israeli military official said Monday evening.

headline: In Coral Fossils, Searching for the First Glow of Bioluminescence
abstract: A new study resets the timing for the emergence of bioluminescence back to millions of years earlier than previously thought.
lead_paragraph: Bioluminescence is used throughout the animal kingdom, particularly in marine environments, to lure prey, startle predators and even act as camouflage in the surrounding light.

headline: Russian Deputy Defense Minister Is Detained on Bribery Charges
abstract: Timur Ivanov, who has long been in charge of major military construction projects and known for leading a lavish lifestyle, was held Tuesday on charges of “large scale” corruption.
lead_paragraph: A deputy minister of defense in Russia has been detained on charges of taking a “large scale” bribe, the country’s top law enforcement investigators announced on Tuesday.

headline: George Santos Said He Was Running for Congress Again. (He’s Not.)
abstract: Less than two weeks after announcing a surprise long-shot bid for a House seat on Eastern Long Island, Mr. Santos said he was no longer pursuing the seat.
lead_paragraph: In the litany of lies and half-truths told by George Santos in a fanciful journey in which he was first elected to and then expelled from Congress, the one he told about his nascent campaign for a different House seat on Long Island was not exactly a lie.

headline: At Brooklyn Seder Protest, Jewish New Yorkers Target Schumer Over Aid
abstract: Approximately 200 were arrested after pro-Palestinian Jewish groups rallied near Chuck Schumer’s home, as the Senate prepared to authorize billions of dollars in aid to Israel, Ukraine and Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: As Senator Chuck Schumer of New York prepared for a final vote to pass an aid package that would provide $26 billion to Israel and billions more to Ukraine and Taiwan, approximately 200 protesters were arrested, according to the police, after blocking traffic in his Brooklyn neighborhood on the second night of Passover to call for an end to the United States’ military support of Israel.

headline: Tennessee Passes Bill to Allow Teachers to Carry Concealed Handguns
abstract: The move came about a year after the state’s deadliest school shooting and was opposed by some of the families whose children survived the attack.
lead_paragraph: Tennessee lawmakers passed a bill on Tuesday to allow teachers and other school staff members to carry concealed handguns on school campuses. The measure, if it becomes law, would require those carrying guns to go through training and to have the approval of school officials, but parents and most other school employees would not be notified.

headline: McCormick and Casey Win Senate Primaries, Setting Up Battle in Pennsylvania
abstract: Senator Bob Casey, the Democratic incumbent, will face David McCormick, a wealthy businessman whose first run for Senate was torpedoed by former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: David McCormick won an unopposed Republican primary for Senate in Pennsylvania on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, securing the party’s nomination two years after former President Donald J. Trump torpedoed his first Senate run by backing his primary rival, the celebrity physician Dr. Mehmet Oz.

headline: Mayor Adams Pushes Out Chairwoman of Police Oversight Board
abstract: Arva Rice was asked to resign after she criticized police handling of a fatal shooting investigation and requested more money and power to investigate misconduct.
lead_paragraph: The interim chairwoman of an independent police oversight panel who had fiercely criticized the Police Department will step down at the request of Mayor Eric Adams, according to three people familiar with the matter.

headline: Clashes Over Gag Order and Tabloid Testimony in the Trump Criminal Trial
abstract: Tuesday’s session of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial began with a heated clash between Justice Juan M. Merchan and Mr. Trump’s lead lawyer over a gag order. It ended with an insider look into a tabloid newspaper practices. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives the major takeaways.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s session of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial began with a heated clash between Justice Juan M. Merchan and Mr. Trump’s lead lawyer over a gag order. It ended with an insider look into a tabloid newspaper practices. Jonah Bromwich, a criminal justice reporter at The New York Times, gives the major takeaways.

headline: ‘Mary Jane’ Review: When Parenting Means Intensive Care
abstract: Amy Herzog’s heartbreaker arrives on Broadway with Rachel McAdams as the alarmingly upbeat mother of a fearfully sick child.
lead_paragraph: Soon after Alex was born at 25 weeks, with multiple catastrophic disorders, Mary Jane’s husband, unable to cope, fled their marriage. Still, she hopes he “finds some peace, I really do.”

headline: Summer Lee, ‘Squad’ Member, Wins Democratic House Primary in Pennsylvania
abstract: A first-term representative, Ms. Lee defeated a centrist Democrat in a race that centered on her opposition to the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Representative Summer Lee, a first-term progressive Democrat, won her primary contest in western Pennsylvania on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, fending off a moderate challenger in a race that centered on her stance on the war in Gaza.

headline: Congress Passed a Bill That Could Ban TikTok. Now Comes the Hard Part.
abstract: President Biden has signed the bill to force a sale of the video app or ban it. Now the law faces court challenges, a shortage of qualified buyers and Beijing’s hostility.
lead_paragraph: A bill that would force a sale of TikTok by its Chinese owner, ByteDance — or ban it outright — was passed by the Senate on Tuesday and signed into law Wednesday by President Biden.

headline: How the Senate Voted on Foreign Aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
abstract: The measure, which includes a provision on the sale or ban of TikTok, had wide bipartisan support.
lead_paragraph: The measure, which includes a provision on the sale or ban of TikTok, had wide bipartisan support.

headline: Bread Spread
abstract: Step into the house of mirrors with Jeffrey Martinovic.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Seder Is About Family, Food, Freedom. And Now, It’s Also About the War.
abstract: At Passover Seders, many families addressed the war in Gaza. In some cases, generations clashed and tensions arose. “That’s the Jewish way,” said one host.
lead_paragraph: Bonnie Rosenfeld had 38 people crowded into her home in Rockaway, N.J., on Monday night. She has hosted Passover Seders for years, but none that felt quite like this. She wanted to address “the elephant in the room” up front.

headline: Three Takeaways From the Pennsylvania Primaries
abstract: A liberal Pittsburgh-area congresswoman turned away a centrist challenger, Nikki Haley kept ringing up votes against Donald Trump, and a Senate race began in earnest.
lead_paragraph: With the 2024 primary season entering the homestretch — and the presidential matchup already set — hundreds of thousands of Pennsylvanians cast their ballots on Tuesday in Senate and House contests as well as for president and local races.

headline: During a Chaotic Day, Columbia’s President Fights for Her Job
abstract: Nemat Shafik, the university’s leader, met privately with faculty members, who could soon decide to admonish her. Columbia’s board, though, made its support clear.
lead_paragraph: Nemat Shafik, Columbia University’s besieged president, faced skeptics on Wednesday in a meeting with the university senate that could vote to censure her over her handling of protests on the Upper Manhattan campus.

headline: Man Who Struck Officer With Pole on Jan. 6 Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison
abstract: The man, David Joseph Gietzen, had failed to show up in court and became a fugitive after a jury found him guilty of committing five felonies during the January 2021 attack on the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: A North Carolina man who was declared a fugitive after being found guilty last year of assaulting police officers during the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol was sentenced on Tuesday to six years in prison, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department said.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: U.S. Senate approves long-stalled foreign aid.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Senate voted overwhelmingly last night to approve a long-stalled $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, sending it to President Biden for his signature and ending months of uncertainty about whether the U.S. would continue to back Kyiv against Russian aggression.

headline: Blinken Goes to China With Potential Trouble on Horizon
abstract: The secretary of state’s visit comes as Democrats and Republicans are vying to appear tougher on China.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken arrived in China on Wednesday to try to preserve the recent and delicate stabilization of ties between the United States and China, as tensions over trade, territorial disputes and national security threaten to derail relations again.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Trapped and Starving, 2 Families Try to Keep Their Children Alive
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 24, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You can find malnutrition in every house and tent.”

headline: Corrections: April 24, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Weekday, Month Date, Year.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about a lack of evidence to support accusations tying many U.N. workers to Hamas described incorrectly what a review said about Israeli concerns about UNRWA employees. The review said that Israel had not flagged concerns about agency employees based on staff lists since 2011, not that Israel had not flagged any concerns about employees since 2011.

headline: Late Night Tackles Trump’s Gag Order Hearing
abstract: “Has Trump ever considered paying himself hush money?” Jordan Klepper asked on Tuesday’s “Daily Show.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: hardscrabble
abstract: This word has appeared in 31 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word hardscrabble has appeared in 31 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 13 in “How Jesmyn Ward Is Reimagining Southern Literature” by Imani Perry:

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,040
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 318
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Breaking Down New Rules About ‘Forever Chemicals’
abstract: Lisa Friedman, who covers climate change, discussed the fight to regulate toxic chemicals found in nearly half of America’s tap water.
lead_paragraph: Cookware. Dental floss. Shampoo.

headline: Tech in the Classroom
abstract: Is there a problem with screens in schools?
lead_paragraph: A recent Times Opinion piece argues that we should “get tech out of the classroom before it’s too late.”

headline: New York City’s Everlasting Scaffolding
abstract: Why the protective barriers over sidewalks stay up for so long.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump returned to the criminal courthouse at 100 Centre Street last week, a familiar feature of the New York City streetscape was there to greet him: a steel-and-plywood parapet the color of a fake Christmas tree, propped over the sidewalk.

headline: A Gun-Toting Crab Confronts a Fiendishly Tough Video Game Genre
abstract: With a rare suite of accessibility options for the Soulslike genre, Another Crab’s Treasure challenges the idea that difficulty is immutable.
lead_paragraph: Upon entering a cavernous room, its barely lit cobblestones reflecting a sickly green, you are charged by a towering beast that can be overcome only through a punishing sequence of precise dodges and parrying. The price for failure is severe. It is a lengthy journey to return to this spot, and one slip-up is all it takes to send you hurtling back.

headline: This Town Had a Reputation Problem. Premier League Soccer Changed Things.
abstract: Having a team in the world’s richest sports competition might alter how people think of Luton, a place long dogged by a ramshackle image and links to extremism.
lead_paragraph: As the announcement trilled out over Kenilworth Road, the jumble of rusted metal and peeling paint that Luton Town F.C. calls home, the tone started to shift. At the start of the sentence, it was little more than the traditional polite welcome to the stadium for that evening’s visiting team, Manchester City.

headline: A Celebrated Artist Finds Joy in a Return to New York
abstract: In his biggest exhibit since a 2013 retrospective at the Guggenheim, Christopher Wool has created his own show in a unique space.
lead_paragraph: The artist Christopher Wool was dressed in a black button-down shirt, matching pants and white sneakers. His long, wiry white hair — pulled back in a ponytail — contrasted nicely with his black-framed glasses.

headline: Tracing the Long, Winding Path of an Ancient Roman Aqueduct
abstract: The Aqua Marcia was the longest of the city’s aqueducts, running nearly 60 miles from its source in the countryside to the heart of ancient Rome. The author followed its course, above and below ground.
lead_paragraph: The stone arches looped solemnly over their shadows, some teetering above the grass, some sinking into it. It was a dazzling January morning, and I was standing in the Park of the Aqueducts, about 20 minutes by metro from central Rome. Here, the ruined arcades of six of the 11 aqueducts that once supplied the Eternal City with an astonishing volume of water — by some counts double the per capita water allotment of a typical 21st-century American city — have been preserved.

headline: Signs Suggest That Invasion of Rafah Is All but Inevitable
abstract: Israel says an assault on Gaza’s southernmost city is vital to dismantling Hamas and has proposed evacuating civilians. But more than a million people have taken refuge in the city.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of delays, negotiations and distractions, Israel appeared to hint this week that its assault of Rafah — a city crowded with displaced persons above ground and riddled with Hamas tunnels below — was all but inevitable.

headline: Could Eating Less Help You Live Longer?
abstract: Calorie restriction and intermittent fasting both increase longevity in animals, aging experts say. Here’s what that means for you.
lead_paragraph: If you put a lab mouse on a diet, cutting the animal’s caloric intake by 30 to 40 percent, it will live, on average, about 30 percent longer. The calorie restriction, as the intervention is technically called, can’t be so extreme that the animal is malnourished, but it should be aggressive enough to trigger some key biological changes.

headline: Manuel Mathieu Finds His Way Through Haitian History, on Canvas
abstract: The young artist interweaves the personal and the political, asking such questions as, “How can we build when we are inhabited by rage?”
lead_paragraph: Before this month, Manuel Mathieu had not had a solo show at a major institution in the United States. Now, Mathieu, a 37-year-old born in Haiti, has not one, but two, exhibitions at the Museum of Contemporary Art North Miami (MOCA North Miami): “World Discovered Under Other Skies” and “Dwelling on the Invisible.”

headline: A Mississippi Exhibition Takes on a Provocative Topic
abstract: A 183-canvas painting by Noah Saterstrom explores mental illness, his family’s struggle with it — and the state’s response to those impaired by it.
lead_paragraph: If museum exhibitions are meant to inspire and unsettle, the Mississippi Museum of Art has embraced its mission wholeheartedly, shining a light on a topic that is still largely taboo: mental illness and the state’s response to it.

headline: Art Seeks Enlightenment in Darkness
abstract: Many artists are dimming the lights of their museum shows, for a mix of symbolic and spiritual reasons.
lead_paragraph: To enter Kehinde Wiley’s show “An Archaeology of Silence” is to step into darkness, where only the art itself seems to emit light. The space feels somewhere between a crypt and a cathedral, featuring paintings and bronze sculptures of reclining Black bodies, spread out in repose or entombed like corpses, that appear to glow from within.

headline: Former Boeing Manager Says Workers Mishandled Parts to Meet Deadlines
abstract: Merle Meyers, who left Boeing last year after a 30-year career, said he was speaking publicly about his experience because he loved the company “fiercely.”
lead_paragraph: Two framed documents from a long career at Boeing hang side by side in Merle Meyers’s home: A certificate from 2022 that thanks him for three decades of service. And a letter he received months later reprimanding him for his performance.

headline: If You Read One Romance This Spring, Make It This One
abstract: Our romance columnist recommends three terrific new books, but the one she loves most is Cat Sebastian’s “You Should Be So Lucky.”
lead_paragraph: Spring! There’s no better time of year for a baseball romance. We’ll wind up the column with a much-anticipated book by Cat Sebastian, but we lead off with KT Hoffman’s endearing and tender new novel, THE PROSPECTS (Dial, 346 pp., paperback, $18).

headline: A Breakout Spanish Novel About Class and Trans Identity Comes to the U.S.
abstract: Alana S. Portero’s debut, “Bad Habit,” follows one woman’s coming-of-age in a blue-collar Madrid neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Madrid Me Mata — or Madrid Murders Me, to replicate the alliterative Spanish — was the name of a short-lived but iconic magazine from the mid-1980s that chronicled the explosion of free expression in Spain’s capital during the post-Franco era. People danced, talked and partied to exhaustion while a deadly heroin epidemic emerged as the dark underside to the art, sex and music. The all-consuming intensity of life in the city seemed to have the power to kill its residents, figuratively and literally.

headline: How a Virtual Assistant Taught Me to Appreciate Busywork
abstract: A new category of apps promises to relieve parents of drudgery, with an assist from A.I. But a family’s grunt work is more human, and valuable, than it seems.
lead_paragraph: I recently downloaded a virtual assistant that promised to ease the burdens of modern parenthood. The app is called Yohana, and it offered to handle a pile of tasks on my behalf. It suggested enlisting a professional to wash my windows, scheduling a lesson with a “private sports coach” or planning a “stylish and sustainable” Earth Day party featuring décor, recipes, activities and party favors, none of which interested me. Finally it volunteered to produce a “chef-curated menu” for Passover.

headline: A ‘Wonderland’ Adventure in the Bronx
abstract: A show at the New York Botanical Garden, inspired by Lewis Carroll’s books, will explore his fictional and real worlds through plants, art and artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Rabbits appear frequently at the New York Botanical Garden. The one that the public will soon see there, however, isn’t a typical little brown cottontail. About 12 feet tall, this creature will hold a pocket watch and have fur made of cream-colored Sedum foliage, a waistcoat of yellowy-green Sedum and a maroon jacket of Alternanthera leaves.

headline: Two Lawsuits, in Texas and Idaho, Highlight Fight Over Emergency Medicine Law
abstract: Federal trial judges in Texas and Idaho came to opposite conclusions in a battle between conservative states and the U.S. government over limits on abortion access.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks after the Supreme Court dismantled a constitutional right to abortion in 2022 and returned the issue of access to the states, a new series of court battles began.

headline: The Supreme Court Has Already Botched the Trump Immunity Case
abstract: The court’s delay may have stripped citizens of the criminal justice system’s most effective mechanism for determining disputed facts: a trial.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision to hear oral arguments in Donald Trump’s immunity-appeal case on Thursday may appear to advance the rule of law. After all, few, if anyone, think that a majority of the court will conclude that a former president is completely immune from federal criminal liability.

headline: Wanted: An Executive to Repair Boeing
abstract: The plane maker, which is searching for a new chief executive, is likely to consider a small number of people, including several former Boeing executives.
lead_paragraph: When Boeing named Stephanie Pope to the new position of chief operating officer in December, the move was widely viewed as a sign that she might succeed the company’s chief executive, Dave Calhoun, in the next few years.

headline: Inside MAGA’s Plan to Take Over America
abstract: “Finish What We Started,” by the journalist Isaac Arnsdorf, reports from the front lines of the right-wing movement’s strategy to gain power, from the local level on up.
lead_paragraph: Despite Steve Bannon’s Wall Street pedigree, his taste for five-star hotels and billionaire-owned yachts, he is truly a man of the people — that, at least, is the impression he strains to convey each time he appears in “Finish What We Started: The MAGA Movement’s Ground War to End Democracy,” a new book by Isaac Arnsdorf, a journalist at The Washington Post.

headline: The Meta-morphosis of Mark Zuckerberg
abstract: The robotic nerd depicted in “The Social Network” has turned into the kinder, more accessible face of Silicon Valley. What’s going on?
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to Meta’s first-quarter earnings report this week, a video image of Mark Zuckerberg suddenly started going viral.

headline: Why Indoor Soccer is the Beautiful Game at Its Best
abstract: In its flamboyance and entertainment factor, it embodies the spirit of street soccer, the real roots of the game.
lead_paragraph: Today, soccer enjoys a presence in America that the sport has never had before: Lionel Messi now plays here, and the 2026 World Cup will take place in 11 U.S. cities. “Ted Lasso” and “Welcome to Wrexham” have made soccer popular television. Yet for all that, it sometimes feels as if there’s no “there” there. The two most watched leagues — the Premier League and Liga MX — are based in England and Mexico. Thousands of people turn up for their local Major League Soccer, National Women’s Soccer League or minor-league teams, but they perform sanitized impersonations of European and Latin-American soccer culture, where teams tend to be rooted in their cities’ history. The sport’s prized stars, teams and tournaments have been purchased, backed and exploited by autocratic rulers, private equity firms and oligarchs. It can sometimes feel as if the romance of the game is slipping away, replaced by an increasingly plastic product.

headline: A Dangerous Game Is Underway in Asia
abstract: The new alliance structure Washington is pursuing in Asia won’t guarantee peace and stability — and may raise the risk of stumbling into a conflict.
lead_paragraph: This month, President Biden threw one of the most lavish state dinners in Washington’s recent memory. Celebrities and billionaires flocked to the White House to dine in honor of Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan, posing for photos in front of an elaborate display of Japanese fans. Jeff Bezos dropped by; Paul Simon provided the entertainment.

headline: ‘Orlando’ Review: A Virginia Woolf Fantasy That Plays With Gender
abstract: In this revival of Sarah Ruhl’s adaptation of the Woolf novel, now starring Taylor Mac, the flashes of comedy can’t make up for the loss of poetry.
lead_paragraph: There’s a slight pause and a knowingly raised eyebrow — enough to provoke laughter from the audience — when the title character of “Orlando” begins to introduce himself with this line: “He — for there could be no doubt of his sex.”

headline: For Maxine Hong Kingston, Age Is Just Time Going By
abstract: At 83, the novelist and professor emerita at the University of California, Berkeley, likes to “go into the new.”
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, the writer Maxine Hong Kingston explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.

headline: Laufey, Gen Z’s Pop Jazz Icon, Sings for the Anxious Generation
abstract: The Gen Z ‘it girl’ singer on the painful push and pull of young love.
lead_paragraph: Laufey, the 25-year-old singer-songwriter, has risen to prominence by taking the trials of today’s dating world — casual relationships, no labels and seemingly endless swiping on apps — and turning them into timeless love songs.

headline: Biden’s Deep Miscalculation on Israel and Gaza
abstract: Nicholas Kristof asks: Where has our moral president gone?
lead_paragraph: The war in Gaza has become President Biden’s war, the Times Opinion columnist Nicholas Kristof argues in a recent column criticizing what he describes as a moral failing on Biden’s part. In the following conversation, the Opinion editor Sarah Wildman asks Nick to elaborate on where he thinks Biden went wrong and what he hopes the president will do to try to end the conflict in the Middle East

headline: Libraries Hold Their Breath and Await the Budget
abstract: Five renovated branches are waiting to reopen, if the system receives sufficient funding.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out why five newly renovated branch libraries in New York City have yet to reopen. We’ll also hear what Mayor Eric Adams said in defending a nominee who worked for Rudolph Giuliani when he was mayor.

headline: ‘Kharkiv Is Unbreakable’: A Battered City Carries On
abstract: For residents of Ukraine’s second-largest city, daily Russian attacks have escalated fears but have not brought life to a standstill.
lead_paragraph: The espresso machine was warming up and Liliia Korneva was counting cash at the coffee shop in Kharkiv where she works when a powerful Russian bomb detonated nearby, sending up a deafening explosion and knocking her to the floor.

headline: Why Losing Political Power Now Feels Like ‘Losing Your Country’
abstract: It is difficult, if not impossible, to attempt to counter polarization at a time when partisan sectarianism is intense and pervasive.
lead_paragraph: Is partisan hostility so deeply enmeshed in American politics that it cannot be rooted out?

headline: $700,000 Homes in Kentucky, New Hampshire and Minnesota
abstract: A 1926 brick house in Lexington, a two-bedroom condominium in Lyme and a Tudor Revival home in Minneapolis.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Ashland Park, less than a mile from the University of Kentucky and within a 15-minute walk of several university athletic fields. Woodland Park, which has an indoor aquatic center and a skate park, and a shopping center with a florist, an ice-cream parlor and a number of restaurants are also within walking distance.

headline: How Do You Turn ‘Urban Decay’ Into a Garden?
abstract: Apiary Studio in Philadelphia works with whatever a site holds to create landscapes that match the city’s aesthetic: “gritty, punk, improvised, layered with history.”
lead_paragraph: “Don’t throw it ‘away.’ There is no ‘away.’”

headline: How Should Colleges Handle Student Protests?
abstract: Where is the line between protecting students’ right to freedom of expression and ensuring their safety and ability to get an education?
lead_paragraph: Since the Oct. 7 surprise attack in which Hamas killed 1,200 Israelis and took hostages — around 100 of whom remain in Gaza — and the start of an Israeli counteroffensive in Gaza that has killed over 33,000 Palestinians, colleges and universities across the United States have been struggling to handle the debate and protests over the war.

headline: Supreme Court Appears Sharply Divided in Emergency Abortion Case
abstract: The justices weighed whether a federal law aimed at protecting access to emergency medical care superseded Idaho’s near-total abortion ban.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court appeared sharply divided on Wednesday over whether federal law should allow doctors to perform emergency abortions in states with near-total bans on the procedure, in a case that could determine access to abortion in emergency rooms across the country.

headline: What Directors Love About Nicole Kidman
abstract: As the actress receives a life achievement award from the American Film Institute this week, five filmmakers discuss what makes her work so singular.
lead_paragraph: “We come to this place for magic,” Nicole Kidman says in the well-known AMC Theaters preshow advertisement. And who could better welcome back audiences to experience movies on the big screen than an acclaimed artist who’s illuminated stories across all genres?

headline: The Humbling of Marjorie Taylor Greene
abstract: She has, in very little time, undermined the influence of her party’s entire right flank.
lead_paragraph: In our Trump-era politics, there’s always the question of how crazy is too crazy — how disruptive and extreme an elected official can get before becoming so embarrassing that members of her own team feel compelled to abandon her?

headline: High Borrowing Costs Have Some Democrats Urging Biden to Pressure the Fed
abstract: Polls show voters are angry about costs, like mortgages, and worried they will stay high if the president wins re-election.
lead_paragraph: Sky-high mortgage rates and other elevated borrowing costs are pinching American consumers ahead of the 2024 election, threatening President Biden’s chances at a second term.

headline: Aid to Ukraine Is on the Way. Here’s How It Might Help.
abstract: Weapons from the support package, considered “a lifeline” for Ukraine’s military, could be arriving on the battlefield within days.
lead_paragraph: Now that the Senate has approved a nearly $61 billion aid package to Ukraine, and President Biden has signed it, desperately needed American weapons could be arriving on the battlefield within days.

headline: Skepticism Is Healthy, but in Medicine, It Can Be Dangerous
abstract: Skepticism and distrust of health practitioners is on the rise. How are doctors supposed to restore patient trust?
lead_paragraph: I arrived at the hospital one recent morning to find a team of doctors gathered just outside a patient room. The patient was struggling — his breaths too fast and too shallow. For days we had been trying to walk the line between treating the pain caused by his rapidly growing cancer and prolonging his life.

headline: Arizona House Votes to Repeal 1864 Abortion Law
abstract: The almost-complete ban on abortions in the state could go into effect as soon as June 8 if the State Legislature does not repeal it, the state’s attorney general said.
lead_paragraph: Arizona took a major step on Wednesday toward scrapping an 1864 law banning abortion, when three Republican lawmakers in the state House of Representatives broke ranks with their party and voted with Democrats to repeal the ban.

headline: Meta’s A.I. Assistant Is Fun to Use, but It Can’t Be Trusted
abstract: Despite Mark Zuckerberg’s hope for the chatbot to be the smartest, it struggles with facts, numbers and web search.
lead_paragraph: In the last few days, you may have noticed something new inside Meta’s apps, including Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp: an artificially intelligent chatbot.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Tonga?
abstract: Can you find Tonga on a map? What else do you know about this Pacific island nation with about 106,000 people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Tonga on a map? What else do you know about this Pacific island nation with about 106,000 people?

headline: Is $60 Billion Enough to Save Ukraine?
abstract: Congress approved a new aid package after months of delay, potentially throwing the country a lifeline in its war with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers approved a giant new tranche of support for Ukraine late last night after a tortured passage through the U.S. Congress, where it was nearly derailed by right-wing resistance in the House.

headline: What a TikTok Ban Could Actually Mean, and More
abstract: Plus, clashes over Donald Trump’s gag order.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Horses Run Loose Through Central London in Surreal Spectacle
abstract: A number of runaway army horses galloped through London on Wednesday morning, causing alarm and injuring pedestrians. All of the animals were eventually recovered.
lead_paragraph: Several runaway military horses galloped through the streets of London on Wednesday morning, alarming pedestrians, sideswiping cars and buses, and turning an ordinary rush hour into a frightening, almost surreal spectacle.

headline: TikTok’s Pro-China Tilt
abstract: A bill that will force the app’s Chinese owners to sell will soon become law.
lead_paragraph: The debate over TikTok has shifted very quickly. Just a few months ago, it seemed unlikely that the U.S. government would force ByteDance, the Chinese company that owns TikTok, to sell it. The platform is popular, and Congress rarely passes legislation aimed at a single company.

headline: After U.N. Report, Germany Says It Will Resume Funding for UNRWA
abstract: The announcement was likely to further strain Germany’s longstanding ties with Israel, which have deteriorated because of differences over the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Germany said on Wednesday that it would resume funding for the main U.N. agency aiding Palestinians in Gaza, known as UNRWA, after an independent review found that Israel had not provided evidence of an allegation that led many donor nations to withdraw support for the agency.

headline: Let This Breakfast Change Your Life
abstract: A simple miso-roasted salmon, part of a traditional Japanese spread, is both sustenance and self-care.
lead_paragraph: The chef Shota Nakajima goes to bed early and wakes up early. He walks his dog for an hour and a half every day. He doesn’t drink anymore, thriving on a diet of rice with grilled fish and pickles for most of his meals, especially breakfast. Getting to this place in life, a state of peace and equilibrium, was one of the hardest parts of transitioning from his 20s to his 30s, Nakajima says, but he is happier than he has ever been — as he describes it, “You know, just chilling, cranking.”

headline: Athens Turns Orange Under a Saharan Dust Cloud
abstract: In Photos
lead_paragraph: The skies above Athens turned orange on Tuesday as clouds of dust from the Sahara blew north, casting an eerie glow over the Greek capital’s landmarks.

headline: Bird Flu Outbreak in Cattle May Have Begun Months Earlier Than Thought
abstract: A single spillover, from a bird to a cow, led to the infections, a review of genetic data has found.
lead_paragraph: The bird flu outbreak in American dairy cattle may have begun in January, or even as early as December, a new analysis of genetic data suggests.

headline: Myanmar’s Junta Recaptures Town That Was a Significant Gain for Rebels
abstract: Resistance soldiers were forced to leave Myawaddy, a key trading center on the border with Thailand, weeks after capturing it.
lead_paragraph: The Myanmar junta has recaptured the town of Myawaddy, an important trading hub on the border with Thailand, reversing a key victory for resistance soldiers who seized it nearly two weeks ago then were forced to withdraw, a spokesman for the rebel Karen National Union said on Wednesday.

headline: Who Stands to Gain from a TikTok Ban
abstract: The Senate has finally passed a law that could bar the  video-sharing app in the U.S., leaving some tech giants in pole position to profit — or pounce.
lead_paragraph: The countdown to TikTok disappearing from the United States is about to start.

headline: Boeing Loses $355 Million in Latest Quarter
abstract: The manufacturer has had to slow production of its popular 737 Max planes after a hole blew open on a jet during an Alaska Airlines flight in January.
lead_paragraph: Boeing on Wednesday reported a $355 million loss for the first three months of the year, as it deals with a quality crisis stemming from a Jan. 5 flight during which a panel blew off one of its planes.

headline: New Nutrition Guidelines Put Less Sugar and Salt on the Menu for School Meals
abstract: The Agriculture Department finalized a new rule to bring the meals more in line with federal dietary standards.
lead_paragraph: School meals will soon contain less salt and sugar, but can still include chocolate milk, under new nutrition guidelines released by the Biden administration.

headline: Cicadas Are Emerging Now. How Do They Know When to Come Out?
abstract: Scientists are making computer models to better understand how the mysterious insects emerge collectively after more than a decade underground.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, millions of Americans looked up at the sky to witness a total eclipse. Now, another cyclical marvel has arrived, this time at our feet. Trillions of noisy, red-eyed insects called cicadas are emerging from the earth after more than a decade of feeding on tree roots.

headline: Starbucks and Union Restart Contract Talks After Bitter Standoff
abstract: The company and Workers United, which represents more than 10,000 of the chain’s employees, broke off negotiation nearly a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Starbucks and the union that represents over 10,000 of its workers returned to the bargaining table on Wednesday for the first time in nearly a year, a pivotal moment in the yearslong battle between the coffee giant and its organized workers.

headline: Can I Ask My Mother-in-Law Who My Wife’s Biological Father Is?
abstract: Although his wife has long maintained that she doesn’t want to know the identity of her birth father, a reader is tempted to find out on her behalf.
lead_paragraph: Ever since my wife was a girl, she was close to her stepfather, a lovely man who has now passed away. She always said he was her one and only father, and she had no interest in knowing who her biological father was. Recently, though, she hinted to me that she would like to know her biological father’s identity. But time is running out: We are in our 60s and her mother is approaching 90. Her mother is a forceful woman, and she has always been frank that it was her intention to become a single mother. She never mentioned the biological father’s name — not least because it was a badge of honor for my wife to proclaim that she had “only one dad.” I intend to ask my mother-in-law who the man was, but I worry about upsetting the family narrative. Thoughts?

headline: We’re Adding New Songs to Our California Soundtrack
abstract: Our playlist reflects the breadth and diversity of the Golden State.
lead_paragraph: As a midweek pick-me-up, today I’m sharing some music for your listening pleasure.

headline: Every Tech Tool in the Classroom Should Be Ruthlessly Evaluated
abstract: Screens in K-12 schools need ‘a hard reset.’
lead_paragraph: Educational technology in schools is sometimes described as a wicked problem — a term coined by a design and planning professor, Horst Rittel, in the 1960s, meaning a problem for which even defining the scope of the dilemma is a struggle, because it has so many interconnected parts that never stop moving.

headline: Biden Says Weapons Will Flow to Ukraine Within Hours as He Signs Aid Bill
abstract: The $95.3 billion measure comes after months of gridlock in Congress that put the centerpiece of President Biden’s foreign policy in jeopardy.
lead_paragraph: President Biden said on Wednesday that weapons would begin to flow to Ukraine “within hours” as he signed a $95.3 billion package of aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan, reaffirming U.S. support for Kyiv after months of congressional gridlock put the centerpiece of the White House’s foreign policy in jeopardy.

headline: Australian Journalist Says She Was Pushed Out of India
abstract: Avani Dias said that she had been denied a visa renewal for weeks because of her reporting on the Sikh separatist movement. Indian officials disputed her account.
lead_paragraph: A senior journalist with Australia’s national broadcaster says she was effectively pushed out of India after her reporting on Sikh separatism angered the Indian government, accusing the authorities of hindering her from going to events, seeking to have her reporting taken down and refusing for weeks to renew her visa.

headline: Automatic Refunds and No More Hidden Fees: D.O.T. Sets New Rules for Airlines
abstract: The Transportation Department issued new requirements on refunds when flights are canceled or delayed and on revealing “junk” fees before booking. Here’s what passengers can expect.
lead_paragraph: The Transportation Department on Wednesday announced new rules taking aim at two of the most difficult and annoying issues in air travel: obtaining refunds and encountering surprise fees late in the booking process.

headline: ‘Thunder Run’: Behind Lawmakers’ Secretive Push to Pass the TikTok Bill
abstract: A tiny group of lawmakers huddled in private about a year ago, aiming to keep the discussions away from TikTok lobbyists while bulletproofing a bill that could ban the app.
lead_paragraph: Just over a year ago, lawmakers displayed a rare show of bipartisanship when they grilled Shou Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, about the video app’s ties to China. Their harsh questioning suggested that Washington was gearing up to force the company to sever ties with its Chinese owner — or even ban the app.

headline: ‘Oh, Mary!,’ a Surprise Downtown Hit, Will Play Broadway This Summer
abstract: Cole Escola’s madcap comedy about the former first lady Mary Todd Lincoln will begin performances in June.
lead_paragraph: “Oh, Mary!,” an outrageously madcap comedy that imagines the former first lady Mary Todd Lincoln as an oft-inebriated chanteuse-wannabe, will transfer to Broadway this summer after becoming a surprise hit downtown.

headline: ‘So Far From Ukraine’: A Princely Dancer Finds a Home in Miami
abstract: Stanislav Olshanskyi has had to battle homesickness and adjust to Miami City Ballet’s style: quick, light, constantly in motion. He’s also the prince in “Swan Lake.”
lead_paragraph: “Imagine you’ve been rushing through the forest for hours,” the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky called out to Stanislav Olshanskyi as he ran across an airy ballet studio in Miami Beach. Olshanskyi, playing a prince, was searching for the woman he has been duped into betraying. “You are just now realizing the consequences of what you’ve done,” Ratmansky said. “How does it feel?”

headline: Turner Prize Shortlist Leans In to Artists’ Identities
abstract: This year’s four nominees are Claudette Johnson, Jasleen Kaur, Pio Abad and Delaine Le Bas, whose works draw on personal history and cultural interpretations.
lead_paragraph: Claudette Johnson, a Black British visual artist who is experiencing a late-career renaissance, and Jasleen Kaur, an artist whose installations have explored her upbringing in a Scottish Sikh community, are among the nominees for this year’s Turner Prize, the prestigious British art award.

headline: Robert Kraft’s Fight Against Antisemitism Began Long Before Oct. 7
abstract: The New England Patriots owner said this week that he was “no longer comfortable supporting” Columbia University, his alma mater, which has been disrupted by protests.
lead_paragraph: Protests at Columbia University have attracted national headlines, prompted congressional hearings and led to the arrest of more than 100 students. This week, the New England Patriots owner, Robert K. Kraft, one of the school’s most famous and wealthiest graduates, stepped into the fray.

headline: Why Is This Seder Unlike All Other Seders?
abstract: The dinner parties held by Shtick, a pop-up series celebrating Jewish culture, draw out New York’s influencers, artists, designers and celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Why was this Seder different from all other Seders?

headline: Homeless Georgians Could Face Hurdles to Voting Under New Legislation
abstract: A provision in an election bill would bar homeless voters from receiving mail-in ballots and election information at shelters or other temporary addresses.
lead_paragraph: After more than 40 years of struggling with drug addiction and homelessness, Barry Dupree has a distinct memory of a milestone in his recovery: casting a ballot in the 2020 election.

headline: ‘It’s Just Agony’: A Suburban Family Mourns Nearly 200 Gaza Relatives
abstract: Adam and Ola Abo Sheriah absorb a loss few of their friends and neighbors in New Jersey can imagine, and scramble to help surviving family members in Gaza while trying to get their kids to school on time.
lead_paragraph: The call came in around 4 p.m., while Adam Abo Sheriah was still at work in his pharmacy in New Jersey.  The voice on the other end was sobbing.

headline: Inside the Crisis at NPR
abstract: Listeners are tuning out. Sponsorship revenue has dipped. A diversity push has generated internal turmoil. Can America’s public radio network turn things around?
lead_paragraph: NPR employees tuned in for a pivotal meeting late last year for a long-awaited update on the future of the public radio network.

headline: A Classy (but not Fussy) Clam Dinner
abstract: Lidey Heuck’s one-pot recipe for littleneck clams with cherry tomatoes and pearl couscous feels restaurant-fancy but is weeknight-easy.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Mia here, filling in for Melissa today and Monday. I hope your week has been sunny.

headline: 7 Books on Navigating Grief
abstract: Psychologists, counselors and other experts share the titles they recommend most.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Luttrell is well acquainted with grief. The bereavement coordinator supports families that are navigating a child’s terminal illness at St. Jude’s Children’s Hospital in Memphis.

headline: This Is What a Miracle Drug Looks Like, and It Costs Only $5 to Make
abstract: The effects of semaglutide drugs won’t be just cosmetic.
lead_paragraph: Last year was called the year of Ozempic, though it was also a year of Ozempic backlash and Ozempic shortages, which could persist for years. Even so, we appear very far from a peak for GLP-1 drugs, like Ozempic and Wegovy, which are powered by a molecule called semaglutide, and Mounjaro, which uses its cousin tirzepatide. It seems possible to imagine a future in which almost everyone is taking some variety of GLP-1 drug, and with a pretty good reason to do so.

headline: The International Date Line Is ‘Pretty Arbitrary.’ Here’s Why.
abstract: That squiggly line through the Pacific where days begin and end has no legal authority and technically doesn’t exist.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift flies to Las Vegas from Japan and gains several hours. Hong Kong’s stock market closes as London’s opens. A clock on a remote Pacific island strikes midnight 24 hours early on a politician’s order.

headline: What to Make of the ‘Zombie Vote’ Against Donald Trump
abstract: Votes for dropout candidates, such as Nikki Haley, have been features of past election cycles, too.
lead_paragraph: Votes for dropout candidates, such as Nikki Haley, have been features of past election cycles, too.

headline: Is It Wrong for Public School Principals to Send Their Kids to Private School?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on double standards — and possible hypocrisy — among educators.
lead_paragraph: One of our friends is a principal at a charter high school for underprivileged kids. My youngest son goes to public school with a wonderful principal. Between the two principals, they have five children. All five of these children go to private high school. I have never asked the principals to explain their reasoning, but it seems hypocritical. It’s fine for them to work there, but not fine enough to send their children there? — Name Withheld

headline: Business Groups Sue to Stop F.T.C. From Banning Noncompete Clauses
abstract: The lawsuits contend the F.T.C. does not have the authority to prohibit companies from limiting their employees’ ability to work for rivals.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce fulfilled its promise to sue the Federal Trade Commission over a ban on agreements that prevent workers from leaving a company for a rival, arguing in a lawsuit filed Wednesday that the agency overstepped its authority.

headline: Joe Biden and the Israel-Gaza War
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Nicholas Kristof. Also: Donald Trump, “unprecedented”; tech in school; how sorrow changes us; California’s property taxes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Elon Musk Clashes With Australian Court Over Violent Videos on X
abstract: Mr. Musk’s defiance over removing content is testing the boundaries of international legal systems.
lead_paragraph: An Australian court on Wednesday extended an injunction ordering the social media platform X to remove videos depicting the recent stabbing of a bishop, setting the country’s judicial system up for a clash with the company’s owner, Elon Musk, who has denounced the court’s order as censorship.

headline: RZA of Wu-Tang Clan Has a Beef With Meat
abstract: The rapper, producer, actor and vegan talks about the connections between meat and masculinity, animal welfare and the environment.
lead_paragraph: RZA, the leader of the groundbreaking hip-hop collective Wu-Tang Clan, is a producer, rapper, writer, director, film scorer and actor. He is also a promoter of a meatless lifestyle.

headline: Senate Committee Investigates Ozempic and Wegovy Costs
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders is pressing the drugmaker Novo Nordisk for details on its pricing of the popular diabetes and weight loss medications.
lead_paragraph: A Senate committee is investigating the prices that Novo Nordisk charges for its blockbuster medications, Ozempic and Wegovy, which are highly effective at treating diabetes and obesity but carry steep price tags.

headline: What’s the Best Way to Salt Scrambled Eggs?
abstract: Paying close attention to timing can help you avoid watery eggs. Kenji López-Alt explains why.
lead_paragraph: In this column, Ask Kenji, the cookbook author Kenji López-Alt answers your questions. This week, he discusses the surprising science of salting scrambles.

headline: Binance Founder Should Get 3 Years in Prison, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Lawyers for Changpeng Zhao, the founder of the crypto exchange Binance, countered that he should receive no prison time.
lead_paragraph: Changpeng Zhao, the founder of the giant cryptocurrency exchange Binance, should go to prison for three years after breaking the law “on an unprecedented scale” and pleading guilty to a money-laundering violation, federal prosecutors wrote in a court filing on Wednesday.

headline: The Venice Biennale and the Art of Turning Backward
abstract: Every art institution now speaks of progress, justice, transformation. What if all those words hide a more old-fashioned aim?
lead_paragraph: There is a sour tendency in cultural politics today — a growing gap between speaking about the world and acting in it.

headline: With Temperatures Soaring, Gazans Swelter in Makeshift Tents
abstract: The tents that failed to keep out the cold when many Gazans first fled their homes have now become suffocating as highs surpass 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
lead_paragraph: When Maryam Arafat, her husband and their three young children fled their home in Gaza City under Israeli bombardment, it was the dead of winter. Forced to shelter in a ramshackle tent in Deir al Balah, the family shivered during the bitterly cold nights, as there was no fuel to heat up and not enough clothes to stay warm.

headline: The Only Girls’ Team in a Boys’ Soccer League Has Gone Undefeated
abstract: The Queens Park Ladies, an under-12 soccer team in Bournemouth, England, hopes to inspire younger girls to get into the sport after a dominant season against the boys.
lead_paragraph: With about four games left in the season, it became mathematically clear to the players and coaches of the Queens Park Ladies, an under-12 girls’ soccer team in Bournemouth, England, that they would win their league.

headline: Hersh Goldberg-Polin, an Israeli-American Hostage, Is Seen in a Hamas Video
abstract: The video appeared to be the first time that Mr. Goldberg-Polin, who was grievously injured in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attack, has been seen alive since he was taken captive.
lead_paragraph: Hamas released a video on Wednesday apparently showing Hersh Goldberg-Polin, an Israeli American dual citizen who has been held hostage since the Oct. 7 terrorist attack on Israel. It appeared to be the first time that Mr. Goldberg-Polin, who was grievously injured in the attack, has been shown to be alive since his captivity began.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | May 1, 2024
abstract: How involved are parents in their young adult children’s lives?
lead_paragraph: The above graph was previously published in The New York Times. The data is from an online survey of 1,495 young adults ages 18 to 34. Young adults who responded that they are not in contact with their living parents were screened out of the survey.

headline: U.S. Secretly Shipped New Long-Range Missiles to Ukraine
abstract: Ukrainian forces for the first time used a longer-range version of weapons known as ATACMS, striking an airfield in Crimea and Russian troops in southeastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The United States last week secretly shipped a new long-range missile system to Ukraine, and Ukrainian forces immediately used the weapons to attack a Russian military airfield in Crimea last Wednesday and Russian troops in the country’s southeast overnight on Tuesday, according to a senior U.S. official.

headline: NATO Puts on a Show of Force in the Shadow of Russia’s War
abstract: The alliance’s largest exercises offer a preview of what the opening of a Great Power conflict could look like. How it ends is a different story.
lead_paragraph: About 90,000 NATO troops have been training in Europe this spring for the Great Power war that most hope will never come: a clash between Russia and the West with potentially catastrophic consequences.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘The X-Files’ and More
abstract: I’m an editor that works primarily with breaking and trending news. Here are a few things I have been enjoying.
lead_paragraph: I’m an editor that works primarily with breaking and trending news. Here are a few things I have been enjoying.

headline: Helen Vendler, ‘Colossus’ of Poetry Criticism, Dies at 90
abstract: In the poetry marketplace, her praise had reputation-making power, while her disapproval could be withering.
lead_paragraph: Helen Vendler, one of the leading poetry critics in the United States, with a reputation-making power that derived from her fine-grained, impassioned readings, expressed in crystalline prose in The New Yorker and other publications, died on Tuesday at her home in Laguna Niguel, Calif.  She was 90.

headline: Solar Companies Seek New U.S. Tariffs on Asian Imports
abstract: Firms warn that China uses its neighbors to skirt existing levies, depressing prices and threatening U.S. investments.
lead_paragraph: A group of seven leading solar manufacturers filed trade complaints on Wednesday formally requesting that the Biden administration impose tariffs on solar products being exported from Southeast Asia into the United States.

headline: Biden Says Aid Bill for Ukraine and Israel Will ‘Make the World Safer’
abstract: President Biden signed an aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan after it received bipartisan support in Congress.
lead_paragraph: President Biden signed an aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan after it received bipartisan support in Congress.

headline: In Immunity Case, Trump Can Lose in Ways That Amount to a Win
abstract: After the justices hear arguments on Thursday, how they decide may be just as important as what they decide.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Trump immunity case before the Supreme Court.

headline: Trump’s Immunity Claim Joins His Plans to Increase Executive Power
abstract: The former president is asking the Supreme Court to put the presidency above criminal law as he pursues a broader agenda of expanding the office’s power should he win the election.
lead_paragraph: From the courts to the campaign trail, former President Donald J. Trump is challenging a hallmark of American-style democracy: its suspicion of concentrated power.

headline: Cristian Macelaru, Decorated Maestro, to Lead Cincinnati Symphony
abstract: He will begin a four-year term as the orchestra’s music director in the 2025-26 season, succeeding Louis Langrée.
lead_paragraph: The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, which has a history of attracting top conductors, including Fritz Reiner and Leopold Stokowski, announced on Wednesday that its next music director would be Cristian Macelaru, a Romanian-born maestro who has helped champion music education.

headline: Bucking G.O.P. Isolationists, McConnell Was Linchpin in Winning Ukraine Aid
abstract: The leader said he often “felt like I was the only Reagan Republican left” as he pushed back on rising forces in his party arguing against American intervention in foreign affairs.
lead_paragraph: Senator Mitch McConnell does not give much away even in the most private of settings.

headline: Review: John Adams’s ‘El Niño’ Arrives at the Met in Lush Glory
abstract: The opera-oratorio, an alternate Nativity story, featured a flurry of Met debuts, including the director Lileana Blain-Cruz and the conductor Marin Alsop.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, the Metropolitan Opera continued to play a bit of catch-up with the American composer John Adams.

headline: Grandmother Becomes Second Patient to Receive Kidney From Gene-Edited Pig
abstract: NYU Langone Health surgeons performed the transplant after implanting a mechanical heart pump in the severely ill patient.
lead_paragraph: A severely ill 54-year-old woman earlier this month became the second person to receive a kidney transplanted from a genetically modified pig, surgeons at NYU Langone Health in New York announced on Wednesday.

headline: Steak From Dairy Cows? It Could Be a Lifeline for American Farmers.
abstract: Letting milk cows graze longer can produce superior beef — a largely  European practice that is now gaining ground in America.
lead_paragraph: Where’s the rib-eye? Someday soon it might be grazing on a dairy farm.

headline: Is New York Improv Back? I Went on a One-Week Binge to Find Out.
abstract: The pandemic dealt a major blow to the once-thriving comedy form, but a new energy can be seen in performances throughout the city.
lead_paragraph: Improv comedy became so influential in the first two decades of this century that you could make an argument it mattered more to popular culture than stand-up.

headline: Long-Lost Klimt Painting Sells for $37 Million at Auction
abstract: The portrait was left unfinished in the painter’s studio when he died, and questions persist over the identity of the subject and what happened to the painting during Nazi rule in Austria.
lead_paragraph: “Portrait of Fräulein Lieser,” an enigmatic, long-lost 1917 painting by Gustav Klimt, sold Wednesday for 35 million euros with fees, or about $37 million, at the auction house im Kinsky in Vienna.

headline: Trump Named as Unindicted Conspirator in Michigan Election Interference Case
abstract: An investigator said in court that former President Donald J. Trump and some of his aides conspired with fake electors to overturn his 2020 defeat in Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump was named as an unindicted co-conspirator on Wednesday in the investigation by the Michigan attorney general’s office into interference in the 2020 election.

headline: How a Broadway Theater Was Remade Into a Queer Cabaret
abstract: The set and costume designer Tom Scutt has conjured a surreal, New York-inspired version of the fictional Kit Kat Club for the latest revival of the 1966 musical “Cabaret.”
lead_paragraph: The set and costume designer Tom Scutt has conjured a surreal, New York-inspired version of the fictional Kit Kat Club for the latest revival of the 1966 musical “Cabaret.”

headline: Dairy Cows Transported Between States Must Now Be Tested for Bird Flu
abstract: Since a new form of bird flu arrived in 2022, federal officials have sought to reassure Americans that the threat to the public remained low.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday said that it would begin requiring dairy cows moving across state lines to be tested for bird flu, which has been spreading in herds for months. The new policy is part of a growing effort to stamp out the spread of a virus that federal health officials have sought to reassure Americans poses little risk to people so far.

headline: Here’s Where Protesters on U.S. Campuses Have Been Arrested
abstract: A crackdown on demonstrators at Columbia University in New York spawned a wave of activism at universities across the country, with more than 800 arrests.
lead_paragraph: Police officers and university administrators have clashed with pro-Palestinian protesters on a growing number of college campuses across the country in recent days, arresting students, removing encampments and threatening academic consequences.

headline: On TikTok, Resignation and Frustration After Potential Ban of App
abstract: While Congress says the social app is a security threat, critics of the law targeting it say it shows how out of step lawmakers are with young people.
lead_paragraph: As Congress voted Tuesday night on legislation that could ban TikTok, Americans were posting their real-time reactions on the embattled video-sharing app.

headline: ‘Unborn Child’ or ‘Fetus’: Parsing Word Choices on Abortion at the Supreme Court
abstract: The word choice is not merely a question of semantics but gets to the heart of the ultimate goal of the anti-abortion movement: fetal personhood, and prohibiting abortion entirely.
lead_paragraph: On its face, the case argued before the Supreme Court on Wednesday was about whether doctors in Idaho have the obligation to provide abortions to women facing emergency risks to their lives.

headline: Review: Noche Flamenca, Raising the Dead With Goya
abstract: In “Searching for Goya,” at the Joyce Theater, the troupe uses the painter’s images as frames for flamenco dances.
lead_paragraph: As models for choreography, even the greatest painters are of limited use. Dance, for all of its concern with stage compositions, is an art of motion; painting, even when it implies action, is static. But painters can provide choreographers with an angle of vision, a way of looking at the world.

headline: 10 Highlights From the Venice Biennale
abstract: A tour of the international exhibition, which opened last week and runs through November.
lead_paragraph: The Venice Biennale, the art world’s most prestigious exhibition, opened last week to some fanfare, some criticism and a number of protests. Viewers generally look to the Biennale as a reflection of its time, and this one arrived at a fraught moment in history defined by political unrest and distrust for traditional systems of power. (And not for nothing, Indigenous and African artists, historically underrepresented in Venice, are notably more visible than in previous iterations of the show.) Here, a look at some of the standouts from the 2024 edition.

headline: The Volkswagen Union Win Shows That Labor Is Becoming a Bigger Tent
abstract: Republicans tried to quash the union drive with partisanship. It didn’t work.
lead_paragraph: Put yourself in the steel-toed boots of a worker at Volkswagen’s auto assembly plant in Chattanooga, Tenn. Let’s say you vote Republican — not a stretch, since Donald Trump got 60.7 percent of the popular vote in Tennessee in 2020, versus 46.9 percent nationally.

headline: Five Moments That Have Defined Donald Trump’s Trial So Far
abstract: Trials are wars of words. These are some of the most memorable that have been spoken as a jury hears the criminal case against Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: The initial six days of Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial, the first for an American president, were a high-intensity spectacle.

headline: In response to protests, Brandeis invited students to transfer to its campus.
abstract: The university’s president, Ronald D. Liebowitz, promised in an open letter that Brandeis would provide an environment “free of harassment and Jew-hatred.”
lead_paragraph: In response to pro-Palestinian protests on campuses across the country, Brandeis, a historically Jewish university in Massachusetts, announced it would extend its deadline for transfer applications to May 31, and that it was prepared to accept a larger-than-typical number of transfer students.

headline: Mayor Adams Walks Back Budget Cuts Many Saw as Unnecessary
abstract: The mayor released a revised $111.6 billion budget, which included $2.3 billion that would restore some funding for schools and cultural institutions.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, Mayor Eric Adams called for a number of contentious, anxiety-producing cuts to the New York City budget, slashing funds meant for schools and cultural institutions, among other things.

headline: Authorities Offer $20,000 to Find Person Who Fatally Shot Dolphin
abstract: The dolphin, a juvenile found on a Louisiana beach, had injuries “consistent with being shot with a firearm,” marine officials said.
