lead_paragraph: On a recent sunny Sunday, residents of San Francisco’s Noe Valley gathered to celebrate the opening of a toilet. But not just any toilet. This was the nation’s most infamous public toilet.

headline: Real Estate Fantasies
abstract: Celebrity agents are selling a dream, as real homes get more out of reach.
lead_paragraph: There are few acts more optimistic than shopping for a home. You walk through its doors, run your fingertips along its appliances and see your face reflected in its windows and mirrors. You consider untapped versions of your life, imagining yourself waking up every day in that bedroom, cooking every day in that kitchen and letting the years unfold between those walls.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 29, 2024
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: On This Saturday Night, Colin Jost’s Jokes Fell Flat
abstract: The White House Correspondents’ Association dinner has occasionally featured some great stand-up comedy. This “S.N.L.” veteran’s set will not join that list.
lead_paragraph: People in the media have long worried about the impact of the White House Correspondents’ Association dinner on journalism. The concern is that it makes the press look too chummy with politicians it’s covering. But what is the impact on comedy?

headline: Maximizing Profits at the Patients’ Expense
abstract: Readers discuss an article about insurers sending large bills for out-of-network care. Also: Brave Trump jurors; Black voters; better than debates.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Taste of Now
abstract: Go big on asparagus while it’s in season: Slather it with miso-chile sauce, toss it in a creamy pasta with peas and mint or pair seared stalks with cashews and coconut.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I love the green I’m seeing at the tips of the hardwoods, the bright harlequin vibrancy of the alliums along the stream beds, the way the grass in the park is starting to thrive again after a long winter of abuse at the feet of dogs. Here’s spring garlic at the market, funky bouquets of ramps and, best of all, asparagus.

headline: On the Met Roof, Skywriting His Way to Freedom
abstract: Petrit Halilaj of Kosovo began drawing as a refugee child in the Balkans during a violent decade and invented a calligraphic world of memory.
lead_paragraph: When this old world starts getting me down

headline: Review: Gustavo Dudamel Saves the Day at the Philharmonic
abstract: Dudamel, the New York Philharmonic’s incoming music and artistic director, stepped in after a guest conductor fell ill.
lead_paragraph: It was lucky that Gustavo Dudamel was in town.

headline: Puerto Rico Democratic Primary Results
abstract: Get live election results from the 2024 Puerto Rico Democratic presidential primary.
lead_paragraph: Get live election results from the 2024 Puerto Rico Democratic presidential primary.

headline: Review: A Fierce Soprano Arrives at the Met in ‘Madama Butterfly’
abstract: Asmik Grigorian, a star singer abroad, made her Metropolitan Opera debut by lending lyricism, complexity and spontaneity to a classic role.
lead_paragraph: In the most heartbreaking scene of Puccini’s opera “Madama Butterfly,” the title character waits. A teenage geisha married off to an American naval lieutenant, she remains devoted to him long after he abandons her. He will return, she believes — one fine day.

headline: Biden Confers With Netanyahu on a Possible Cease-Fire and Hostage Deal
abstract: The president spoke with the Israeli prime minister on Sunday, the same day Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken left for his latest trip to the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: President Biden spoke with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Sunday to discuss the prospects of a possible cease-fire deal to secure the release of hostages held by Hamas, while repeating his warnings about a new Israeli assault on the city of Rafah in southern Gaza, officials said.

headline: Archie Cooley, Football Coach Known as ‘the Gunslinger,’ Dies at 85
abstract: At Mississippi Valley State University, he unleashed a high-powered, pass-heavy offense that featured the future Pro Football Hall of Famer Jerry Rice.
lead_paragraph: Archie Cooley, the exuberant architect of a passing-crazy offense at Mississippi Valley State University in the 1980s that featured the wide receiver Jerry Rice, a future Pro Football Hall of Famer, died on April 18 in Fort Worth. He was 85.

headline: In Northern Israel, Clashes With Hezbollah Drive a Hospital Underground
abstract: Subterranean operations at Galilee Medical Center are a striking example of how life in northern Israel has been upended since Hezbollah began launching near-daily attacks.
lead_paragraph: The entrance hall to the Galilee Medical Center in northern Israel is mostly empty and quiet. Roaring warplanes and the intermittent thunder of artillery have replaced the sounds of doctors, orderlies and patients at this major hospital closest to the border with Lebanon.

headline: Monday Briefing: Plans for Gaza’s Future
abstract: Plus, European countries crack down on China’s influence.
lead_paragraph: Development agencies and Middle Eastern businesses have been meeting to discuss the eventual reconstruction of Gaza and to develop plans for its long-term economic future. They seek to transform Gaza into a commercial hub centered on trade, tourism and innovation.

headline: As Colleges Weigh Crackdowns on Protests, Questions About Outsiders Linger
abstract: With pro-Palestinian protests spreading across campuses nationwide, university leaders have had to confront a central question: When does a demonstration cross the line?
lead_paragraph: Amid a dizzying array of standoffs involving pro-Palestinian demonstrations and encampments at colleges, schools that cracked down on protesters over the weekend have given varying justifications for their actions, while others sent mixed signals with their inaction.

headline: World Central Kitchen Will Resume Operations in Gaza
abstract: The organization halted aid efforts in the enclave after seven of its workers were killed in an Israeli attack. It said it would resume operations with a local team of Palestinian aid workers.
lead_paragraph: World Central Kitchen said on Sunday that it would resume operations in Gaza with a local team of Palestinian aid workers, nearly a month after the Israeli military killed seven of the organization’s workers in targeted drone strikes on their convoy.

headline: College Protests Over Gaza Deepen Democratic Rifts
abstract: Scenes of chaos unfolding on campuses across the country are stoking internal divisions and carry political risk as a major election year unfolds.
lead_paragraph: Nearly seven months after the Israel-Hamas war began, the demonstrations convulsing college campuses nationwide are exposing fresh tensions within the Democratic Party over how to balance free speech protections and support for Gazans with concerns that some Jewish Americans are raising about antisemitism.

headline: Trump and DeSantis Meet for First Time Since Bruising Primary
abstract: The former president and his vanquished rival met in Florida, months after Ron DeSantis dropped out after a contentious Republican contest.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida met on Sunday morning, according to three people briefed on the meeting, the first time they’ve done so since the end of a bruising Republican presidential primary that Mr. Trump won while relentlessly attacking Mr. DeSantis.

headline: Israeli Officials Believe International Court Is Preparing Arrest Warrants Over War
abstract: The officials said they thought that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and others could be charged by the International Criminal Court and that the court was also considering warrants for Hamas leaders.
lead_paragraph: Israeli officials increasingly believe that the International Criminal Court is preparing to issue arrest warrants for senior government officials on charges related to the conflict with Hamas, according to five Israeli and foreign officials.

headline: Boots From Office
abstract: Tom Locke makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Says Americans Are ‘Voting Out of Fear’
abstract: At a rally outside New York City, he questioned the nation’s Covid response and returned to a favorite issue: vaccine skepticism.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. sought to make the case on Sunday that he can do something no third-party or independent candidate has come close to doing in modern U.S. history: win a presidential election. Although polls show him far behind, both major-party campaigns, those of President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump, view Mr. Kennedy as a potential spoiler.

headline: With Israel Poised to Invade Rafah, Negotiators Try Again for Cease-Fire Deal
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was headed to Saudi Arabia in search of an agreement that would pause the fighting and free hostages held by Hamas.
lead_paragraph: As international diplomats converged in the Middle East on Sunday seeking a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, Israel wrestled with whether to go forward with a ground invasion of Rafah, Hamas’s last bastion in the enclave, according to Israeli officials and analysts.

headline: Robbi Mecus, Who Fostered L.G.B.T.Q. Climbing Community, Dies at 52
abstract: A New York State forest ranger who worked in the Adirondacks, she died after falling about 1,000 feet from a peak at Denali National Park and Preserve in Alaska.
lead_paragraph: Robbi Mecus, a New York State forest ranger who led search-and-rescue missions and became a prominent voice within the L.G.B.T.Q. climbing community, died on Thursday after falling about 1,000 feet from a peak at Denali National Park and Preserve in Alaska. She was 52.

headline: PEN America Has Stood by Authors. They Should Stand by PEN.
abstract: PEN America needs to ensure more than one point of view is heard on even the most contentious issue.
lead_paragraph: All strong institutions stand to benefit from internal dissent and external pressures. But too often, recent efforts to reform institutions have meant reconstituting them in ways that distort or fundamentally undermine their core mission.

headline: TikTok Star Is Killed in Third Death of Social Media Influencer in Iraq
abstract: The shooting of Ghufran Mahdi Sawadi, known online as Um Fahad, comes amid tightening laws and increasingly conservative attitudes in the country.
lead_paragraph: It took less than 46 seconds for the helmeted assassin to pull over his motorcycle, walk to the driver’s side of the S.U.V., yank open the door and fire his handgun four times, killing one of Iraq’s most prominent TikTok personalities, a 30-year-old woman whose name on social media was Um Fahad.

headline: No Corrections: April 29, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Covid Class Denied Second Chance at Normal Senior Year
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a very big hit to morale for the exact class that felt like they lost their high school graduation.”

headline: Friends From the Old Neighborhood Turn Rivals in Big Tech’s A.I. Race
abstract: Demis Hassabis and Mustafa Suleyman, who both grew up in London, feared a corporate rush to build artificial intelligence. Now they’re driving that competition at Google and Microsoft.
lead_paragraph: Mustafa Suleyman grew up in subsidized housing in one of London’s roughest areas. His father, a Syrian immigrant, drove a taxi. His mother was a nurse with the National Health Service. When the prestigious Queen Elizabeth’s School accepted him at the age of 11, the family moved into a safer, leafier neighborhood a few miles north.

headline: A.I. Start-Ups Face a Rough Financial Reality Check
abstract: The table stakes for small companies to compete with the likes of Microsoft and Google are in the billions of dollars. And even that may not be enough.
lead_paragraph: Call it the end of the beginning of the A.I. boom.

headline: What to Know: First Trial in Alleged Coup Plot in Germany Begins
abstract: Three trials this spring are centered on the Reichsbürger movement. Some of its members say the modern German state is actually a corporation run by shadowy bureaucrats.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year and a half after police and intelligence officers in Germany uncovered a plot to overthrow the country’s government and replace its chancellor, the first of three trials in the sprawling case began on Monday in Stuttgart.

headline: As Anger Grows Over Gaza, Arab Leaders Crack Down on Protests
abstract: Grief and rage over the war and Israel have led to demonstrations across the Arab world. Arrests suggest governments fear the outrage could boomerang.
lead_paragraph: Like other governments across the Middle East, Egypt has not been shy about its position on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Its denunciations of Israel over the war in Gaza are loud and constant. State media outlets broadcast images of long lines of aid trucks waiting to cross from Egypt into Gaza, spotlighting Egypt’s role as the main  conduit for aid entering the besieged territory.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The latest push for a cease-fire in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: International diplomats converged yesterday on the Middle East to press for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas as Israel wrestled with whether to begin a ground invasion of Rafah in southern Gaza, according to Israeli analysts and officials. The officials said that they were open to holding off on an invasion if it meant that Israeli hostages taken during the Oct. 7 attacks would be released.

headline: This Isn’t the China I Remember
abstract: Chinese pride and triumphalism have given way to malaise in the post-Covid era.
lead_paragraph: In 1979 my mother pulled out a Band-Aid in a Nanjing hospital. The nurses clustered around it, amazed. “The West has everything!” they said.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Catfish’ and ‘Welcome to Wrexham’
abstract: The show, hosted by Nev Schulman and Kamie Crawford, begins its ninth season on MTV. Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney’s soccer series on FX is back for Season 3.
lead_paragraph: For those like me who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, April 29-May 5. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Blinken Meets With Arab Officials to Discuss Gaza and Postwar Plans
abstract: “The only thing standing between the people of Gaza and a cease-fire is Hamas,” said Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke with Arab officials on Monday in Saudi Arabia about the war between Israel and Hamas and the difficult issues it has created, from humanitarian aid to hostages. Mr. Blinken plans to travel to Jordan and Israel on Tuesday.

headline: Word of the Day: grueling
abstract: This word has appeared in 380 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word grueling has appeared in 380 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 19 in “F.A.A. Will Require More Rest for Air Traffic Controllers” by Sydney Ember:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 323
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,045
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Aggressive and Expensive Legal Team Defending Mayor Adams
abstract: With Mayor Eric Adams and his top aides facing several investigations, he is amassing a team of high-powered lawyers paid by his donors and city taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Eric Adams became the mayor of New York City, he quickly rewarded a cadre of loyalists with plum jobs in his administration. Now Mr. Adams is casting favor upon a new set of people looking out for his interests: defense lawyers.

headline: Philippines Closes Schools as Heat Soars to ‘Danger’ Level
abstract: Scorching temperatures coincided with a nationwide strike of jeepneys, the main mode of public transport in the country.
lead_paragraph: The Philippines closed all public schools on Monday and Tuesday because of dangerously high temperatures, moving classes online in a country where schools are typically shut because of tropical storms.

headline: What Are Americans So Ticked Off About, Anyway?
abstract: In “The Age of Grievance,” the New York Times opinion writer Frank Bruni chronicles the nation’s descent into constant kvetching.
lead_paragraph: While conceding that many people have legitimate beefs, the New York Times opinion writer Frank Bruni portrays the contemporary United States in “The Age of Grievance” as consumed by a corrosive resentment on both ends of the political spectrum, driving its poles further apart and rewarding hyperbole, bitterness, acrimony and self-pity.

headline: When Your Mom Is Famous for Hating Motherhood
abstract: In Heidi Reimer’s debut novel, “The Mother Act,” a daughter grapples with being parented (or not) by an actress who happily mines her life for material.
lead_paragraph: Writing about one’s own children has always been a delicate matter. It’s itchy and complicated, and there is no right way to do it. As a child who was often a subject of the writing of my mother, Erica Jong (and sometimes my grandfather Howard Fast), I have very mixed feelings about the phenomenon. I like to think I truly hated being written about, but who can remember? Later, I found it gave me a profound lack of shame and no expectation of privacy, which helped me pursue a public-facing career I might otherwise not have. All of this is to say that as I read “The Mother Act,” I felt uncomfortably close to the topic.

headline: In a Communist Stronghold, Capitalists Become an Economic Lifeline
abstract: Cuba’s Communist revolution took aim at private businesses, making them largely illegal. Today, they are proliferating, while the socialist economy craters.
lead_paragraph: A modern grocery store whose shelves are packed with everything from pasta to wine fills a spot in central Havana once occupied by a drab state-owned flower shop, its ceilings and walls repaired and repainted.

headline: 17 New Books Coming in May
abstract: New novels from R.O. Kwon, Kevin Kwan and Miranda July; a reappraisal of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy; memoirs from Brittney Griner and Kathleen Hanna — and more.
lead_paragraph: Once called “the Julia Child of Chinese cooking,” Fu Pei-Mei taught generations of Taiwanese people to cook through her long-running TV show and many cookbooks. King presents not just a biography of an indomitable woman, but a portrait of how cultures eat.

headline: Can a Sound Bath Wash Away Your Worries?
abstract: We asked experts about the health benefits of listening to gongs, chimes and crystal bowls.
lead_paragraph: As the sun set over the Pacific Ocean, the beach cool against my back, a voice invited me to scan my body for feelings of powerlessness. “Then breathe in that area to help it release,” said Sara Sofia Bousiali, the leader of the evening’s sound bath.

headline: A Return to New York and, Finally, an Apartment She Can Afford
abstract: After moving 10 times in 10 years, a woman found that a little luck was the best companion for a lot of hard work. She won a studio in a lottery on her fifth try.
lead_paragraph: Tanzania Hughie had a vision. “I was going to come back to New York, get a job and live in a beautiful place,” she said. “That did not happen right away.”

headline: 9 Places to See the Summer Olympics Without Setting Foot in Paris
abstract: You may have trouble finding accommodations or tickets to events in Paris, but other destinations around France are hosting sports like soccer, sailing, basketball and surfing.
lead_paragraph: For sports fans, Paris will be the center of the universe this summer — and with 15 million Olympic and Paralympic visitors expected, it will feel like it, with crowds and high prices. But Paris isn’t the only Olympic site in France: Nine destinations outside the metro region are also hosting events, giving travelers a way to catch some action without getting caught up in the crush.

headline: Judd or Dud: Can You Tell the Difference?
abstract: It’s not that easy to tell fake Donald Judd furniture from the real thing. See if you can do a better job than Kim Kardashian.
lead_paragraph: “If you guys are furniture people, because I’ve really gotten into furniture lately,” Kim Kardashian said in a YouTube video, gesturing toward a large wooden table and set of chairs, “these Donald Judd tables are really amazing and totally blend in with the seats.”

headline: Columbia Protests: The Musical
abstract: Students at the university staged “Mayday,” a show that satirizes the administration, especially the beleaguered president, Nemat Shafik.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at a musical satire by undergraduate students from Columbia and Barnard that took aim at university administrators. We’ll also find out how music therapy is helping some children in Brooklyn cope with the stress of homelessness.

headline: They Shoot Owls in California, Don’t They?
abstract: An audacious federal plan to protect the spotted owl would eradicate hundreds of thousands of barred owls in the coming years.
lead_paragraph: In the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest, the northern spotted owl, a rare and fragile subspecies of spotted owl, is being muscled out of its limited habitat by the barred owl, its larger and more ornery northeastern cousin. The opportunistic barred owl has been moving in on spotted owl turf for more than half a century, competing with the locals for food and space, outnumbering, out-reproducing and inevitably chasing them out of their nesting spots. Barred owls have also emerged as a threat to the California spotted owl, a closely related subspecies in the Sierra Nevada and the mountains of coastal and Southern California.

headline: The Tony Nominations Are Tomorrow. Here’s What to Expect.
abstract: The contenders from a crowded season will be announced by Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Renée Elise Goldsberry.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the Tony nominations.

headline: Some Concrete Reasons Not to Be Totally Panicked
abstract: And a few things we’d like to forget.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, I have a feeling we’re going to be spending a good amount of time talking about the adventures of Donald Trump.

headline: How They Served the Tennis Scenes in ‘Challengers’
abstract: Painstaking effort went into building the energetic competition moments in Luca Guadagnino’s love-triangle tennis drama. Here’s a closer look at the process.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s not make a tennis film.”

headline: The 25 Best Restaurants in Washington, D.C., Right Now
abstract: The food scene in and around the nation’s capital is vibrant these days, with Italian, Ethiopian, Salvadoran and more. Comments are open.
lead_paragraph: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free dishes.

headline: A Starry Cast Navigates ‘Uncle Vanya’ and ‘Every Emotion Under the Sun’
abstract: Steve Carell, William Jackson Harper, Alison Pill and Anika Noni Rose discuss the new translation of Chekhov that brought them to the farm.
lead_paragraph: Broadway shows usually come with a back story about the yearslong slog it took to get them there. Not so with Heidi Schreck’s new translation of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya,” which arrived at Lincoln Center Theater’s Vivian Beaumont Theater not even 12 months after its inception.

headline: I Was an Attorney at the D.A.’s Office. This Is What the Trump Case Is Really About.
abstract: Boring as it may sound, it is a case about business integrity.
lead_paragraph: Now that the lawyers are laying out their respective theories of the case in the criminal prosecution of Donald Trump in New York, it would be understandable if people’s heads are spinning. The defense lawyers claimed this is a case about hush money as a legitimate tool in democratic elections, while the prosecutors insisted it is about “a criminal scheme to corrupt the 2016 presidential election.”

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1926 Spanish-style home in Pasadena, a five-bedroom retreat in Lake Arrowhead and a midcentury ranch house in La Mesa.
lead_paragraph: This house, which is on the market for the first time in 40 years, is in a historic district in the Casa Grande neighborhood, where many of the homes date to the early 20th century. It is about a mile from Pasadena High School and Victory Park, which has baseball fields and a recreation center with an indoor gym. The Rose Bowl Stadium and the Los Angeles County Arboretum, in Arcadia, are about 10 minutes away.

headline: How Supplement Stores Are Trying to Tap Into the Ozempic Boom
abstract: GNC and the Vitamin Shoppe are redesigning displays and taking other steps to appeal to people who are taking or are interested in drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy.
lead_paragraph: As diabetes and weight-loss drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy took off in the last few years, many people turned away from established diet and nutrition products.

headline: Florida Abortion Ban to Take Effect, Cutting Off Major Access Point
abstract: The state has dozens of clinics that serve tens of thousands of women a year, including from across the Southeast. The six-week ban will require most to travel much farther.
lead_paragraph: Florida has long played a significant role in the American abortion landscape, with dozens of clinics providing the procedure to tens of thousands of residents a year while also taking in patients from across the Southeast.

headline: What Should Be Done About the Gender Pay Gap in Sports?
abstract: Caitlin Clark’s rookie salary in the W.N.B.A. is a fraction of the multimillion dollar contract that Victor Wembanyama signed last year.
lead_paragraph: Caitlin Clark, the electrifying basketball point guard for the University of Iowa, ended an extraordinary, record-breaking year on a high note when she was selected first in the W.N.B.A. draft on April 15.

headline: Young, Cool, Coddled and Raised on the Internet
abstract: The best stories in Honor Levy’s “My First Book” capture the quiet desperation of today’s smart set. But there is such a thing as publishing too soon.
lead_paragraph: “Thank God I won’t have to deal with the internet.” According to Bruce Jay Friedman, those were the last words his friend Mario Puzo ever said to him. We forget — or at least I do — how many writers from the last century made it into the age of email. Muriel Spark lived long enough to write a series of online diaries for Slate.

headline: When It Comes to TikTok, the World’s Democracies Have Played the Sucker for Far Too Long
abstract: With its TikTok bill, Congress sent a message to the world: You cannot disregard basic internet norms and expect to be treated like any other country.
lead_paragraph: China’s violations of human rights and the basic norms of internet freedom are blatant and obvious. This month, with little fanfare, the country ordered Apple to block downloads of WhatsApp, Threads and Signal within its borders. It already prevents citizens from connecting to dozens of other providers of information, including this newspaper and Wikipedia, and for years, it has aggressively surveilled journalists and dissidents.

headline: How ‘History and Tradition’ Rulings Are Changing American Law
abstract: A new legal standard is gaining traction among conservative judges — one that might turn back the clock on drag shows, gun restrictions and more.
lead_paragraph: In November 2022, a group of L.G.B.T.Q. students at West Texas A&M University started planning a drag show for the following spring. They wanted to raise money for suicide prevention and stand up for queer self-expression at a time when conservatives in Texas, in the name of protecting children, were mobilizing to shut drag shows down.

headline: With Abortion and the Border, Arizona Becomes a 2024 Political Hothouse
abstract: A battle over abortion bans and criminal charges against allies of former President Donald J. Trump continue to raise the state’s election-year profile.
lead_paragraph: To see the battle lines over Arizona’s political future, head to a patch of dirt along the Carefree Highway on the edge of Phoenix, where the state’s big ambitions and bitter grievances are separated by a wire fence.

headline: Student Protest Is an Essential Part of Education
abstract: Student protests at their core are really an extension of education by other means.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who was at Columbia University in the spring of 1968 cannot help but see a reprise of those stormy, fateful and thrilling days in what is happening on the Morningside Heights campus today.

headline: Can Nonprofit News Save the South From Itself?
abstract: If old school public-service journalism can make it anywhere, it can make it here.
lead_paragraph: When I moved here in 1987, Nashville had two daily newspapers: a morning paper, The Tennessean, whose editorial page leaned left; and an evening paper, The Nashville Banner, whose editorial page leaned right. I still subscribe to The Tennessean, but The Banner is long gone. In 1998, The Tennessean bought its longtime competitor and shut it down.

headline: Where Third-Party and Independent Candidates Are on the Ballot
abstract: For presidential candidates who are not the Republican or Democratic Party nominee, getting on the ballot for the general election is a state-by-state, make-or-break scramble.
lead_paragraph: For presidential candidates who are not the Republican or Democratic Party nominee, getting on the ballot for the general election is a state-by-state, make-or-break scramble.

headline: Are We All Really Supposed to Wear Cargo Pants?
abstract: A reader tries to square the style’s enduring appeal with her own reluctance to wear them.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time cargo pants, otherwise known as “the military’s greatest fashion contribution,” were created to fulfill a very specific function: allowing soldiers to carry crucial tools (or cargo). Invented by the British military in 1938 as part of the new Battle Dress Uniform, cargo pants included a field dressing pocket on the side of the right hip for emergency first aid and a map pocket just above the left knee for navigation.

headline: Koch Group Attacks Biden on the Economy, Hoping to Engage Latino Voters
abstract: Libre, an arm of the conservative network, is set to spend millions of dollars on outreach and advertising as Republicans seek to expand inroads with Hispanic voters.
lead_paragraph: The Libre Initiative, part of the political network created by the billionaire industrialist Koch brothers, on Monday will unveil a seven-figure voter engagement effort and ad campaign targeting members of Congress who have supported what it calls President Biden’s “punitive economic policies.”

headline: Amid Cases on Abortion and Trump, Roberts Reflects on Supreme Court’s Work
abstract: Oral arguments serve a crucial role at the Supreme Court, Chief Justice John Roberts said last week at Georgetown University. But they are not always what they seem.
lead_paragraph: Just hours after the Supreme Court heard arguments last week in an important abortion case and the day before it considered whether former President Donald J. Trump must face trial on charges that he plotted to subvert the 2020 election, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. took a break to share some timely reflections on the role of oral arguments in the court’s work.

headline: After Mulling Resignation, Spain’s Leader Says He’ll Stay On
abstract: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, a progressive with a reputation as a wily survivor, had considered stepping down over corruption accusations against his wife that he says are a smear.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain declared on Monday that he would not resign, nearly a week after publicly raising the possibility in response to corruption accusations against his wife that he and other officials denounced as a smear campaign.

headline: Stowaway Cat Gets From Utah to California in Amazon Returns Package
abstract: Galena, a 6-year-old shorthair, was found in an Amazon warehouse a week after she climbed into a 3-by-3-foot cardboard box at her owner’s home.
lead_paragraph: When Carrie Clark got a phone call on April 17 from a veterinarian in California informing her that her cat, which had vanished from her Utah home a week earlier, had been found some 500 miles away, her first reaction was disbelief.

headline: The Latest Push for a Gaza Pause, and Crackdowns on College Protests
abstract: Plus, a debate about killing owls.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Trump 2.0: What a Second Trump Presidency Would Bring
abstract: On the campaign trail, Donald Trump has signaled that a second term would be more radical and vindictive than his first one.
lead_paragraph: In a special series leading up to Election Day, “The Daily” will explore what a second Trump presidency would look like, and what it could mean for American democracy.

headline: Delay, Delay, Delay
abstract: How Donald Trump has slowed the cases against him.
lead_paragraph: It now seems likely that Donald Trump will be able to run for president this year without having faced any legal penalties for his effort to overturn the last presidential election. To many of his supporters, of course, this outcome is just. But it is also striking.

headline: Humza Yousaf Resigns as Scotland’s First Minister
abstract: Mr. Yousaf, the leader of the Scottish National Party, announced that he was stepping down, days after the collapse of his coalition government.
lead_paragraph: Scotland’s first minister, Humza Yousaf, resigned on Monday in a fresh setback for his Scottish National Party, which has been engulfed in a slow-burning crisis over a funding scandal that erupted after a popular leader, Nicola Sturgeon, stepped down last year.

headline: Ukraine Retreats From Villages on Eastern Front as It Awaits U.S. Aid
abstract: Ukraine’s top commander said his outgunned troops were facing a dire situation as Russia tried to push its advantage before the first batch of an American military package arrives.
lead_paragraph: Russian troops have captured or entered around a half-dozen villages on Ukraine’s eastern front over the past week, highlighting the deteriorating situation in the region for outgunned and outnumbered Ukrainian forces as they wait for long-needed American military aid.

headline: Who Gains From Elon Musk’s Visit to China?
abstract: Tesla’s C.E.O. appears to have landed a deal that moves the company closer to bringing fully autonomous driving to a giant market. But Beijing is keen to exploit the visit for its own purposes.
lead_paragraph: Just days after Secretary of State Antony Blinken traveled to Beijing and warned China about unfair trade practices, Elon Musk landed in the Chinese capital. The Tesla boss’s meeting with China’s No. 2 official may have paid off: Musk reportedly cleared two obstacles to introducing a fully autonomous driving system in the world’s biggest car market.

headline: Flash Floods Kill at Least 45 in Kenya
abstract: Heavy rains have been pounding parts of East Africa for weeks, and the flooding has killed hundreds of people in recent days.
lead_paragraph: Flash floods and a landslide sent a deluge of muddy water over a Kenyan village early Monday, killing at least 45 people, as torrential rains continued to pound East Africa.

headline: Museums to Visit in California This Year
abstract: A special section of The New York Times on museums highlights art across the state.
lead_paragraph: Happy Monday.

headline: Tesla Reaches Deals in China on Self-Driving Cars
abstract: Elon Musk met with the country’s premier, a longtime Tesla ally, and secured regulatory nods and a necessary partnership with a Chinese tech company.
lead_paragraph: Tesla has concluded a series of arrangements with regulators and a Chinese artificial intelligence company during a quick trip to Beijing on Sunday and Monday by Elon Musk, the carmaker’s chief executive, potentially clearing the way for the company to offer its most advanced self-driving software on cars in China.

headline: Hamas Fires Rockets Into Israel from Lebanon
abstract: The launches, nearly all of which Israel shot down, were an apparent attempt by the group to show it remains a threat even as the war has degraded its military capabilities in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Hamas’s military wing said on Monday that it had launched a salvo of rockets from Lebanon into northern Israel, an apparent attempt by the group to signal that it is still capable of striking within Israel’s borders even as it studies the latest proposal for a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Tortured Poets’ Breaks Records With Blockbuster Debut
abstract: Only the Beatles have more No. 1 LPs now: The pop superstar reigns atop the Billboard 200 for the 14th time with the equivalent of 2.6 million album sales.
lead_paragraph: There was never any doubt that Taylor Swift’s latest release, “The Tortured Poets Department,” was going to be big. The question was just how big.

headline: Surprise Tactics and Legal Threats: Inside R.F.K. Jr.’s Ballot Access Fight
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s effort to get on the ballot in 50 states has already cost millions, federal campaign finance records show.
lead_paragraph: As Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s independent presidential campaign mounts a bruising state-by-state battle for ballot access, he has often credited enthusiastic volunteers and grass-roots backers with driving the effort.

headline: A Quick Fish Recipe That Covers All the Bases
abstract: Made with mild white-fleshed fish, bacon and mushrooms, Melissa Clark’s new dish is fast, flavorful and good for the fishy-fish averse.
lead_paragraph: Hello and “happy” Monday! I’m filling in for Melissa today, so it feels only right to kick things off with her new recipe for creamy fish with mushrooms and bacon.

headline: Jazz Saved the Bassist Luke Stewart. Now He’s Working to Rescue Others.
abstract: Stewart’s many projects — Silt Trio, Irreversible Entanglements, Blacks’ Myths and others — make strong statements and foster community. A new LP is out Friday.
lead_paragraph: On a Sunday afternoon in March, Luke Stewart — a bassist and composer who has gradually emerged as a galvanic force in the contemporary jazz vanguard — stood at the corner of Pine and Broadway, in Manhattan’s Financial District, running down some local history. He pointed across the street, where the American Stock Exchange sat next to Trinity Church, and noted our proximity to the former site of New York’s municipal slave market.

headline: Physical Fitness Linked to Better Mental Health in Young People
abstract: A new study bolsters existing research suggesting that exercise can protect against anxiety, depression and attention challenges.
lead_paragraph: Physical fitness among children and adolescents may protect against developing depressive symptoms, anxiety and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to a study published on Monday in JAMA Pediatrics.

headline: Love, War and the Refugee Crisis, Set to the Music of Sting
abstract: In “Message in a Bottle,” a dance show opening at City Center, Sting’s songbook helps tell the story of a family fleeing conflict.
lead_paragraph: When the choreographer Kate Prince set out several years ago to create a dance show based on the music of Sting, she was unsure what story she might be able to tell using his varied songbook.

headline: Skydance Offers Paramount a Deal Sweetener: A $3 Billion Cash Infusion
abstract: The terms of the new deal would provide Paramount shareholders with an investment to pay down debt and buy back stock.
lead_paragraph: With the fate of Paramount hanging in the balance, its leading suitor has just upped the ante.

headline: Philips Settles CPAP Breathing Device Lawsuits for $1.1 Billion
abstract: Thousands of people with sleep apnea and other illnesses had sued the company, claiming flawed devices were harming them.
lead_paragraph: Philips Respironics has reached a $1.1 billion settlement over claims that people who used their CPAP and other breathing devices were harmed by noxious gasses and flecks of foam that lodged in their airways, sometimes for years.

headline: Deadly Mudslides Hit Kenya After Weeks of Torrential Rain
abstract: Flash flooding sent a deluge of muddy water over an area in the Rift Valley region of southern Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Flash flooding sent a deluge of muddy water over an area in the Rift Valley region of southern Kenya.

headline: Inflation Is Stubborn. Is the Federal Budget Deficit Making It Worse?
abstract: Economists are divided over whether the growing amount of federal borrowing is fueling demand and driving up prices.
lead_paragraph: A crucial question is hanging over the American economy and the fall presidential election: Why are consumer prices still growing uncomfortably fast, even after a sustained campaign by the Federal Reserve to slow the economy by raising interest rates?

headline: The Campus Protests: Voices From Columbia, Barnard and Beyond
abstract: Sampling the outpouring of responses to the continuing protests on college campuses. Also: The Trump criminal cases; Trump, Pence and abortion.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Ash’ Review: A Nobel Prize-Winner Confronts Environmental Collapse
abstract: Elfriede Jelinek’s latest play deals with collective calamity and individual grief, but is let down by a chaotic production.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, when the Austrian writer Elfriede Jelinek received the Nobel Prize in Literature it was a surprise that the award had gone to an author who was barely known outside the German-speaking world. It set off a scandal, too. A juror from the academy that makes the decision resigned, calling Jelinek’s work “unenjoyable, violent pornography.”

headline: How Rachel Khong Conjures Worlds, in Her Books and Beyond
abstract: She wrote her much-anticipated second novel, “Real Americans,” while also creating the Ruby, a co-working collective for writers and other artists.
lead_paragraph: By the time Rachel Khong was finishing her latest novel, “Real Americans,” in 2022, interest in the book was so high that it sparked a 17-way bidding war between many of the country’s top publishing houses.

headline: A Former ‘Bachelor’ Finds Love Off-Screen
abstract: When Natalie Joy sent Nick Viall a direct message in 2019, she said she had no idea about his run on reality TV. About a year after meeting in person, their casual arrangement got serious.
lead_paragraph: Nick Joseph Viall is used to his dating life being on public display. From 2014 to 2017, he appeared in four seasons of the “Bachelor” franchise: two seasons of “The Bachelorette,” one season of “Bachelor in Paradise” and, finally, “The Bachelor.”

headline: A Peek Inside the Brains of ‘Super-Agers’
abstract: New research explores why some octogenarians have exceptional memories.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to aging, we tend to assume that cognition gets worse as we get older. Our thoughts may slow down or become confused, or we may start to forget things, like the name of our high school English teacher or what we meant to buy at the grocery store.

headline: Environmental Prize Highlights Work to Keep Fossil Fuels at Bay
abstract: Around the world, grass-roots organizers and Indigenous communities are taking proposed coal, oil and gas projects to court — and winning.
lead_paragraph: New coal mines continue to open each year, and oil and gas companies are still exploring new parts of the world. But increasingly, people — especially Indigenous communities — are saying no to new fossil fuel developments on their land and using courts and legislatures to deliver the message.

headline: A Smooth-Running Gallery Weekend Amid a Shaken Berlin Art Scene
abstract: The annual event brings art collectors to the city, but the spirit of freedom that draws artists there has been damaged by the fallout from the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Berlin’s international reputation as a liberal, relaxed city that nurtures artists’ freedom to express whatever they want is under threat. The art scene here has been roiled by protests, cancellations and boycotts after the Oct. 7 attacks in southern Israel, and many artists now say that a climate of fear has replaced the city’s anything-goes vibe.

headline: Right-Wing Network Retracts False Story About Key Witness in Trump Trial
abstract: Michael D. Cohen’s lawyers took on OAN over the false story. The settlement came as right-wing news outlets face a barrage of defamation suits.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Student Protester Is Suspended After Anti-Zionist Video
abstract: Khymani James, a Columbia University student, was barred from campus after his January video resurfaced online last week.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University officials are now weighing what final disciplinary action to take against a student leader of the pro-Palestinian movement after an inflammatory video resurfaced in which the student said “Zionists don’t deserve to live.”

headline: Omar Draws Criticism for Suggesting Some Jewish Students Are ‘Pro-Genocide’
abstract: Representative Ilhan Omar made the comments at Columbia University, where her daughter was among the students arrested protesting against Israel’s actions in Gaza. The protests have drawn visits by leaders across the political spectrum.
lead_paragraph: Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota, whose daughter was among the students arrested at a Columbia University protest encampment against Israel’s actions in Gaza, suggested while visiting the protesters on campus last week that some Jewish students supported genocide.

headline: A Student Orchestra Shouts ‘Mambo!’ and Meets Gustavo Dudamel
abstract: Our photographer followed 95 young musicians for six days as they prepared to perform with Dudamel, the next music director of the New York Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: The student musicians, dressed in jeans, T-shirts and hooded sweatshirts, were rehearsing an excerpt from “West Side Story” in a high school auditorium one recent afternoon. Then, as the trumpets blared and the timpani went wild, a voice broke out from the conductor’s podium.

headline: A Strong U.S. Dollar Weighs on the World
abstract: Two-thirds of the roughly 150 currencies have weakened against the dollar, whose strength stems from high interest rates because of stubborn inflation.
lead_paragraph: Every major currency in the world has fallen against the U.S. dollar this year, an unusually broad shift with the potential for serious consequences across the global economy.

headline: Universities Face an Urgent Question: What Makes a Protest Antisemitic?
abstract: Pro-Palestinian student activists say their movement is anti-Zionist but not antisemitic. It is not a distinction that everyone accepts.
lead_paragraph: In a video shared widely online, a leader of the pro-Palestinian student movement at Columbia University stands near the center of a lawn on the campus and calls out, “We have Zionists who have entered the camp.”

headline: Federal Agencies to Restore Grizzly Bears in Washington State
abstract: Grizzly bears haven’t been seen in the North Cascades range, where they were once a vital part of the ecosystem, in nearly 30 years.
lead_paragraph: The federal government plans to restore grizzly bears to the North Cascades range in northwestern Washington state, where they once roamed and were an essential part of the region’s ecosystem, officials said.

headline: Read the Notice From Columbia Administrators
abstract: Students in the encampment were told they would be suspended if they did not leave before the deadline.
lead_paragraph: Students in the encampment were told they would be suspended if they did not leave before the deadline.

headline: How Did Black Forest Cake Become the World’s Favorite Dessert?
abstract: Dessert lovers from Chile to Pakistan to Fiji claim it as a national treat. How did it get there from the woods of Germany?
lead_paragraph: It’s a classic Trinidadian dessert — a chocolate cake soaked in overproof rum and topped with swoops of ultrapasteurized whipped cream.

headline: Class of 2024, It’s Not in Your Head: The Job Market Is Tough
abstract: College-level jobs still pay a lot more overall, but not every grad can get one.
lead_paragraph: Here is a brutal fact for the college class of 2024: There aren’t enough college-level jobs out there for all of you. Some of you will snag them. Others will have to settle for jobs that don’t require a college education. And history shows that many of those who start out in a job that doesn’t require a college education are still toiling in that kind of job a decade later.

headline: A D.A. Was Caught Speeding. Her Outburst Earned Her More Than a Ticket.
abstract: Sandra Doorley, the district attorney of Monroe County, N.Y., refused to pull over and responded angrily to the officer who confronted her, body camera footage showed. Now she faces calls to resign.
lead_paragraph: It was 5:30 p.m. last Monday in Webster, N.Y., a Rochester suburb, when Police Officer Cameron Crisafulli noticed an S.U.V. being driven 20 miles per hour over the speed limit on Phillips Road.

headline: Why an Immunity Ruling in Trump’s Favor Might Not Alter the Shape of His Trial
abstract: Prosecutors believe Donald J. Trump’s official acts in trying to overturn the election should be admissible evidence even if the Supreme Court rules they cannot be the basis of the charges.
lead_paragraph: If the Supreme Court rules that Donald J. Trump is immune from being charged with crimes over official actions he took as president, it would be a momentous decision for the future of executive power and American-style democracy.

headline: The Book Review’s Best Books Since 2000
abstract: Looking for your next great read? We’ve got 3,228. Explore the best fiction and nonfiction from 2000 - 2023 chosen by our editors.
lead_paragraph: Looking for your next great read? We’ve got 3,228. Explore the best fiction and nonfiction from 2000 - 2023 chosen by our editors.

headline: 4 Zebras Broke Free on a Highway. A Rodeo Clown Stepped In.
abstract: One zebra was still on the loose, after it and three others escaped a trailer in North Bend, Wash. Dozens of people scrambled to help and corralled some of the animals.
lead_paragraph: Four zebras escaped from a trailer on a highway exit in Washington State on Sunday, leading dozens of residents, police officers and volunteers to join in an effort to corral them.

headline: Ireland Threatens to Return Asylum Seekers to U.K., Sparking Diplomatic Squabble
abstract: The Irish government said it was drafting emergency legislation to return asylum seekers to Britain, after seeing a surge of people leaving there for sanctuary in Ireland.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s newly ratified plan to put asylum seekers on one-way flights to Rwanda has drawn objections from human rights groups, British and European courts, the House of Lords and even some members of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Conservative Party.

headline: 8 Officers Are Shot, 4 Fatally, While Serving Warrant in Charlotte
abstract: Three of the four were part of a U.S. Marshals task force. The felon whom they sought was also killed.
lead_paragraph: Eight law officers were shot on Monday, four fatally, as a U.S. Marshals fugitive task force tried to serve a warrant in Charlotte, N.C., the police said, in one of the deadliest days for law enforcement in recent years.

headline: Pennsylvania Hospital Suspends Its Liver Transplant Program
abstract: The move by the Penn State Health Milton S. Hershey Medical Center was the second time this month that a hospital has taken this rare step.
lead_paragraph: A major Pennsylvania hospital shut down its liver transplant program last week, becoming the second medical center this month to take such an unusual step.

headline: Gérard Depardieu Ordered to Stand Trial in Sexual Assault Case
abstract: The actor, who has become a #MeToo flashpoint in France, will be tried in October over allegations that he sexually assaulted two women during a 2021 film shoot.
lead_paragraph: Gérard Depardieu was ordered on Monday to stand trial on criminal charges that he sexually assaulted two women during a 2021 film shoot in France, deepening the French actor’s legal woes and further tarnishing his global reputation as he faces a growing number of accusations of sexual violence.

headline: With Paramount in Chaos and Its Future Uncertain, Its Chief Steps Down
abstract: Bob Bakish was once a staunch ally of Shari Redstone, Paramount’s controlling shareholder. His departure comes as the company considers a major merger.
lead_paragraph: Shari Redstone, the controlling shareholder of Paramount, has tried to resist the erosion of her media empire over the last decade as she confronted the death of cable TV, the rise of streaming and even a failed boardroom coup from a longtime ally.

headline: Jeffries’s Hint of a Lifeline Bolstered Johnson on Ukraine. Will He Need It?
abstract: The House Democratic leader has suggested his members would protect Speaker Mike Johnson if right-wing Republicans tried to oust him over Ukraine aid, strengthening the speaker’s hand.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the House Democratic leader, was in Munich in mid-February for the annual international security conference, Representative Michael R. Turner, the Ohio Republican and chairman of the Intelligence Committee, quietly sought him out with a request.

headline: Blue Ivy Carter to Join Beyoncé in ‘Mufasa: The Lion King’
abstract: Beyoncé’s 12-year-old daughter will make her feature film debut as Kiara, Nala and Simba’s daughter, in a prequel to the 2019 hit.
lead_paragraph: Blue Ivy Carter will be joining her mother, Beyoncé Knowles-Carter, in the movie musical “Mufasa: The Lion King,” which is expected in theaters in December.

headline: Biden and Mexico’s President Vow Combined Action on Illegal Immigration
abstract: President Biden is under intense political pressure, including from within his own party, to address migration before the election.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and the president of Mexico on Monday vowed combined action to prevent illegal immigration as Mr. Biden remains under intense political pressure from all sides to address the impact of surging border crossings ahead of the presidential election this year.

headline: Where in the West Do These Books Take Place?
abstract: Try this short quiz on novels, geography and history of the American West.
lead_paragraph: Try this short quiz on novels, geography and history of the American West.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Hope Rises for New Cease-Fire Talks
abstract: Also, Russia advances in eastern Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Negotiations for a pause in the fighting between Israel and Hamas could restart as soon as today, officials said. A mid-level Israeli delegation is planning to fly to Cairo for new talks mediated by Egypt, but only if Hamas also agrees to attend, Israeli officials said.

headline: New Round of Arrests at University of Texas as Protesters Defy Governor
abstract: Days after a crackdown on pro-Palestinian protesters, at least 50 people were arrested after new tents were erected on the Austin campus.
lead_paragraph: Police officers from the University of Texas at Austin and state troopers in riot gear swept in on Monday to clear a small number of tents erected on campus by pro-Palestinian protesters, arresting dozens of people and briefly deploying pepper spray against demonstrators who were chanting “Off our campus!” and trying to block law enforcement vehicles.

headline: Israel Softened Its Demands in Cease-Fire Negotiations
abstract: Also, Russian forces advance in Ukraine before U.S. aid arrives. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Israeli officials said today that they had reduced the number of hostages they were asking Hamas to free in exchange for a temporary cease-fire in the war in Gaza. The new stance raised expectations that the two sides might be edging closer to agreeing on their first truce in five months. A new round of cease-fire negotiations could begin as soon as tomorrow.

headline: Kamala Harris Leads Push to Shore Up Democratic Support From Black Voters
abstract: Speaking in Atlanta, the vice president began a national tour to highlight how the Biden administration is trying to help Black Americans economically.
lead_paragraph: Vice President Kamala Harris made a new effort to energize Black voters in battleground states on Monday, visiting Atlanta for the kickoff of a national economic tour that will highlight how the Biden administration says its policies are helping a constituency that will be vital to Democrats’ success in November.

headline: N.Y.U. Says It Will Discipline Students Who Remain in Encampment
abstract: The university had set a noon deadline for an end to overnight stays at the site, but students remained there on Monday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: New York University officials will move to discipline student demonstrators who remain in a pro-Palestinian encampment on campus, the university announced in a statement on Monday.

headline: Surrounded by Fighters and Haunted by Famine, Sudan City Fears Worst
abstract: A powerful paramilitary group has encircled El Fasher, the last remaining obstacle to domination of the sprawling Darfur region, raising alarm about mass killings if the city is taken.
lead_paragraph: Fears of renewed ethnic slaughter in the Sudanese region of Darfur, where genocidal violence killed as many as 300,000 people two decades ago, have soared in recent days, with a looming assault on an embattled city that is already threatened by famine.

headline: Biden Team Sees Narrow Window for Deal on Cease-Fire and Hostages in Gaza
abstract: A number of factors have converged to make this a moment when the president might be able to break through the stalemate, advisers say. But their optimism has been dashed before.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his national security team see a narrow window to finally seal an agreement that would at least temporarily halt the war in Gaza and possibly end it for good even as they deflect pressure from college campus protests to abandon Israel in its fight against Hamas.

headline: Hope Rises for New Talks on Gaza Cease-fire as Israel Scales Back Demands
abstract: Israel reduced the initial number of hostages it wants released to 33. If Hamas agrees to attend, negotiations on a cease-fire could resume in Cairo this week.
lead_paragraph: Israeli negotiators, offering a hint of hope for negotiations over a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, have reduced the number of hostages they want Hamas to release during the first phase of a truce, three Israeli officials said on Monday.

headline: Trump Is Flirting With Quack Economics
abstract: Beware strongmen who engage in magical thinking.
lead_paragraph: More than 30 years ago, the economists Rudiger Dornbusch (one of my mentors) and Sebastian Edwards wrote a classic paper on what they called “macroeconomic populism.” Their motivating examples were inflationary outbreaks under left-wing regimes in Latin America, but it seemed clear that the key issue wasn’t left-wing governance per se; it was, instead, what happens when governments engage in magical thinking. Indeed, even at the time they could have included the experience of the military dictatorship that ruled Argentina from 1976 to 1983, which killed or “disappeared” thousands of leftists but also pursued irresponsible economic policies that led to a balance-of-payments crisis and soaring inflation.

headline: Matt Gaetz Faces Last-Minute Challenger in Republican Primary
abstract: The Florida representative will face off against Aaron Dimmock, a retired Navy officer and aviator.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Dimmock, a retired Navy officer and aviator, has entered the Republican primary to challenge Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida — jumping into the race hours before a filing deadline last Friday.

headline: Election Deniers Are Still Shaping Arizona Politics
abstract: There have been few political consequences for many Republicans accused of helping Trump try to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, a group of election deniers ran for office in Arizona, with Kari Lake’s campaign for governor topping the ticket. When many of them lost, it seemed like a convincing rebuke of the conspiracy theory-steeped Republicans who wanted to control the levers of electoral power in 2024.

headline: Arizona Rancher Accused of Killing Migrant Won’t Be Retried After Mistrial
abstract: George Alan Kelly was accused of murdering Gabriel Cuen-Buitimea, an unarmed migrant from Mexico, on his 170-acre ranch in Kino Springs, Ariz., last year.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Arizona said on Monday that they would not retry a rancher who was charged with murdering an unarmed migrant on his property last year after a mistrial was declared last week.

headline: Columbia Faculty Block Encampments, Protecting Student Protesters
abstract: On Monday, Columbia administrators issued an ultimatum to student protestors: leave their encampments or face suspension. In response, several faculty members created a human barrier.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, Columbia administrators issued an ultimatum to student protestors: leave their encampments or face suspension. In response, several faculty members created a human barrier.

headline: Contents of a Pizzeria Shaker
abstract: Michèle Govier has us dwelling on the details.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: A Small Campus in the Redwoods Has the Nation’s Most Entrenched Protest
abstract: Pro-Palestinian protesters have occupied the administration building at California State Polytechnic University, Humboldt, for the past week and forced a campus closure until May 10.
lead_paragraph: When university administrators across the nation worry about the potential fallout from campus protests, they may have Siemens Hall in mind.

headline: Ilhan Omar Plunges Into Democrats’ Political Storm Over War in Gaza
abstract: Suggesting that some Jewish students are “pro-genocide,” the Minnesota congresswoman seemed to further polarize an already polarizing debate.
lead_paragraph: It was just one sentence, uttered to reporters who had gathered around Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota last week when she turned up at a Columbia University encampment to offer a show of support for pro-Palestinian protesters — among them, her daughter, a student activist — demonstrating against the Israeli attacks on Gaza.

headline: All New U.S. Cars Must Carry Automatic Brakes by 2029
abstract: The technology is already sold on most vehicles, but a new federal safety regulation raises the standards.
lead_paragraph: Starting in 2029, a new federal safety regulation will require all new cars and trucks in the United States to be sold with automatic emergency braking — sensors that hit the brakes to avoid a collision if the driver does not.

headline: Even as He Faces Prison Time, Binance’s Founder Plans a Comeback
abstract: Since pleading guilty to violating money-laundering rules, Changpeng Zhao, who ran the giant crypto exchange Binance, has networked across the United States to set up his next act.
lead_paragraph: He enjoyed a home-cooked dinner in Montana with a former U.S. senator. He visited Telluride, Colo., and Moab, Utah, a vacation spot known for its national parks. And he chatted about start-ups with Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI.

headline: Chad Election 2024: What to Know
abstract: The Central African nation’s May 6 election appears to offer voters a choice. But it’s been masterminded, analysts say, to rubber-stamp the rule of the incumbent, Mahamat Idriss Déby.
lead_paragraph: Chad’s election on May 6 appears to offer voters a choice. But it’s been masterminded, analysts say, to produce a single outcome: to rubber-stamp the rule of the incumbent, Mahamat Idriss Déby, who is seeking to transform himself from military leader to civilian president.

headline: Hydrogen Offers Germany a Chance to Take a Lead in Green Energy
abstract: A subsidiary of ThyssenKrupp, Germany’s venerable steel producer, is landing major deals for a device that makes the clean-burning gas from water.
lead_paragraph: In the city of Duisburg in Germany’s industrial heartland is a vast steel complex that is one of Europe’s largest polluters. But alongside the mill’s furnaces and smelters, technicians have developed a machine that could soon play a vital role in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Hope for a cease-fire in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israeli negotiators have reduced the number of hostages they want Hamas to release in the initial phase of a truce to 33 from 40, Israeli officials said yesterday, offering a hint of hope for a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Communist Cuba Grasps a Lifeline: Capitalists
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “You have to be a millionaire to live in Cuba today.”

headline: Corrections: April 30, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, April 30, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about an all-women heavy metal band in Indonesia misstated the name of the band’s drummer. She is Euis Siti Aisyah, not Eusi Siti Aisyah.

headline: Columbia Protesters Occupy Building on Campus
abstract: People inside barricaded the doors of Hamilton Hall with furniture. Outside, demonstrators linked arms to wall off entrances.
lead_paragraph: People inside barricaded the doors of Hamilton Hall with furniture. Outside, demonstrators linked arms to wall off entrances.

headline: Word of the Day: equilibrium
abstract: This word has appeared in 102 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word equilibrium has appeared in 102 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 7 in the Opinion essay “My Faith Forbade Eclipse Gazing. Now It Inspires My Art” by Balarama Heller:

headline: Stephen Colbert Scolds Kristi Noem for Killing Her Puppy
abstract: “No! Bad, psycho governor! No! Sit down!” Colbert said on Monday’s “Late Show,” spraying water from a bottle.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Honeybees Invaded My House, and No One Would Help
abstract: Responding to fears of a “honeybee collapse,” 30 states have passed laws to protect the pollinators. But when they invaded my house, I learned that the honeybees didn’t need saving.
lead_paragraph: I noticed the first bee one afternoon as my dog gleefully chased it around the house. When the pest settled on a window by the stairwell, I swatted it with a cookbook and cleaned up the mess.

headline: From Baby Talk to Baby A.I.
abstract: Could a better understanding of how infants acquire language help us build smarter A.I. models?
lead_paragraph: We ask a lot of ourselves as babies. Somehow we must grow from sensory blobs into mobile, rational, attentive communicators in just a few years. Here you are, a baby without a vocabulary, in a room cluttered with toys and stuffed animals. You pick up a Lincoln Log and your caretaker tells you, “This is a ‘log.’” Eventually you come to understand that “log” does not refer strictly to this particular brown plastic cylinder or to brown plastic cylinders in general, but to brown plastic cylinders that embody the characteristics of felled, denuded tree parts, which are also, of course, “logs.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 324
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,046
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: An Intimate Look at Modern Love and Marriage
abstract: Amanda Montei, a contributing writer for The New York Times Magazine, spoke to more than 30 married people for whom sex is not essential.
lead_paragraph: When Amanda Montei began reporting an article last year about married couples who had little to no sex, she didn’t know how forthcoming people would be about their sex lives.

headline: N.Y. Criminal Justice Group to Push for More Scrutiny of Judges
abstract: The group, which led the fight against Gov. Kathy Hochul’s nominee to lead the state’s top court, argues that judges are routinely reappointed to the bench without sufficient evaluation.
lead_paragraph: A group that helped thwart the confirmation of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s choice to lead New York’s highest court last year has announced a campaign aimed at pushing elected officials to more closely scrutinize judicial nominees and appointees across the state.

headline: Trump, Venting About Lawyer in His Criminal Trial, Seeks More Aggression
abstract: Todd Blanche upended his career to represent Donald J. Trump and has been the former president’s favorite. But Mr. Trump has made him a focus of his episodic wrath.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s hush money trial in Manhattan.

headline: Graphs
abstract: The Times’s Upshot is a section devoted to visualizing data behind news stories. How good is your graph literacy?
lead_paragraph: How comfortable are you with reading graphs? Have you ever found them to be useful or meaningful to your life? Are you ever confused or intimidated by them? What strategies do you use to read, interpret and evaluate them?

headline: A Proposed Law Targeting ‘Foreign Interests’ in Georgia Riles the Opposition
abstract: Opponents of the measure, which resembles a Russian law that Moscow has used to crack down on dissidents, say it could undermine efforts for Georgia to join the European Union.
lead_paragraph: For the past month, the Georgian capital of Tbilisi has been engulfed in turmoil. Protesters have taken to the streets of the city night after night. A fistfight broke out between legislators in the country’s Parliament. And over the weekend, there were clashes between police and protesters at a large demonstration in the center of the city.

headline: Are Disposable Hotel Slippers the Next Plastic Straws?
abstract: Slippers supplied by hotels — flimsy models usually made of plastic and fabric — are the next single-use item in the cross hairs of sustainability activists.
lead_paragraph: In November, managers at the Arenas del Mar resort near Manuel Antonio National Park in Costa Rica, challenged employees to come up with ways to operate more sustainably. The maintenance crew suggested electric locks on guest room doors. The food and beverage department proposed making jams from fruit peels. And the housekeepers advised: Ditch the slippers.

headline: A Gripping Family Saga Asks, What Makes for ‘Real Americans’?
abstract: Rachel Khong’s new novel follows three generations of Chinese Americans as they all fight for self-determination in their own way.
lead_paragraph: As the story goes, after the death of China’s first emperor in 210 B.C., Chen Sheng, a military captain, organized a motley band of soldiers in a revolt against the Qin dynasty and its harsh penal laws. Sheng was defeated, but he became known for his belief that one’s status is not intrinsic — that one can change, grow, transcend. “Are kings, generals and ministers merely born into their kind?” he asked, a rhetorical question that became a rallying cry about identity and self-determination.

headline: Singing for the Dead, a Woman Finds Her Purpose
abstract: Wenyan Lu’s novel, “The Funeral Cryer,” explores a Chinese tradition through a modern, more personal lens.
lead_paragraph: Every year or so, a version of the same article will come across my social media feeds, having gone freshly viral among a cohort of Westerners still unfamiliar with the “odd job” of professional wailers, usually from China, who are paid to cry at funerals. The pieces explain that this is a common custom with ancient roots, and the ensuing commentary is usually gobsmacked or overly admiring: how strange, how clever for a community to help one another express grief; how weird that there are people who can’t cry naturally.

headline: Alien Terrors, Vampire Conspiracies and More in 4 New Horror Books
abstract: Our columnist reviews this month’s latest scary releases.
lead_paragraph: If you want to read a novel that feels like a puzzle, look no further than Thomas Olde Heuvelt’s ORACLE (Tor Nightfire, 376 pp., $29.99). The novel, which is translated from the Dutch by Moshe Gilula, opens with two friends, Luca and Emma, who one morning spot a hulking shape in the middle of a flower field. The object is the Oracle, a sailing ship from the 18th century. Curious, Emma goes down the ship’s hatch and vanishes in the darkness beyond. She never comes out. Soon, others — including Luca’s father — and a handful of police officers suffer the same fate.

headline: The Wartime Music of Debussy and Komitas, Still Resonating Today
abstract: Kirill Gerstein’s immense recording project “Music in Time of War” surveys works by artists who witnessed World War I and the Armenian genocide.
lead_paragraph: Kirill Gerstein, a Soviet-born pianist whose parents sold their only proper asset — a garage — so that they could afford plane tickets to the United States for their son’s education, approaches music in a way that recalls something his countryman, the conductor Kirill Petrenko, once told him: “I sacrificed so much in my life to not do things by default.”

headline: Why Is It So Hard to Shower When I’m Depressed?
abstract: Issues with hygiene are common symptoms of depression. Here’s why, and how to make bathing a little easier.
lead_paragraph: Q. I find many tasks challenging when I’m depressed, but showering feels especially difficult. Why is that? And what can I do about it?

headline: Black Entrepreneurs, Frustrated by High Rates, Look to the Election
abstract: In the battleground state of Georgia, some Black entrepreneurs are frustrated over the impact of higher interest rates, a source of economic anxiety.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Jolasun, a 32-year-old entrepreneur in Atlanta, has never voted for the Republican candidate for the presidency. That may be about to change.

headline: Maybe Erik Larson Should Have Left the Civil War Alone
abstract: In “The Demon of Unrest,” present-day political strife inspires a dramatic portrait of the run-up to the deadliest war on American soil.
lead_paragraph: The Civil War is one hell of a drug. It’s plentiful and Main Street-legal, but can induce hallucinatory visions when mixed with inflammatory substances. “I’m so attracted to seeing it,” former President Donald J. Trump confessed at a rally this past Jan. 6, three years after his “Big Lie” inspired followers to storm the Capitol — a feat the Southern Confederacy and its campaign to preserve slavery were unable to accomplish, even as the effort left more than 600,000 people dead in its wake.

headline: Edward Dwight Aims for Space at Last
abstract: Six decades ago, Mr. Dwight’s shot at becoming the first Black astronaut in space was thwarted by racism and politics. Now, at 90, he’s finally going up.
lead_paragraph: Edward Dwight is going to space, finally.

headline: The First Six Weeks of Pregnancy, Explained
abstract: Florida is set to ban abortions after six weeks. Experts explain how that can often be before a woman knows she is pregnant.
lead_paragraph: By the time a woman is considered six weeks pregnant, she would have had two weeks, at most, to realize it.

headline: How Michigan Ended Minority Rule
abstract: Though the notion would have been laughable a decade ago, Michigan is one promising national model for how state-level activists can retake power.
lead_paragraph: On April 8, one day before the Arizona Supreme Court reinstated a ban on abortion from 1864, Donald Trump said the issue of abortion rights should be left to the states and “whatever they decide must be the law of the land.”

headline: Inside a Navy Submarine Navigating the Arctic
abstract: A Times photojournalist embarked on a nuclear-powered attack sub to see how the Pentagon is training for a potential war below the frozen sea.
lead_paragraph: U.S. Navy sailors aboard nuclear-powered submarines have long trained in the Arctic, learning to hunt their Russian counterparts in case of war. But America’s sub force is sharpening its combat skills at the edge of the world as Russia expands military operations there.

headline: Queen Snakes Are Back, and They’re in New Jersey
abstract: The reptiles, an endangered species, hadn’t been seen in the state since the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll meet a creature that you might not want to encounter face-to-scaly-face. We’ll also get details on Columbia University’s decision to begin suspending students who remained at the pro-Palestinian encampment after a deadline set by the university.
